GAF_Rupantaran_Foundation_AmpliCommuVoic.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 6. Context (The context section should not exceed two pages.)6a. Describe the organisation (include information on leadership, governance, structure and staff) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):There is much discrimination in our society based on economic condition, gender, caste, age, educational qualification etc. We believe that being treated equally with dignity is the basic thing one should expect from the society. With a vision of a transformed society built on equity, dignity and peace Rupantaran Foundation was formed in 2009 as not for profit, non-political organization. The word Rupantaran literally means the process of positive transformation. As our name suggests we are facilitating an empowering process of transformation towards equality, dignity and peace with the disadvantaged people to shape a just, equitable and nonviolent world. Presently we are directly operating in 4 blocks of Sunderbans in South 24 Parganas district and Kolkata in West Bengal on the issues of child protection, gender equity, education, and livelihoods. Our aim is to build leadership, enable social justice and promote responsive citizenship among communities through engaging young people, women and marginalized people. Rupantaran also works as a resource and capacity building organisation for social partners and institutes. Rupantaran Foundation is registered as a Society under West Bengal Societies Registration Act XII of 1860, bearing Registration Number S/1L/60699 of 2009  10. The Society is governed by a Governing Body comprising 8 members: Ms Shruti Kundu (President), Mr Himangshu Das (Vice President)  Mr Abhishek (Secretary), Ms Debjani Barman (Assistant Secretary), Mr Snehasish Sarkar (Treasurer), Mr Gajendra Kumar (Member), Ms Jayati Mal (Member) and Ms Urmita Ghosh (Member).  Director Ms Smita Sen is currently leading Rupantaran. The organization has Program Coordinator, Supervisor, Field Worker along with a considerable number of paid volunteers.Grant Application Form, July 1 201356b. Describe the financial situation (include information on annual operating costs, fundraising strategy, reserves and debts) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):The financial situation of Rupantaran Foundation has been on a growing curve with every passing year, especially after receiving the FCRA registration.  In previous year, the annual operating costs of the organization was around 67 lakhs and this financial year its expected to reach 1 crore. Rupantaran Foundation is grassroots implementing organisation as well as it serves as resource organisation. One of Rupantarans modes of raising funds for its programme initiatives are to provide knowledge services to likeminded organizations operating in the development sector.Along with that Rupantaran Foundation has good individual donors base which serves as a backbone and cope with shock in any sudden change in funding context e.g. recent FCRA amendment. Also, Rupantaran is supported by few individuals who have provided us with Corpus Fund which will act as a reserve for maintaining its core program and team. As on date, Rupantaran Foundation doesnt have any outstanding debts.6c. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):Despite representing a large proportion of the population, adolescent and youth are widely excluded from the decision making process, as they have limited access to information, space and opportunity to acquire and share knowledge, and limited participation. In this light, Rupantaran Foundation has started its journey in 2009 aims to create a safe space, where marginalization cease to exist, and adolescent and youth can build their own agency and voice their opinion. We started our journey from a single village in Sundarbans. Through participatory vulnerability and capacities analysis and micro plan with the youth, the need for working on education, prevention of early marriage and child labour etc. were pointed out as the menace to be fought against. In that time, our team along with those youth designed and shaped the initial programmes of Rupantaran. Gradually, along with young people we started engaging with women and other marginalized communities and activating government delivery mechanisms and bodies. Past Achievements:Two of our youth collective members from remote villages from South 24 Parganas received the Bravery Award, 2020 from West Bengal Commission for Protection of Child Rights for their extraordinary community development work during pandemic.Grant Application Form, July 1 20136 In one of the panchayat where we did our pilot work with VLCPCs, the VLCPCs over the period of 3 years addressed 11 cases of trafficking, 200 cases of child marriage, 97 cases of dropout prevention and 70 cases of gender based violence (including eve teasing). A sample of 220 adolescents and youth with whom we worked reached out to 11818 peers, 3652 family members and 3527 community members on awareness on Child Marriage, Trafficking, Reproductive Health Rights, Gender equity, Education and Online Safety.6d. Describe the current strategy of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):Rupantarans key strategies are:1) Collectivisation and creating safe spaces for the marginalised2) Strengthening the local governance   We believe that collectivizing or bringing together the marginalized people in a safe space enable them to articulate their oppression and strategize for individual and social change. In rural areas, especially in Sundarbans there is a crunch of space to engage the marginalised people in the social development processes as the politics of spaces significantly plays its role in allowing and rejecting dialogues and discussions. For us at Rupantaran, creation of safe space was not about creating a physical space rather, creating a socio-cultural and psychological space where marginalization would cease to exist, celebrates a bond of trust, encourages building their own agency and facilitating a platform for a transformative journey from self to society.6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):The development landscape of backward areas such as the Sundarbans points at a glaring dearth of people-centred processes and sustainable initiatives of change. While a number of development interventions are being implemented in the Sundarbans, the relative degrees of participation and leadership of local communities, especially those hailing from vulnerable sections, appears to be low. There seems a significant scope for assimilation of an agenda for nurturance of people-centred agencies of change, for greater sustainability of interventions and empowerment of peoples agencies. The proposed intervention aims at addressing the non-availability of a facilitative Grant Application Form, July 1 20137platform for vulnerable people in the Sundarbans to come together, diagnose their vulnerabilities and act upon the same. Such a platform has been elusive on account of high opportunity cost of participation of vulnerable groups in processes of development, lack of any favourable prior experiences, and increasing alienation from their core habitat and livelihoods. The proposed thrust of the intervention, i.e. creating enabling conditions for specific groups of vulnerable people in the Sundarbans to assess and act upon their vulnerabilities, is likely to pose multiple challenges to facilitating agencies. The challenges were identified through the participatory vulnerabilities and capacities analysis along with micro plan. This includes related to mobilisation of vulnerable groups amidst their day-to-day struggles, finding acceptance within the community for a slow process of change, and potential resistance on the part of powerful vested interests. Internally, these include the challenge of restraint needed on the part of facilitating agencies, especially at the frontline level, in order that they do not pre-determine the directions of the process and allow the same to emerge naturally from the community level processes and perspectives of vulnerable groups. Other challenges relate to probable gaps in understanding and commitment needed to a rights-based community-led approach to development, or probable non-availability of necessary skills of facilitation at the frontline level, among others.  The proposed intervention offers a great opportunity for strategic leveraging of available strengths of other identified organizations, towards creation of pathways for emergence of peoples agency for sustainable change.

GAF_Rupantaran_Foundation_AmpliCommuVoic.8. COOPERATION: 8. CooperationDescribe the level of cooperation with other organisations and networks and explain how this cooperation helps achieve your goals (maximum 300 words):Rupantaran Foundation proposes to work closely with seven collaborating organizations in the Sundarbans (which include BTS, DRCSC, ISWS, Mukti, Praajak NCAS and Praxis). Being a co-learner in this journey, we aspire to gain learning from their unique strengths and contribute our experiences and strengths considering their strategic interests in pursuing the intent of leveraging greater levels of leadership and participation of local communities within development initiatives in the Sundarbans. The learning will not only help to achieve goals in our Gopalnagar hub but also extend a role in enhancing organisations knowledge base and in turn the scope of our work. All the collaborating organizations will collectively create spaces for local communities, in order that their interventions emerge more aligned to the real needs of local communities, facilitate increasing greater leadership of local communities and acquire higher levels of cooperation and accountability. Rupantaran has dual role in this project, on one hand we are acting as resource 7.2.b. Objective 2 Expected results/outcomes and timeframe (maximum 300 words):Adherence of a set of commonly agreed principles and values of collaboration (July 2021  July 2023)Institutionalization of commitment to rights-based, community-led approaches to development (July 2021  July 2023)Grant Application Form, July 1 201310organisation extending our skills to other collaborating organisations , while on other hand we are implementing the project.  In fact, to ensure quality work for better achievement of goals, Rupantaran Foundation at Gopalnagar hub is jointly implementing the program with DRCSC, where both organisation will contribute their complementary strength areas.To ensure cooperation and coordination a steering committee with key members of each collaborating organizations is formed. The steering committee conducts regular meetings to lead towards bringing about a common understanding and alignment of the processes. Also, the key members of the resource agency will conduct regular meetings for alignment and smooth coordination to extend capacity building support to the implementing organisations for carrying out processes for amplifying the community voices.
GAF_Rupantaran_Foundation_AmpliCommuVoic.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. ImpactWhat is the change you want to achieve from the overall project? (maximum 300 words):The primary change one expects to achieve from the proposed process is to see greater levels of participation and leadership of local communities in development initiatives in the Sundarbans, evident in greater centrality of their voices and roles in processes of conceptualisation of initiatives, planning, implementation, monitoring and evaluation10. EvaluationHow will progress be monitored and evaluated? (maximum 300 words):Within the alliance of organizations coming together to implement the grant, a Steering Committee, comprising of key functionaries of each organization (including of Rupantaran Foundation) will meet once every month to take stock and reflect upon the progress of the initiative vis--vis a calendar of actions that would be jointly developed by them.   Monitoring and evaluation of the progress of the initiative would be primarily geared upon a community-led process itself. Opportunities would be created for the anchor-groups of collective action, comprising representatives of vulnerable sections, emerging in each location of action to articulate statements and indicators of transformation sought from the collective initiative, as well as indicators of the desired process and values of collaboration. A range of Grant Application Form, July 1 201311participatory methods shall be deployed in the process.
GAF_Rupantaran_Foundation_AmpliCommuVoic.11. ADDITIONAL QUESTIONS/ Future Plans: 11. Future PlansHow will the grant influence the organisation and future plans? (maximum 300 words):The thrust of the proposed initiative of enabling vulnerable groups in the Gopalnagar hub of Sundarbans to diagnose vulnerabilities, articulate aspirations of change and pursue at least one positive transformation in their lives is expected to generate good learning with regards to dynamics of participation of vulnerable groups in community-led processes of change, besides regarding the relative strengths of a collaborative, cluster-based approach within a forum of diverse entities. We would like to reflect critically on the dynamics of participation of vulnerable groups and among facilitating agencies, to assess how agency opportunities can be created for vulnerable groups, so that the learning can be used in facilitating similar collaborations in future.

Summarise the projects ultimate goal(s) (maximum 200 words):( NOT REQUIRED FOR CORE SUPPORT GRANTS)To promote sustainable reintegration of survivors of trafficking and exploitation and reduce risks of unsafe migration in West Bengal and Jharkhand.This will be achieved through mainstreaming learnings within and beyond the network, systems strengthening, establishing multi-stakeholder coordination to strengthen community level safety nets and building resilience of children and young people to challenge harmful social norms.Tdh is committed to making significant and lasting improvements to the lives of the most vulnerable children worldwide.

GAF_Terre_des_hommes_Lausanne_AddreTraff.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 6. Context (The context section should not exceed two pages.)Grant Application Form, July 1 201356a. Describe the organisation (include information on leadership, governance, structure and staff) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):Terre des hommes Foundation, based in Lausanne, is a member of the Terre des Hommes International Federation, which includes sister organisations worldwide. Its Executive Board's role is to oversee the organisation of the Foundation and to monitor ongoing activities, administration, use of the Foundation's resources, risk management and regulation. 2019 was marked by a major financial crisis requiring a reduction in the volume of expenditure in order to guarantee the sustainability of the organization while ensuring the continuity of operations. Measures were taken to adjust priorities at the level of each programme, leading to the restructuring of the operational procedures of the Children in Humanitarian Crisis programme, which is now managed by a single Operations Department in order to promote coordination between emergency, rehabilitation and development activities; and to the termination of certain programmes (Child Labour Exploitation, Advocacy in Switzerland). The HQ Operations department has been restructured into 4 portfolios: Africa, MENA, Asia-South America-Europe and FAST (dedicated to humanitarian crisis). This new organization supports project implementation in a more efficient way, without changing roles and responsibilities at country level. Tdh started its work in India in 1976; the India Delegation Office was established in 2008 as a Liaison Office which implements its programmes and projects through local partner organisations. The office is led by the Country Representative with a Team consisting of Programme Managers of the main thematic areas, supported by Programme Officers and other programme and office assistance staff. Strengthened by its resilience and commitment of its 2059 national and expatriates employees and volunteers worldwide, Tdh has been able to cope with the challenges in this exceptional context in order to maintain its commitment to vulnerable children.6b. Describe the financial situation (include information on annual operating costs, fundraising strategy, reserves and debts) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):6c. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):Tdh, founded in 1960 by Edmund Kaiser in Lausanne, is a leading Swiss child rights organisation that was born during the Algerian conflict to provide direct help to children in need. Tdh is active in over 40 countries worldwide. In India, Tdh has been working since 2008 in the areas of Child Protection, Mother and Grant Application Form, July 1 20136Child Health, WASH and Emergency Response. Tdh co-manages a Global Safeguarding and Support Hub, supported by UK Aid and has been awarded Level 1 certification from Keeping Children Safe.1.PM+: In 2019, Tdh successfully rolled-out the PM+ approach, a brief psychological intervention for adolescents and adults (16+) in Bangladesh. In keeping with WHO Mental Health Global Action Program, PM+ was developed to manualize a brief counseling approach for mild to moderate mental health disorders. The approach focuses on addressing common psychological problems  like stress, anxiety, depression symptoms and where possible, practical problems like livelihood difficulties, family discords etc.2.Art-based methodology (YouCreate toolkit) for youth participation and social cohesion: The toolkit (Art-kit) has been developed by the International Institute for Child Rights and Development to train youth champions and their adult allies to use various kinds of arts to support children and young peoples psychosocial wellbeing. Lessons learnt from this project in Egypt and Iraq can be adapted and applied to support young peoples participation and build their self-confidence, resilience and empowerment in various contexts.3.Sport for Protection Toolkit: Programming with Young People in Forced Displacement Settings is the result of a multi-agency collaboration between the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, the International Olympic Committee and Tdh. The toolkit focuses on three key protection outcomes: Social inclusion; Social cohesion; and Psychosocial well-being. The methodology has been successfully used in Iran, Colombia, Sri Lanka, Palestine, Egypt, Georgia, Eastern Europe and India. 6d. Describe the current strategy of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):India has 450 million internal migrants (2011 census), an increase of 45% since 2001. Of this, 68% are women. A study[1] conducted by Association for Stimulating Know-how showed that West Bengal and Jharkhand are among the states from where women migrate for work in high numbers. Children migrate either alone or with their family to work. While migration does not necessarily lead to trafficking, it creates conditions which make migrating women and children more vulnerable to being traf?cked for sexual exploitation/labour.The COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated these vulnerabilities, putting children and young people at increased risk of trafficking and exploitation.Arriving at a new place, the survivors are cut off from the outside world and forced Grant Application Form, July 1 20137to live in prison-like conditions by their captors. Documents of identification and money are immediately seized, and their movements restricted and continuously monitored. Repeated violence triggers suicidal tendencies and trauma in many survivors. Rescue typically occurs through police raids, help from clients, or captors releasing the survivors due to age, health conditions, etc. However, their trauma does not end with withdrawal.What follows is a chaotic and unprepared journey, into an extremely challenging process of reintegration. Survivors suffer constant terror, guilt, shame and hopelessness. Unaware of service providers and bereft of a social support system, survivors lack adequate occupational skills to begin anew, feel too weak to voice their concerns and consequently, find it impossible to reintegrate into their own society.The study conducted by Tdh highlights survivors experiences of stigma and the hardships they face upon return to their communities, that are major barriers to their successful reintegration.  Continued stigma, denial, rejection in their own communities and lack of preparedness of family members to handle the social stigma leave them feeling crippled and isolated.Tdh has been successfully implementing the Learning Grant supported by Oak Foundation since 2013 and is currently in Phase II of the grant that concludes in October 2020. The grant has supported 35 partners to strengthen their existing practices of working with survivors and support their mental health and wellbeing. It has also supported development of child centric participatory tools (BECOME, EMpowerPLus, Livelihood Precondition) and Counselling Handbook to support frontline workers carrying out the reintegration process.44 social workers have been trained on mental health and counselling that has increased their self-confidence and helped them build a trust-based relationship with children.  In 2019, 1124 children were cared for individually, 445 children were supported to receive services and 6508 family members were counselled and assisted. 1,933 stakeholders were reached through meetings, workshops and consultation including village and block level child protection committees (VL/BL CPCs), Panchayats and Self-Help Groups. The project has engaged with 91 VLCPCs for providing support to children and young people.Partners have been supported to take up joint advocacy initiatives on the gaps in services.Using the seed grant from Tdh, JLKP was able to support 30 young girls and 45 women vulnerable to trafficking earn livelihood through making and selling sal leaf plates, in an initiative supported by the Pradhan and other villagers. This has immensely enhanced the confidence and self-esteem of the girls whose average monthly family income is now between Rs. 6000-7500. With the money earned from selling the plates, some women have also initiated poultry farming and piggeries.  Villagers have also been connected to government schemes such as the Jharkhand Tribal Agency.Using the BECOME and Livelihoods pre-condition tools, GGBK staff are now able to help survivors identify livelihood options and in the last two years, 46 out of 52 girls receiving livelihood support are earning an income and slowly increasing profits.[1] https://www.verite.org/ask-indias-migration-initiatives/

CooperationDescribe the level of cooperation with other organisations and networks and explain how this cooperation helps achieve your goals (maximum 300 words):The project will ensure meaningful participation of children and youth in planning, decision-making, facilitation, reflection and evaluation on issues that matter to them, using actions they want to use. CYP led participatory approaches to influence negative norms will be a model for other organisations to adopt and replicate. Tdh will collaborate with organisations active in the social norm change domain and join interagency groups to share the community led participatory pathways evolved from this intervention.A collaborative network of organisations with different capacities will be brought together through this project to address unsafe migration of children and young people. This network will extend beyond the boundaries of the partner organizations to agencies that are partners and collaborators of Oak Foundation in India. Organisations such as Human Rights Law Network (HRLN), Association for Advocacy and Legal Initiatives (AALI) will be essential collaborators under this project that can extend their legal expertise in areas  including trials and accessing victim compensation schemes. CREA will come on board as a resource agency for conducting trainings with duty bearers, families, community people and CYP on gender issues. Breakthrough can offer its expertise on creation and dissemination of behaviour change communication (BCC) materials as well as running BCC campaigns on negative social norms. The project will also collaborate with Tafteesh to align joint advocacy messages to amplify demands of the survivors.Cross sharing and learning will be fostered and facilitated within the ambit of the Projects direct partners with grassroots experience of working on unsafe migration. Each of the 14 partner organisations bring its distinctive strengths, for example - strong programming on mental health and psychosocial elements in Malda; strengthened community access in Koderma. Such collaborations will help strengthen the quality of services, improve management of unsafe migration cases and enhance organisational capacities of partners.

GAF_A_Sign_of_Hope_StrenTribaVoiceInSund.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT 5a. Tell us about your governance and leadership structures, as well as staff and volunteer base. Highlight any significant recent or expected future changes. If you have an explicit approach to increasing diversity and/or advancing race equity within the organisation, please tell us. (300 words):Oak Application Form     5Re-granting organization: Hoffnungszeichen | Sign of Hope e.V. (SoH) is a legally registered German NGO (reg. no. VR 380978). It is governed by an Executive Board comprising of 2 members and a Supervisory Board comprising 4 members. 37 full-time staff are located in the main office in Konstanz and 3 in Berlin. 44 full-time employees work for SoHs East Africa Branch (EAB), and are based in the main EAB office in Nairobi, Kenya, in Uganda, South Sudan and Ethiopia. Cooperation and partnerships with local organisations are at the centre of SoHs work and its staff is thoroughly experienced in the facilitation of larger donor-funded projects together with local partners.Development Research Communication and Services Centre (DRCSC) is a non-profit development organization registered under West Bengal Societies Registration Act 1961, bearing registration no. S/39363. It is governed by an Executive Council comprising 9 members.The staff and volunteers of DRCSC include more than 180 people, ensuring adequate representation of women and persons from marginalized communities. The organization has four senior management team members with longstanding experience in different areas of programme implementation and financial management.Lokamata Rani Rashmoni Mission (LRRM) is a non-profit organization registered under West Bengal Societies Registration Act, 1961, bearing the registration no. S/59662. It is governed by an Executive Council comprising 11 members.The staff of LRRM includes 44 people, headed by the President, while the number of volunteers and community resource persons are 25 and 22, respectively. The management team members are thoroughly experienced in programme design, implementation and financial management. LRRMs mission  to advance gender and ethnic equity  is also ensured organisationally in the adequate representation of women and persons from marginalized communities (Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes and Other Backward Classes) among its staff and volunteer base. 5b. Summarise the organisations history.  In addition, highlight 2-3 key achievements.Please keep this brief and list up to 3 key achievements as bullet points. Even though you may have many achievements, please share what is most relevant to the proposed grant. (300 words)SoH was founded in 1983 (at that time as CSI-Deutschland e.V.) as a registered association in Bonn. In 1999, it was renamed Hoffnungszeichen | Sign of Hope e.V. SoH provides humanitarian aid in the form of disaster and emergency relief worldwide and is involved in sustainable development cooperation and human rights work in line with the LRRD approach and the HDP nexus. The prior regional focus is central East Africa, specifically Ethiopia, Kenya, Uganda and South Sudan, where it is represented by own staff and operates basic health stations and mobile clinics. Further developing regional focus areas are the Bay of Bengal Region (India and Bangladesh), Oak Application Form     6southern and central Africa, and Armenia. Thematic focus areas are WASH, food security, livelihoods, adaptation to climate change, and health.Key achievements:1. Based on its research in affected countries and through networks in Germany, SoH aims to exert influence on the public. Our expert knowledge is also in demand at the United Nations. SoH has a consultative status and can influence the discussions and decisions of the relevant UN bodies with submissions, publications, and events.2. Since 2016 SoH has been a successful partner to the German Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development (BMZ) in 28 finished and ongoing projects in 11 countries with a total funding amount of 17,991,318 euros. SoH is focused on the Sundarban region in the Bay of Bengal area in India and Bangladesh with 3 implemented projects amounting to 2,307,685 euros and one additional project (332,648 euros) in Bangladesh currently in the planning phase.Also, private foundations and initiatives are valuable partners for SoH, e.g. Bild hilft e.V., SKala Initiative, Sternstunden e.V.3. SoH is a member of ECHO (European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations) and is eligible to apply for grants at the German Federal Foreign Office (GFFO). DRCSC was established in 1982 as a resource centre for collection, collation and dissemination of information on various socioeconomic issues in order to promote social justice, especially for informal sector workers, indigenous communities, small and marginal farmers, landless laborers, and self-employed artisans. Since 1992, DRCSC has been engaged in promoting awareness of environmental degradation, sustainable agriculture and natural resource management for improving food and livelihood security in ecologically vulnerable rural areas across 12 districts of West Bengal. DRCSC is a leading resource centre with a current record of training 17 non-profits and nearly 500 community groups to implement innovative region-specific participatory models of sustainable and climate resilient agriculture, community-based common resource management with the aim to reduce food and livelihood insecurity, seasonal migration and to  improve the nutritional status of girls and women. The organization encourages handing over of administrative responsibilities to user groups in a phased manner. DRCSC has participated in and co-hosted the Bay of Bengal meeting on Sundarban eco-zone (a forum of major resource agencies to focus on problems and possibilities in the coastal areas of Bay of Bengal).Key achievements:1. It is one of 6 agencies to receive a grant from Adaptation Fund through the National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development, or NABARD (designated Government of India agency for Climate Change funds) for facilitating community-led interventions to promote resilience and climate change adaptation among small and marginal farmers in the drought-prone red-and-lateritic zone in Purulia and Bakura districts, West Bengal.2. It is one of the collaborating organizations in a community-led initiative to strengthen the agency of vulnerable communities in Patharpratima Oak Application Form     7Community Development Block (CDB) in the South 24 Parganas district, West Bengal.3. It was chosen as a lead agency in a project supported by the Department of Science and Technology, Government of India, to coordinate a multi-state research project on bio-diverse integrated farming system for four years across 12 states, in collaboration with 18 NGOs and development organizations. LRRM was founded in 1986 with the vision of empowering Indias rural poor to overcome inequality and poverty and creating a healthy environment for their overall well-being and prosperity. Its Mission is presently engaged in multidirectional developmental activities involving skill development, capacity building, alternate livelihood generation, rational utilization of natural resources, and health support, to promote sustainable development among poor rural communities in the South 24 Parganas district and urban slum dwellers in southern Kolkata. LRRM is specially committed to serving and empowering women, children, old and disabled persons. Over the last 33 years, it has successfully implemented 65 projects for 65,000 direct and 300,000 indirect beneficiaries in 32 CDBs with support from 26 government departments and 4 international organizations. LRRM regularly organizes awareness camps, cultural and sports events and seminars to promote socio-culturally-grounded awareness and knowledge dissemination.Key achievements:1. It has imparted skill training/capacity building for 34 trades to 6,582 poor, rural, unemployed youth/womens self-help groups (WSHGs), and created alternate livelihood opportunities for 3,409 women through post-training support.2. It has prepared 71 Peoples Biodiversity Registers, promoted in-situ conservation of 50 indigenous paddy and 50 vegetable varieties, installed 1,216 improved cook stoves, and planted 7,009 saplings for natural resource conservation.3. It has received 1 district-level and 11 state-level awards from government departments/agencies, and 5 affiliations from different agencies.5c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and decide your approach? If you have undertaken a theory of change exercise, or if you are influenced by research, policy or your own organisations experience, please tell us about this.  Have you consulted with relevant stakeholders, including your communities and others experiencing the problem? Is there an intention to address equity, diversity and inclusion? (600 words):The project aims to promote inclusive social change by amplifying the voices of tribal households in 8 villages in the SBR region of the North and South 24 Parganas and representing them in research, governance and development interventions. In 4 phases, it aims to (1) enable communities in identifying their vulnerabilities and development needs and aspirations, and assess their Oak Application Form     8vulnerabilities and climate risks, (2) develop community-led interventions to address those needs and aspirations and reduce vulnerabilities to climate change, and (3) implement these interventions through women-led processes, facilitated by like-minded organizations, (4) assess the effectiveness of the interventions and disseminate the knowledge gained with relevant actors.Core Problem: Tribal communities are specifically vulnerable to the effects of climate change and have limited assistance to adapt to climate change.According to researchers from Jadavpur University, the majority of the over 200,000 tribal people in the SBR remain the most resource-poor and vulnerable, inhabiting forest fringe areas characterized by high hazard risks. Predominantly landless and ecosystem-dependent, the tribal households have low adaptive capacity. Efforts to uplift tribal communities in the SBR are underwhelming, with limited research on their situation and needs and few to no interventions support them adapt to climate change. Underlying Problem 1: Needs of tribal communities are unknown and unaddressed as they are not represented in research, policy, governance and leadership.Despite the existence of several pro-tribal policies in India, tribal communities remain largely socioeconomically marginalized and poorly represented in research, policy and governance. Several lacunae in policymaking, such as the mandate that the tribal population of a location/region must be at least 50,000 or 50% of the total population to qualify for pro-tribal schemes and interventions, exclude and further disempower these communities in the SBR, where the tribal population is non-dominant and dispersed. With low levels of participation and leadership, their development needs remain largely unknown and unaddressed. Underlying Problem 2: Tribal communities have limited or no access to interventions and initiatives to reduce their vulnerability to climate change. Due to the lack of alternatives they often rely on indiscriminate exploitation of natural resources and lack sustainable resource management.Being predominantly ecosystem-dependent and non-agrarian, with little to no landholding, makes a significant contribution to the disempowerment of tribal communities, exposing them to man-animal conflict, denial of forest access, and forced migration to urban areas for contractual labour. The loss of livelihood due to natural disasters and lack of sustainable management of natural resources are the main drivers of negative coping strategies adopted by the tribal communities. The consequences of these are emissions from deforested mangrove forests and blue carbon loss, decline of fish, crabs and shrimps, food insecurity and increase of human-animal conflicts. Though the SBR has been globally identified as a key climate change and biodiversity, climate change adaptation for the local communities have been slow and unsustainable, owing primarily to the absence of community-centred approaches and failure to develop sustainable initiatives which are both locally relevant and accessible. From their previous experience of working for the development and protection of vulnerable rural communities in the SBR, both DRCSC and LRRM have noted a dearth of development programs and interventions with a special focus on tribal communities.Oak Application Form     9 Underlying Problem 3: Tribal women are specifically marginalized, experience gender inequality and often face domestic abuse, neglect and deprivation, with no access to mental health care.The disproportionate burden on tribal women remains unaddressed as they are severely marginalized by the existing vulnerabilities, climate-related stresses and gender inequality. They often assume the role of de facto household head in the absence of migrant men, carry overwhelming proportions of care work, while also experiencing domestic abuse, neglect and deprivation. Women and children in the SBR have no recourse to formal mental health support.
GAF_A_Sign_of_Hope_StrenTribaVoiceInSund.7. OBJECTIVES: 7. OBJECTIVESThis is the most important part of your application, as it is your opportunity to explain what you want to achieve and what will be different because of your work. We understand that social and environmental change is complex and there are a multitude of factors that contribute to change. We want to understand how you define your role in the overall change you hope to make. You may find it helpful to discuss this with your Oak Programme Officer, and others in your own organisation.   7.a. ObjectivesList here up to 3 main objectives for this grant (one sentence per objective). Think of objectives as goals that can be achieved within the lifetime of the grant.  We encourage you to think of objective(s) that are ambitious but also achievable.  Objective: Resilience to climate change among tribal communities is increased through identification of their challenges, their empowerment to active participation in finding solutions for the same and consecutive dissemination of the knowledge gained with relevant actors. Interventions to improve the resilience and living conditions of tribal communities, that are tested, adjusted to the context and identified as effective, are scaled up in terms of geographical and target group outreach through a follow-up project for which funding from private and public institutions is secured.The activities will be undertaken by DRCSC and LRRM as local partners, research consultants and SoH as German re-granting organisation, facilitator and supporter of capacity building workshops in India and knowledge dissemination and advocacy events/workshops in India and Germany. DRCSC will be responsible for the direct implementation of research and interventions in Hingalganj, Sandeshkhali I Block and Kakdwip Block. LRRM will be responsible for direct implementation of research and interventions in Kultali Block. A project Management board fitted with staff members from both organizations will ensure the appliance of equal standards, approaches and Oak Application Form     10methodologies during research and interventions and support cooperation between the organizations.The project shall lay the foundation for a planned follow-up project to strengthen the resilience against climate risks of tribal communities in the Sundarbans and to improve their living conditions. The Objective of the present project (knowledge gained on needs & challenges; development of effective and context specific interventions; establishment of networks and knowledge sharing between local and international practitioners and donors) will serve as a basis for this purpose. The follow-up project shall be timely overlapping with the present project (planned start in 2024/25  depending on the evolvement of the present project) and shall have a budget of between 800,000  1,200,000 EUR. Public and private funding will be secured, inter alia, through networking activities under Outcome 1.7.b. Expected Outcomes (bullet points):What do you expect will change because of this grant? What does success look like? List here the main outcomes you hope to achieve or make significant contributions towards with this grant, and for whom.  If you have concrete targets, please also list them here. Outcomes describe significant changes for people, communities, organisations or systems. Some examples are changes in policies and legislation; changes in knowledge, awareness, attitudes, beliefs, behaviours or social norms; changes in capacities, level of influence, agency or access to services. Please refer to the guidance for additional examples.Outcome 1: Needs and challenges of tribal communities are identified through an ethnographic research and different Participatory Rural Appraisal (PRA) tools. Interventions adapted to the local context and target group (Outcome 2) are assessed and best practices are identified. The knowledge gained on challenges and effective interventions is shared with relevant stakeholders and decision makers.Given the currently scant ethnographic engagement with tribal communities in the SBR, research consultants in cooperation with DRCSC/LRRM will conduct an in-depth ethnographic study to understand the sociocultural context, practices, development needs and aspirations of vulnerable tribal communities, assess their vulnerabilities and climate risks in order to promote awareness of, and protection for, their cultures, customs, rights and interests and to adapt effective interventions for their needs. To avoid further alienating the marginalized communities and to ensure that development initiatives are sustainable in the long term, intervention design must be just, fair, inclusive, locally relevant, and developed and implemented through a people-centred approach. Insights from the ethnographic survey, vulnerability and risk assessment study and relationship-building exercise will enable the project organisers to both assess the needs and aspirations of the communities and facilitate their participation and stewardship in intervention design and activity implementation. Outcome 2: Community-led development interventions aligned to the needs of tribal communities have been designed, piloted, evaluated and improved. Oak Application Form     11Climate risk reduction is increased and the socioeconomic resilience of the target group is strengthened.The planned activities under this Outcome will be based on the findings of the preceding research and assessments (Outcome 1). They are designed participatory together with the target group in a form that indigenous knowledge systems are upheld and combined with scientific methods. The process is community-led, meaning that the collaborating organizations and researchers primary moderate the process, contributing their knowledge and capacities rather than taking the direct lead. The interventions are continuously monitored, evaluated and improved. The interventions focus on group formation and empowerment, climate adaptive and diversified livelihoods, organic agriculture, shore protection and dissemination of critical information to the target group. As the process unfolds over time, the capacities of the community representatives are enhanced to emerge as competent trainers who can achieve self-reliance and continue the community-led work after the completion of the project. Local stewardship will not only enable the project team to successfully overcome the communities hesitation or reluctance in adopting the initiatives but also promote leadership, cohesion and decision-making agency. Outcome 3: Physical and mental health challenges of the tribal communities are addressed. Good health is promoted and access to government health programs is established.The absence of adequate healthcare facilities is accompanied with a lack of awareness of locally prevalent healthcare issues and health-seeking behaviour among the communities. While there is scant literature on the condition of physical and mental health in the SBR, there is an absolute absence of tribal communities in health and well-being-related research, policy and governance in the region. In addition to hypertension, pulmonary and gastrointestinal issues associated with certain environmental hazards like soil and water salinity, mental health disorders like depression, suicide and deliberate self-harm, often linked with experiences of man-animal conflict, frequent disaster-related losses and morbidities, are also widely prevalent. Mental health support is limited to non-existent in the region, with health camps and awareness-building workshops seldom mainstreaming mental healthcare. In the event of the dual crisis of pandemic-induced reverse migration and cyclone-induced rural-urban migration, the lack of infrastructural support and safety nets for migrants and their families became glaringly obvious, and communities relied only on psychosocial support from their friends and relatives.While there is no disaggregated data on the health conditions and needs of tribal communities, the collaborating organizations are aware that inter-generational poverty, neglect and exclusion leads to poor physical and mental health outcomes within these communities. However, knowledge of the specific drivers of poor health and well-being can only emerge from the proposed ethnographic survey. The present objective will synthesize relevant insights from the survey to design interventions to reduce the physical and mental health challenges of the tribal communities and promote good health and overall well-being through the following activities.Oak Application Form     127.c. Activities and timeframe (bullet points):List in bullet points the main types of activities that you plan to to carry out to achieve your expected outcomes. Please keep these at a high level and and dont include the full list of every activity you plan to carry out, instead, concentrate on the type of activities this grant will fund. If your Programme Officer wants more information, we will ask you separately for a work plan. Examples might include: (1) Research; (2) Provision of legal advice to...; (3) Training on movement building for...Activities to achieve Outcome 1.i. Ethnographic survey of 800 tribal households across 8 villages, conducted 3 times (= 2,400 households) during the project period to identify and understand the socio-historical context, tribal practices and the local dynamics of power, gender and exclusion, drivers of vulnerability. The methodology (ethnographic methods, participatory research, semi-structured and unstructured interviews and discussions with community members and other relevant stakeholders, photography and videography, photo voice method) will focus on the lived experiences of the communities and foster meaningful relationships between them and the project team.ii. A Participatory Vulnerability Capacity Assessments (PVCA) to assess the vulnerability and climate risks of the communities based on climate data and accounts of experiencing environmental hazards and climate change impacts and to explore the potential for leadership among the most vulnerable sections of the communities (namely women, youth and marginalized occupational groups) for participation and stewardship in the design and implementation of appropriate interventions to promote inclusive development, resilience und climate risk reduction.iii. Action research comprising monitoring and evaluation at regular intervals to repeatedly assess the efficacy and outcomes of the interventions, and introduce necessary modifications to the intervention strategies and design.iv. Empowerment of the target group through collaboration with community representatives in reviving tribal customs and practices, observing tribal holidays, celebrating tribal festivals, organizing tribal food festivals, etc. to promote awareness of tribal cultures, knowledges and languages, prevent their erosion and loss, and encourage social cohesion.v. Workshops with regional actors for advocacy and sensitization. Sharing the knowledge gained and the results of the action-interventions (under Outcome 2) with stakeholders, and advocating tribal needs and interests to the relevant governmental authorities for appropriately streamlining the implementation of government policies and schemes. This will include the publication of research papers, policy briefs, survey reports, blog posts and yearly knowledge dissemination workshops at the block level and practitioners Workshops with local organizations. The activity will target specialised and non-specialised audiences and address the invisibility of tribal experiences, needs, aspirations, issues and interests Oak Application Form     13in the media and scholarship, to ensure that relevant government schemes and programs reach the tribal communities. vi. Empowerment of the target group to express their thoughts, needs and demands via media (social media, radio, vlogs, etc.).vii. Dissemination of knowledge gained (identified needs & tested solutions) with Indian and international practitioners. The aim of this activity is (1) to exchange knowledge and best practices gained during research and implementation, (2) to have the findings of the project critically reviewed with other practitioners in the field, (3) to connect local and international practitioners and promote networking and knowledge sharing between these. The activity will be conducted in the form of workshops, seminars and similar events. Activities to achieve Outcome 2.i. Formation and revival of community-based groups such as WSHGs and local youths groups and identification of leaders from these groups, to lead and monitor the design and implementation of the interventions.ii. Promotion of climate adaptive and diversified livelihoods (nutrition gardens, small farm improvement, small animal rearing-oriented livelihood, ecological/organic farming, mixed cropping, aquaculture (fish, crab and snail)) through skill development trainings, practical assistance and exposure visits.iii. Promotion of collective organic agriculture by developing one model agro-farms using bio-diverse integrated farming system (IFS) in each of the four blocks. Innovative desalinization models will be established along with the developed farms.iv. Promotion of participative shore protection on 5 hectares of land along the coast, freshwater harvesting (rain/surface/subsurface), mangrove plantation and community-based conservation, promoting avian and aquatic biodiversity. This community-based process is also expected to promote sustainability and social cohesion. The plantation areas will be protected and maintained through the formation of a mangrove plantation committee.v. Establishment of information hubs at the block level in cooperation with local Gram Panchayats to disseminate information about education and employment opportunities and Natural Resource Management (NRM) based vocations towards tribal communities, raise awareness with regards to government schemes and initiatives, ensure access to different rights and entitlements, and promote awareness of measures for safe migration.vi. Workshops to raise awareness for existing Government schemes and initiatives and to ensure access to rights and entitlements.vii. Dissemination of weather forecast, agro-advisory and hazard warning (cyclone, surge) issued at the block level in the villages, using simple and easily understandable terms and local languages. Activities to achieve Outcome 3.Oak Application Form     14i. Organisation of free physical and mental health check-ups, counselling, awareness campaigns and workshops, and vaccination campaigns (linked to government schemes) in the communities.ii. Impart training in physical exercises and equipment for non-intensive sports like kabaddi, football and volleyball as a means to improve physical and mental health, particularly for tribal women and youth.iii. Collaboration with medical experts, rural doctors, and the local communities to strengthen the available infrastructure of physical and mental healthcare service delivery as well as dispense advice on individual, household and community-level coping mechanisms to strengthen available psychosocial support bases for mental health needs. Necessary modifications to interventions will be made as and when required in the course of the project, to ensure their acceptance by the tribal communities and sustainability. Appropriate scope and opportunity to suitably upscale the initiatives will also be identified in the course of the project.
GAF_A_Sign_of_Hope_StrenTribaVoiceInSund.8. COOPERATION: 8. COOPERATION  How will you involve others in your approach to achieving change? If you are planning to engage in partnerships with other organisations, communities, people with lived experience, academics or secure the support of key individuals, please tell us about this.  Why are these the right partners to engage with?  Is there anything new about how you are choosing to work - for example, new partnerships or an approach that is different to how you usually work? (300 words):SoH proposes to work closely with the 2 collaborating organizations DRCSC and LRRM, so that their unique strengths and strategic interests can accommodate the projects objective. In addition to SoHs administrative role as the re-granting organization (transfer of funds, accounting, M&E, reporting, etc.) SoH will provide guidance and capacity building for the collaborating organisations and organizes practitioners workshops and networking events with Indian and international stakeholders.DRCSC and LRRM will be involved in facilitating research and undertaking on-ground implementation of the project interventions, ensuring that these are closely aligned with the needs, aspirations and realities of the tribal communities and nurturing the leadership potential of community-based groups like WSHGs and local youths groups.DRCSC and LRRM will work closely in 8 villages in the SBR, within the CDBs of Hingalganj and Sandeshkhali I in the North 24 Parganas district, and Kakdwip and Kultali in the South 24 Parganas district, West Bengal. DRCSC will exercise the primary facilitation role in the villages in Hingalganj, Sandeshkhali I and Kakdwip CDBs while LRRM will do so in the villages in Kultali CDB. A project management team consisting of one staff member of Oak Application Form     15each organization will facilitate the cooperation between both organizations. A Steering Committee made up of representatives of DRCSC, LRRM, researchers and SoH will serve as a forum to discuss upcoming matters.  2 researchers will be engaged in full capacity for 3 years while an expert, Dr. Sugata Hazra, will participate in the project in an individual capacity, to address the project design, action research and evaluation components data collation and analysis and vulnerability assessment, climate risk reduction, and design of interventions.
GAF_A_Sign_of_Hope_StrenTribaVoiceInSund.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING This section is twofold. Please tell us:a) Monitoring and evaluation. How will you know if you are achieving your objectives? Please describe briefly how you will know if you are making progress and if what you are doing is working. If you have a formal monitoring and evaluation system and if you plan to collect indicator data or conduct an external evaluation, please provide details here.b) Learning. Please tell us if there anything in particular that you are hoping to learn more about or test through this grant.(300 words):a) Monitoring and evaluation: The key functionaries of each collaborating organization and the researchers will meet on a bi-monthly basis to reflect on learnings from the community processes, and assess the progress of the initiatives vis--vis a calendar of activities jointly developed by them.  The success and failure of different activities and the outcome will be assessed through household surveys repeated annually and issue-based focus group discussions in terms of specific indicators.The assessments under Outcome 1 will examine the degree of vulnerability and the scope of climate risk reduction, and agency, leadership and self-reliance within the vulnerable communities, particularly women and youth. For that matter a performance indicator matrix will be set up and baseline indicators will be assessed.Monitoring and evaluation of the progress of the initiatives will be primarily geared upon a WSHG-led process. The collaborating organizations will evaluate at 2 levels: (1) internal, to continuously examine how effective, people-centric, culturally-sensitive and gender-responsive the decisions, approaches and interventions are throughout the lifecycle of the project. The researchers will conduct yearly and final evaluation surveys, prepare survey reports, and identify avenues/indicators of improvement; and (2) at the community level, where the group leaders shall continually examine the progress of the initiatives over time, in terms of indicators of inclusivity, gender-responsiveness, vulnerability reduction and self-reliance etc.b) Learning: The project seeks to learn about the unique vulnerabilities, needs and aspirations of marginalized tribal groups in the SBR, that are largely invisible in research and unreached in development governance. These ethnographic insights will create a support base for planning, up-Oak Application Form     16scaling and implementation of suitable community-led initiatives in future, to address the needs and reduce the vulnerabilities of this population.
GAF_A_Sign_of_Hope_StrenTribaVoiceInSund.10. RISKS AND CHALLENGES: 10.  RISKS AND CHALLENGESWhat are the risks or barriers that might prevent you from achieving your outcomes and how will you address these?  What are your opportunities?We understand that achieving long-lasting and meaningful change is hard and we expect that the work you want to do will mean taking risks.  We encourage you to be open to telling us these, as well as how you will address these risks.  If some of your outcomes are risky, are there any incremental achievements that you could identify? (300 words):The projects approach and proposed thrust of interventions i.e., encouraging vulnerable tribal communities in the SBR to articulate their vulnerabilities and unique development needs, and piloting suitable interventions to address these through WSHGs and local youths groups, is likely to pose multiple challenges and risks. Some of these anticipated challenges relate to mobilization of disempowered groups like tribal women and youth amidst their regular duties and struggles, and finding acceptance within the community for the implementation of innovative and modern initiatives which demand significant behaviour change and inform a slow process of transformation. The anticipated risks include potential resistance on the part of powerful vested interests and political lobbies, which poses a threat to community-led work at the frontline. The collaborating organizations can reduce these risks by facilitating regular and transparent communication between the community representatives, state and local governments and the project team. Another challenge would be in promoting sustainable livelihood options among some of the tribes, like the Shabars, who are traditionally hunter-gatherers, predominantly non-agrarian and dependent on forest and ecosystem services. The research team shall address this challenge through knowledge-sharing efforts, learning from indigenous in similar conditions from other parts of the country/ world as well as by negotiating with the Department of Forest for sustainable use of forest resources. Other challenges relate to knowledge gaps about tribal concerns and interests, and gaps in understanding of, and commitment to, an inclusive approach to sustainable development, and probable non-availability of necessary skills and local resources for facilitation at the frontline level. These knowledge gaps and capacity deficits will be addressed through research to gain relevant ethnographic insights and training and information materials for the staff, facilitators, researchers and community representatives, to enhance their understanding and capabilities vis--vis rights-based, gender-responsive, culturally-sensitive and locally-relevant community-led approaches to tribal development.Oak Application Form     17

GAF_A_Praxis_UK_AmpliCommuVoiceInTheIndi.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT 5a. Tell us about your governance and leadership structures, as well as staff and volunteer base. Highlight any significant recent or expected future changes. If you have an explicit approach to increasing diversity and/or advancing race equity within the organisation, please tell us. (300 words):Oak Application Form     5Praxis UK is a not-for-profit NGO specialising in participatory approaches to international development. Set up in 2007, Praxis UK aspires to change the practice of the North talking on behalf of the South to the South engaging directly in debates and policies. Praxis UK acts as a platform for grassroots NGOs, CBOs and peoples movements from the South to express their voices in the North. It is part of a global movement that encourages ordinary and often marginalised people to exercise their right to participate in their own development.Undertaking participatory action research, enhancing capacities for participatory development work and engaging with the state through voices of disadvantaged identities are some of Praxiss core domains of work. Our vision, beliefs and values influence our work at the local, national and international level. Our work is wide ranging and spans individuals and communities and extends up to governments and intergovernmental agencies across the globe. We engage closely at all levels to facilitate community leadership and work to implement the most appropriate and effective solution in any particular situation. The breadth of our network, combined with our knowledge, experience, resources and collaborative approach, enable lasting change to be realised.The trustees of Praxis UK include a mix of senior development sector and industry practitioners who guide the organisations work, fundraising, legal and other matters. The staff of Praxis UK includes four full time consultants and one part time support colleague for administrative and financial matters. 5b. Summarise the organisations history.  In addition, highlight 2-3 key achievements.Please keep this brief and list up to 3 key achievements as bullet points. Even though you may have many achievements, please share what is most relevant to the proposed grant. (300 words)Praxis UK was established in 2007 and over fifteen years its focus has expanded to a wide span of issues of social exclusion, participation and governance. Praxis breadth of experience ranges across most sectors of social development in Asia and Africa. Three recent relevant achievements are:1.         Developing community-led ethical review processes to challenge institutional review boards and ensure that for research to be an intervention communities affected by the processes have a say in how the research study, questions and instruments are designed and findings analysed. Supported by Durham University (2020- 2022)2.         Landscape analysis to inform international evaluation in the service of equity to explore the paradigm shift, particularly within global evaluation policies and practices. In collaboration with partners in Latin America, Africa and Asia, the research included exchanges with a range of funding mechanisms to explore how the most excluded and historically oppressed peoples, specifically those in the Global South, play a role in determining the impact and value of any program, policy, or initiative developed in their Oak Application Form     6name and for their development. It helped deconstruct the multiple understandings of equity in evaluation while capturing how some actors in the evaluation ecosystem overcome concrete barriers to achieving equity. Supported by Ford Foundation (2022  2023)3.         Transparency and Accountability Initiative (Track) supported by Laudes Foundation, aims to strengthen existing voluntary and emerging mandatory responsible business regulations in Asia by building enabling ecosystem collaboration with varied stakeholders and making publicly available a set of quality standardised and stakeholder useful information, which can be used by stakeholders to hold businesses to the account. (2021-2025)5c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and decide your approach? If you have undertaken a theory of change exercise, or if you are influenced by research, policy or your own organisations experience, please tell us about this.  Have you consulted with relevant stakeholders, including your communities and others experiencing the problem? Is there an intention to address equity, diversity and inclusion? (600 words):Sundarbans is an ecologically fragile zone spread across two countries. There is a space for learning from interventions across both. In Phase 1, 114 groups of vulnerable people in five Gram Panchayats of Patharpratima (Digambarpur, Gopalnagar, Herambagopalpur, Achintyanagar and Banashyamnagar), South 24 Parganas, West Bengal, were identified and brought together to diagnose their vulnerabilities, articulate aspirations and avenues of change, and work together. The project covers 20 villages with a population estimate of 1,06,650.After Phase 1, field staff assessed that 29% groups were active and functional  meeting frequently, discussing issues of relevance, taking part in activities, taking ownership of issues and expressing a need for continued engagement. Group members found value in learning new information, finding confidence and exercising collective bargaining power.  They identified issues for action in Phase 2:Effects of climate change (life and livestock threatened by eroding embankments and frequent flooding; livelihoods impacted by increasing soil salinity, limited water resources, poor market linkages);Gender-based discrimination and violence (early marriage; domestic violence; limited opportunities for girls in education /livelihoods; lower wages for women workers; menstrual taboos);Limited access to rights and entitlements (poor healthcare; limited awareness about government schemes);Unsafe migration (dropouts, especially among boys;)Lack of sustainable livelihood options (unsafe migration, dropout)Phase 2 aims to continue the work done while bridging some gaps:Oak Application Form     7Target-driven activity-focus of implementation that overshadowed process-oriented actionsLimited coordination amongst resource agencies affected holistic perspective for staff and communitiesCommunity leadership devoid of perspectives / standsFocus of what should change rested with organisations rather than with communitiesHesitation / reluctance to PRI engagementTo meet these gaps, the consortium framed a theory of change which is presented below:1. How is change within community visualised?After forming their own micro-level plans, the dynamics between community and organisation changed to dependence because of the nature of interventions and expectations of communities. The transformation being visualised in the community isFrom formulating plan to owning the plan by periodic revisiting / evolving their change journey driven by their unique needs (and perspectives)From individual actions / actions that benefit individuals to collective actionsFrom receiving organisations strategies and directions to community-led actions that are more organic, impactful, and sustainable transformationFrom implementing organisations agenda to informing organisations agenda through careful assessment of their strengths, weaknesses, risks and opportunities2. How is change within organization visualised?As community groups assume leadership roles, the organisations role transformsFrom direct control to providing facilitative supportFrom providing trainings to mentoring community resource personsFrom leading networking initiatives to strategic advice on stakeholder engagementFrom a culture of learning (one-way) to a culture of reflection (analytical process)From becoming visible in Patharpratima to networking and collaboration that visibilises ACV beyond Patharpratima3. Is the project truly being able to reach the most marginalised  communities within the village and villages within the block?The consortium must discern whether there are still communities that are sidelined because of identity / the work they do / their inaccessibility / their inability to give time etc. and what further actions are warranted. For this to Oak Application Form     8happen within the people-centred, community-led model, it is important for communities to form their own perspectives around marginalization.Praxis UK sees Phase 2 as an opportunity to showcase ACV as a model of cross-learning and introspection in other geographies, contexts and funding scenarios. ACVs learnings can be offset with similar experiences of community development in Bangladesh and other countries. Praxis UK will reprise the role of facilitating collaborative partnerships to sustain and amplify this model of excellence.
GAF_A_Praxis_UK_AmpliCommuVoiceInTheIndi.7. OBJECTIVES: 7. OBJECTIVESThis is the most important part of your application, as it is your opportunity to explain what you want to achieve and what will be different because of your work. We understand that social and environmental change is complex and there are a multitude of factors that contribute to change. We want to understand how you define your role in the overall change you hope to make. You may find it helpful to discuss this with your Oak Programme Officer, and others in your own organisation.   7.a. ObjectivesList here up to 3 main objectives for this grant (one sentence per objective). Think of objectives as goals that can be achieved within the lifetime of the grant.  We encourage you to think of objective(s) that are ambitious but also achievable.  To strengthen people-centred approach in Patharpratima block of Sundarbans whereby vulnerable communities give voice to their aspirations, better understand their vulnerabilities and work towards a collective resolution of challenges they face Achieving highest standards of cooperation among collaborating organizations, leading to deep institutionalization of values of partnership and commitment for community-led approaches to development that are visibilised before other geographies, contexts and donor organisations7.b. Expected Outcomes (bullet points):What do you expect will change because of this grant? What does success look like? List here the main outcomes you hope to achieve or make significant contributions towards with this grant, and for whom.  If you have concrete targets, please also list them here. Outcomes describe significant changes for people, communities, organisations or systems. Some examples are changes in policies and legislation; changes in knowledge, awareness, attitudes, beliefs, behaviours or social norms; changes in capacities, level of influence, agency or access to services. Please refer to the guidance for additional examples.Oak Application Form     9Outcomes of Objective 1Programme looks at a mix of the following: a) NGOs empower community to collect data on specific issues (a. climate-adaptive livelihood; b. gender-based violence; c. different aspects of child rights; d. climate and environmental impacts such as embankments) and amplifies these; b) NGOs create a platform for communities to present their voice; c) NGOs empower communities to create their own spaces, amplify issues that are important to them through evidence-backed action. By December 2024, at least three community collectives in each hub of Phase 1 will take up and follow through issues of community-led stakeholder engagement / participatory action research, thereby taking small actions towards collective development (some ongoing issues - access to water and strengthening embankments in Achintanagar / Banashamnagar, improving ICDS centre and improving library for children - Digambarpur, access to ambulance - Herambagopalpur, demonstrating models of organic farming and taking actions to sensitise community about child marriage in Gopalnagar). At least five community collectives (model community-led collectives) will follow the trajectory of change from dormant to proactive (existing), from collecting anecdotes / one-time stories to evidence-based analysis, from sharing individual and personal experiences to negotiating solutions; and from having no discussions to having a collective stand on significant issues. By Year 2 and Year 3, ten more such model community collectives will be strengthened. (Total 15) (For example, four surveys covering 500+ respondents have been undertaken by adolescents across all hubs on menstruation-related issues such as taboos / menstrual hygiene; this will be analysed through different lenses and the groups will carry out stakeholder engagement on accessing menstrual hygiene and addressing root cause of taboos - analysis is ongoing) By Year 3, at least 180 community persons (including 30 fellows and at least ten members from each of the above mentioned 15 collectives) will emerge as informed change agents equipped to engage on different issues with different stakeholders - such as PRI members, VLCPC members, village elders, block officials. The themes the collectives work on will be visibilised through events, at different forums and platforms. (Specific focus on use of theatre, folk culture and songs, panchayat-level events and three block-level events will provide ample visibility and space)In newer areas, a similar process will be followed, with a maximum of two collectives per new village.  Outcomes of Objective 2Each collaborating organization has initiated attempts to inform and influence their other programmes and projects with learnings from the people-centred approach of the ACV project. For eg, Mukti's ACV team regularly informs and supports its other projects on approaches learnt through ACV. Rupantaran's team has proposed the use of similar approaches in other blocks of South 24 ParganasIn Phase 2, organisations must find ways of strengthening implementation of their safeguarding policies, which were evolved and Oak Application Form     10framed in Phase 1 with support from Oak.
