GAF_A_Praxis_UK_AmpliCommuVoiceInTheIndi.8. COOPERATION: 8. COOPERATION  How will you involve others in your approach to achieving change? If you are planning to engage in partnerships with other organisations, communities, people with lived experience, academics or secure the support of key individuals, please tell us about this.  Why are these the right partners to engage with?  Is there anything new about how you are choosing to work - for example, new partnerships or an approach that is different to how you usually work? (300 words):In Phase 1, the consortium publicised different aspects of its experiences in a range of forums, regional, national and international. Through Oaks grantee meetings too, the ACV experience has received wide attention and interest with organisations expressing interests in supporting the initiative.Despite this, the consortium in Phase 1 has been guarded about sharing its experiences widely. This is anticipated to change in terms of visibilising the consortiums work. The consortium shall proactively seek spaces where community leaders can present their experiences of being part of collectives. The planned block-level consultations is a step in this direction. The platforms for the same must be identified through a thorough mapping of risks and opportunities.As mentioned in Section 7.1.a and 7.2.b, the consortium members are also identified spaces where they can facilitate networking platforms, as in Gopalnagar Panchayat, through partnerships with organisations such as Terre des Homme and Welthungerhilfe.There is much scope for engagement with PRIs. In Phase 1, some partners actively engaged with PRIs resulting in actions that not only enhanced the confidence of the community, but also created communication channels. This will be taken further in Phase 2.Oak Application Form     14Engagement with media is another area of cooperation which will be targeted in Phase 2. In Phase 1 several articles about activities were published. In Phase 2, the consortium will try to facilitate articles that collective members can directly contribute to.
GAF_A_Praxis_UK_AmpliCommuVoiceInTheIndi.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING This section is twofold. Please tell us:a) Monitoring and evaluation. How will you know if you are achieving your objectives? Please describe briefly how you will know if you are making progress and if what you are doing is working. If you have a formal monitoring and evaluation system and if you plan to collect indicator data or conduct an external evaluation, please provide details here.b) Learning. Please tell us if there anything in particular that you are hoping to learn more about or test through this grant.(300 words):a. Through Phase 1, several successes were achieved.  1. Individual actions such as standing up to domestic violence; supporting neighbours / family members in cases of violence2. Formation of models of climate adaptive agriculture in Gopalnagar including crab culture, integrated farming; organic farming.3. Increase in self-confidence fo members, especially women members (women acknowledged that they were being valued as farmers in their own households and decisions around cultivation of the second crop was left to them); women organised a solidarity event in Gopalnagar in 2022 on their own, taking part in rallies, events; adolescents carried out a survey of 500+ respondents on menstruation-related taboos and practices 4. Activities related to embankment protection - In Hermabagopalpur collectives formed groups to monitor the embankments and saplings that had been planted5. In Digambarpur, adolescents negotiated with Panchayat to set up a library for them. Panchayat is carrying out this process     b. The consortium has already started the process of instituting an M&E framework within the consortium. Through the experience anchored by Niti Consulting, the consortium actively participated in developing a theory of change for the Sundarbans. Following this, the consortium engaged in a two-day workshop to evolve its own theory of change. This theory of change will be finalised in December 2023 and followed by entity-level theories of change that each collective can map itself against.Oak Application Form     15The broad trajectory of change as visualised by the workshop is described below, moving from D to A in each category:   1 2 3 4CategoryPROACTIVE GROUPOBSERVATION AND EVIDENCE SKILLSNegotiating ExperiencePerspectiveA Proactive Comparative analysis of evidenceSharing solutions in perspective of other solutionsHas a collective stand on significant issuesB Active Mapping and surveysSharing solutions in demonstrated wayDebates, and arguments, and building consensusC Responds, when soughtCertain case examplesSharing problemsDiscussions happenD Dormant Anecdotes Sharing own individual experienceNo discussions as suchIn Phase 1, consortium evolved indicators to map the success of the programme against. These will be reviewed and revised based upon the finalized theory of changeAn endline evaluation will be facilitated in July-August 2026)
GAF_A_Praxis_UK_AmpliCommuVoiceInTheIndi.10. RISKS AND CHALLENGES: 10.  RISKS AND CHALLENGESWhat are the risks or barriers that might prevent you from achieving your outcomes and how will you address these?  What are your opportunities?We understand that achieving long-lasting and meaningful change is hard and we expect that the work you want to do will mean taking risks.  We encourage you to be open to telling us these, as well as how you will address these risks.  If some of your outcomes are risky, are there any incremental achievements that you could identify? (300 words):Through Phase 1, the following risks have been identifiedUncontrollable factors such as the Covid-19 pandemicRepeated incidents of natural disasters (two cyclones in the three-year project cycle)Challenges imposed by adverse local governance systems and individuals within the panchayatOak Application Form     16Pushback by some elements within the community because of gains being made by communityThe first two are risks that the project experienced and found a way of converting into opportunities for building a rapport in the communities they worked in. This built a foundation for the ACV in several locations, visibilising the partners. This also exposed the project in its initial days to unreasonable expectations from the community. These were and will be addressed through a process of sensitisation.Through gradual processes of trainings, partner staff are being oriented on engaging with local administrations such as panchayat, police officers, service providers and others through negotiations and rapport building. As the PRI members in some locations are newly elected, partners can build new relationships through the community members rather than being at the forefront of networking. Also, outgoing PRI members whom the project has built a rapport with can be roped in as community advisors to support the work.

Summarise the projects ultimate goal(s) (maximum 200 words):( NOT REQUIRED FOR CORE SUPPORT GRANTS)Grant Application Form, July 1 20134To reduce poverty and bring about socio-economic empowerment of women in the informal economy and adolescent girls in Murshidabad and Malda districts in West Bengal and Ranchi and Hazaribagh districts in Jharkhand. The project aims to build on its past work to nurture, strengthen and consolidate the existing SEWA movement; to promote womens leadership at the grassroots, build local resource centres and respond to the sector-specific needs. The project goals align with SEWAs main goals of organizing women workers for full employment and self-reliance and it would allow us to address SDG goal 5 - gender equality and goal 8 - decent work and economic growth

GAF_SEWA_Bharat_AssisWomenWorkeInTheUnor.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 6. Context (The context section should not exceed two pages.)6a. Describe the organisation (include information on leadership, governance, structure and staff) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):SEWA was founded in 1972 by Smt. Ela Bhatt who was honoured with the prestigious National award of Padmashri and Padma Bhushan and gained international acclaim for her work and was awarded the Ramon Magsaysay award. With her guidance, SEWA has been instrumental in spreading across eleven states of India.SEWA Bharat, all India federation of SEWA is headed by Smt. Renana Jhabvala who worked in the initial years in Gujarat. She is the recipient of Padma Shri from Government of India.The Organisation has an executive board which comprises five distinguished women leaders nominated from the different member organizations of the Federation. These members are experienced social workers who have given shape to the organization. Their vast experience in the informal economy and with women workers has contributed to organizing women of the informal sector and expanding the SEWA movement. These leaders have been instrumental in many policy decisions affecting the poor women working in the informal economy, both in their states and at the national level.The SEWA Bharat National Coordinator is appointed by the Board to oversee all the activities within the organisation and coordinate with other SEWA institutions in a manner that the Federation office can pull in resources from other mature SEWAs in addition to the projects that SEWA Bharat implements directly. The National Coordinator is also a bridge between the two National Institutions -SEWA Bharat and SEWA Union to highlight advocacy issues from the ground to the Grant Application Form, July 1 20135National platform.SEWA Bharats broad organisational strategies are made through the Working Committee, which is elected from the Executive Board with the support of the National Coordinator. The National Coordinator is supported by a Central team of sector-specific professionals, Finance & Accounts, HR and Admin teams. Each state also has state coordinators and other programme coordinators and field staff. Where the work covers several districts, the state may have its local admin team. SEWA Bharat has a total staff strength of 300+ Employees and full-time consultants.A Central Team, consolidated  at SEWA Bharat in 2019, whose core mission to focus on organizational development and strategy, along with the respective state CORE teams to work with each other in an integrated approach and create a platform of learning and growth; this enables a streamlined approach to increase productivity and ensure a holistic and integrated approach  towards issues of women workers 6b. Describe the financial situation (include information on annual operating costs, fundraising strategy, reserves and debts) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):Financial Overview:SEWA Bharat has committed funding for the organisation for the next three years to the tune of INR 61 Crores. We have committed funding of INR 87lacs - for supporting the project activities in Jharkhand & West Bengal. A dedicated team of professionals under the guidance of the President and National Coordinator through networking, bids and any other source of the proposal, tries to raise funds for the normal and special requirements of the organisation. Many of the programs work closely with the Government where the gaps are filled in through Government support like training space, modules and workshops.SEWA Bharat tries to build up a Core and Reserve fund to mitigate against any future risks and it explained in details in the following section. One of the challenges that we may foresee is exchange rate fluctuations impacting the FCRA funding. The other challenge is the ongoing pandemic situation, where we have planned certain activities which may not happen in the expected scale if the pandemic and lockdown extends beyond an estimated guess. However, SEWA Bharat is trying to mitigate these by bringing Digital knowledge to as many of the grassroots leaders through the support of ongoing and potential funding and building the capacity of grassroots leaders and staff to hold meetings for training, sharing learning and other activities Funding Model:SEWA Bharat has secured funds from various donors like USAID, BMGF, EILEEN FISHER, etc to support our ongoing activities. We have also submitted proposals for fundraising which are currently in pipeline through IDS, Pacesetter, Fidelity, Upwork Foundation, PCI, etc. We are also applying different strategies for fundraising like focusing on individual donors, Exploring online platforms for Grant Application Form, July 1 20136fundraising, like Guidestar, Razorpay,  etc. We are also registered as Guide star; Milaap; Give India; Upwork; WEIGO; Benevity; Keeto, Equality Fund; USAID; JICA Charities Aid foundation. Crowdfunding- we are focusing on our PR and Communications, donations, etc. Reserves and Endowments:Since SEWA Bharat goal is to organize workers to achieve their goals of full employment and self-reliance through the strategy of struggle and development. The struggle is against the many constraints and limitations imposed on them by society and the economy. In order to maintain continuity and to keep our activities ongoing and address challenges from time to time especially at the grassroots level, we have created a CORE and reserve fund, where we receive funds through an overhead contribution from different projects implemented, interest income, membership fees, donations, etc. Since we are expanding at it is becoming difficult to maintain a sufficient level of funds in CORE, we keep on putting our efforts to raise funds from different sources. 6c. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):1. Establishing SEWA Shakti Kendras (SSKs) as local resource centres have been one of the most successful initiatives so far. Through the SSKs, SEWA acts as an important link with the government for successful outreach of its programs. These SSKs in Bengal have been instrumental in registering 2000 members and spreading awareness around the State Scheme for Unorganised Sector workers introduced in 2018, which led to 5000 more members registering themselves under this scheme.2. Created a network of grassroots leaders called agewans across India in specific geographies. They are the link between people and the government and make efforts to reach information to community members, address community needs as well as ensure linkages with compensatory packages, welfare schemes and developmental programs. They are at the frontline supplementing the government efforts during COVID-19. Agewans have spearheaded the SEWA-led distribution of 50,000+ food and hygiene kits and last-mile delivery in places where the reach of the PDS system has been erratic. The work of Agewans has been recognised and SEWA Bharat has been specially mentioned for its support during COVID-19 by the NITI Aayog.3. Most significant in recent times is SEWA Bharats participation at the UN High-Level Panel [UNHLP] on Womens Economic Empowerment [WEE] and subsequent conversations in India to contextualise the UNHLP recommendations for India. During this period, SEWA Bharat hosted a discussion with Phumzile Mlambo-ngcuka, Executive Director of UN Women at its headquarters in Delhi and is right now contributing towards the development of a national roadmap on WEE in India. Grant Application Form, July 1 201376d. Describe the current strategy of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):A detailed note on the strategic plan for the states of West Bengal and Jharkhand addressing key questions is also attached (Annexure 1)6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):As of 2018, both the states feature very low on the Human Development Index [HDI] (0.641 and 0.599[1]), and their HDI score is below the national average (0.647). With 19.98% and 36.96%[2] of the population of West Bengal and Jharkhand living in poverty and 71.16% and 56.21%[3] female literacy rates, the problems of poverty, the gender divide in educational attainment, income and access to resources is widespread. Women are often the primary breadwinners and caregivers of a household in these states as men tend to migrate out for better work opportunities, yet, women remain at the fringes of work and income, eking out a livelihood under extremely exploitative conditions. This gets reflected in the falling Female Labor Force Participation Rate [FLPR] in both states. The female labour force participation in West Bengal has increased from 18.08 in 2011 to 23.3 in 2018, the same has reduced from 29.10 in 2011 to 18.08 in 2018 in Jharkhand[4]. If we see in terms of trades, research shows that most agricultural workers are women in these states, but their landholding is minimal and productivity has been constantly decreasing due to climate change, migration of males and limited access to government benefits. Beedi workers are struggling to continue with their livelihood and domestic workers are denied leaves and fair wages. SEWA has done an exploratory study in Jharkhand, (SEWA Exploratory Study Jharkhand, 2016) which shows that 63% of women have no awareness of the welfare boards and very few workers have identity cards. We have seen that women take up seasonal work and remain unemployed for a large part of the year. They rely on contractors and middlemen to broker their salary and conditions and often entangle themselves in large amounts of debt. Not being able to go up the supply chain, upskill themselves or gain income mobility are predominant issues as well. Their working conditions are equally precarious owing to their lack of bargaining power. Early pregnancy[5] is reportedly common, women and girls face restrictions on their mobility and traditional caregiving roles are encouraged for women while taking up non-traditional work is frowned upon.In the past 3 years in Jharkhand and 16 years in West Bengal, SEWA has unionised and collectivised more than 20,000 women in the informal economy. SEWA has worked towards increasing collective bargaining strength, empowering communities to access information and entitlements through SSKs, enhancing skill and creating opportunities for access to markets. The effort is being led by a cadre of 129 agewans (grassroots leaders). Following are the preliminary findings from the end-project impact assessment (phone-based) study conducted in both states in July-August 2020.[6]A majority of the respondents, that is 65.60%, women attend unit meetings organised by SEWA at least once a month. While the remaining members attend meetings once in two or three months.Grant Application Form, July 1 2013850% of all members have received at least one type of training offered by SEWA in the last 2 years.Among all trades/work, a majority of domestic workers (57%) and beedi workers (51%) are aware of at least one form of entitlement/govt. or employer benefit that they are eligible for (minimum wages[44%], weekly offs [31%], provident fund [24%], Occupational Health Safety compensation [29%], Tool and Safety Kit Support Scheme (25%), Use of traditional seeds (13.6%) and Organic fertilizers(10.6%)66.3% SEWA members have indicated that they received information about trade-specific entitlements and benefits from SEWA compared to other sources of information.22% of SEWA members have ever used the SEWA Shakti Kendras premises  to apply for a scheme or to apply for a government identification or avail a government benefitGoing forward, we would strengthen the existing cadre of agewans so they can lead community efforts and SSKs and create new agewans and SSKs. We would also address womens trade-specific needs, explore alternate livelihoods so women can diversify or pivot their income sources and simultaneously, look to build our grassroots advocacy. The next generation of young leaders will also be created to ensure continuity of the movement and relationships with the local administration and government officials will be nurtured to ensure strong private-public partnership. The above feeds into SEWA Bharats commitment to ensuring full employment and self-reliance for women in the informal economy. SEWA Bharat has been building the capacity of its member organisations and advancing the rights of women workers through its twin goals of organising and struggle. We have different streams of work focused on unionising women; advancing gender equality and rights; trying out innovative and different models of organising women such as union, federation, cooperatives, collective social enterprises, producer companies; and fostering womens economic empowerment by increasing womens access to market and finance.Though the registration process for a state union has been facing bureaucratic barriers in Bengal, SEWA members continue their alliance with the National Union and would continue holding trade group meetings as is done within a formal union structure in the state. [1] Sub National HDI Global Database https://globaldatalab.org/shdi/shdi/IND/[2] Handbook of Statistics on Indian States by the Reserve Bank of India https://m.rbi.org.in/Scripts/AnnualPublications.aspx?head=Handbook%20of%20Statistics%20on%20Indian%20States[3] Census of India, 2011[4] Annual Report - Periodic Labour Force Survey 2018-2019 by Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation http://mospi.gov.in/sites/default/files/publication_reports/Annual_Report_PLFS_2018_19_HL.pdf[5] In the Fourth National Family Health Survey Percentage of women aged 15-19 years who were pregnant or already mothers during the survey in West Bengal is 18.3%  and in Jharkhand is 12%. http://rchiips.org/NFHS/factsheet_NFHS-4.shtml[6] The final report is being compiled for circulation.Grant Application Form, July 1 20139
GAF_SEWA_Bharat_AssisWomenWorkeInTheUnor.7. OBJECTIVES: 7. Objectives (maximum 2,200 words)For a core support grant, state the purpose of this grant request and complete the objectives.  After consultations with an Oak PO, you may decide to summarise your mission as one broad objective. In this case, it is still necessary to specify activities and results/outcomes for this objective.For project support grants please list your objectives for this project in bullet point format. (You may use additional space if you have more than three objectives)?. Under each objective describe the activities that your organisation will undertake to achieve it, including time frame and the results or outcomes you expect to achieve.7.1.a. Objective 1 (maximum one sentence):To strengthen the collective bargaining capacity of new and existing grassroots leaders and young girls by building capacity and nurturing grassroots leadership 7.1.c. Objective 1 Activities and timeframe (maximum 300 words):1.Strengthening the capacity of the cadre of Agewans: Currently, we have developed 129 agewans [69 agewans in Jharkhand and 60 agewans in West Bengal]. SEWA is now looking to intensify its agewan strengthening program with a total of 205 agewans. We will use SEWAs agewan development module to give training to new agewans and refresher training to the existing cadre. In addition, the agewans are also trained in negotiation skills with their employers, Mahajan, local authorities and family members. We will be adding new topics such as addressing violence in the world of work, basics of data collection, evidence-based advocacy and digital literacy. Exclusive training will be held on digital literacy with online training during the COVID restriction phase.2.Community Meetings led by agewans: Agewans will lead the village-based unit meetings with the women over the next 3 years. They will also 7.1.b. Objective 1 Expected results/outcomes and timeframe (maximum 300 words):A cadre of 205 grassroots leaders/agewans will be built in the next 3 years with leadership, negotiation and decision-making skills to lead the community advocacy efforts14 Yuva Mandals of 15 girls each will be created to foster youth leaders and champions at the grassroots level in the next 3 yearsA total of 41,000 members will be strengthened across the two states over the next 3 yearsGrant Application Form, July 1 201310contribute to and participate in village council meetings. SEWA will handhold agewans during the 3 years and track progress post-training.3.Developing youth leaders and champions and strengthening the existing champions: SEWA has created 10 Yuva Mandals reaching out to 140 girls in West Bengal in the past 3 years. SEWA will make efforts to sustain the existing 10 Yuva Mandals in West Bengal and the 4  new Yuva Mandals in Jharkhand while seeking to initiate a few new Yuva Mandals in Jharkhand. These youth groups will be trained in two thematic streams: basic aspects of gender equality being one which will include good touch and bad touch, life skills, sexual and reproductive health, problems related to early marriage; social issues and technical skills including digital literacy, research methods and data collection techniques. Emphasis will be laid on the importance of safe migration and self-defence to prepare girls for their life going forward. We will work with Integrated Child Development Services [ICDS] to link with government schemes, with counselling and health services meant for adolescent girls. These youth leaders and champions will play a key role in taking this movement forward.4.Organizing exposure visits: SEWAs training model integrates classroom training with practical training that includes regular interaction with stakeholders and exposure visits. To this end, exposure visits are aimed to engender cross-learning and information sharing, building a broader and pragmatic understanding of ground-level situations and understanding the different models/pathways of work in other states and organisations along with developing empathy and compassion among the grassroots leaders, youth groups and SEWA team members. In the past, SEWA has conducted exposure visits to different other SEWA states, for example, women of West Bengal visited Jharkhand earlier to meet SEWA Jharkhand members. This helped them to see the replicability of learnings and adapt the learning from the other states. In a similar manner, exposure visits will be organized to other SEWA states to facilitate an understanding of the nuances around SEWAs unionisation and movement building work over the years.5.Capacity building sessions of state teams to SEWA ethos and objectives of the program: SEWA Bharat has worked with a dynamic project team in the past years and will continue to build their capacities so they can effectively implement this project as well. To this end, SEWA will carry out refresher training for team members on SEWA ethos, on SEWA union and its years of struggle and movement building work. Additionally, team members will receive training in gender equality and decent work for women, how to take collective action, and how to challenge patriarchy. SEWA will develop the teams understanding of the objectives of this program. Though the project has been developed in consultation with grassroots teams, orientation and onboarding exercise will revitalise the team spirit, triggering cross-learning and information exchange.6.Organising campaigns for community awareness generation: In the past years, campaigns have played a crucial role in inspiring attitudinal change in West Bengal and Jharkhand. Therefore, SEWA will organise campaigns on a rolling basis to circulate key messages on welfare schemes, life skills, health and on prevention of violence against women in the world of work. Information on new opportunities will be circulated. Examples of role models will be shared through these campaigns and linkages will be ensured.Grant Application Form, July 1 2013117.2.a. Objective 2 (maximum one sentence):To empower communities through access to information and entitlements with the help of the SEWA Shakti Kendras [SEWA empowerment centres] in Jharkhand and West Bengal7.2.c. Objective 2 Activities and timeframe (maximum 300 words):1.Strengthening the existing SEWA Shakti Kendras [SSK] and creating new SSKs: SEWA has set up 6 SEWA Shakti Kendras (SSKs) as local resource centres in West Bengal and Jharkhand. The SSK is a place where people meet and share their common concerns and have dialogues to address larger issues faced by them, at the same time obtain up-to-date information on all programmes and schemes. It connects community members with government schemes and services. Our efforts are to make it a community-owned, community-managed centre under the leadership of women and young people. Based on the needs assessment done this year, SEWA will aim to set up 8 new SSKs and strengthen the 6 existing SSKs with infrastructure and digital tools across the two states in the course of 3 years. (Refer to Annexure 2 for the model)2.Training cum orientation of SSK centre-in-charges: A total of 14 SSK in-charges will be trained in two-phased training with a focus on digital literacy and use of digital devices and software. Government linkages and trade memberships, linking with social security, how to operate an online application platform, and a broader understanding of advocacy and government interactions etc. will be a part of the training.3.Procurement of new software and hand holding on how to use the software: A software will be procured and will be tailored to the needs of the SSKs. This will be installed in the desktops/laptops and tablets at the SSKs. The software will help generate dashboard, maintain database and record of members among other things.4.Delivery of services by the SSK: SSKs will carry out linkages with government schemes and services. A digital database on relevant schemes will be provided to the SSKs by the national SEWA Bharat team to help SSKs carry out the linkages. The SSK will also respond to the health 7.2.b. Objective 2 Expected results/outcomes and timeframe (maximum 300 words):Over the next 3 years, 100% linkages with state-specific schemes such as Samajik Suraksha Yojna;all-India schemes such as MGNREGA, ration card, JSY and health schemes will be ensuredIn the next 3 years, registration of workers under the sector-specific schemes and boards will be ensuredSSKs will reach out to over 50,000 community members for social security outreach.Grant Application Form, July 1 201312concerns affecting women and girls. It will also address issues of violence in the world of work. SSK will act as the site for training and learning at the unit level.5.Providing handholding support and overall tracking: SEWA Bharat will provide handholding support to all stakeholders and will track their work throughout the course of three years. MIS systems will help record and track information on members and help generate reports. All data will be entered into the digital MIS systems. SEWA will continue with its holistic approach of hand-holding beyond the training period through post-training agewan engagement activities and meetings and will prepare the agewans for community engagement, government liaisoning and grassroots advocacy.7.3.a. Objective 3 (maximum one sentence):To collectivise women workers [beedi workers, domestic workers, construction workers, street vendors, agri-workers] to enable them to better engage with stakeholders in the value chain for full employment and have better access to markets and resources7.3.c. Objective 3 Activities and timeframe (maximum 300 words):1.Strengthening the trade groups: In the past years, SEWA has organised and unionised women into separate trade groups at the community level. So far, West Bengal has 1 domestic worker group and 3 beedi workers groups while Jharkhand has 1 construction worker group, 15 domestic workers groups, 9 construction worker groups, 22 agricultural worker groups. These have been formed for women to share and discuss their concerns within these groups. In the next few years, SEWA will strengthen these groups further with the leadership of the agewans. Strengthening a group will require training and handholding agewans and linkage building. The trade groups will address the sector-specific needs.2.Strengthening trade committees: SEWA has set up trade committees 7.3.b. Objective 3 Expected results/outcomes and timeframe (maximum 300 words):30% of the women domestic workers trained will have increased wages and weekly offs10,000 beedi workers will have access to PF benefit30% trained in tailoring and stitching will have increased income10% agri-workers will have increased productivity200 women/girls will be linked with alternate livelihoodGrant Application Form, July 1 201313(representation from all sectors, unlike Trade group which is sector-specific) in the two states. In West Bengal, trade committees will decide the work and strategy for the whole year for the different trade groups and will carry out the advocacy agenda on specific issues along with sector-specific workers and local and state-level authorities. They will feed into the advocacy of SEWA national council meetings and unions. The trade committees will look to increase the membership base within the trade groups to bring more workers under this solidarity building movement. Trade committee meetings will take place once a year.3.Promoting evidence-based advocacy through multi-stakeholder platforms and meetings: Past learnings have shown that multi-stakeholder meetings are a great way to advocate and increase the visibility of SEWAs work. SEWA will create a platform for members so they can articulate their needs in front of the inter-sectoral agencies, including government officials, private sector players and other CSOs etc. Block, district level and state level meetings in both states will be conducted in year 2 and 3. The main purpose of these meetings will be to highlight challenges in front of government officials and figure out synergies to enable the creation of shared agendas that can help take common initiatives forward in a collaborative partnership with multiple agencies. The evidence generated at the unit meetings, trade group meetings and the MIS will feed into the advocacy event. The key emerging advocacy issues have been around wages, working conditions, provident fund, workers recognition, income and market access so far. Alongside this, separate trade-specific campaigns will help highlight and collectively bargain for the needs.4.Exploring and linking with alternate livelihoods: Due to COVID, SEWAs stream of workaround exploring and linking with alternate livelihoods has become strong. To that end, an orientation program on alternative livelihoods will be organised in partnership with National Rural Livelihoods Mission [NRLM] district representatives at the block level in both the states. Simultaneously, the sectors of agriculture and animal husbandry will be explored in Jharkhand with local authorities and NGOs. In West Bengal, through the existing 2 centres, we will continue to offer a 6-monthly training on sewing-tailoring for young girls. SEWA in Malda will tie-up with the government training programs for preliminary and advanced training in sewing and tailoring. We will also explore other hyper-local needs so the children of beedi workers can take up other trades as beedi work has emerged to be unsustainable due to anti-beedi campaigns.

EvaluationHow will progress be monitored and evaluated? (maximum 300 words):Monitoring: SEWAs existing monitoring system would be used, for example, the Monthly progress report [MPR] formats. There is an ongoing effort to digitise the inputs feeding to the MPR formats, particularly those related to SSKs. Reporting of the SSKs will be digitised through this process. National coordinator and the senior leadership will provide the overall leadership and strategic inputs, Program Coordinator will carry out the day-to-day coordination, oversee the MEL and overall project management, and state coordinators will assist the Program Coordinator.Evaluation will be outsourced to an external evaluation agency. The method of evaluation will be decided with the external agency and will depend on the most robust methodology that will be available and which will fit into the time frame of the program. Given the COVID realities, the method of evaluation will be explored. Usually, mid-term and end-line evaluations including iterative assessments, process tracing, case studies and interviews etc are ways in which programs are evaluated. We will measure the ability of youth groups to undertake collective action, measure the ability of self-reliant agewans to lead the community efforts, and the effectiveness of state committees to undertake state-specific advocacy.Learning: SEWAs Learning Hub, a vertical for research and advocacy will carry out in-depth research and analysis on various aspects of our programs over the next 3 years. Learning outcomes will be documented at every stage of the program. These learning outcomes will draw on both quantitative and qualitative analysis, building on SEWAs long history of research, and will culminate in case studies, blog posts, policy briefs and other learning material which will be disseminated widely through the SEWA Bharat website, social media platforms, newsletters as well as newspaper articles, research forums, journals, amongst others.A MEL plan will be created in the project inception phase, elaborating all the processes.Grant Application Form, July 1 201316

Highlight any significant recent or expected future changes. If you have an explicit approach to increasing diversity and/or advancing race equity within the organisation, please tell us. (300 words):Established in 1962, Welthungerhilfe (WHH) is one of Germanys largest private aid agencies. Welthungerhilfe is non-denominational and politically independent and works together with local partner organisations  to fight against hunger using a holistic, quality and impact-oriented concept ranging from immediate disaster relief and reconstruction to long-term development projects. WHH has the structure of an association with the federal President as the patron. WHH works under an honorary Supervisory Board headed by Marlehn Thieme, President and an Executive Board chaired by Secretary General Mathias Mogge. WHH has 2,404 staff worldwide. This number includes about 2,000 national colleagues, 191 colleagues abroad and 213 colleagues in Germany.In India, WHH is working as a liaison office and has around 22 colleagues who are managing around 40 local partners on development project focusing on rural skill building, agroecology, nutrition, governance, WASH and civil society empowerment.Oak Application Form     6 5b. Summarise the organisations history.  In addition, highlight 2-3 key achievements.Please keep this brief and list up to 3 key achievements as bullet points. Even though you may have many achievements, please share what is most relevant to the proposed grant. (300 words)Welthungerhilfe started as the German section of the Freedom from Hunger Campaign  one of the first global campaigns to fight hunger. In 1962 Welthungerhilfe was established under the umbrella of the FAO (UN Food and Agriculture Organisation). Since its inception, the organisation has organized funding of EUR 3.71 billion for more than 9,331 overseas projects in 70 countries.During last 10 years Welthungerhilfe has developed framework, module and examples of rural skill building across 5 states through 13 skill building institution named Green College. Through these colleges 50000 trainees were trained on green skills. The proposed project will use experience of this Green College initiative (https://welthungerhilfeindia.org/initiative/green-colleges-initiative/).5c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and decide your approach? If you have undertaken a theory of change exercise, or if you are influenced by research, policy or your own organisations experience, please tell us about this.  Have you consulted with relevant stakeholders, including your communities and others experiencing the problem? Is there an intention to address equity, diversity and inclusion? (600 words):Sundarbans is a part of the tidally active delta where the land building process is still incomplete with Ganges-Brahmaputra River system carries suspended sediment load through numerous interlacing channels, intervening islands with the elevation of less than 3 meters above msl. Agriculture forms the backbone of the economy of Sundarban, where the entire area is dependent on a single crop, the rain-fed (mostly high yielding varieties) paddy. Sundarbans, is threatened by various biophysical and social barriers, emerges as a unique case where the most vulnerable population lives in an extremely vulnerable situation with high risk of hazards which is characterized by a low level of development and lack of infrastructure, prevalence of extreme poverty and lack of health facilities. It is also under the threat of severe coastal erosion due to relative sea level rise, increase in surface air temperatures and increased intensity of cyclone. All these results into the following negative impacting factor for livelihood systems of Sundarbans - a) increased anthropogenic pressure for livelihood on natural resources b) increased seasonal and permanent outmigration c) lack of stability in livelihood operations d) landlessness and poor resource profile triggered by land loss/degradation and debt trap.Oak Application Form     7There is a pressing need of a strategy to create examples of sustainable livelihood options which can transform the local economy. Such transformational strategy needs to be built on:Value chain-based approach where various business opportunities (including products and services) can be created along the value chain with backward and forward linkages.  This aims to boost up the entire economy around a product line.Cluster based approach where value chain actors come together in homogeneous or heterogeneous groups depending on the product and associated services. This will create scope of inclusion of members who do not possess resources/means of primary production.Inclusion of vulnerable communities like traffic survivors, landless, forest dependents etc. with special focus on youth and women. Gradual shifting from livelihood approach to microenterprises.  Organizing farmers into Farmer Producer Companies for achieve economies of scale and long-term sustainability.Networking with knowledge and financial institute/agencies to leverage funding/technical support. Already established Green College can be a strategic institute to support training and capacity building.Developing a team with local CSO partners who can own and continue the initiative.The approach is developed on the basis of a) Welthungehilfes experience of last two decades in the region where we have been active with the transformative approaches of multisectoral approach to nutrition, rural skill building through green colleges, microplanning involving local community to support government planning program of GPDP and ecological agriculture b) Scoping study commissioned by Oak Foundation c) FGD with CSOs of Sundarbans.

Examples might include: (1) Research; (2) Provision of legal advice to...; (3) Training on movement building for...Associated with Objective 1A1.1Conduct participatory trade identification exercise to identify and prioritize locally available resources and potential market opportunities and assess the feasibility of value chain development for each identified opportunity.This will be conducted by a team of enterprise facilitator from the CSO network on the basis of Trade Identification Tool already developed by Welthungerhilfe. A ToT before the identification and a consolidation workshop to analyze the result of the identification exercise are planned to take decision of trades.A1.2Develop comprehensive and tailored training curriculum for community members, which covers technical skills, business development, and marketing skills needed to strengthen the identified value chains.This will be supported by the existing curriculum framework of Welthungerhilfe but will be adopted through writeshops with local trainers/entrepreneurs. Writeshops are manual development workshops where content writer, content expert, artist and designers work together. 5 trades will be picked up from the Trade Identification exercise (A1.1). While developing/adopting the content, climate friendly, green, fair and ethical trades/technologies will be given preference.A1.3Conduct training courses and mentor high-potential trainees on each value chain, to build their skills and confidence in managing their own businesses as well as create job opportunities.The enterprise facilitator team will identify potential trainees from their respective location in a geographical cluster on the basis of set criteria and send them to Green College. Depending on the content, the trainees will go through training of short term (7 Days), Mid Term (15~30 Days) or Long Term (60 Days) courses. The days will be divided equally into residential sessions and self-practice sessions. The training method will be a mix of theoretical (10~20%), practical (50~60%) Business development skill building (15%) and soft skill building (15%). After the training, the enterprise facilitator will follow up and mentor the trainee for a duration of 3~6 months, depending on the need of the trainees. 1000 trainees will be trained in batches of 20~25.120 High Potential Rural Youth (HPRY) trainees selected from these 1000, will be taken through Fast Track programme of accelerated learning with ideation Oak Application Form     10phase, innovation camp, communication workshop and network meet. These trainees are expected to not only set up their micro enterprises, but also create job opportunities for others in their respective enterprise. External resource group will be involved to facilitate the process.A1.4Evaluate with relevant stakeholders the identified value chains to identify areas of improvement, such as inadequate infrastructure, and develop appropriate solutions to address them.Value chain analysis with the help of expert and local communities on 2~3 most promising trades and develop improvement plan. These trades will be taken up from the course and will include the microenterprise by HPRY (A1.3). A critical input support to kick-start the business might be offered from the project.A1.5Establish Common Facility Centres (CFCs) to provide shared infrastructure and resources to community members involved in the identified value chains, including access to processing, storage, and market linkages.Around the selected value chain (A1.4) common facility centres with equipment for value addition and quality improvement will be supported for common use for multiple trainees in a cluster. For instance, fish value chain needs fish feed making machineries, aerator, equipment for water quality testing etc. A Resource User Group will maintain this equipment, which will gradually be merged/handed over to the Farmer Producer Organisation (A2.1)  Associated with Objective 2A2.1Form and register 2 FPOs with at least 100 members associated with each.FPOs are institutes owned and run by the farmers which creates scope of collectivization of produce, single input production/procurement & knowledge transfer, better bargain power of the producer. 2 FPOs will be formed and registered from the geographical cluster where the project has larger number of successful trainees around common trades. FPOs around one primary and some other crops/produce, will be formed in the 3rd year of the project, and will need support for another cycle to become a sustainable institute.A2.2Conduct training sessions for the FPO board members on governance, financial management, and leadership skills.The FPO board member will go through workshop with classroom sessions, hands on practice which help the participants to gain a) understanding of FPO and role of BoD in FPO operations b)build confidence of BoDs & staff and motivate them towards good governance of FPO c) build the capacities of BoDs to take appropriate decisions and steer the FPO towards its business and institutional goals d) understanding of statutory regulation and day-to-day operation of financial management of FPO e) prepare action plan. This will be done through external expert agency, who will also mentor the FPOs for the initial few months.A2.3Facilitate the formation of a cluster of 800 trainees across various trades to achieve economies of scale, access networking opportunities and support each other.Rest of the 800 trainees, will be monitored regularly and will be assisted for financial linkages, business development and clustered together as per Oak Application Form     11commonalities in geography and trade. Some critical support can be provided from Common Facility Center (A1.5). It is expected that there will be some drop out (around 10-12% as per Welthungerhilfes previous experience) in terms of trainees not continuing any business.   A2.4Facilitate the establishment of market linkages in the local, peri-urban, and urban (Kolkata) markets, including conducting market research, connecting with potential buyers and distributors, and negotiating favorable terms for the FPOs.Apart from linkage creation, rapport building and mapping the market linkage possibilities by the Microenterprise Facilitators, selected trainees will be encouraged to participate in exhibitions, fair and niche market in the local area, near by town and Kolkata.Associated with Objective 3A3.1 Identify and establish a competent and experienced grassroot team of microenterprise facilitators, and providing them with relevant training and resources to effectively support microenterprises in the targeted communities.10 volunteers will be identified from/by the CSO partners, who will go through series of 2 capacity building sessions on basics of livelihood framework, enterprise development, trade identification (A1.1) and MEAL framework of the project. They are grassroot workers who will keep regular contact with the trainees and mentor them. They will be guided by Welthungerhilfe and other project team members. 6 monthly review meeting will also create scope of mutual learning for them.A3.2 Liaison with existing Green College and upgrade its training facilities to include equipment and demonstrations, and other relevant tools and resources depending on the identified trade.Welthungerhilfe, with its partner developed a Green College in Gosaba to offer skill development program for youth of the Sundarbans. Green College is a sustainable institute with already existing accommodation facilities, training hall, class rooms, kitchen, dining, laboratory and demonstration unit. The identified trainees will be sent to Green College for training  (A1.3) with a fee, rest of the support cost will be subsidized from the project. Depending on the facilities in other locations of CSOs to be involved in the project, Green College can also initiate part of the courses in other location as a branch of Green College.   A3.3 Explore potential partnerships for leveraging resources with knowledge and finance institutes to enhance the effectiveness and sustainability of the microenterprise development program.Trade Identification exercise (A1.1) will conduct trade wise stakeholder mapping to give a complete trade wise picture of the potential stakeholders. The project team will link the microenterprises with the stakeholders through regular a) financer meetings, where entrepreneurs will present their business proposals in open market format to access potential donor/bankers b) regular meetings with line departments on tracking schemes etc. for the benefit of the trainees c) explore internship opportunities with the existing businesses in the local/nodal market for the trainees d) creating long term Oak Application Form     12market linkage through establishment of MoU between the market players and entrepreneurs.
GAF_A_Deutsche_Welthungerhilfe_e_V_Suppo.8. COOPERATION: 8. COOPERATION  How will you involve others in your approach to achieving change? If you are planning to engage in partnerships with other organisations, communities, people with lived experience, academics or secure the support of key individuals, please tell us about this.  Why are these the right partners to engage with?  Is there anything new about how you are choosing to work - for example, new partnerships or an approach that is different to how you usually work? (300 words):Welthungerhilfe is proposing partnership with the following institutesA. Ramakrishna Mission Lok Shiksha Parishad (RKMLSP): RKMLSP manages Green college in Sundarban which is an existing infrastructure. They have already been supported by Welthungerhilfe on identifying/capacitating trainers, curriculum and demonstration site. The team at RKMLSP/Green College understands the concept of enterprise development quite well as they have been trained on the concept. It will be of lesser investment from the project in terms of fund, knowledge and time by getting into partnership with RKMLSP/Green College.   B. CSO partners: To extend the outreach in terms of geography and project participants/beneficiaries  we will take support from local grassroot CSOs to 1) select beneficiaries from their existing and/or outside from that 2) identify enterprise facilitator and other staff for the project from the locality who will monitor, follow up and mentor the beneficiaries to walk the path of entrepreneurship 3) take part in the project management unit (PMU) to track/guide progress of the project through six monthly review meeting 4) provide space to facilitate the project in the locality, if required.   C. Resource Institute: Apart from partners, the project will involve expert agencies time to time.The role and responsibilitiesWelthungerhilfe: Need identification and capacity building of the team, Organize internal and external training of trade identification/curriculum development/trainers capacity building/FPO Management, Developing SOP for enterprise development processes, Develop and follow MEAL processes, Review and monitoring the project team, Setting up and monitoring mentoring framework of the trainees, Liaison with external institute for collaboration and scaling up, Reporting to Oak Foundation.RKMLSP/Project Team with CSOs: Trade identification exercise in the community, Providing training infrastructure, Conducting enterprise development training and mentoring, Monitoring and follow up of the trainees development, Organise business meet and create market linkage for the trainees and FPOs, Forming and guiding FPOs, Reporting to WHH.  Oak Application Form     13
GAF_A_Deutsche_Welthungerhilfe_e_V_Suppo.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING This section is twofold. Please tell us:a) Monitoring and evaluation. How will you know if you are achieving your objectives? Please describe briefly how you will know if you are making progress and if what you are doing is working. If you have a formal monitoring and evaluation system and if you plan to collect indicator data or conduct an external evaluation, please provide details here.b) Learning. Please tell us if there anything in particular that you are hoping to learn more about or test through this grant.(300 words):Continuous monitoring will be based on regular field visits, monthly field reports, documentation of official records and arrangements, monthly review sessions and interaction with various stakeholders.Project coordinator from the partners will monitor progress at project level and prepare a quarterly report to WHH. Financial officers will prepare financial reports after each quarter and assist audit teams in their annual audits.Detailed monitoring plans at operational level, specifying how, when and by whom each indicator of the Project Planning Matrix will be measured, will be developed at the beginning of the program. This information together with the (annual) work plans will be the primary monitoring tool of the project.Six monthly review meeting with all the staffs is also an important process of monitoring and learning.Case studies, sharing and exchange workshop, business meets are part of cross learning.A simple data tracking process of each entrepreneurs will be developed.The strong financial team of WHH will work closely with the implementing partners on orientation, capacity building, follow-up and financial supervision. The partners submit quarterly financial reports to Welthungerhilfe.Annual and final external audits will be carried out for the program.Welthungerhilfes program manager for economic development, MEAL coordinator and country director will provide time as contribution from Welthungerhilfe to monitor, guide and evaluate the program.An endline external evaluation is planned to guide the next steps for the project.Oak Application Form     14

RISKS AND CHALLENGESWhat are the risks or barriers that might prevent you from achieving your outcomes and how will you address these?  What are your opportunities?We understand that achieving long-lasting and meaningful change is hard and we expect that the work you want to do will mean taking risks.  We encourage you to be open to telling us these, as well as how you will address these risks.  If some of your outcomes are risky, are there any incremental achievements that you could identify? (300 words):2024 being the central election year, there might be political disturbances.The political/administrative environment of the state might become vulnerable that the expected support may no longer comes forth.Lobbying from large agrochemical groups could counter the efforts of stakeholders to promote agroecological approaches.Unfavorable climatic conditions, such as floods, can lead to low production and difficulties in applying agroecological approaches.Contract farming for larger food companies can put farmers in a weak bargaining position.Working with people who are not primary producer might be in a scattered geography, so might be difficult to cluster them.

Describe the organisation (include information on leadership, governance, structure and staff) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):Governance of Sanhita is built on the vision of womens leadership. Sanhitas Board of Trustees is drawn from women with years of experience in womens development from India and international development organisations.  The Board of Trustees is responsible for overall growth of the organisation, strategic direction and setting its vision in addition to financial and/ or legal compliance. Profile of Trustees:Ms Rajashi MukherjeeRajashi Mukherjee is a senior PMEL specialist with over 30 years of experience in the development sector. She is specialised in social research and social evaluations. Rajashi has extensive experience in setting up data collection and monitoring systems and has worked with country governments and multilateral organisations like UNICEF, DFID, World Bank, ADB etc. She was the Country Grant Application Form, July 1 20135Director of Water for People between 2005 and 2010. The focus of her work has been wide-ranging including, WASH service and governance, institutional capacity building, gender audits, income generation and agri-income estimation, education and school programmes, civil society and advocacy, child health issues and more. Rajashi has work experience in countries like India, Bangladesh, Nepal, Canada, USA, Central America, Fiji, Kenya and Uganda. Ms Sreela Das GuptaWith an MPhil in Population Studies, Sreela Das Gupta has worked for over two decades in the development sector, focusing on issues related to gender, social inclusion and public health. Sreela has worked both with rural poor communities as well as with international agencies including CARE, International Centre for Research on Women (ICRW) and UNWOMEN. She experiences in research, program implementation and policy formulation. Sreela Das Gupta was a Hubert H. Humphrey Fellow in 2000-01 -- mid career fellowship funded by the US Congress. Presently Sreela Das Gupta is Associate Vice President and Head of Diversity and Inclusion at TATA Consultancy Services, Business Process Services. Ms Soma Sen GuptaSoma Sen Gupta is an Ashoka Fellow with over 30 years of experience in the development sector, especially in the areas of Gender Mainstreaming, Gender Audit, Mapping Studies, Publishing, Training, Institutional Capacity Building etc. related to issues such as governance, gender concerns, violence, sexuality, sexual & reproductive health of the adolescents & the youth, urban poverty, etc. She has experiences in direct implementation of development projects in both rural & urban areas of West Bengal, Bihar and Jharkhand. Experience includes working at policy, statutory & grant making levels both in the eastern region and nationally. Advisors of SanhitaSanhita has been guided in the course of its work by a diverse array of advisors: development and other service professionals, experts on women empowerment and public intellectuals. The organisation will bring together a formal group of advisors drawing from diverse professional and strategic backgrounds such as media professionals, labour experts, research, legal practitioners, and finance consultants. Sanhitas Present Structure: As a Gender Resource Centre, Sanhita is managed by a lean core team which draws its human resources expertise from a pool of experienced retainers as and when required.This core team comprises of 6 people - Managing Trustee, Two Senior Associate  Knowledge Creation & Training, Researchers, Trainer and Accounts Compliance Officer. The core team develop strategies & partnership and deliver projects as per their area of expertise. The board members of Sanhita provide guidance in developing the long-term vision, strategic direction and compliance of the organisation.  Sanhita also hires consultants for specific work on short term basis for expertise and advice, production of IEC materials etc. Interns will be hired periodically on a short-term basis for specific back-end support in research & training.Grant Application Form, July 1 201366b. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):Acquired credibility as an organisation that specialises in training to ensure empowerment and safety of women at all levels over 20 years Contributed in Information Service through development of Resource Directories for Women in Crisis Situation, supported and replicated by UN Women in 11 other states of IndiaResearch and Training on Sexual Harassment at Workplace of Transpersons and Lesbian WomenThe Politics of Silence, one of the earliest researches in India by Sanhita in 2001, broke silence around the issue of denial and brought voices of aggrieved women to the centre stageAward: Sanhita received Rushi B. Gimi Award in 2004 instituted by Governor of West Bengal for contribution to womens empowerment and social work.The following have been achieved through the past 6 years of partnership with Oak Foundation:Dialogue with the Department of Women and Child & Social Welfare (WCD) and West Bengal Commission for Women resulting in their issuing directives for implementation of the SHWW Act, 2013 and constitution of Local Committees across all districts. The present status as informed by the Dept. of WCD is that, all District Officers submit annual reports to the department as mandated in the SHWW Act, 2013.Two state level Orientation Programmes were conducted for the District Social Welfare Officers (DSWOs), Ex Officio of the Local Committee, to strengthen the function of these Committees, in 2015 and 2016 respectively. 15 (out of 20) DSWOs were trained through these Orientation Programmes.However, there is a need in future for a Situation Analysis Research to understand the knowledge, skill and effectiveness of prevention and redress of sexual harassment in the districts, for planning Sanhitas future intervention.Sanhita provides handholding support to deal with SHW complaints lodged in North 24 Parganas Local Committee in the capacity of the Chair of the Committee.Sanhita in response to the request of the DSWOs, has written and produced SHW Primer under Oak Support which is to be disseminated to District Officers, DSWOs and monitoring authorities along with employers and SHW Committees for proper implementation of the SHWW Act, 2013.Dialogue with the Department of Health & Family Welfare and capacity building of the key officials in the districts resulted in the decentralised constitution of Internal Committees at CMOH Chief Medical Officer of Health) offices across all districts of West Bengal. This was followed by training of Internal Committees in five Medical Colleges & Hospitals in Kolkata.Sanhita also provides handholding support to deal with SHW complaints in the Internal Committee of Health Department (Headquarter) and Medical Colleges & Hospitals in Kolkata in the capacity of External Member.A Situation Analysis Research is needed to know about the present status and Grant Application Form, July 1 20138functioning in the district committees.Promoted responsibility of employers for women workers from resource poor backgrounds though issue-based partnership with key Government Departments such as Department of Health, WCD, Panchayat & Rural Development employing large number of women workers.Engagement with the Directorate of ICDS resulting in the decentralised constitution of Internal Committees in select districts of West Bengal.Enrolled as a Technical and Training Organisation by Administrative Training Institute (ATI), GoWB and engaged in institutional capacity building of a range of stakeholders.14 Grassroot leaders were trained on the SHW issue and the SHWW Act. The Grassroot Leaders in turn, have raised awareness of over 1000 women workers; primarily construction, domestic and factory workers through 210 community meetings conducted over a year in 7 clusters spread across 3 blocks of Ranchi District. In all areas ICDS and health workers were involved in the community meetings.The women workers have successfully secured some basic entitlements like toilets and place to rest thereby improving the safety at their work spaces. 28 dynamic, vocal and articulate women leaders participated in a day long camp which has further enhanced their awareness on the issue.In the absence of Local Committees, pre-existing community level institutions (forums and committees) were identified and strengthened to take up cases of sexual harassment/violence against women. At least 30 cases/incidents of SHW have been shared by women workers. Some of these have been taken up for redress with the community level institutions.Conducted an Orientation Programme for Government Officials and NGO representatives from Eastern & North Eastern States in 2017. Subsequently, Sanhita was invited by both the government and NGO Networks from the states like Bihar, Orissa and Meghalaya to design and facilitate further training. Its worth mentioning that Sanhita designed and facilitated the first series of Orientation Programmes for state officials and SHW Committee members for the Government of Meghalaya in 2019.The SHW Primer produced under the Oak Foundation support will be shared with the Govt. of Meghalaya.  Created evidence-based knowledge through field research on SHW from the select institutions and through several multi-lingual IEC materials for a wide range of stakeholders.Strengthened the crisis intervention as external member and advisor of SHW Committees across sectors like PSU, NGOs, Private Organisations, Factories and Hospitals.Sanhita received nearly 100 calls from individuals as well as ICs through the dedicated helpline seeking assistance for SHW redress which has been provided. Based on two rounds of Case Analysis conducted by Sanhita, we observed that the number of complaints reaching out to Sanhita has gradually increased over the years.Award: Founding Director of Sanhita has been felicitated by GoWB for contribution to the SHW issue in 2016. The following achievements of Sanhitas work on the issue of SHW since Grant Application Form, July 1 201392015 under the Oak Foundation Support are recognised in the External Evaluation (conducted in 2021):  Ground Breaking Work:Sanhitas work on sexual harassment at workplace has been ground breaking in the context of West Bengal, their engagement spans across government departments, civil society organisations, law networks and grassroots outreach.Sanhita has established and maintained several partnerships that has helped them grow and expand the work they are doing and the support they are providing spanning from training, IEC materials to research & crisis support.Responses from the Government Stakeholders:Across government stakeholders there is an agreement, that Sanhita was the correct organisation to engage as they were experts in the field of sexual harassment law, specifically the organisations expertise, dedication and long history of working in the field.Sanhita is thus perceived and recognised as being experts in the field by various government departments.The networking efforts have allowed Sanhita to be deeply embedded, that is they are recognised and have established relationships and connections within government systems as the go-to organisation where sexual harassment is concerned.Resourceful IEC and Training Modules:Sanhita has been successful in creating IEC materials whose uptake by government departments is a significant achievement.Across SHW Committee members interviewed there was a great appreciation of Sanhitas IEC materials which have been greatly beneficial to the organisations and have been used for multiple purposes and at multiple levels.The adaptability of their training modules and their ability to engage effectively with a section that is largely left out is commendable.Responses from the SHW Committees and Institutional Associations:Across SHW Committees there is a strong recognition of the support they have received from Sanhita. Especially the fact that Sanhita has been proactive, sensitive and practical in their dealing of complaints.SHW Committee members have also spoken of the times when Sanhita has gone above the call of duty and supported them through very difficult and trying times and how their support gave the Committee courage to fight difficult battles especially against those in power.Sanhita was ascribed to be extremely proactive and consistent in their efforts, by the Institutional Associations. in local languagesPromotion of access of women workers to useful information Review of SHW complaintsThe Recommendations of External Evaluation (conducted in 2021) of Sanhitas work on the issue of SHW Need for an in-depth study to understand the needs of women in the unorganised sector for greater accountability This will be part of our long-term strategy and will be undertaken in collaboration with relevant institutions working with unorganised women.6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):The premise of the project is to work on the issue of creating safe workplaces for women.Sexual harassment is a manifestation of sex discrimination and violence against women at the workplace that thrives in an atmosphere of threat, terror and reprisal. Sexual harassment at workplace adversely affects the safety, dignity, mental and physical well-being of women resulting in loss of life, job and livelihood opportunities Grant Application Form, July 1 201312among others. It is a manifestation of power relations as women are much more likely to be victims of sexual harassment because of their status at work, vulnerability, insecurity, and social conditioning.Challenges24 years post the Vishaka Judgement and 8 years post the enactment of the SHWW Act, implementation of the Act in the true spirit is yet to happen. There is however, no comprehensive data on the complaints of SHW is available. Based on Sanhitas experience, the number of recent court judgments and the narratives available post the #MeToo Movement it emerges that many workplaces still believe that SHW is a rare or trivial issue and that the women are responsible for their harassments.  Evidence shows that the complaints are not dealt with sensitively.  When the woman attempts to speak out the pattern is to subvert her credibility to prove that the complaint is motivated, if not false. Lack of employer accountability towards effective prevention and redress of SHW and the gaps in the Act to define the role of monitoring and regulatory bodies, have created several loopholes and cracks in the redress process.Due to the absence or limited access to redress mechanisms, the women workers from resource poor backgrounds and the precariously positioned ones among the institutionally employed remain particularly vulnerable. The SHWW Act 2013 is geared towards safety of women workforce and as such may be read as gender specific, applicable to only cisgender women. However, in a changing world order where notions around gender identity and expression are important markers of personhood, the Act might have to be extended in order to make it inclusive of transgender persons. OpportunitiesThe legal framework for employer responsibility towards safe working environment is enshrined in the Constitution of India which provides the basic opportunity for working on the SHW issue.The landmark Vishaka Guidelines and the SHWW Act provide a comprehensive definition of SHW and include all kinds of women at workplaces under its ambit. The Act places the onus for safe workplaces on the employer and provides the aggrieved woman recourse to civil proceeding alongside existing criminal proceeding.The scope for addressing and working on the SHW issue expanded manifold when the issue took centre stage in 2018 because of the # Me too movement and brought renewed focus to the prevalent cultures within organizations that perpetuate SHW and victimize women.With regard to the issue of SHW, the legal landscape in India has been a constantly evolving one and has led to progressive judgements of Honble Supreme Court and High Court leading to organisations across sectors reviewing their compliance to the Act. The scope for work increased by inclusion of SHW in the various service rules and in the Section 29 (d) of Code on Wages, 2019 and Section 134 of Companies Act, 2013 which mandated compliances through service rules among others.

Core Support  Yes:_/No:_ No4b (ii)?. Project involves Contact with Children  Yes:_/No:_No4c. Grant period:Start date:(dd/mon/yy)End date:4d. Currency: USD4e. Total Project Cost:567240 4f.
