Summarise the projects ultimate goal(s) (maximum 200 words):Grant Application Form, July 1 20134( NOT REQUIRED FOR CORE SUPPORT GRANTS)The largest cohort of employees, tea garden workers, in West Bengal continues to be deprived of the most basic rights of water, sanitation, electricity, and housing amongst others. While the government has introduced flagship welfare schemes through the tea board and introduced bills such as Plantation Labor Act (1951), poor implementation hasnt improved conditions. In this context, Swaniti aims to work closely with the network of civil society organizations, district administration, and state government to operationalize core welfare programs for tea garden workers. For example, all tea garden workers should have access to adequate housing. However, most local administration does not adhere to even the basic standards of housing. Lack of governance overview has led to the deprivation of this key group. In this context, Swaniti and it's partners proposes to embed teams into each affected district and state government to work with the local ecosystem and ensure the delivery of programs. The team will be expected to come up with joint solutions and implement them with the support of the local administration. By the end of the program, tea garden workers will be expected to have access to public programs.
GAF_Swaniti_Initiative_EnsurAccesToSocio.4. GEOGRAPHY: 5.List the major countries where your activities take place. If this is global policy work, list as worldwide:India  (South Asia)
GAF_Swaniti_Initiative_EnsurAccesToSocio.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 6. Context (The context section should not exceed two pages.)6a. Describe the organisation (include information on leadership, governance, structure and staff) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):Swaniti was founded in 2012 with the goal of strengthening governance tools. We believe that if public services are accessible and inclusive to the most vulnerable then they will have an opportunity to grow and thrive with equal opportunity. With this in mind, Bhattacharya founded Swaniti by supporting Parliamentarians and district administration through key knowledge insights. Bhattacharya drew from her experience of interning at Senators offices. She eventually received a Masters in Public Policy from Harvard Kennedy School and joined the World Bank. The founding of Swaniti has been an accumulation of her experiences in working in the governance space. Today, the Swaniti board consists of similarly passionate individuals including Richard Rossow (India Chair at Center for Strategic and International Studies), Elizabeth Gamino (development professional and advocate on equal rights), and Shantanu Agarwal (Venture Capitalist working on climate and sustainability technologies). Subsequently, Swanitis senior leadership also brings in similar experiences and commitment to government. Our leadership has significant experience in public service with tremendous insights Grant Application Form, July 1 20135into challenges on the ground. For example, our COO comes with experience from NITI Ayog where he was part of the evaluations team. Similarly, our program leads bring in the experiences from institutions such as the Ministry of Planning (central government), the Department of industries (Andhra government) and the Monitoring Project Management Unit (Ranchi district). Given that Swaniti aims to improve local governance in public service delivery, we maintain a decentralized model of placing team members within the community to better understand and deliver on programs. Team members placed with state governments come from grassroots background but are expected to maintain strong communication skills. For example, we have onboarded Aspirational District Fellows who have demonstrated strong verbal and written skills through the recruitment process. These team members come in with 5-7 years of work experience and advanced degrees. We have found such professionals to bring in the emotional intelligence to manage community based roles. All team members are expected to connect with community members, civil society partners, and government stakeholders to ensure that they have the whole picture and their contribution. Swaniti combines a top-down and bottom-up approach: our senior leadership connects with all mid-level and junior associates on a bi-monthly basis to get their insight on projects and their experiences. Based on this feedback we design or iterate projects. This is coupled with our impact evaluation and talent management team also connecting with them.For this project, Swaniti plans on leveraging our previous experiences to ensure strong team design and program implementation.6b. Describe the financial situation (include information on annual operating costs, fundraising strategy, reserves and debts) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):Swaniti is a non-profit entity with seventy percent of its funding coming from foundations such as Climateworks, McArthur, and Ford Foundation. And the remaining thirty percent is through government partnerships. When working with Foundations, Swaniti works in a tri-partite model where we provide technical assistance to state governments with their cooperation while we are being funded by a foundation partner to accomplish specific outcomes. Our annual operating budget for 2021-22 is at 3.5 million USD as we continue to expand our work across states and districts. Our biggest partners include UNICEF, SED Fund, and Laudes Foundation. With the exception of the upcoming grant from National Democratic Institute, all our grants our focused on work within India. Swanitis fundraising strategy is to focus on multi-year state programs where we hope to focus on two areas of development: a.) economic response to climate change and b.) social protection for vulnerable populations across India. Using our corpus which is support by Skoll Foundation, Swaniti is continuing its work with legislators and policymakers. In the upcoming years, Swaniti is currently in conversation with Bloomberg Philanthropies and Childrens Investment Fund for projects in India and Bangladesh.Swaniti recognizes that as we scale up, it is important to have in place partners who can support us in our work in India. In order to strengthen Swaniti systems further, we plan on partnering with reputed organizations who can continue to be key partners on programs. These partners would be FCRA-compliant and include Grant Application Form, July 1 20136the likes of Digital Empowerment Foundation and UN Women. Swaniti expects these agencies to not just be alligned programmatically but also have regional presence in states where it is working, including in West Bengal. Through programs such as the proposed project of the Oak Foundation, we hope to uncover organizations who have alignment with Swaniti's mission, to ensure that programs are codesigned and executed smoothly. We believe that this would allow for our overall systems and programs to be strengthened. Thus we are particularly excited about the Oak proposal since it is providing us the opportunity to build on the above mentioned model. As we continue to scale Swaniti's growth, we hope to be able to establish strong partners and work in India. 6c. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):Swaniti Initiative aims to deliver public services to the poorest of the poor by strengthening governance. Swaniti is a 501(c)3 with a team size of over 100+ professionals. In the past, we have worked in states like Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh, Odisha, Assam, Andhra Pradesh, and Maharashtra. In the process, we have been able to establish direct advisory support to Chief Ministers offices in Chhattisgarh, Jharkhand, Assam, and Meghalaya. Swaniti team constantly monitors our policy impact on the ground. We do so by developing detailed logframes with output, outcomes and impact indicators to tangibly measure the impact of our work. We have seen that our interventions have established inclusive systems and processes for the most most vulnerable in government policies. In Andhra Pradesh, for example, Swaniti Initiative has been able to significantly improve last mile delivery of MGNREGS by reducing payment errors by approximately 90%. In Jharkhand, the team has been able to mobilise public finances to enable the transition towards a green ecosystem in the state by untapping high amounts of public finance. Interventions undertaken include installation of solar rooftops in government buildings, provision of EV vehicles to ANM workers for effective last mile delivery of healthcare, employment generation and increased incomes through solar pumps etc. These are just some of the systemic and process changes that have worked on. To accomplish the goal mentioned above, Swaniti has had the opportunity to partner with established institutions like World Economic Forum, Harvard University, and the Center for Strategic and International Studies. Through our ten-year experience, we have been able to mobilize over 5 million dollars of untapped funding and impacted over 300,000 lives. We have been acknowledged for our exceptional work by publications like Forbes (30 under 30 lists for work with Swaniti), Fortune (40 under 40 lists), World Economic Forum (as Young Global Leader), Special Invitee to the White House, and Australia  India Youth Dialogue Young Leader.Swanitis work has been featured in national and international publications including Indian Express, Times of India, Hindustan Times, Reuters, and NPR.6d. Describe the current strategy of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):Grant Application Form, July 1 20137Key to Swanitis strategy in the next five years is to work in a collaborative model. Specifically, Swaniti plans on building on its current cross-sectoral model of working with multiple stakeholders to ensure policy and implementation change in governance. Swaniti sees the role of the government as being catalytic in serving the community. However, to be sustainable and scalable, programs need to engage with communities and bring together local partners for successful execution. Accordingly, Swaniti pursues a triangular model of collaboration in overall service delivery. The three key stakeholders who maintain a symbiotic relationship are as follows:   The community is our primary stakeholder. To make a program sustainable it is important to ensure that the program is deeply rooted within the requirements and expectations of the community. Therefore, the field teams begin all engagements by holding community-level meetings with key stakeholders like village council members, womens self-help groups, small landholding farmers, etc. Only with key input from community members does the program design move forward. The field teams invest several months to build trust within the communities and understand gaps and opportunities in public service delivery.  As highlighted above, the government is a key collaborator. Swaniti embeds itself in the office of the local administration to ensure the requisite support systems for service delivery exists and complements it with counterparts in state offices to ensure scalability. Swaniti sees government as a critical level in ensuring the delivery of key social safety programs that can lift people out of poverty and provide them with an opportunity for better quality of life. Our government counterparts are a critical part of Swaniti's work. Finally, partnerships of local NGO partners who can help in program implementation are a key part of the program. NGOs bring in critical insights on how to operationalize local solutions within the communities and our seen as the "local solution providers". In this particular program, we hope to partner with the Digital Empowerment Foundation who would be bringing in their "Soochnaprenuers", community members who have a thorough understanding of local programs and will help tea garden workers enroll in various government initiatives. Soochnaprenuers is a program piloted and scaled by DEF. The local entreprenuers, known as Soochnaprenuers, will bring in the hyperlocal solutions needed to resolve the current knowledge and enrollment gaps of various government programs. Our past experience has shown that this is the most impactful model and therefore going forward we are focusing on the same for our current strategy.  6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):Indias local governance systems are broken. This makes it difficult for the most vulnerable to have access to basic public services that are critical to growth. 78 million people are eligible for government-funded programs. The Indian government spends over 58 billion USD on ensuring food security 42 billion on creating economic opportunities, and over 126 billion on social protection programs. Yet India is home to 20 percent of the worlds poor who are living in abject poverty. Despite the governments will to lift people out of poverty, many fall through the cracks because local administrations often dont have the tools for last-mile delivery. Local governments lack the three Ps...Grant Application Form, July 1 20138                     ...skilled people at a local level who have the knowledge, expertise, and drive to effectively execute and reach most marginalized              .meaningful civil society partnerships to complement the government efforts and create checks and balances for robust long term program delivery                .strong processes which include continuous monitoring and evaluation.  Most governance-centric efforts are concentrated at a national level. The weakest states, districts, and villages often have little or no tools to improve local governance. Yet local governments are the touch points for public services. To correct this imbalance, it is critical to work with government administrators at a local level in weak and laggard districts and states. This proposal focuses on working with local governance to be able to solve issues around social protection for tea garden workers. Based on the consultations with grassroots organizations, we learned that there is no role of middlemen/contractors in the hiring of the tea workers. The hiring happens through heredity. For instance, the original person who was hired provides replacement through some family member and the cycle goes on. Office staff are interviewed by the DBITA (Dooars Branch Indian Tea Association). Tea workers lack the required documentation for most schemes and programs. Workers don't have aadhar cards or bank accounts. However, even with an alternate id proof (if any), the process is very cumbersome in accessing programs like maternity benefit scheme. Even RTE is defunct for the tea workers. Paralegals are trained how to acquire the relevant forms etc but implementation hurdles limit possible impact levels. The impact of access to scheme is ultimately seen in developmental outcomes. These include multilayered challenges in the form of health, sanitation etc. Following aare some of the outcome challenges within the state:1. Severely compromised health infrastructure included limited doctors and medicines. 2. Tea workers do not have access to entitled ration3. Sanitation, housing and drinking water are big challenges.4. Separate electricity meters in the living quarters and the electricity bill is borne by the workers. Thus with these outcomes and broken governance systems, it is important to help strengthen the process of public service delivery of tea garden workers. Through this proposal, Swaniti hopes to address this issue.

After consultations with an Oak PO, you may decide to summarise your mission as one broad objective. (You may use additional space if you have more than three objectives)?. Under each objective describe the activities that your organisation will undertake to achieve it, including time frame and the results or outcomes you expect to achieve.7.1.a. Objective 1 (maximum one sentence):To identify the availability and extent of accessibility of tea workers to government welfare schemes and other entitlements7.1.b. Objective 1 Expected results/outcomes and timeframe (maximum 300 words):The output would include recommendations on ways to improve access to schemes while also generating livelihood opportunities. From this exploratory study, we hope to understand the dynamism and challenges faced by the tea workers in their ecosystem in terms of their access to social security entitlements such that an implementable and sustainable policy recommendation can be designed. The exercise will be built on the existing research studies that focus on the tea garden worker community and their vulnerability in terms of access to their entitlements. Insights from existing research studies such as Bhowmick (1982,1992, 2011, 2015), Sadhukhan (2014), Ghosh (2014), Thakur (1995) etc will serve as the base for the project.To meet the objective, the Swaniti team and it's partner will be performing the following set of activities:Conducting FGDs with constituents, semi-structured interviews, and household surveys on various socio-economic-infrastructural indicators to achieve an in-depth understanding of the on-ground situation.The findings from the field will then be substantiated by engaging with various stakeholders from different spheres, including government, civil society organizations, and grassroots partners to leverage their knowledge of institutional and local enforcement challenges and to identify needs for institutional capacity building. The Swaniti team would also conduct a pilot survey for the questionnaire testing before rolling out the final survey.Based on the survey findings and stakeholder consultations, the Swaniti team will then also map out the government processes and bottlenecks in program delivery.Since tea plantations fall under the agrarian economy it is likely that tea workers have limited or no exposure to modern skill development training or technology. Accordingly, Swaniti will leverage the expertise that it has gathered through its experience in the RESET (Roadmap for Ecological and Sustainable Energy Transformation) project in Jharkhand in employment generation and apply them for West Bengal. The indicators for skill identification will include:Number of skill development workshops conductedNumber of workers trained; the number of alternate jobs generatedGrant Application Form, July 1 2013107.1.c. The first objective and the associated activities will be carried out in Phase I which is a period of 3 to 4 months. In this phase, the fieldwork will begin with data collection in at least three districts, namely Jalpaiguri, Alipurduar and Cooch Behar. Swaniti team proposes to carry out data collection in four tea estates within each district where the estates will be decided based on the following indicators:Estate Size: STGs and Large estatesStatus of the estate: profit-making closed tea estateNumber of currently employed tea workers Swaniti will also be interviewing retired tea workers. The prospective theme for data collection will comprise but not be limited to:household details (education/ nutrition statistics for children; number of dependents etc)socio-economic statusawareness and access to schemes and entitlementsdetails about working conditionsmajor challenges etc The primary study participants will include tea workers, we have found that and estate owners/managers. Secondary stakeholders include worker trade unions, nearby SHGs, Panchayat, etc. We have done an inter-district comparison between Jalpaiguri and Kooch Behar in terms of socio-economic indicators including sex ratio. The final sex ratio will be decided once the sampling strategy is finalized. However, as per our standard practice, we aim to keep an equal composition of men and women in FGDs. Additionally, Swaniti team will also engage in consultation with stakeholders including the government, field partners, like-minded CSOs, and grassroots organizations. Digital Empowerment Foundation (DEF) will be supported Swaniti to design the survey by leveraging their past experience of working with team garden workers in Assam. Additionally, they will expect to mobilize young people from the ground to support conducting these surveys, with the hopes that these youth can eventually become Soochnaprenuers and help inform tea garden workers about their rights and ways to access them. DEF will build on its Soochnaprenuer model from other districts and states. Secondary stakeholders include worker trade unions, nearby SHGs, Panchayat, etc. Additionally, the Swaniti team will also engage in consultation with stakeholders including the government, field partners, like-minded CSOs, and grassroots organizations. Data will be collected through the following methods:( Phase 1: 3-4 months)Focus group discussions: Within each tea estate, the Swaniti Initiative team will conduct 1 FGD with a cohort of 10-15 people each. Beneficiaries will be sampled through purposive sampling in consultation with our on-ground partners. Further, the team will ensure that each focus group discussion consists of a diverse range of beneficiaries including women, tribal/ SC population, and contractual/ permanent employees. We expect that the primary resistance to enter the estate and communicate with the workers will in fact come from the garden owners. In order to counter this, we are working on a separate risk and mitigating strategy that involves working with various tea councils and the Ministry of Commerces cooperation with the Tea Board.Household surveys: Apart from the focus group discussions, in order to gain a thorough understanding of the situation on-ground and to begin developing a baseline, the Swaniti Initiative team will conduct household surveys in each estate. Households will be selected through snowball sampling. Data will be collected on various indicators including current socio-economic conditions, access to schemes, challenges being faced, etc. The sets of entitlement to the workers come from two broad sources. (i) Flagship schemes of the government through Tea Board and State government (Chai Sundari) and (ii) the now-dissolved PLA 1951 where under the Act, the entitlements are the responsibility of the estate owners and the administering the process is the responsibility of the state government. Through the baseline, we aim to understand the challenges to accessing both these.Semi-structured/ in-depth interviews: Apart from the data collection from beneficiaries, the team will be conducting interviews with other identified stakeholders to substantiate its findings from the field as well as to understand the supply side of the issue.The outcome of this phase is to understand the major challenges being faced by plantation workers in accessing benefits and identify potential interventions to address these issues.While the Swaniti team will be collecting data from the ground, the Digital Empowerment Foundation will take this opportunity to recruit young people from the community to support the on ground data collection process. These youth will also have their capacity built about the rights and services that tea garden workers should have access toward. In the upcoming phases of the program, the youth, known as Soochnaprenuers, will be expected to help in increased awareness and enrollment of tea garden workers, into government programs. These resources will translate the working module of the recommendations into a continued government mechanism.Training and Capacity Building: To ensure that the project will keep running even after Swanitis tenure is over and in the absence of continuous involvement of on-ground partners, Swaniti will ensure that the local administration is trained for sustainable implementation of the recommendations. Swaniti team and it's partners, Digital Empowerment Foundation, will also aim to bridge the gap between the government and the community. This is important because, without this connection, there will be no advantage of proximity which can exploit transparent communication optimally. Hence, despite implementing the recommendations, there will always remain a gap between the beneficiaries lack of entitlement and /or access to the same and the governments attempt to solve the same. Accordingly, the Swaniti team seeks to engage with multiple stakeholders including:The broader outcomes of this phase are: Recommendations have been adopted by the departmentReports/ findings/ recommendations have been submitted to the departmentNew departments have been onboarded Grant Application Form, July 1 201313respect, the training of government officials will be based on the statement of purpose (SoP) of the recommendations which can be process correction/new schemes/increasing budget allocation of existing schemes, etc. This training can be done for example by conducting capacity-building workshops. Pilot Testing Interventions: Swaniti will support the government to pilot-test the interventions in the selected baseline geographies in order to understand the efficacy of the project. Objective 3 Expected results/outcomes and timeframe (maximum 300 words):The outcome of this phase is to create a local ecosystem of accountability and oversight by connecting civil society partners with government agencies to ensure the sustainability of the program. Swaniti will facilitate such that local NGOs hold periodical meetings with the district magistrates and provide him/her with continuous insights, state of conditions, and solutions about the tea garden workers. Additionally, the presence of local youth, Soochnaprenuers, who would be expected to continue supporting tea garden workers, will also ensure the sustainability of the program.   The Soochnapreneur model has volunteers who have door-to-door access to beneficiaries. The total number of such volunteers will be decided at a block level during the mid-term stage of the program once the first phase of adoption or implementation starts. One may consider this model very similar to a CSC ( Common service center) hub and spook ecosystem or a Banking Correspondent setup.Since we are collaborating with the Soochnapreneur program, we will be leveraging their model to ensure there is no exclusion such that the program is sustainable.Grant Application Form, July 1 2013147.3.c. Objective 3 Activities and timeframe (maximum 300 words):Sharing the SoP of Recommendations with Sectoral Experts: Swaniti will assist in conducting high-level meetings with sectoral experts, bureaucrats etc where the SoP of the recommendations can be revisited and brainstormed on to obtain specialized insights on improving inclusivity and sustainability. The last two months in the final phase of the project can be dedicated for impact assessment to understand the sustainability of the The intent would be to institutionalize a culture of engagement of civil society with the government. Through this project, Swaniti aims to not just aid in short-term program delivery but also hope to create long-term systems.The medium-term output would be measured by: oThe increase in access and uptake of schemes and entitlements can be measured by the percentage of beneficiaries registering for and/or registered beneficiaries accessing the entitlements.  This can be verified with government data/surveys.oA number of changes are institutionalized within the governance systems and local ecosystem. This is only possible with a robust monitoring system created through the local civil society ecosystem. This component will focus on translating the recommendations and solutions as part of government functioning. For example, the administration might implement systems to ease the enrollment of tea garden workers into various programs. This can be a permanent change that should be implemented at a district level.  In order to ensure the long-term sustainability of our interventions, Swaniti Initiative ensures the capacity building of government officials and relevant stakeholders. Grievance redressal and timely monitoring of interventions are a part of this training. This is done by establishing a strong communication channel and feedback loop between the district and state teams of Swaniti who form a point of bridge between these two administrative bodies. In Andhra Pradesh, Swaniti Initiative has successfully demonstrated this model where due to our intervention the grievances recorded have jumped from 25 complaints a month to 125 a month for the MGNREGS scheme due to our systems that have been adopted by the Dept of RD and PR.The long term output would be measured by:Change in the socio-economic parameters of the beneficiaries. This can be measured by recording the change in income, socio-economic indicators like health, education, nutrition, access to safe drinking water, sanitation, hygiene, housing, etc, through government data or surveys. In short, the long-term expected outcome would be an improvement in the quality of life of the beneficiaries. Swaniti Initiative will develop a log frame identifying outputs (short term), outcomes (midterm), and impact (long term). The short-term indicators would measure factors like awareness levels, documentation for accessing entitlements, etc. The projected timeline to witness this is 7-8 months. In the medium term, the outcomes measured will include percentage increase in beneficiaries, uptake of schemes, etc. We predict approximately 12-16 months to witness this change. In the long term, Swaniti envisages better socio-economic indicators for the beneficiaries. This will be measured at the end of the project, but it might take longer than 2 years to witness the tangible socio-economic impact. Grant Application Form, July 1 201315project.Monitoring and Evaluation: Swaniti will work closely with local partners to develop a culture of periodic information sharing with the local and state administration by sharing real-time data assessment on the performance and feedback on grievances. Having a continuous monitoring system would provide the government with a ground perspective on the state of rights and services of tea garden workers and open up an active discussion with the government.Establish a Continuous Feedback Mechanism: to enable beneficiary inputs at every stage of the project by leveraging our on-field network of partner organisations, district associates, and the state lead. In this phase. Swaniti will also focus on community engagements. It is critical to take a constructive tone to ensure that these conversations are fruitful and sustainable. Thus, Swaniti will be leveraging its experience from other projects to ensure that this is the case in West Bengal.  Additionally, state and district fellows will analyze how community actors and government can develop a continuous feedback and course correction loop to ensure that tea garden workers continue to receive basic rights. For example, convening monthly meetings where civil society members can share key data points about how tea garden workers are performing. The convening will hope to nudge conversation about the continued gaps and possible solutions in public programs. This will also feed into the monitoring and evaluation process. GAF_Swaniti_Initiative_EnsurAccesToSocio.8. COOPERATION: 8. CooperationDescribe the level of cooperation with other organisations and networks and explain how this cooperation helps achieve your goals (maximum 300 words):Swaniti has been continuously engaging with grassroots organizations like Nazdeek, Traidcraft, and the Family Planning Association of India. These organizations work with marginalized communities and have helped us to refine our proposal based on their on-ground insights. The organizations have provided deeper insights on violation of rights and institutional and local enforcement challenges to policy implementation. Cooperating with these organizations has highlighted issues that not only reveal violations of tea workers rights to social security but also identify implementation problems that require immediate attention. These findings include (1) since PLA is the employer's responsibility the local governments (PRIs) have moved away from Grant Application Form, July 1 201316assuming any responsibility for the welfare of tea workers despite being included in schedule 6. Also, it remains unimplemented in West Bengal; (2) most tea workers are from Oraon community but not included in ST list and hence have no access to public programs; (3) tea workers have no access to schemes like PM Kisan which are applicable to farming programs; (4) absence of labour commissioners and hence unsettled disputes related to employers provident fund persist; (5) although 50% to 60% of tea workers are women, there is a huge lack of organization bodies for women representation and they are not allowed to form SHGs; (6) high rates of school dropout, child labour where children are remunerated based on per kilo lifting basis; (7) tea workers are not allowed to migrate unless they provide replacement from family; (8) significant lack of accountability as there is a lack of audit certification for most tea estates as owners don't allow audits; (9) there is a nexus between estate owners and local administration where owners register for MNREGA with false promise of providing 100 days work to tea workers and obtain the funds without actual employment. Cooperating with this network of organizations, can help us understand the tea workers ecosystem and challenges better and hence create targeted policy interventions that can be implemented to strengthen governance for the delivery of welfare entitlements to the tea workers community.In addition to working with these organizations, Swaniti also plans on partnering with Digital Empowerment Foundation. Digital Empowerment Foundation has worked  with tea garden workers in Assam in increasing access to government programs. With a budget spent of 22 crores annually (approximately 3 million USD), Digital Empowerment Foundation has previous experience of working on large scale programs. We hope to be able to build on their experiences of working with tea garden workers and bring in ours of working with government. The partnership will allow for a strong program delivery. With DEF being a FCRA-compliant, we hope to provide a sub-grant to them through this program and have a programmatic partnership. We are in the process of finalizing the above (and have provided a tentative budget based on discussions thus far). We plan on submitting the details of finalized roles and responsibilities to Oak Foundation team members in the next month.
GAF_Swaniti_Initiative_EnsurAccesToSocio.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. ImpactWhat is the change you want to achieve from the overall project? (maximum 300 words):Given the distressed background of tea workers, the goal of this project is to strengthen the delivery of government programs to tea garden workers. In this respect, first, Swaniti aims to improve the delivery of public programs to tea garden workers by translating the set of recommendations to government functioning. The primary focus of this impact of the project is to create a sustainable program delivery change to secure the social rights and entitlements and access to government programs by strengthening implementation. For instance, through this project as the gaps and challenges in accessibility and provision of tea workers entitlements and reasons for the same are identified, Swaniti aims to highlight whether there is (a) complete absence of some socio-economic entitlements; (b) difficulty in access to the same; (c) impediments in the delivery mechanism at the Grant Application Form, July 1 201317administration level which requires process correction, etc. Following the identification, Swaniti will work with the administration and other stakeholders in correcting the loopholes. For instance, if the main obstacle is administrative process impediment, Swaniti with work in tandem with the administration with the help of the district and state fellows to correct the same. Further, to achieve sustainable adoption of the recommendations, Swaniti will work towards utilization of funds from the Government's side. We would ensure that the policy recommendations that get adopted will have a separate budget head or mobilize the government to allocate under-utilized funds that make the program institutionalized. The second impact Swaniti aims to achieve is to create a local ecosystem of accountability. Swaniti aims to achieve this impact by engaging the community with civil society partners and grassroots organizations through regular sessions where the tea workers can update their existing conditions and whether there has been any tangible change. This feedbacks will then go to the government through the civil society members to create a continuous feedback and correction mechanism which will ensure the sustainability of the program.10. EvaluationHow will progress be monitored and evaluated? (maximum 300 words):For evaluation, a monthly monitoring system will be put in place in the form of an excel tracker the team leads or a person appointed by the lead will update the monthly deliverables at the beginning of each month. At the month-end, the tracker will be updated with the actual outputs. This will enable us to map the monthly deliverables with the actual progress. The tracker will also note the reasons for being unable to achieve the monthly deliverables, the challenges faced, mitigation strategy to ensure a course-correction mechanism. This includes gathering insights on the process being followed, external and internal challenges faced as a team, and feedback to make the process more effective and efficient. Process monitoring will be further substantiated by a quarterly HR review, conducted through anonymous surveys. All team members will fill in their responses, to track their views on challenges being faced and means to improve on the project. Problems of a severe nature can be addressed by the HR/project lead, as convenient. This will provide a space for the individual team members to provide their views on the workings of the project. Apart from these, the M&E team will also carry out spot checks and back-checks to ensure the quality of data being collected. For impact assessment, every 6 months, there will be a medium-term outcome evaluation report which will assess if the targeted outputs have been achieved or not as per the pre-defined project design and goals. At the end of the project, a broader impact assessment will be carried out which along with outcome evaluation, will also assess the impact of the project on the lives of beneficiaries/key stakeholders/change in governance mechanisms, etc. through a pre-post assessment methodology. In addition to this Swaniti Initiative follows the recommended 2-5% allocation for MEL activities. This is a best practice based on Development Assistance Committee (DAC) recommendations for OECD. Just to explain this in a bit more detail, Swaniti Initiative will follow a pre-post Grant Application Form, July 1 201318methodology to measure outputs, outcome, and impact. Our internal Evaluation framework comprises 4 key performance indicators centers around systems and processes, bottom-up planning, capacity building, and mobilizing public finance for key welfare programs. Apart from these, the team in collaboration with the relevant stakeholders and will develop a detailed log frame to identify project-specific output and outcome indicators and the ways of measuring the same.
GAF_Swaniti_Initiative_EnsurAccesToSocio.11. ADDITIONAL QUESTIONS/ Future Plans: 11. Future PlansHow will the grant influence the organisation and future plans? (maximum 300 words):As mentioned in the previous section, this project is part of Swanitis larger goal of being able to create models of effective implementation in social welfare programs at the state level. Having models of excellence will allow creating a national program for countrywide improvement since we would be able to showcase the steps taken for more inclusive and accessible government schemes and programs. The focus of this program being rights and entitlements of tea garden workers would help create one such intervention that can be showcased to NITI, PMO, and other state governments for larger adoptions. Swaniti will hope to take the learning from this particular condition to other districts and states and provide pointed feedback on how to bring systemic change. We have already initiated many of these practices. For example, we are bringing our experiences of working on job creation in Jharkhand to West Bengal. Similarly, we plan on taking these experiences to other states as well. We see this program as being pivotal to our future work of strengthening systems and processes in governance.

GAF_A_Water_For_People_StrenIntegWaterMa.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT 5a. Tell us about your governance and leadership structures, as well as staff and volunteer base. Highlight any significant recent or expected future changes. If you have an explicit approach to increasing diversity and/or advancing race equity within the organisation, please tell us. (300 words):Oak Application Form     5Water For Peoples governance and leadership structure includes two Co-CEOs, Samson Haile Bekele and Mark Duey, a 15-member Board of Directors, an 8-member Global Leadership Team that includes the Co-CEOs, and several regional and country directors. Across all nine country programs and the Global office based in Denver, Water For People has 268 full-time staff members, three part-time staff members, and two volunteers. In India, Water For Peoples programs are jointly managed through a Branch office and Water For People India Trust, whose procedures align with Indian government requirements. This Trust was established in 2008 as a locally registered arm governed by an eight-member board of Indian citizens. The Trust receives funds from entities in India such as corporations, whereas the Branch office is authorized to receive funds from international organizations. Bishwadeep Ghose is the Water For People India Country Director, a member of the Global Leadership Team, and member of the India Trust board. He contributes his 25 years experience on national and international programs to realize impact and manage the team spread across four states in India. The Trust currently has 24 full time members while the Branch office has 40. Since 2020, Water For People has placed a heightened focus?on increasing diversity and advancing race equity within the organization. We have a Justice, Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion (JEDI) Policy which defines our organizational commitment to championing this culture and environment for all employees, board members, volunteers, business partners, and members of the communities we serve. To support the implementation of this JEDI policy and overall workplace culture, we have a staff volunteer-led Global Transformation Committee made up of the chairs of four Regional Transformation Committees. We also have a Global Advisor for Gender, Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion who supports our internal implementation as well as our external programming related to justice and equity.  5b. Summarise the organisations history.  In addition, highlight 2-3 key achievements.Please keep this brief and list up to 3 key achievements as bullet points. Even though you may have many achievements, please share what is most relevant to the proposed grant. (300 words)Water For People began working in India in 1996 in North 24 Parganas in West Bengal. In 2008, we established a locally registered arm governed by an eight-member board, Water For People India Trust. Since 2011, we have applied the Everyone Forever model, a long-term approach focused on sustainable water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH) services. Applying our Everyone Forever model, with its emphasis on partnerships with local governments and communities, has resulted in significant progress towards the completion and rehabilitation of improved water and sanitation systems, strengthened by municipal and local structures. This transformative WASH program in India is helping Everyone  every community, household, school, and clinic  gain access to these critical resources across 10 districts/blocks in West Bengal in South 24 Parganas (Sagar Island, Oak Application Form     6Patharpratima, Namkhana) and Birbhum (Rajnagar), in Bihar, Sheohar (Sheohar block, Dumri Katsari, Piprahi, Traini Chowk, and Purnahiya), and in Maharashtra, Amravati (Chikhaldara). Eight districts/blocks now have new or improved water services in all communities, the five blocks of Sheohar (Bihar), Sagar Island, Patharpratima, and Rajnagar (West Bengal) and seven have new or improved water services in all households, including Patharpratima.  These efforts have resulted in intermediate or high levels of water services for 1,548,915 people across 10 Everyone Forever districts/blocks, affecting 93% of the population in these blocks. These areas include five blocks in Sheohar (Bihar), Chikhaldara block in Amravati (Maharashtra), and four blocks in West Bengal. Water For People and Panchayat and Rural Development Department (Governments of West Bengal and Bihar) have signed Memorandum of Understandings in which Water For People formed a Technical Support Unit with embedded staff to assist government flagship programs such as Jal Jeevan Mission. The Unit provides support to these departments for community engagement, program management, capacity building and training of state, district, and local level officials. This support aims to assist these states to achieve the ambitious goals of the Jal Jeevan Mission (a functional household water tap connection to all households in rural India by 2024), SBM Phase II, and Jal Shakti Abhiyan (water conservation initiative). This Unit also works with communities to develop plans and models to manage their water resources.  Water resources in the areas where we work in India are severely affected by climate change. There are more frequent tropical storms, sea levels are rising, and drought persists. Erratic rainfall, changes in timing, intensity and duration of precipitation has adversely affected surface water, putting additional pressure on ground water resources. Water For People India aligns its water resources management (WRM) activities with the Indian governments water conservation initiative, Jal Shakti AbhiyanCatch the rain when it falls where it falls. We provide training to master trainers, guiding them to work closely with communities and villages to develop climate resilient Village Water Safety and Security Plans (VWSSPs). These plans include budgets for conducting water quality testing, measuring water sources, and planning availability. Under these plans, Water for People supports the installation of aquifer storage units, ridge and furrow models, and creation of recharge pits for surface water management. VWSSPs are incorporated into Gram Panchayat Development Plans. We also work with farmers to reduce pumping needs for irrigation. In addition, in schools, we install roof top rainwater harvesting systems to serve as an alternative/supplemental water source.  5c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and decide your approach? If you have undertaken a theory of change exercise, or if you are influenced by research, policy or your own organisations experience, please tell us about this.  Have you consulted with relevant stakeholders, including your Oak Application Form     7communities and others experiencing the problem? Is there an intention to address equity, diversity and inclusion? (600 words):Water For People is very familiar with the Sundarbans challenges, having working in Parganas, West Bengal since 1996. This area has a population of 2.79 million living in about 1,100 villages. Most people, including many from scheduled tribes and castes, live in acute poverty and depend on agriculture for their livelihoods. This region is very vulnerable to climate changes frequent cyclones, floods, and sea-level rise. These events have led to saline soil, seawater intrusion, aquifer contamination, brackish aquaculture ponds, and increased incidence of waterborne diseases. Progressive salinization of rivers and groundwater has resulted in the decline of available fresh drinking water. The demand for groundwater has increased to meet increasing demand for crops, which, combined with limited rainfall, is resulting in the over-extraction of groundwater and a severe crisis during the summer.  Based on our experience, all activities that Water For People India carries out in communities related to water security aim to build resilience as part of the overarching goal of communities surviving climate change. A community cannot survive climate change if water sources are not secure, namely accessible and of sufficient quantity and quality. The people contributing the least to climate change are suffering the most. We cannot continue to wait for mitigation efforts to reduce global greenhouse gas emissions to correct the injustice.?It is time for the people directly facing threats to their water sources to have resources necessary to adapt.? We plan to use Oak Foundations funding to strengthen integrated water resources management (IWRM) in Patharpratima and Gosaba, two blocks with ecosystems highly vulnerable to cyclones. In Patharpratima block, 23% of the population is Schedule Caste, 0.8% is Schedule Tribe. In Gosaba block, 62.7% is Schedule Caste, 9.5% is Schedule Tribe. We will work closely with community leaders and members, particularly those from marginalized groups such as Schedule Castes and Tribes, and women.  This work will empower those community leaders to lead efforts to adapt to climate change by ensuring water security.?IWRM acknowledges the pivotal role of water as a finite resource and advocates for its judicious allocation using a comprehensive approach to address the multifaceted challenges posed by climate change, particularly for tribal communities. These communities are often reliant on local water sources for sustenance with IWRM offering enhanced water security. By implementing sustainable practices such as rainwater harvesting, groundwater recharge, and efficient irrigation methods, women who traditionally bear the responsibility of water collection, can experience reduced physical burden and increased access to clean water.  IWRM can also serve as an educational tool, enhancing tribal communities' understanding of hydrological processes, water conservation strategies, and climate change impacts. This knowledge empowers everyone, especially women, to make informed decisions regarding water use and management, producing a culture of environmental stewardship and adaptive learning. Also as women are primary users of water, they are interested in learning Oak Application Form     8the scientific and social context of ground water depletion as it greatly impacts their daily lives, and how to put into practice newly acquired knowledge for the community's benefit. IWRM also enhances public health through improved water quality due to IWRM's emphasis on monitoring water quality, pollution control, and watershed management. By mitigating waterborne diseases and contamination, tribal communities experience improved overall well-being and reduced healthcare burdens, particularly benefitting women in tribal communities through improved maternal and child health. For women's empowerment, IWRM and the approaches proposed are inherently transformative as it involves women in decision-making processes related to water management, challenging traditional gender roles and amplifying women's voices. Participation in water committees, resource planning, and advocacy initiatives elevates their status and influence within the community, nurturing a more gender-equitable society. In addition, IWRM can catalyze diversification of livelihoods by integrating water-sensitive agricultural practices and aquaculture. This not only mitigates climate risks but also stimulates economic growth within tribal communities, reducing their vulnerability to external shocks. By enhancing water security, supporting education, promoting health, elevating women's empowerment, and augmenting livelihoods, IWRM becomes a catalyst for inclusive and sustainable development. To strengthen IWRM, Water For People, PRASARI, and Akvo propose to build on the tested approach of participatory groundwater management (PGWM) for select villages in the Sundarbans. This approach incorporates a deep understanding of surface and groundwater interactions and values and incorporates community knowledge to solve complex water problems. Successful implementation of PGWM requires an understanding of groundwater science from the perspective of the local population too.  Firstly, within the Participatory Groundwater Management (PGWM) process, the community will engage in the mapping of IWRM activities and models currently in place. It is necessary to validate the traditional IWRM models using scientific methods. Subsequently, this knowledge will be disseminated to the community through various platforms, leading to the development of a comprehensive community plan focused on ensuring the sustainability of water sources. As a result, the PGWM process will involve the identification of different categories of traditional IWRM models, with particular attention given to identifying models that have been damaged or reduced in effectiveness. During the execution phase, appropriate modifications will be made to ineffective traditional IWRM models either with direct support or with convergence from government departments.? We will nurture local leaders and community-based institutions, particularly among women-led Self-Help Groups, supporting them to map the aquifers, delineate resources, facilitate water budgeting, and scenario building for managing water. In addition, we will combine outcomes of community-based water quality mapping with predictive analysis models leveraging available and relevant historical data for community and local institutions to make informed decisions regarding the sustainability of their water sources. We intend to act as enablers, with local communities and their institutions Oak Application Form     9driving the process. Since PRASARI and Water For People have built trust in communities in these blocks for years, interventions will begin quickly.  Participatory approaches and IWRM require investments of time and resources before fully realizing benefits. We will use Oak Foundations funding to design the program and activities together with the government, traditional leaders from schedule castes and tribes, and local communities. We will facilitate discussions between local government and communities to ensure sustainability by creating an advisory committee that includes senior government officials from state and district governments, local elected bodies, and Panchayati Raj Institution members. We will involve traditional leaders, developing a cadre of communities to build their capacity to plan, budget, and develop demonstration of freshwater harvesting and aquifer recharging models for three years. After the close of the initial project, we will build on investments and link communities to government campaigns/ resources to fund water security plans and infrastructure solutions. As Water For People is embedded in the West Bengal state government, we will foster incorporating water security plans into Gram Panchayat Development Plans (GPDPs).  In addition to incorporating these plans in GPDPs, locally elected bodies and Panchayati Raj Institution members will play an important role in decision making to leverage government resources. From project inception to capacity building exercises and workshops to develop community-led water security plans and solutions, vulnerable community members, traditional leaders, and locally elected bodies will participate in every stage. We will ensure regular communication among all stakeholders and jointly celebrate successes. By aligning water security plans with existing government schemes (Jal Jeevan Mission) and programs, we will also facilitate efforts to ensure that community institutions and their representatives receive government acknowledgement to access water security financing. Within communities, we will apply Elinor Ostroms principles to strengthen community-based institutions. We recognize that based on data collected and analyzed, these principles may be modified to fit the Sundarbans challenges such as cyclones. We will embed possibilities for modifications. Participatory planning along with building capacity of local communities will result in the development of evidence-based water security plans with local community leaders conducting water budgeting, identifying potential recharge areas, and/or expanding traditional water harvesting practices. In addition to these activities, demonstration models complete with freshwater harvesting or aquifer recharge solutions will be completed in select villages of Patharpratima and Gosaba blocks. Informed by data and depending on community consensus, solutions could include land shaping for furrow and high ridge cultivation, Five Square water harvesting structures that PRASARI has implemented in Gosaba, aquifer storage and recovery systems, and/or rooftop rainwater harvesting systems with tanks. In general, PGWM may seem like a niche topic. But at its core, PGWM builds capacities of communities to map and manage their own resources, generates local employment (e.g., barefoot hydrogeologists), and empowers local communities to make data-driven decisions. Our initial projections suggest that about 200 barefoot hydrogeologists and the corresponding 1,000 water and sanitation committees will participate. It's important to note that this is a preliminary estimation, and the final figures may vary. Oak Application Form     10Oak Foundation's investment in PGWM will show the multi-faceted successful outputs of this approach to strengthen IWRM, allowing other large funders to leverage this water-focused method to achieve their outcomes related to job creation, community development, and climate change adaptation. The three organizations (Water For People, PRASARI, and Akvo) work with several donors that are interested in climate-water-food nexus and/or livelihood development, such as Caterpillar Foundation, Welthungerhilfe (WHH), Axis Bank Foundation (ABF), and Ajim Premji Philanthropic Foundation. We also work closely with global knowledge platforms like World Water Quality Alliance and Water Point Data Exchange, which have a keen interest in the Sundarbans, SDGs and specifically water quality. There are also talks with donors that are showing interest in citizen engagement, data-based decision making and collective action. We will leverage Water For Peoples Technical Support Unit and embedded staff in West Bengals state government and agreement with the Public Health and Engineering Department (in Birbhum and South 24 Parganas District) to ensure government convergence in this program.  We also propose to establish a multi-stakeholder platform that includes local Civil Society Organizations (CSOs), such as Oak Partners, in collaboration with Water For People, PRASARI, and Akvo. The objective of this platform would be to facilitate learning, sharing, implementation, and scaling up of the interventions within and beyond the project locations. We propose to conduct an annual sharing workshop with our partners to provide a more detailed update on the results and the processes followed to arrive at those results. In this workshop, we will encourage feedback from the partners and use this as an opportunity for cross learning.

GAF_A_Water_For_People_StrenIntegWaterMa.8. COOPERATION: 8. COOPERATION  How will you involve others in your approach to achieving change? If you are planning to engage in partnerships with other organisations, communities, people with lived experience, academics or secure the support of key individuals, please tell us about this.  Why are these the right partners to engage with?  Is there anything new about how you are choosing to work - for example, new partnerships or an approach that is different to how you usually work? (300 words):Water For People India has been working in West Bengal/ the Sundarbans for 20+ years. PRASARI, our partner in this region for 10+ years, works closely with local communities. PRASARI is currently working with Water For People in four blocks in West Bengal, with communities on improving water services, integrating water resources management, rainwater Oak Application Form     14harvesting and building recharge structures. Akvo Foundation and Water For People have a decade-old partnership across the globe generating evidence for program decision making. As program lead, Water For People India will lead project design, establish learning processes, liaise with Oak Foundation and relevant government departments, communicate regularly to all stakeholders, create policy and public facing communications, and submit required reports. We will also leverage our relationship with West Bengals state government to link these communities to government resources.  PRASARI will support on-ground implementation. PRASARI will focus on strengthening social capital, building community capacity while incorporating traditional knowledge, facilitating aquifer mapping, water budgeting, and water security planning. It will apply Ostroms principles for management of commons1, modifying as necessary and developing processes that can sustain momentum after the project has ended. In early stages of community interactions with local administration, PRASARI will act as a facilitator. Akvo is our technology and data partner, using appropriate technology to help us to report and build evidence. Local communities will use Akvos tools to collect data and information. Akvo will analyze data, summarize findings, indicate trends, and develop data visualizations that Water For People and PRASARI will use for community engagement and to promote policy and model scale up. Akvo will work closely with Water For People to develop documentation useful for replicating and scaling up this program in similar contexts.  Additionally, Water For People and Prasari will leverage their other donors working in West Bengal that are interested in the climate-water-food nexus and/or livelihood development, such as Caterpillar Foundation and Ajim Premji Philanthropic Foundation.  We will also establish a multi-stakeholder platform that includes local CSOs, such as Oak Foundation Partners, in collaboration with Water For People, PRASARI, and Akvo. The objective of this platform would be to facilitate learning, sharing, implementation, and scaling up of the interventions within and beyond the project locations. We will work with these stakeholders (Oak partners and non-Oak partners) from the very beginning to identify the operational villages and ensure integration with other issues from the outset. The operational villages will be selected based on the vulnerability mapping of the Gram Panchayats (an administrative unit that represents a cluster of villages). To conduct vulnerability mapping, a participatory tool will be used to assess 15 indicators distributed across four categories: Social, Climatic, Institutional and Economic.  Social:  i. Ratio of Schedule Caste, Schedule Tribal & Other Backward Caste(s) ration to total population, ii. Literacy Rate, iii. Rate of migration to total no of families, iv. Ratio of total number of toilet blocks to total number of households. Climate: i. Ratio of vulnerable river embankment to total embankment, ii. Climatic disaster impact ratio (Ratio of number of disaster(s) in a Oak Application Form     15particular year with average number of climate disaster in last 10 years, iii. Ratio of total submergent area to total area. Institutional: i. Rate of migration to total number of families, ii. Child mortality rate, iii. Participation of women to the labor force, iv. Average number of families dependent on drinking water from tube wells, v. Ratio of average distance from school, Panchayat and hospital to national average. Economic:  i. Ratio of mono-cropped and double cropped area, ii. Ratio of waterborne diseases to non-communicable diseases, iii. UN Household Dietary Diversity Score,  iv. Average income from farm-based livelihoods and manufacturing + service sector.These indications have been carefully outlined, agreed upon in public forums, and weighed uniformly. In addition, it is evaluated using a 5-point Likert scale, with the combined scores for each metric serving as the final evaluation. Gram Panchayats (GP) with a score of less than 2.5 are at risk of vulnerability. If a vulnerable GP is identified, all its corresponding revenue villages will be included for implementation. As GPs are clusters of villages without further assessment, we incorporate all the revenue villages of a vulnerable GP for action.??
GAF_A_Water_For_People_StrenIntegWaterMa.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING This section is twofold. Please tell us:a) Monitoring and evaluation. How will you know if you are achieving your objectives? Please describe briefly how you will know if you are making progress and if what you are doing is working. If you have a formal monitoring and evaluation system and if you plan to collect indicator data or conduct an external evaluation, please provide details here.b) Learning. Please tell us if there anything in particular that you are hoping to learn more about or test through this grant.(300 words):The project team (Water For People, PRASARI and Akvo) will employ effective MEL mechanisms (includes practices and tools) that provides a structured approach to track project progress, assess impact, and foster continuous learning in a comprehensive and meaningful way.  The following points describe our approach: - We will jointly design theory and pathways of change to create a logical framework to understand how our intended project activities will lead to the desired outcomes and impact. This step is critical as it underpins every aspect of the proposed project's implementation, monitoring, and evaluation. During the design step, we will develop results framework, a high-level Oak Application Form     16structure, that outlines the project's objectives, outcomes, indicators, activities, inputs, and assumptions in a concise manner. - We will flesh-out an Monitoring & Evaluation (M&E) framework from the project results framework focused on how monitoring and evaluation will be conducted to track progress. We will develop a well-structured monitoring plan to transform the M&E framework into actionable steps by outlining the methodologies, responsibilities, timelines, and resources required for effective project monitoring. At project inception, the team will outline data needs and data use (for reporting, community, dissemination, advocacy, and decision making) based on the M&E framework. To measure progress and impact accurately, the project team will jointly design and implement baseline and endline assessments. For concurrent monitoring, the team will design data collection instruments (qualitative and quantitative) aligned with the indicators and ensure these are user-friendly and capture the required information accurately. Additionally, we will leverage on Water For People's current resources, including internal tracking spreadsheets, biannual reports, and the Sustainable Services Checklist for water and sanitation. Our approach involves enhancing such existing data and processes to optimize their effectiveness for the proposed project.  - We will employ real-time (near real-time) progress tracking of key performance indicators and milestones to gain insights into how the project is advancing toward its set targets across the time and space of the project context. We will use technology and data to provide up-to-date information about the project's status, enabling swift decision-making and adjust strategies/activities based on real-time data and learning. Akvo will enable a centralized web-based platform to monitor project data and prepare a predictive analysis model/simulation for forecasting conditions that impact water sources and make informed decisions about the sustainability of their water sources.  - We will integrate Data-Driven Insights into project operations to conduct realistic assessment of project achievements and challenges and incorporate a learning component in the project plan. These insights will reveal trends, patterns, and areas of improvement in the project.  We will also use these insights to develop adaptive strategies and refine our approach during project implementation. These may include insights that help us assess what elements of our interventions are working and if there is a need to improve/change project activities and/or intervention logic. The project team will utilize appropriate analytical techniques to derive and present insights using compelling visualizations to enhance understanding and communicate project findings to project stakeholders in a clear and accessible manner.  In a broader sense, these monitoring insights will contribute to the collective learning of all project stakeholders, including the project donor. Additionally, the project team will create learning documentation to be shared with Oak Foundation partners both within the current project area and in other regions. We will jointly conduct the baseline and endline assessments.  Akvo will develop a web-based platform to track project data and also prepare a predictive analysis model/simulation for forecasting conditions that impact water sources and make informed decisions about the sustainability of their water sources. We will also build on Water For Peoples existing tools, such as the Sustainable Services Checklist for water and sanitation which includes Oak Application Form     1711 indicators with specific criteria to meet, particularly for Water Resources Management.  We anticipate that by adopting a participatory approach, villages will teach all partners about the challenges they face and solutions they may have already attempted. We will apply these learnings to demonstrate models for interventions. Learnings in the form of reports and policy briefs will be shared with Block, District and State administration officials to identify the implementation issues and to gain buy-in on successful models. Learnings in the form of blogs, success stories will be shared on different social media platforms. Water For People will also share data with World Water Quality Alliance and Water Point Data Exchange and results with wider audiences as relevant such as during World Water Week and the All Systems Connect symposium. We will create a culture of using data for decision making and ensure community engagement and active participation in water security planning by implementing the following strategies:? At the projects outset, we will engage community members to collaboratively design the water security plans within the project's regions. This approach ensures ownership, cultivates awareness, and familiarizes them with the nuances of the planning process. Our intent is to create a culture of using data to make decisions and align incentives (improving water security, lives and livelihoods) to sustain the habit beyond the tenure of a project.? We will ensure the project data about the water security planning process is transformed into simple, clear and actionable information that local communities and their governments (GP, block and district) can understand and utilize to make key water management decisions. Water user communities will be involved in the design of data collection and analysis process (what data to collect, who would do the analysis, in what form the analyzed data will be available to make decisions). Based on the user feedback, we will create a set of quantitative and qualitative tools. Local communities will be trained to field test the tools, give feedback, and help improve the tools. We will also engage members of local communities (Self Help Groups and other community-based organizations) to collect the actual data, be involved during the analysis and present the data back to their fellow community members.? We will ensure communities are actively involved in the periodic (most likely annual) updates of water security plans to ensure that the plans remain relevant, effective, and aligned with the evolving needs and priorities of the community.??

Core Support  Yes:_/No:_ No4b (ii)?. Project involves Contact with Children  Yes:_/No:_Yes4c. Grant period:Start date:(dd/mon/yy)End date:4d. Currency: INR4e. Total Project Cost:4299214 4f.
