Summarise the projects ultimate goal(s) (maximum 200 words):( NOT REQUIRED FOR CORE SUPPORT GRANTS)The projects ultimate goal to enable identified groups of people in Sunderban to come together to diagnose their vulnerabilities , articulate aspiration  and avenue of change and produce a plan for acting upon vulnerabilities as well as achieving highest standard of cooperation among collaborating organisations, leading to deep institutionalisation of values of partnership and commitment for the community-led approaches to development.  In India, Sunderbans lies in the vast delta on the Bay of Bengal formed by the super confluence of the Ganges, Brahmaputra and the Meghna rivers. The place has always earned a special interest in the world map because of its uniqueness of the Mangrove forests and the lifestyle of the local inhabitants. People have been mostly dependent on agriculture and fishing. Owing to recent climatic changes, there is evidence of livelihood dearth adding to increasing vulnerability amongst all sections of the inhabitants. Interventions and support from the various local level organizations, government schemes have remained detrimental to the development of this area. Day-by-day, people are becoming increasingly dependent on immediate support rather than making themselves more reliant and capacitated by participating in sustainable processes of growth and development.Among the 15 Blocks in the South 24 Parganas district of West Bengal, Pathar Pratima is one of the largest blocks and known as one of the critical blocks in terms of adverse social issues. The various publications and researches have pointed towards the increasing adversities related to human trafficking, increasing migration, insufficient alternatives to livelihood, frequent disasters in this block leading to severe adverse consequences on all section of inhabitants.Herambagopalpur Gram Panchayat is located in the northern side of the Patharpratima Block. The size of the area is about 868.3 hectares. It comprises 4 main villages, namely, Heramba Gopalpur, Dakshin Kashinagar, Kuemuri and Purba Surendranagar. Kuemuri in the Dakshin Kashinagar in the South-East surrounds Heramba Gopalpur along the Matla river. A total of 17 Sansads are included in these 4 villages.Due to its deltaic location, the river network forms the major transport system of this area and people are dependent on the river both for transportation and livelihood. Being located in the deltaic region, the rivers here are tidal in nature. The area remains flooded mostly during the rainy season and the situation worsens at times of natural calamities. Breaching of river embankments, river bank erosion are thus very common phenomena here. All these natural calamities have an adverse effect on the people residing there. Remoteness and undeveloped infrastructural facilities add to irreparable damages of life and property.   MUKTI has been working for the underprivileged people in the Sundarban area since 2003. Interventions at Patharpratima Block by Mukti started almost 5-6 years back. More than 70 students in the Herambagopalpur GP are being benefited through the Mukti Support School Centres. The women empowerment programme focussing on developing entrepreneurship skills through the MCDF project includes almost 1200 women from the GP. Mukti aims to continue ongoing such initiatives to achieve sustainable development for these people.
GAF_MUKTI_AmpliCommuVoiceInPatha_2023103.4. GEOGRAPHY: 5.List the major countries where your activities take place. If this is global policy work, list as worldwide:Grant Application Form, July 1 20135India  (South Asia)
GAF_MUKTI_AmpliCommuVoiceInPatha_2023103.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 6. Context (The context section should not exceed two pages.)6a. Describe the organisation (include information on leadership, governance, structure and staff) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):MUKTI, is a non-profit socio-economic organization, working for the Sundarban people in the Delta region of South 24 Parganas, West Bengal, India since 2003. It is registered with the Government of India Trust Act 64 in the year 2005, Ministry of Corporate Affairs under CSR form 1, 12AA, 80G, TISS, FCRA (Foreign Contribution Regulation Act 1976) and ISO certifications in 2005 and is also supported by almost 74 enterprises. The organisation was started by a group of local youths who had gradually decided to develop the vision and lay the foundation for a sustainable development.Today, the organisation is spread across 54 Gram Panchayats in the whole of North and South 24 Parganas. The organisation has been working intensively with almost 50,000 households, 30,000 SHG women, 3500 children who are mostly in penury, social exclusion and myriad discrimination and are extremely vulnerable to climate hazards like strong storms, cyclic cyclone and frequent dreadful disasters adding to resource dearth, penury, vulnerability and violence. In addition to this, Mukti has provided scholarships to more than 2000 students for higher studies, planted 2.5 lac mangrove, created and provided livelihood opportunities to the local people. Mukti is governed by the Board of Trustees comprising of the Founder-President, Secretary, Assistant Secretary, Treasurer and other members. Each trustee in their roles, function with specific assigned responsibilities. Mukti has almost 35 Consultants directly working in different areas and capacities and more than 200 volunteers who are involved with the day-to-day functioning of the organisation. Each project team reports to the Programme Officer, President and Secretary for project implementation and planning. All activities are aimed towards community development and focusing on the most marginalized sections. Muktis works on the community led approach and beliefs that it is the best way to create sustainability.6b. Describe the financial situation (include information on annual operating costs, fundraising strategy, reserves and debts) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):In order to maintain a stable financial situation in the organisation, Mukti has developed its own financial policy to be adhered to by each and every concerned person. Mukti also shared the financial planning with every Project Coordinator to Grant Application Form, July 1 20136maintain the costs and avoid any discrepancies or over expenses or even any unnecessary expenses. To prevent any hindrance in regular project activities, majority of the donors of Mukti offer to transfer the whole amount after which utilisation is shared. This helps in meeting the gap in the other projects which transfers the funds almost like giving reimbursements to the organization after completion of the activities.The operation cost of each project is maintained with the line time and involves a major part of the budget. All operational costs requests are raised from time to time for seeking approval of the Secretary and thereafter expenses are made. Submission of the utilization is made as per the donor requirement at specified intervals and in specified formats.Fundraising has been an important aspect of Mukti. Since the previous year, Mukti has hired a qualified Consultant for CSR and Fundraising. All necessary information and updates on the projects are in knowledge of the fundraising expert which are shared with potential donors and grant givers. Face to face meetings, presentations and practical knowledge sharing, exploring scopes of fundraising through crowdfunding platforms are commonly practiced in Mukti.Mukti believes in utilizing the majority of the amount for the activities rather than maintaining a huge amount for contingency. Any odd situations / financial crisis in the organisation have been faced with help of the team members. Mukti does not request for any such miscellaneous funds and tries to keep the requests very defined.6c. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):Though a young institution of more than 17 years, MUKTI, a non-profit socio-economic organization, working for Sundarban people in the Delta region of South 24 Parganas, West Bengal, India, has accumulated a lot of accolades.It was in the year 2003 when a few enthusiastic young minds of Sunderban became determined to redress some of the most intrinsic problems involving education and health. They decided to involve the educated and energetic local youth in the various community development projects. These youths gradually started developing the vision and finally laid the foundation of MUKTI. The local people supported them in this quench and the services continued and grew every year paving its way for a sustainable development for these marginalised people.  The commendable job by the team has been broadcasted by BBC Worldwide service and the Dadagiri show. The organization has received various accolades like Vivek Samman award, Star of Asia award, Bharat Excellence award, Krishi Ratna, APJ Abdul Kalam award, True legend award by Telegraph, AmiCare award on livelihood. The work of the organisation is visible in various national and international platforms and in state newspapers.  Today, MUKTI has been able to spread its wings in almost every state and country. Hundreds of volunteers have become associated with us and are supporting our noble cause. Our volunteers are involved with providing expertise knowledge to fund raising and also to work with the people directly in the field. Educational institutions have reached out to Mukti for placements and internships for building a strong foundation among their students entitled with social commitment and values.Grant Application Form, July 1 201376d. Describe the current strategy of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):Mukti is already developing strategy to explore new geographical areas and exploring feasibility of new initiatives as per community requirement. The organization will be expanding to other districts in West Bengal in the next few months. With this, our organization is also focusing on reaching out to the maximum population who are very deserving and need support. Mukti believes in maximizing quality initiatives which will directly impact the beneficiaries. And to learn from them how projects may be implemented as all the communities are dynamic in nature and have their own individualities. It is important for us to develop strategy accordingly. The current strategy also involves capacitating the team for better understanding of the realities and efficient outcome. In order to get timely outputs, responsibilities are well decentralized amongst the team members and regular meetings and field visits are a continuous process of the strategy. This is not only at the ground level but also at the Board level where each Trustee has definite function to do in their own roles. Mukti invites volunteers and interns and respects their interest in social work. They are involved and assigned with specific tasks as per their expertise, interest and convenience which helps in the development of strong values among the youngsters. Regular information sharing through newsletters, press releases are an important part of the work to reach out to more and more people. Already many associations, national and international have joined hands with Mukti for the commendable initiatives. It has been our strategy to upkeep these and share all updates about the organisation from time to time.6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):Mukti is working towards an enabling environment for the community people so that these people are capacitated in such a way that they are able to identify their vulnerabilities and address them to reduce their vulnerability. In the process of doing that, Mukti has helped the community people to identify their own problems and people have been able to come up with solutions related to livelihood, dearth in resources, disaster preparedness, gender equality, education, health, adolescent problems and at the same time have also been able to identify ways to mitigate them from their own levels. These problems are related to agriculture, fishing and honey collection and how improvement can be brought into them. Community people have discussed about gender discrimination, evidence of drop out among school children, absence of basic health facilities in the communities, especially for women, impact of frequent disasters and how important is disaster preparedness essential in the community along with problems of deforestation and was to address them. As observed by Mukti, it is crucial to develop the insight among the community people to identify these as problems and strengthen their capacities to help them address them.For  fulfilling the objectives of the project, Mukti has also identified lots of opportunities. Firstly, there is ample scope to involve youths and volunteers from the communities having understanding of the dynamics of the  community and Grant Application Form, July 1 20138making them learn and develop skills to lead the community development initiatives.  Secondly, this project creates opportunities for networking partnerships among other grass root organizations and resource organizations which has a great scope for learning and understanding issues better.  Thirdly, the project has a good scope of adapting to the community needs rather than creating any unnecessary imposition on the community people. This is a great opportunity to understand the socio-economic-cultural contexts of the community and accordingly plan with them the future steps.While working in the community, Mukti has observed certain challenges as well. Firstly, it has been noticed that the community people are very much influenced by the local politicians in each and every step. All schemes, provisions are very much influenced by the politicians and the community is divided into  privileged and the underprivileged. Secondly, frequent disasters have hampered the functioning of the community severely. Everytime, such disasters have been havoc and people have lost everything. It is very difficult for the community people to re-start, even though that becomes difficult because of the severe financial crunch. Thirdly, the current pandemic situation has not improved overall in the rural areas. People restrain outsiders from coming inside, many have lost jobs, demoralized and uncertain when the situation will improve and if there will be any scope to get back to work. The pandemic has jeopardized the families leading to precipitating other adverse social issues. Fourthly, the capacity of the community people in terms of motivation and willingness has severely been hit by the various calamities and other factors in the community. Hence, the outcomes expected are long term and have to undergo continuous process

CooperationDescribe the level of cooperation with other organisations and networks and explain how this cooperation helps achieve your goals (maximum 300 words):The project demands cooperation with other grass root organisations working with similar goals in the neighbouring hubs of the same block. Hence, even if there is a clear demarcation of no geographical overlapping, yet the project develops lots of scopes for learning and understanding the communities from various angles. This will help to plan the activities accordingly and in a similar line encompassing the majority of the inclusion of the project goal. The organisation will have exchange of ideas and best approaches will be applied for better outcomes with cooperation from other organisations and networks. Such actions will also bring about quality in the work rather than focussing only on the quantity and the mass. Cooperation and networking will also help in understanding each others limitations and support required from the other partners. It will also help our organisation to speak openly about the issues and the problems and help us to seek expert advice from the partners in addressing those. This creates a scope of learning for our organisation and establishing a good rapport with each other

(maximum 300 words):Through the project, Mukti aims to re-instill the leadership within the community.  The project will create confidence among the leaders to be more understanding and empathetic towards the community's fellow feelings, develop understanding on the dynamics of the community for all perspectives and motivate people to come together to bring in change. These leaders, in turn, will gradually develop more and more insights towards the  community issues and take steps Grant Application Form, July 1 201313together. In the process, they will be able to effectively communicate and also develop vision  similarly for others.  For every activity, leaders will be able to bring in people together. Ideas from the leaders will be accepted and it is likely that people will come together to make those realize10. EvaluationHow will progress be monitored and evaluated? (maximum 300 words):Core committee including all community-representatives of the village will review all the activities to implement the whole project. This will happen through community participation. In this process, the community will influence and execute the development projects rather than just be beneficiaries. Here  Mukti will be committed for undertaking and facilitating with the community , such meetings will be chaired by community people.

(maximum 300 words):The grant is going to influence the organisation in a bigger way. Initially, this grant creates a lot of scope of understanding the communities and the people from various angles. Thus, it aims to develop a good document at hand for referring to any point of time for planning and implementing any activity to create a meaningful impact. Grant Application Form, July 1 201314The grant has a good scope of developing various capacities of the community people and the team which will help to develop insights on the various issues in the communities. This will help the organisation to  examine and understand any  issue with well developed insights and accordingly develop plans to mitigate them.The grant also creates ample scope for sustainability. The process involved with starting the initiatives has been so deep that the actions and initiatives will surely take us to the path of sustainability. It creates more opportunities to take next steps for the community, help community people to choose their strategies, looking for development seeking areas, and so on. The long term effects will go beyond the services which are done by the community people or other organizations.The grant will help to understand the failures, positive outcomes, lessons learnt.

GAF_Indraprastha_Srijan_Welfare_Society_.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 6. Context (The context section should not exceed two pages.)6a. Describe the organisation (include information on leadership, governance, structure and staff) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):GOVERNANCE : The governing body meeting is held quarterly with participation of its members maintaining quorum (2/3rd) to discuss and decide on the current activities done, performances of the staff, community response and the stakeholders opinion, what should be the fund raising strategy to continue the programme, inter-organisational strategy, network with resource and funding agencies, regarding documentation and monitoring etc. For this purpose, what will be the responsibilities of the governing body members? And the problems and issues presently the organisation facing both internal and external and what will be probable solutions are discussed thoroughly and decided unanimously. For any emergency interim and special meeting is also convened by the secretary as convenor. The annual general meeting is also held annually to discuss on the annual activities carried out during the last year and the last year annual receipts and payments as depicted in annual audited statement, the assets and the reserves and liabilities, almost all the general members take part. It is also decided on the appointment of auditor for the next financial year. The collective leadership is practiced in the organisation.Communication flows from the bottom to upwards as well as from the top to down. As deliverables/ MIS, every volunteer reports to the respective upper level and field facilitator reports to programme coordinator on daily basis after collecting the report from the field. Staff meeting is organised monthly. The programme coordinator, upper level management also monitor the activities to review as per plan on regular basis. Organisation has equipped office premises and training centre with the capacity of 30 participants (non-residential) at its registered address. A Grant Application Form, July 1 20135team of 7 (3 Females and 4 Males) staff experienced in the field of social development and many volunteers are associated with this organisation.6b. Describe the financial situation (include information on annual operating costs, fundraising strategy, reserves and debts) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):The annual operating cost of the organization is INR 14, 40,000.00 (approx.). The amount of reserves is INR 3,11,050.00 and the amount of debt is nil.There is fund raising strategy in our organization. A team of fund raising is formed and updated always with information of different sources of funds from local, national and abroad. They are being equipped with the required skills, knowledge and specialization. Setting a realistic long term targets usually for one year and developing a transformation statement cultivating donor retention, trying to track and leverage fund from government, individual donor, membership fees, private donations, grants from non-profit organizations etc.    The expected changes regarding the financial situation of the organization is to increase the total project cost (programme and administrative cost) by 50 % in the coming year.6c. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):Indraprastha Srijan Welfare Society (ISWS) came in force in 2005 and registered in 2009. It was initially intervening in Pathar Pratima block area with its mission of environment friendly farm base sustainable livelihoods programmes and activities. The activities were towards reaching the better livelihood of the rural community. Now it has developed its mission, added new strategy to ensure participation of the vulnerable community in their process of development, emphasizing on development of human potentials with natural leadership and capacity building help to create an enabling environment to raise voices towards exercising rights and entitlements with leadership from their own.Achievements:a.Nutrition Gardening:SHGs members are well acquainted with sustainable agriculture includes-vermi composting, integrated and organic pest management, mixed and integrated farming, floating gardening, fish rearing, animal husbandry and practicing accordingly using local and natural resources in an environment friendly manner.b.Grain Bank:Adult males and females members from economically poorest 20-25 households are Grant Application Form, July 1 20136organized to form a group and motivated to set up grain bank as they feel the need of food security. Rules and regulation is framed by the members themselves for its effective functioning. Members can take loan from the bank without mortgaging any asset or labour during lean period or natural calamities. The group members save a portion of their crop (usually 50 kg.) in the grain bank.Integrated Farming:Diversified self-supporting farming system that integrates at least production of 5-6 types of crops, 9-10 kinds of vegetables, the trees yield food, fuel and fodder, medicinal plants, 2-3 kinds of animal- bird- fish at a time with the help of an innovated land shaping. It is mostly suitable for the marginal farmers of agro-ecologically vulnerable areas like Sundarban, which makes them self-reliant6d. Describe the current strategy of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):The current strategies are like:1. To create a model of development in rural base and replicate the same to address the vulnerability in other areas.7. Acquire expertise in different issues and context and expansion of activities, where needed.Vision of the organization is to develop self-sustained society with improved living of the marginalized community irrespective of religion, caste, sex, colour, creed through participatory planning on development of human potentials and sustainable usage of local and natural resources, enabling them to cope up with the challenging situation of natural calamities, climate resilience livelihood, issues of women and child, rights and entitlements.Mission is developing life and sustainable livelihood model for the poor and marginalised community through strengthening the peoples organisation with natural leadership on their rights and entitlements linking with government schemes and programmes, their strategic empowerment to adapt with the critical situation.Values Statement :Ensure Community Participation in vulnerability assessment, micro planning, implementation and monitoringCommunity leadership developmentGrant Application Form, July 1 20137Gender equalityIntegrityAssurance to Innovation and ExcellenceTransparencyCommitment to Environment Protection and Sustainability6e. GAF_A_Kamonohashi_TaftePreveNext_2023103.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT 5a. Tell us about your governance and leadership structures, as well as staff and volunteer base. Highlight any significant recent or expected future changes. If you have an explicit approach to increasing diversity and/or advancing race equity within the organisation, please tell us. (300 words):The Trustees shall constitute the Board of Trustees (the Board) of Kamonohashi Project, and they shall monitor the business of the Organization in accordance with the provisions of the Articles of Incorporation and the decisions of the Board.  The Board is responsible for managing and supervising the Secretary General (SG) and the Directors to ensure that they are properly executing their duties in accordance with the decisions made at the General Assembly (GA). The Board shall also make recommendations, advice, supervision, and decisions on resolutions and reports proposed by SG and the Directors with the aim of improving the management of the organization. With regard to the recruitment of the Trustees, the Board shall recommend the candidates to GA, and GA shall appoint the trustee among those candidates. The tenure of the Board is 2 years, and currently 6 members (list as per below) holds the position in the Board. The Board holds meetings on quarterly basis, in addition to any special meetings that the Head of the Board deems necessary. All the meeting minutes are kept as official records.There are 21 people (including 7 Indian members who are hired through third-party payroll service, Attachment A) working as full time, while 6 people work in Japan office as part-time. Kamo has a wide volunteer base called Kamo Caf in Japan, which was organized and formed in 2010 and registers 1,000 people in Japan at present as volunteers. Kamo Caf is managed by 10 volunteer leaders and supports Kamonohashi Project to mobilize the monthly subscribed supporters as well as to bridge the communication between Kamo and the general public in Japan through visibility building and support to fundraising. 5b. Summarise the organisations history.  In addition, highlight 2-3 key achievements.Oak Application Form     6Please keep this brief and list up to 3 key achievements as bullet points. Even though you may have many achievements, please share what is most relevant to the proposed grant. (300 words)Kamonohashi Project was founded in 2002 in Japan, aiming at combatting human trafficking of children for commercial sexual exploitation in the world. It started the projects in Cambodia where the child trafficking for commercial sexual exploitation was rampant, and it focused (1) to build community-based factory for the most vulnerable populations in rural Cambodia not to take the risk of unsafe migration, and (2) to support police training to strengthen the prosecution against traffickers. With the gradual shift of the issue, Kamo embarked on the global field study and concluded to support India in 2012. Kamos support in India aims to strengthen access to justice by the survivors of human trafficking through systems strengthening approach. Kamo facilitates breaking polarization in development debates through dialogue and deep listening. Kamo also strongly believes in leadership development in survivors and among organizational founders and second line leaders to strengthen the ecosystem of the civil society. In 2022, after three-year internal dialogue, Kamo decided to shift from mission-driven to the principle-based organization, and the new principle, Dignity for All, was approved by its General Assembly. Key achievements are;1. Kamo handed over the Cambodia Programme to build further social leadership programme using the community-based factory. This process was handled professionally with financial transaction, and this type of business succession was of a rare case in the Japanese social sector;2. Kamo built, nurtured and supported Tafteesh Programme since 2013, and Tafteesh received the Stop Slavery Collaboration Award from the Thomson Reuters Foundation in 2022;Kamo is supported by 14,999 subscribed supporters as of May 2023. The fundraising model of Kamo is recognized as successful and unique in Japanese civil societies. The donations from those individual supporters have been enabling Kamo to design and support strategic programmes based on the contextual needs in India.5c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and decide your approach? If you have undertaken a theory of change exercise, or if you are influenced by research, policy or your own organisations experience, please tell us about this.  Have you consulted with relevant stakeholders, including your communities and others experiencing the problem? Is there an intention to address equity, diversity and inclusion? (600 words):Secondary Research on Global Prevention of Human Trafficking (Balu et al, 2021) under the last phase of Tafteesh revealed that (1) prevention of human trafficking is defined in a highly varied manner, depending upon the approach to human trafficking, (2) vulnerability to trafficking may show a stronger correlation with relative poverty rather than absolute poverty, (3) communities and systems sustain vulnerability through permissive Oak Application Form     7environment that prevent quick identification of victims, and (4) the research calls for ecological, holistic and multidisciplinary approaches, reiterating that single-focused interventions will not impact the overall vulnerability of populations that are at risk of trafficking (Attachment 3).Preventing Trafficking: Sustainable developmental solutions to combat trafficking (Change Mantras, 2021) under the last phase of Tafteesh also clarified that (1) there is no cogent policy on prevention of trafficking either in India or other parts of the world, (2) most anti trafficking programmes focus on responses to trafficking, rather than pre-emptively seeking to mitigate or prevent exploitations or violations that lead to trafficking, and (3) interventions are largely community based and making parents more responsible to prevent their children from being trafficked, and they lack the clarity of responsibility of duty-bearers such as district administration, panchayat and police in prevention (Attachment 4).West Bengal is reportedly one of the most affected states by human trafficking and has been a high prevalence state according to the National Crime Records (Attachment C). Existing anti trafficking policies, laws or programmes, by the government or NGOs do not seem to have created any dent on the prevalence. Anti trafficking interventions have long focused on responsive initiatives - rehabilitation of survivors, reparation and penalisation of offenders. Even though all instruments on human trafficking to address prevention, there are, in fact, very few policies, laws or programmes that are focused on prevention, not only in West Bengal, but across India.Tafteesh is one of the largest and most significant civil society led anti trafficking initiative in India today, that has mobilised and organised survivors of sex trafficking in North and South 24 Parganas in West Bengal and have succeeded in establishing survivor led initiatives in claiming rehabilitation and protection services from local governments, administration and health service providers, claiming compensation and assert rights to accountability from law enforcement agencies, legal services authorities and the judicial system in prosecution of traffickers. This led to the question - now that community based organisations and survivor collectives in these two districts that have become empowered to design and take action, how would it address the gap in absence of any preventative measures on human trafficking?The Preventing Trafficking research indicated distinguishable patterns and differences in opinion on effective prevention between youth and adults, state duty bearers and common people. The research also identified information gaps in areas of labour trafficking, trafficking in men and boys, trafficking in transgender persons as well as underlying factors that explain higher vulnerability amongst people from scheduled caste and Muslims[1].The opportunities emerged through the last two phases to build on this prevention piece is the survivor collectives, people who are victims of labour trafficking seeking support services, the enhanced capacities of the NGOs, the wide network of Tafteesh which include established connections with the legal, law enforcement and other relevant departments. This request from Oak Foundation is to enable Tafteesh to build on and implement diverse and unique prevention approaches relevant to local contexts based on rights-based and community-based initiatives in West Bengal.Oak Application Form     8[1] That Muslims and SC have a disproportionate vulnerability was claimed by social workers, activists and survivors who participated in the research, based on their own experiences, data and observations.

Psychological and emotional resilience of adolescents directly addressed through this intervention will improve by 60% as a result of improved parenting practices, building resources for the community on building childrens safety and protection from trafficking. 70% of the parents and other adults engaged with in this intervention will demonstrate responsive parenting and take concrete measures to protect their children from being trafficked.2. Participation of marginalised communities in governance agenda setting will improve by 50%, resulting in District administration and Panchayats increased awareness of their vulnerabilities to trafficking and  will become responsive taking measures that will address the contributory factors to human trafficking in these communities.3. Violence against gender variant boys in their families, communities and schools will reduce by 40% as a result of increased protection systems such as support group of parents, school committees to address violence against gender variant boys as well as a shift in attitudes towards these boys amongst parents, teachers, peers and other guardians as well as neighbours, reporting of incidents of sexual abuse and violence will be increased by 20% to the Panchayats and/or police.4. Panchayats, police, block and district administrations awareness on the prevalence of human trafficking in the communities, other than sex trafficking for girls and women, will increase by 50% leading to and increase in responsiveness from these offices for prevention.7.c. Increase in the number of initiatives taken of Panchayats, District Administration and Police to address vulnerability of SC, ST and Muslim communities to sex trafficking and labour trafficking, as well as forced migration of stigmatised individuals, including gender variant boys; and3. Increase in actions taken by district administration, law enforcement, labour department and the Panchayats to regulate labour migration operators who operate in the project area;Monitoring approach: (1) baseline and endline survey to track measurable changes as expected from the outcome indicators, (2) each partner organisation to have its own M/E framework based on the project focus aligned with the indicators in this proposal, (3) project management team, comprising of managers and project officers, to visit project sites and conduct participatory review and assessments, (4) MIS to be developed and used by the project participants (youth and adult leaders of the community) to build aggregate data on progress, challenges and solutions, (5) annual assessment to identify innovations and experiments (successes and failures) to strengthen learning agenda of this programme.Learning questions;1. GAF_A_Kamonohashi_TaftePreveNext_2023103.11. ADDITIONAL QUESTIONS/ Future Plans: 11.  ADDITIONAL QUESTIONSPlease use this space to respond to any specific questions from your Oak programme officer. If none were received, please leave this section blank. 1. How will this phase ensure that the survivor groups play a larger role in defining strategy and interventions undertaken by Tafteesh. Please highlight the strategic approaches and processes through which the survivor groups will have enhanced participation in designing and implementing the prevention approaches.(a) Tafteesh member organisations will conduct refresher trainings and workshops with survivors to help them understand Tafteesh and a programme, its goals, objectives and activities, (b) share the monthly or quarterly cumulative reports with them to increase their understanding, (c) the Programme Manager gets workshops done with the survivors collectives to identify their critiques and recommendations, and lastly, (d) each member organisation shall implement the monitoring recommendations that come from survivors from these workshops. 2. As the Anti-Trafficking legislation currently pending in parliament, what will be the TMCs strategy to ensure that all groups (survivors, sex workers etc.) voices are factored in the legislation? This we understand is a larger objective of TMC and ties into the prevention domain. So therefore the application should outline the broad strategies on this.The three broad strategies: (a) support ILFAT to raise demand for legal reform with funding to build the narrative, (b) support allies to get domestic funding to renew litigation in the Supreme Court using research on impact of ITPA and Oak Application Form     14section 370, the litigation may be filed by any of the survivors, and (c) support Vimukthi to establish to its action in Andhra Pradesh on co-holding sex workers' rights agenda with the agenda of trafficked victims, and support them and the state government to take it to the centre. 3. What is the arrangement and why such a mode of engagement is followed? Please address this question in the Additional Questions  Section 11.Based on the risk assessment studies done by four legal and consulting firms in India in 2018 and 2019, Kamos Board decided to hire all team members as full-time consultants through third party payroll service. This has been practiced by multiple international foundations as well as UN agencies for decades, and this is a part of Kamos risk-mitigation strategies when it does not have any registered office in India. Strategic Alliance Management Services Ltd. (https://www.sams.co.in/) is the contract holder of all Kamo India team members, and Kamo and SAMS are in this arrangement since 2020. 4. About Tafteesh Organizational Mission and HistoryTafteesh was formed in a response to its action research conducted in 2013, and it is the platform of 6 social impact organisations, 2 legal teams, 12 member survivor collectives, Change Mantras (CM) for programme directorship and Kamonohashi Project (Kamo) as fund manager.  The platform has grown from 3 organisations and Kamonohashi to the current size with the annual budget increased from USD 45,680 to USD 447,335. Survivors are at the centre of the programme, and 246 survivors of trafficking as of May 2023 plays the role of collaborator, feedback provider, monitor and advisor to the Tafteesh Management Committee, as well as co-implementor and co-planner with grassroots NGOs and legal teams.Tafteesh is a Justice Programme for and with survivors of human trafficking, including children (girls and boys) and adults (women and men), for sexual exploitation and forced labour that aims to provoke state and national governments of India to develop policies, laws and systems and to allocate resources for rights of survivors and to protect rights of communities vulnerable to trafficking and exploitation in migration. For this mission, followings are the key achievements of Tafteesh;Development of Tafteeshs prevention strategy, theory of change (Attachment B) and objectives, based on the community-based research conducted by survivors and social activists;Stigma reduction in survivors, survivors have organised themselves into organisations and have formed Indias first survivors exclusive leadership forum called Indian Leadership Forum Against Trafficking (ILFAT) in 2019;Empowerment of CBOs in anti-trafficking programming. CBOs are skilled with case-management based practice, which enables CBOs to hold district administrations accountable. CBOs are also skilled to provide legal services to survivors both for victim compensation and prosecution of traffickers, making legal services available from DLSA and private lawyers, escalating dereliction of duties or faulty investigations in cases to High Court using protest petitions or appeal.Oak Application Form     15 5. Please state the factors behind prevalence of trafficking.Indias policy on rehabilitation is ineffective, with poor rates of trauma-recovery, economic security or social assimilation or protection from stigma. This systemic neglect alienates survivors from the State. Because India does not have a rehabilitation policy nationally or in any state, the role and accountability of duty bearers - Panchayats, administration, health departments remains fuzzy. This leaves survivors vulnerable to further violence in families and communities, and results in domestic violence and re-trafficking. Investigations of cases of human trafficking are handled by the general police stations with limited resources and structural support for interstate investigations. The chain of crime is not investigated or established leading to poor case for prosecution. The non functioning of Anti Human Trafficking Units leads to poor conviction rates to deter trafficking crimes across states over years. Poor rate of access of compensations by survivors is a result of lack of the implementation of victim compensation scheme by Legal Services Authorities across states. Due to the lack of prevention policy throughout the country, the roles and responsibilities of government duty-bearers to prevent human trafficking remains unclear to all. Lack of investment in survivors leadership in the sector lead to lack of inclusion of survivors as active agents in designing, implementing and monitoring interventions contributes to the fragmentation and also results in lack of ownership, sustainability and alignment of anti trafficking approaches with needs of communities vulnerable to trafficking. 6. Coverage of this Tafteesh Resilient Communities (including religious leaders, targeted group communities, PRI level stakeholders, survivor leaders, duty-bearers)12 blocks with 3,500 people approximately in South 24 Parganas, West Bengal15 blocks with 4,500 people approximately in North 24 Parganas, West Bengal 7. Additional learning questions pertaining to the overall Tafteesha) How common or distinctive are the labour trafficking prevention approaches with adult men and women as opposed to sex trafficking in children and women or trans-women?b) How strong is the prevalence of forced migration of gender variant boys and how vulnerable are they to trafficking?c) How prepared is the Panchayati system to community participation to address issues of prevention of human trafficking?

GAF_National_Centre_for_Advocacy_Studies.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 6. Context (The context section should not exceed two pages.)6a. Describe the organisation (include information on leadership, governance, structure and staff) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):NCAS is a membership based organisation, it began with an idea to make advocacy people centered, hence several stalwarts contributed to this collective idea of people centered advocacy. NCAS membership is both organizational and individuals, the board approves the memberships of the organisation and individuals. As per the rules of the organisation, the executive director or the National Co-ordinator are appointed by the board and report to the board. The executive director in consultation with the key functionaries of the board makes other appointments, like the senior program officer, program officer, researcher etc. The Executive Committee is headed by the president and assisted by the secretary and the treasurer, the other members of the board help in decision making process, largely related to the membership of the general body, funding, program strategy etc. As a research organisation the composition of the staff is expected to be that of researchers, research director, senior program manger, program officers- Admin and accounts persons. Independent consultants are hired for specific tasks when required.  Depending on the availability of funds in the future the staff capacity will be increased. Currently including the executive director there is a senior program officer, an admin person and a part time finance person.  Consultants are hired as requiredGrant Application Form, July 1 201356b. Describe the financial situation (include information on annual operating costs, fundraising strategy, reserves and debts) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):Currently the organisation has got just one small grant from Centre for budget governance and accountability- about 5,40,000/-. Some of the Indian funding groups have gotten in direct contract with our staff, which covers only program cost. Oak grant is the other foreign grant that we are dependent on. The annual operating cost for Admin, maintenance cost and Salary is about 30lakhs (With a small staff) the program cost and programmatic costs are about 20 lakhs. Funding is sought through RFPs, other announcements, partnership with organisation for training and capacity building, efforts towards achieving accreditations are being made. NCAS has also now moved towards an academics and has initiated short certificate courses for development sector professionals, students and individuals interested in public policy and advocacy, this is program for NCAS to increase its visibility and also sustain itself.  NCAS also has a corpus however the efforts of fund raising are made to ensure that the corpus is not depleted.6c. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):NCAS is a premiere policy research institution in India. NCAS was formed in 1992 by leading academics, jurists and social activists. since its inception, the Board of Directors is led by people of eminence with Justice P. N. Bhagwati, (former Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of India) as the founding President, followed by noted playwright Vijay Tendulkar and Dr. Aruna Roy, among others. Over the years, NCAS has gained recognition as a premiere institution in policy research and governance in India and global south. NCAS has over 29 years of experience in capacity development, knowledge creation, networking in public policy and governance in India and internationally. It has trained leaders in academia, journalism, policy think tanks in India and 30 countries in the world. NCAS believes proper policy and its governance can create huge differences in the lives of millions of people. NCAS pioneered the idea of people centered advocacy, enabling marginalized communities to participate in the process of policy advocacy.Since last 29 years, NCAS is actively engaged in capacity development, research and knowledge creation, campaign support, social movement and knowledge networking and media with a particular focus on the policy and governance from the lens of the marginalized.The Advocacy Internship Program, for building capacities of youth, was launched in 1999. A meticulously formulated curriculum to understand the complexities of the Indian condition  its social fabric, economics and politics  both academically and in the context of socio-cultural realities, guided this program for preparing youth in the praxis of people-centered advocacy it produced around 100 young leaders who are working in various positions in organizations from academics, media, policy think tanks and civil society organisations from grassroots to international level. NCAS has conducted evidence-based research on various issues especially tribal land rights and has published knowledge materials that were very useful for students, researchers and activists.  NCAS has initiated certificate courses on public policy and advocacy reaching out to more and more Grant Application Form, July 1 20136professionals who are interested in Public Policy.6d. Describe the current strategy of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):The scenario of the contemporary socio-political environment mandates that more than management and consultancy skills, a studied approach towards social change shall prove to be more beneficial. In this light the National Center for Advocacy Studies (NCAS) will prove to be the perfect agent to advance both the requisites of the contemporary scenario:1.      Nurturing professional experts with an academic background for evidence-based advocacy2.      Creating research materials and advocacy resources enabling generation of effective policy and productive interventions.Social Enterprise model of developmentMainstreaming Public Policy EducationEnhancing the skills of professional to develop creative innovations in the social sector domainCreating a market for social sector change makers.Strategic Direction1. Promoting and strengthening Sustainable development goals particularly in relation improving quality of public services.2. Strengthening accountability, participation and capacity of Civil society and local governance3. Nurturing professional knowledge leadership among young people in the area of public policy, SDGs and governanceThe approachPublic Policy analysis and advocacy, knowledge creation, impact studies, creating evidence-based policy research, evaluation of government policiesCapacity development of civil society, government agencies and the MediaBuilding Strategic leadership in Advocacy. For the next five years NCAS plans to work on access to public services, health, food security, education, disaster management and climate change6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):With gaping problems consisting of threats to natural and human capital it was clear that any action by the formulation of Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) has to be formulated to ensure protection and thriving of humanity and the Grant Application Form, July 1 20137environment. Seeking accountability from the system has now become the most challenging task for the civil society actors. The changing political scenario has tried hard to silence the voices from the margins, the current economic crisis in the country affects the marginalized communities the most, discrimination, and denial of social justice have become more pressing, giving a push to the civil society in the direction of people-centered and people-monitored advocacy for accountability of egalitarian State actions.One of the thematic, education is the one we have been focusing on in Maharashtra, the New Education Policy of 2020 which has now moved into the implementation phase, has been under heavy criticism while the policy seems to provide a wide range of opportunity for students, there is still a huge gap between the ground realities and the implementation plan. While one of the major challenges that has engulfed us is the pandemic, which has pushed some of the most vulnerable sections to the margins even further. Children have dropped out of school; loss of learning is one of the major concerns in this era where digital learning has taken over. A number of children have fallen in the cracks due to lack of opportunity. With the state wide networks and other civil society groups, there has been a constant effort to highlight the plight of these children by constantly engaging with the government agency to not overlook the ground realities, one of the major struggles is towards reopening of schools, the government is yet to take a clear stand on the same.   Demanding accountability from the government especially while accessing the right to food is yet another major problem especially in the remote tribal areas where access to services is still very low. The systems and structures that need to be in place to ensure that access to food is not hampered are also in a limbo, the vigilance committees formulated under Public Distribution System still continue to be either dysfunctional or have not been formulated. These committees play a key role from within the village to ensure quality control and equal distribution. However, the lack of these committees or the dysfunctional nature is due to the lack of will within the system to ensure transparency and accountability. NCAS has been engaged in creating awareness, enabling communities to seek accountability from the government in two districts, here the communities being close knit usually do not raise questions against their own members who are in position of power, thats a major hurdle. It is evident that malnutrition became a very serious concern hence seeking accountability for food security is a very key concern.In terms of opportunities- National and local networks are of a great support to amplify the issuesAt state lever there are still avenues for negotiation and dialogue with the government.Some of the major challenges is the ongoing pandemic that takes over all other issues and has slowed down negotiations. The current dispensation also leaves very little room for rights of people. In such a climate the only hope is to uphold the democratic rights given in the constitution of India.

It will help in a collaborative intervention rather than stand alone activities.Grant Application Form, July 1 2013107.2.c. Objective 2 Activities and timeframe (maximum 300 words):Institutionalization of commitment to rights-based community led approaches to development (to be achieved among all collaborating agencies over the project time-frame spanning up June 2023. Each collaborating organisation shall develop plans for ploughing back learnings from the collaborative processes in the design of their other programs and invest in building capacities of their staff to acquire essential skills and perspective to anchor right based, community led, gender responsive program. GAF_National_Centre_for_Advocacy_Studies.8. COOPERATION: 8. CooperationDescribe the level of cooperation with other organisations and networks and explain how this cooperation helps achieve your goals (maximum 300 words):Local organisations based in the communities are well acquainted of the ground realities, these ground realities are important to understand the landscape of the area and also the dynamics within communities, organisations have their own rapport with the community and have established a space for engagement with the community which is essential to explore any new ideas.  The project has been envisaged as a collective and participatory process for the expected changes. As a resource organisation, cooperation with the organisations is necessary for designing and execution of training and capacity building programs, local knowledge and conducive time for trainings will be done in collaboration with the organisations. Local stakeholders can be linked with the help of the local organisations, both state level and national level networks on right to food, education, disasters, land and soil, womens issues exist, these networks are important to engage with to link the local issues to the national level. Linkages with the networks for discussions, for advocacy and training purposes will have to be forged to ensure that the advocacy agenda has a definite outcome.
GAF_National_Centre_for_Advocacy_Studies.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. ImpactWhat is the change you want to achieve from the overall project? (maximum 300 words):Patherpratima block has been identified due to its extremely vulnerability but socially and also due to natural calamities. Issues pertaining to trafficking, Grant Application Form, July 1 201311migration, lack of access to basic services have made the communities very vulnerable. It is important that the organisations working with the community bring about a shift in their interactions with the community, due to the heightened risk of natural calamity the relief operations conducted by local organisations have also raised the expectations of the community from the organisaitons. Hence the narrative of charity, empowerment through skill development that increases employability should shift to making the communities self sustained, aware about their rights and that  seeks accountability on the services that the government provides to them. Participation of the community in decision making process of the Panchayat, increased participation of women in the panchayat, gram sabha etc. build capacities of their staff to acquire essential skills and perspective to anchor right based, community led, gender responsive program.10. EvaluationHow will progress be monitored and evaluated? (maximum 300 words):As a process for advocacy agenda that the community would like to lead, the monitoring and evaluation process will also be developed in a participatory manner. The communities will also monitor the progress of the interventions, assess the changes that have taken place. Monthly interactions with the organisations feedback on the training programs, process documentation will enable the monitoring of the progress of the project. The evaluation of the project will be done on the basis of the expected outcomes from the two main objectives of the project. Aspects of gender responsive interventions, community led activities, rights based perspective in all the interventions would be critical evaluation indicators for the progress and long term sustainability of the interventions. Local leadership development and their capacity building and subsequent actions in the field will also define the impact of the projectGrant Application Form, July 1 201312
GAF_National_Centre_for_Advocacy_Studies.11. ADDITIONAL QUESTIONS/ Future Plans: 11. Future PlansHow will the grant influence the organisation and future plans? (maximum 300 words):As a resource organisation working in a particularly vulnerable geographical location, gives us an opportunity to design interventions after acquiring  information of the basic ground realities from partners working there.. This gives us an opportunity to work closely on disaster response and climate change issues which are both part of the next 5 years strategy of NCAS. West Bengal will be a new area and state where we will be able to engage with the local networks and support in state level advocacy. The grant gives us an opportunity to explore these networks and work at the grassroots in a new state with existing partners, it feeds into our future strategic plans as well. Research and knowledge creation is also part of NCASs mandate this grant gives us an opportunity to understand the economic and social dynamics of the sundarbans to create knowledge documents specific to the area. As a capacity building organisaiton this experience helps us further to strengthen our training designs.

GAF_A_iProbono_UK_UnresProgrSuppoAccelAc.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT Oak Application Form     55a. Tell us about your governance and leadership structures, as well as staff and volunteer base. Highlight any significant recent or expected future changes. If you have an explicit approach to increasing diversity and/or advancing race equity within the organisation, please tell us. (300 words):iProbono is a global women and LGBT+ led social justice organisation with an active, UK based Board of five trustees including iProbonos founder, Shireen Irani. iProbono operates globally with a strong presence in South Asia. IProbono (India) Legal Services is registered as a s.8 company in India and the Indian and UK entities operate completely separately in relation to finance and governance, they are linked for branding purposes by an IP agreement. iProbonos UK-based CEO works closely with our UK Board to plan and ensure impactful delivery of our program strategy. Our CEO is supported by our Global Operations Director (also Chair of our India Board) and they ensure overall compliance and our local programs team are embedded in each of the countries we work in including in the UK, India, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh and Nepal. Team Directors, who are qualified lawyers supervise a team of legally trained Program Officers and Managers including two Justice Leila Seth Fellows in India and a team of social workers. Under the guidance of our Research and Impact Director, we enhance our monitoring and evaluation capacities to maximise learning and strengthen programs accountability and an India and South Asia Advisory Committee provide substantive guidance to programs. Our work is enabled and supported by a robust volunteer base of over 5000 qualified pro bono community lawyers from across the globe. We also regularly engage law students from universities in as interns to support us with our day to day activities. 5b. Summarise the organisations history.  In addition, highlight 2-3 key achievements.Please keep this brief and list up to 3 key achievements as bullet points. Even though you may have many achievements, please share what is most relevant to the proposed grant. (300 words)Inspired by the belief that, at their best, lawyers are rights protectors and defenders who can unlock opportunities iProbono was established in 2009. We embedded our model locally in India and other South Asian jurisdictions striving to deliver our mission to ensure access to justice for all in pursuit of a just society.Core achievements:2023: iProbono India was awarded the Children Champions Award by the Delhi Commission for the Protection of Child Rights (DCPCR) in recognition of our work to ensure justice for all. More details here: https://i-probono.com/case-study/iprobono-wins-childrens-champions-award-2023/2018 to date: Our successful pilot Accelerate Program provides sub-grants t projects in India and Bangladesh. For example, in Assam, we provide funding and legal expertise to a group of lawyers to protect Oak Application Form     6citizenship rights of the most vulnerable people. Deliverables include: Direct litigation support before Foreigners Tribunals (FT) and Gauhati High Court; legal training and capacity building for lawyers and community members; awareness campaigns including social media, public events and door to door outreach. iProbono maintains an under the radar approach and a no visibility policy. This year we ensured the release of 5 people from detention centres, provided 33 clients with interim protection from arrest, contested 3 FT cases and filed 41 writ petitions to protect the citizenship rights of our clients.2019: iProbono hosted over 50 human rights defenders, lawyers, activists and storytellers working in South Asia at a closed Forum in Colombo Sri Lanka to Accelerate Inclusive Movements for Social Justice in the region. The aim was to discuss strategies for litigation and legal advocacy as well as change hearts and minds of the public on key thematic areas including citizenship rights and LGBT+ rights: decriminalisation of homosexuality and legislating for transgender communities. We maintained this group and achieved impact in these areas.5c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and decide your approach? If you have undertaken a theory of change exercise, or if you are influenced by research, policy or your own organisations experience, please tell us about this.  Have you consulted with relevant stakeholders, including your communities and others experiencing the problem? Is there an intention to address equity, diversity and inclusion? (600 words):Problem statement: Our work in South Asia over the past 10 years has shown us that despite sustained efforts by both government and civil society, access to justice in the current economic, social and political scenario in India remains extremely unequal. A two-tiered justice system allows only a privileged minority to understand the law and access justice. While state-led legal aid provisions and other legal recourse mechanisms do exist, not every marginalised community/individual (women, children, survivors of abuse, religious minorities, migrant workers and the disabled to name a few) has easy access to these mechanisms. Poor legal literacy and/or the lack of awareness of ones rights under the law further hinders any meaningful engagement with the justice system. As a result, legal representation remains beyond the reach of poor and vulnerable communities. We also note that grassroots organisations representing the interests of these vulnerable communities similarly suffer from a lack of quality and affordable legal advice. And finally, primary stakeholders within the justice system (for example, public prosecutors, the police, lawyers, and so on) often lack nuanced knowledge of the laws that serve to protect the rights of these communities.Theory of Change: iProbonos pathway to real change is based in a law and development paradigm that ensures the most vulnerable communities in our society have access to and a voice within the legal system. Our model of holistic counsel engages and combines a series of tools including litigation, direct legal advice, professional development, outreach and community education, research advocacy and policy, and capacity building. Storytelling Oak Application Form     7to change hearts and minds cross cuts across our tools and the concept of comprehensive care provides us with an additional tool to go one step beyond the legal. Alongside our capacity building and litigation support, we have also provided our partner organisations across India with emergency hunger relief funding during the Covid pandemic, or psychosocial support our clients who are survivors of sexual abuse in India or the ability to evacuate and support of 120 at risk women from Afghanistan when the Taliban seized power in 2021.This holistic justice model thus aims to both prevent rights violations, seek solutions when violations have occurred, and catalyse deeper systemic change. With the Oak Foundations support, we intend to deepen our engagement in each of these areas with selected sub-grantees in West Bengal: 2 carefully selected partner organisations to deliver holistic access to justice to vulnerable communities in West Bengal.We have held an initial consultation with a core group of 8 organisations currently supported by the Oak Foundation to gain insight in to the type of access justice issues faced by communities. As part of the proposal, we have included an initial scoping period to allow our internal team to apply the stated theory of change in the selection of sub-grantee organisations as well as in the process of supporting these organisations to plan delivery.Diversity, equity and inclusion underpin our theory of change and an active internal Equality Law team advises on how we inform each of our programs from choice of delivery partner to thematic issues covered in our work. iProbono intends to monitor implementation in this area during the grant period.

OBJECTIVESThis is the most important part of your application, as it is your opportunity to explain what you want to achieve and what will be different because of your work. We understand that social and environmental change is complex and there are a multitude of factors that contribute to change. We want to understand how you define your role in the overall change you hope to make. You may find it helpful to discuss this with your Oak Programme Officer, and others in your own organisation.   7.a. ObjectivesList here up to 3 main objectives for this grant (one sentence per objective). Think of objectives as goals that can be achieved within the lifetime of the grant.  We encourage you to think of objective(s) that are ambitious but also achievable.  1.Build the capacity of civil society in West Bengal by providing 2 carefully selected organisations ('Sub-grantees') with a sub grant to design and deliver an access to justice program that can Oak Application Form     8impact the lives of local grass roots communities in West Bengal including vulnerable women and young people, migrant workers and others working in the unorganised sector.2.Strengthen the voice and capacity of local, vulnerable populations in West Bengal through knowledge of the law, legal design and storytelling by working with selected Sub-grantee organisations in specified geographies to curate programs.3.Strengthen the organisational capacity of iProbono, in particular our core senior global leadership team which will provide Sub-grantee partners with vital strategic guidance and input, communications support, and monitoring and evaluation expertise. 7.b. GAF_A_iProbono_UK_UnresProgrSuppoAccelAc.8. COOPERATION: 8. COOPERATION  How will you involve others in your approach to achieving change? If you are planning to engage in partnerships with other organisations, communities, people with lived experience, academics or secure the support of key individuals, please tell us about this.  Why are these the right partners to engage with? (300 words):As discussed with the Oak Foundation, we will identify 1-2 partner organisations as 'Sub-grantees' to implement activities envisioned under this grant. iProbono (our senior leadership and programmes team) will provide strategic direction, advice, and expertise to partners as well as overall programme oversight with input from the Oak Foundation where relevant. The success of programme deliverables will also depend largely on close collaboration with other civil society organisations (including, for example, other grantees of the Oak Foundation), lawyers, and propose to deliver our change strategy in partnership with other civil society organisations, lawyers, as well as affected community members. This is in line with iProbonos standard operating procedure: we are a collaborative, consultative and partnership-oriented organisation and we ensure that our programmes - whether at the design, strategy or implementation level - is at all times informed by the experiences, expertise, and knowledge of those who have the power to make change as well as those who are most affected by it.
GAF_A_iProbono_UK_UnresProgrSuppoAccelAc.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING This section is twofold. Please tell us:a) Monitoring and evaluation. How will you know if you are achieving your objectives? Please describe briefly how you will know if you are making progress and if what you are doing is working. If you have a formal monitoring and evaluation system and if you plan to collect indicator data or conduct an external evaluation, please provide details here.b) Learning. Please tell us if there anything in particular that you are hoping to learn more about or test through this grant.(300 words):MEL at iProbono is supported by our CEO and a Research and Impact Director. With their support we guide our team to integrate M&E into all stages of an intervention and create institutional spaces for learning, reflection, and feedback to maximise programme impact and ensure accountability to the communities we serve. We would similarly work with Sub-grantee organisaitons.To assess the impact of  legal representation work, we gather data from both the individuals/litigants (or their representative in case the litigant is a minor) as well as grassroots organisations to whom we offer this support. Here data collection takes place via the gathering of testimonials and/or conducting short surveys by the team;For community outreach/legal empowerment initiatives we aim to track changes in knowledge, perception, and attitudes via feedback forms/interviews conducted pre and post the module/training;Oak Application Form     11For the bespoke impact assessment being planned with MLT, we will conduct a more formal evaluation, potentially with additional support that this grant will unlock.To measure the effectiveness of our training initiatives to build the capacities of any lawyers working with us in Kolkata or more rural areas in West Bengal we will similarly conduct pre and post module surveys/questionnaires.
GAF_A_iProbono_UK_UnresProgrSuppoAccelAc.10. RISKS AND CHALLENGES: 10.  RISKS AND CHALLENGESWhat are the risks or barriers that might prevent you from achieving your outcomes and how will you address these?  What are your opportunities?We understand that achieving long-lasting and meaningful change is hard and we expect that the work you want to do will mean taking risks.  We encourage you to be open to telling us these, as well as how you will address these risks.  If some of your outcomes are risky, are there any incremental achievements that you could identify? (300 words):We are acutely aware of the geo-political implications of delivering our programs in the face of shrinking civil society space. Beyond this we assess risk across the organisation and maintain a risk register which we review regularly with our board and funders where We are well networked with key players in the social justice field who support us to navigate and manage risk in the current environment.During discussions with the Oak Foundation team over the past 6 months, we discussed our risk strategy for maintaining a literal and theoretical separation between our UK and India entities. With the shift in climate for the non-profit sector in India and government clamp downs we maintain our decision not to register for FCRA and rely in India on local funding resource. The sub-granting model described in this proposal mitigates possible risks to our work in West Bengal and we will work closely with our partner organisation to keep up to date with any legal changes that may impact progress. We maintain a policy of low visibility and keeping certain programmatic achievements, impact and the names of our supporters carefully under the radar of any publicity or social media.We maintain a strict communications policy across teams and regularly train our in-house team on how to navigate the changing scenario in our region and beyond.

Summarise the projects ultimate goal(s) (maximum 200 words):( NOT REQUIRED FOR CORE SUPPORT GRANTS)The projects ultimate goal is to highlight child agency as one of the critical components that need to be kept in mind while amplifying community voices. The adult-child axis of power is a difficult power gradient to engage with by both adults and children. This becomes even more complicated in case of adolescents where issues about choice and consent assume very different nuances.Agency in children and adolescents is also strongly related to gender identity and expression and is shaped by gender norms and expectations. The project hopes to capacitate implementing organisations to acknowledge  agency of children and adolescents and appreciate the role that gender plays in hindering and facilitating participation of children and women so that their opinions and choices are reflected adequately within community voices and action.
