Describe the organisation (include information on leadership, governance, structure and staff) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):New Alipore Praajak Development Society (hereafter referred as Praajak) is led by Mr Savarni Purkayastha who is the Secretary cum Director of the organisation. Praajak is governed by it Governing Body members.Praajak follows this given structure in case of programmes  Governing BodyDirectorConsultant Project ManagerConsultant Project Operations  Consultant Field Animator.The following structure is followed in case of accounts and administration:Governing BodyDirectorConsultant Finance & logisticsConsultant Cash ManagementGrant Application Form, July 1 201356b. Describe the financial situation (include information on annual operating costs, fundraising strategy, reserves and debts) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):The annual operating cost for the year 2020-21 was Rs. 2,27,46,956. This included approximately Rs. 40,00,000 which was received as Covid Relief Grants.Praajak currently depends on donor agency grants to finance more than 95% of its projects and is currently developing a sustainability plan by building reserves which it hopes to adopt by the end of 2021. Praajak has adopted a reserve policy in 2020 to streamline these concerns.6c. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):Since 2015, Praajak has implemented its strategy for youth collectivization reaching out to approximately 3500 adolescents and youth.A series of dynamic gender and sexuality modules have been developed for young people and for use in meetings with adult mens and womens groups.  It has been adapted to work with boys who are vulnerable to coming into conflict with the law.Praajak continues the Annual Kabaddi Tournament with girls and women in the intervention communities, in collaboration with the State and District Kabaddi Associations. It continues to reinforce the learning in study circles by building skills on team work, leadership and assertiveness.Praajak hopes to reach out to more organisations so that to they are encouraged to develop programmes with boys and push for the adoption of a root cause approach to prevention of violence against children. It has also consolidated its relief and emergency support work in the context of Covid with nomadic and semi-nomadic populations The two Railway Childlines run by Praajak in Malda and Asansol are playing a critical role in supporting them6d. Describe the current strategy of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):Praajak is focusing on its DNA to move on to its mission and vision. This referred to Praajaks core competency in working with adolescents at the cusp of child protection and gender equity and its belief that adolescent and youth are best positioned to lead efforts for social and cultural transformation and shape a world of empathy, esteem and acceptance. Praajak felt the most validated as it worked to facilitate boys and girls to transform their worlds by transforming themselves first and fostered a network of vibrant community spaces that are designed and led by youth. These spaces were promoted as places for exploration, agency and behavioural change.The strategy that was adopted was called the 3C Model which referred to Grant Application Form, July 1 20136Collectives (collectivising adolescents), Community (advocating with and mobilising the community in favour of the rights of children and adolescents) and Campus (developing leadership programmes for young people so they can set up their own projects)6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):The problems we are addressing are chiefly around   understanding community led actions, is the meaning of effective participation and revisiting boundaries between the community and the organization. Simultaneously we are also looking at how the concept of child agency can be integrated into child rights/protection work and how by addressing masculinities related issues we can include boys and men as allies in our efforts to assume gender equity.Praajak believes that any capacity development should be built on the foundation of the existing strengths of trainees and make use of their experiences. This will mean any capacity building will use both experiential training and handholding during implementation as major methodologies.Communication and appropriate messaging have emerged as a major challenge for partner organization and there is a legacy of organisational interaction with stakeholders which needs to be tackled in a way that harm can be reduced for the organisations current operations.A comprehensive advocacy workshop emphasising needs to be conducted for all staff in one or more phases as is suitable to the organisation.The following areas will need to be addressed:The difference between advocacy on one hand and community mobilisation, public relations and IEC/BCC on the other.Formulation of SMART advocacy adjectivesStakeholder Analysis and MessagingA framework for organisational strategy regarding stakeholder communication.Additionally, a tool called the CCC-NERO will be introduced that will help to enhance the skills of social workers of partner organizations on the frontline.Child Marriage, Child Trafficking and Child Labour in terms of Root Causes, Identifying Vulnerabilities, Legislation Custody vs Agency, Response SystemsGender and Social Development- Concept of Gender, Gender Norms and Roles, Patriarchy, Gender based Discrimination and Violence, Gender EquityDocumentation-Understanding Narratives and Storytelling, Understanding Audience, Documentation Skills The overall recommendation is the following:1. Praajak will create a module (in Bangla, if that is convenient) for the above areas2. Praajak will use the module to organise a Training of Trainers (TOT) of senior officials. The trainers can then use the module and the experience of Grant Application Form, July 1 20137the training to further train their staff who work on the frontline.3. The training may be organised online or in case travel restrictions are eased may be organised as a face-to-face workshop.

(maximum 300 words):The primary change one expects to achieve from the proposed process is to see greater levels of participation and leadership of local communities in development initiatives in the Sundarbans, evident in greater centrality of their voices and roles in processes of conceptualisation of initiatives, planning, implementation, monitoring and evaluation. This will be reflected in increased inclusion of the voices of women, adolescents, children and other marginal groups in the processes mentioned above.10. EvaluationHow will progress be monitored and evaluated? (maximum 300 words):Within the alliance of organizations coming together to implement the grant, a Steering Committee, comprising of key functionaries of each organization (including of Rupantaran Foundation) will meet once every month to take stock and reflect upon the progress of the initiative vis--vis a calendar of actions that would be jointly developed by them.  Additionally, Praajak will be part of a team constituting resource organisations who will jointly monitor the work including the activities and outcomes mentioned in this proposal.Monitoring and evaluation of the progress of the initiative would be primarily geared upon a community-led process itself. Opportunities would be created for the anchor-groups of collective action, comprising representatives of vulnerable sections, emerging in each location of action to articulate statements and indicators of transformation sought from the collective initiative, as well as indicators of the desired process and values of collaboration. A range of participatory methods shall be deployed in the processGrant Application Form, July 1 201310

(maximum 300 words):The organisation has adopted a strategy to recreate itself as a resource organisation situated at the cusp of gender equity and child rights development domains that can help individual social entrepreneurs and organisations to integrate these concerns within their existing work. This project helps Praajak to gain valuable experience to move towards that goal. Additionally, it also enhances learning for Praajak as it will have the opportunity to move beyond its existing partners in the gender and child rights domains and understand the perspectives of other organisations. This will expectedly enrich its future grassroots work in terms of gaining new perspectives, developing innovative strategies and making the deliverables more wholesome for the communities we work with.

(300 words): Pratham Education Foundation is governed by a Board of Directors. There are 15 Board Members whose names and details are listed below. The Board of Directors needs to attend Annual General Meetings conducted at least thrice every year according to the Memorandum of Association. The Board has no specific advisory board or committee. The overall management approach towards planning and implementing projects is one of managing various operations through a vertical division of Prathams programs. Our management structure is a hierarchical one led by our Board as well as the Chief Executive Officer. Thereafter, Regional/State Heads, Content & Training teams, Program Development teams, Monitoring & Evaluation Unit and Central Admin & Accounts team are incharge of program strategy and evaluation whereas the State and Implementation teams are incharge of the implementation of the project on the field. Frequent program reviews, training sessions as well as conferences ensure that the field teams are constantly in touch with the central teams so that the  implementation of the project on the ground happens in an efficient manner as originally envisioned and in case of any obstacles in implementation, intervention can happen immediately so that the potential impact of the project is not hampered in any manner. Summarise the organisations history.  In addition, highlight 2-3 key achievements.Please keep this brief and list up to 3 key achievements as bullet points. Even though you may have many achievements, please share what is most relevant to the proposed grant. (300 words)Pratham was established in 1995 to provide pre-school education to the children in the slums of Mumbai. Since then, the organization has grown both in scope & geographical coverage and has expanded to most parts of India reaching millions of children in both rural and urban areas across 20 states and 3 union territories. Pratham has grown to address a gamut of educational problems  pre-school education, learning support to both in-school and out of school children and youth, mainstreaming of out-of-school  children, computer literacy, vocational training for youth and special programs for vulnerable and working children. Pratham Skilling is the vocational training arm of Pratham, established  in 2005 with the aim of empowering youth (age 18-35 years) from economically disadvantaged backgrounds by creating avenues for them to attain employability and/or entrepreneurship. Since 2005, we have trained 1,76,000+ youth in industry specific trades and placed 75-80% youth in jobs in automotive, hospitality, healthcare, electrical, beauty & construction trades among our 2000+ industry partners at our 130+ centers spread across 16 states. We also run entrepreneurship development projects and have supported 5,300+ entrepreneurs.The following are some of Prathams key achievements:1.Blended learning approach: Effective blended learning project in 1000 communities since 2016. 8000 tablets and 1000 Raspberry Pis distributed, impacting 60,000 children and 6000 youth, including 2000 drop-outs.2.Hybrid Skilling Innovation: Pratham pivoted to a remote-contact self-learning and virtual-training model in 20,000+ villages during the lockdown leading to employment for 32,000+ youth from Oct 2020-March 2022.3.Post-Placement Tracking: To ensure continued retention in employment, Pratham reaches out to each trainee every 3 months, for a period of 1 year, collecting 110+ data points tracking their employment status and need for further placement assistance. Pratham is the only organization in the ecosystem to conduct such a tracking.5c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and decide your approach? If you have undertaken a theory of change exercise, or if you are influenced by research, policy or your own organisations experience, please Oak Application Form     8tell us about this.  Have you consulted with relevant stakeholders, including your communities and others experiencing the problem? Is there an intention to address equity, diversity and inclusion? (600 words):The communities of North Bengal live in precarious conditions, highly dependent on employment provided by tea-plantation owners. Low wages, seasonal employment cycle, plantation owners restrictions and lack of alternative income-earning opportunities are some of the key challenges faced by these communities. To understand the region in more detail, a team of 4 Pratham members, including program leadership visited Soongachi, Naxalbari, Kakarvita & Cooch Behar tea estates in March 2022. The team interacted with the sarpanch & gram-panchayat members and conducted 3 focused group discussions with the youth & their parents on their current employment situation, aspirations and challenges. Most of the youth majorly belonged to SC/ST sections with someone from their family working in a tea garden. Some key insights from their discussions:1. Current Employment Status: While some youth were still studying, majority of them had completed their 12th and graduation and were not engaged in any employment activity. 2. Aspiration: The youth showed disinterest towards working in tea-gardens and were looking for other job opportunities. However, they lacked exposure about jobs available in different sectors, how to access them and industry requirements. There was a clear need for guidance and mentorship for these youth. 3. Willingness to migrate for training & job: Majority of these youth showed willingness to join a vocational training course near their communities and migrate for a job opportunity within Bengal. Hospitality, Automotive 4W, Healthcare and electrical trades were some of the most chosen preferences of these youth. 4. Workforce demand: The tea-gardens being a tourist attraction, there is massive demand for hospitality staff. Interaction with a couple of automotive showrooms and service dealerships and resorts reflected the need for skilled staff within this region. Year 2 onwards electrical trade will also be introduced based on a need assessment study conducted with industry partners.  Another interaction with Adivasi Vikas Parishad and SPAN NGO further emphasized livelihood related challenges, trafficking issues, mobility and connectivity problems, education and healthcare related issues within the region. While these interactions clearly indicate lack of awareness on vocational training led employment pathways, Pratham will conduct a detailed need assessment survey both in the community and with industry partners in North Bengal to understand aspirations and needs in greater depth. The survey will also capture potential job opportunities within tea manufacturing units. Insights from this detailed survey will feed into the program design.  Oak Application Form     9Based on Prathams experience of 17 years training over 1,75,000 rural youth across India, we propose  a  community-focused youth training initiative in Hospitality and Automotive 4W trades in Year 1 and Electrical trade in Year 2 of the engagement with the youth. Following are the key components of the programs: Building Awareness : Mentors will interact with youth, panchayat and community leaders spreading awareness on career pathways through vocational training focusing primarily on communities working in the tea garden areas of Darjeeling, Kalimpong, Alipurduar, Jalpaiguri, Coochbehar, Uttar Dinajpur and Dakshin Dinajpur districts of North Bengal region. Group meetings, skill-melas, video testimonials of Prathams alumni will be leveraged to build awareness. At this stage, youth will be enrolled in Level 1 -7-day long self-placed digital courses giving exposure to 7 different industry trades and potential job opportunities within them. Training  Conducted in a hybrid approach, the core training includes two components namely, Level 2 (virtual sessions) and Level 3 (in-person practical sessions). The entire training spans roughly 45-60 days. Job Placements- Trained youth will be oriented with available job opportunities within Hospitality and Automotive sectors. Pratham negotiates with its placement partners for salaries and additional benefits- food, accommodation and transportation allowance for its trainees. Youth will be guided throughout the interview and joining process. Post-Placement Tracking: To ensure continued retention in employment, Pratham reaches out to each trainee every 3 months, for a period of 1 year, collecting 110+ data points tracking their employment status and need for further placement assistance.

OBJECTIVESThis is the most important part of your application, as it is your opportunity to explain what you want to achieve and what will be different because of your work. We understand that social and environmental change is complex and there are a multitude of factors that contribute to change. We want to understand how you define your role in the overall change you hope to make. You may find it helpful to discuss this with your Oak Programme Officer, and others in your own organisation.   7.a. ObjectivesOak Application Form     10List here up to 3 main objectives for this grant (one sentence per objective). Think of objectives as goals that can be achieved within the lifetime of the grant.  We encourage you to think of objective(s) that are ambitious but also achievable.  Objective 1  To provide industry relevant technical and life skills to youth, making them ready for formal job opportunities.Objective 2  To link youth to employment opportunities in their chosen sectors towards achieving income security.Objective 3  To provide a support network for youth helping them grow in their professional journey through career guidance, migration and placement support.  7.b. Youth of tea gardens can avail skill education as per industry specific technical skills and requirements.2. 80% of trained youth are placed and employed by the end of the programme period.3. 90% of youth placed after the training programme continue in their employment after one year.4. 100% of Youth enrolled in training are equipped with life skills like problem solving, teamwork, collaboration, leadership, digital literacy, media literacy, communication, planning, social awareness and resilience.5. This allows maximum interaction and longer engagement.In Year 1, 400+ youth to be mobilised for the hospitality and the automotive programs.In Year 2, 1000+ youth to be mobilised for the hospitality, automotive and electrical programs.Year 3 and Year 4, 1200+ youth will be mobilised. GAF_A_Pratham_Education_Foundation_Vocat.8. COOPERATION: 8. COOPERATION  How will you involve others in your approach to achieving change? If you are planning to engage in partnerships with other organisations, communities, people with lived experience, academics or secure the support of key individuals, please tell us about this.  Why are these the right partners to engage with?  Is there anything new about how you are choosing to work - for example, new partnerships or an approach that is different to how you usually work? (300 words):Oak Application Form     14Pratham engages with multiple stakeholders within the community and industry in all its programs. The success of the program is a collaborative effort between all stakeholders including Prathams team at all levels. For the proposed vocational training program, Pratham will be engaging with the following stakeholders over the course of the program period:Community members: Prathams mentor leaders consistently engage with community members, including the Sarpanch, local influencers, households and youth groups spreading awareness of vocational training programs.Industry partners: Prathams placement team engages with its strong network of 2000+ placement partners spread across the country. For the purpose of this project, new placement partners in the northeast region will be explored and partnered with for placements of youth trained through the program.Local NGOs/groups: Mentor leaders also engage with local NGOs and groups periodically to explore mutual interests in terms of spreading awareness on vocational skilling and leveraging each other's community presence.
GAF_A_Pratham_Education_Foundation_Vocat.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING This section is twofold. Please tell us:a) Monitoring and evaluation. How will you know if you are achieving your objectives? Please describe briefly how you will know if you are making progress and if what you are doing is working. If you have a formal monitoring and evaluation system and if you plan to collect indicator data or conduct an external evaluation, please provide details here.b) Learning. Please tell us if there anything in particular that you are hoping to learn more about or test through this grant.(300 words):Measurement is an integral part of all Pratham programs. Be it internal measurement, or external evaluations such as by government assessment agencies and industry sector bodies, Pratham has established a strong culture of capturing and using data rigorously to demonstrate impact over the past several years.In 2013, Pratham set up a separate Measurement, Monitoring and Evaluation (MME) Unit to be able to systematically carry out a set of planned evaluations to measure and track progress and impact.  This evidence is now internally analyzed to understand the strengths and shortcomings of Prathams programs, and to assist in developing solutions to improve the effectiveness of the programs.A key measure of our impact is the number of youth trained that retain jobs beyond 6 months  this is a measure we have adopted above and beyond the standard metrics of training and placement that are the norms for the sector. We are also trying to use the insights from our measurement of impact to get a similar measurement adopted by the entire ecosystem.Currently, Pratham gathers both quantitative and qualitative information about all students enrolled at the training center. At each of the centers, Oak Application Form     15concerned staff will gather extensive background details such as family income, educational qualifications and fee status of each student which will then be compiled in the Salesforce Management Information System (MIS). The reports generated will include both Quantitative Metrics (such as the number of students enrolled, trained, certified, and supported as entrepreneurs, as well as retention and dropout rates) and Qualitative Data about the social and economic impact of our programs (e.g. through student case studies). Entrepreneurs are also tracked on a monthly basis once supported, for the period of a year, to better understand their progress and any challenges faced. The Central Team provides them with ongoing support and mentorship during this period.Data Checks through Internal Dashboard: Pratham uses Salesforce to capture all center & student level data. Pratham has developed centralized monitoring and reviewing through an advanced dashboard (on Salesforce) to monitor progress of the centers. This helps us to monitor the data at the micro level and take actions as required. Pratham has developed an independent audit team responsible for planned and impromptu audits at the center level. They are responsible for overall quality check with a comprehensive checklist and feedback mechanism. Supporters are also encouraged to visit the Centers they sponsor and assess the impact their investment is having through this transformative educational and vocational training program.Daily monitoring process at centers: Regularized monitoring - The rationale is to get an understanding about the daily processes and activities occurring at the center. Through this we aim to collect data that represents staff attendance, center photographs, students mobilization, expense details, etc.All programs will be tracked throughout the year and an annual report will be submitted at the end of every year. Pratham will also share reports along with case studies, videos and photographs. We are now planning to use apps to get information from centers, feedback from students, etc on a regular basis to ensure better quality and checks. The center heads are required to fill the data like no. of students present, no. of staff present with an option to upload live pictures on a daily basis. Given that this will be our first project in the far north-east part of the country, we will leverage this opportunity to learn in-depth about youth from this region. We would like to learn about the aspirations of these youth and explore the need for starting new vocational training programs/ entrepreneurship models suited specifically for this region. Periodic surveys and focused group discussions will be conducted to understand the target group of youth in greater depth.
GAF_A_Pratham_Education_Foundation_Vocat.10. RISKS AND CHALLENGES: 10.  RISKS AND CHALLENGESOak Application Form     16What are the risks or barriers that might prevent you from achieving your outcomes and how will you address these?  What are your opportunities?We understand that achieving long-lasting and meaningful change is hard and we expect that the work you want to do will mean taking risks.  We encourage you to be open to telling us these, as well as how you will address these risks.  If some of your outcomes are risky, are there any incremental achievements that you could identify? (300 words):The project may entail the following risks.1.Timeline: Project may not be implemented as per timeline/schedule mentioned in the MoU due to operational challenges, unexpected holidays, local festivals, Government elections, environmental stresses.Mitigation steps: Pratham will deploy monitoring checks at the center, state and central level at regular intervals to ensure that the proposed implementation timeline is adhered to. The teams are committed to complete the project on time as per the schedule of activities mentioned in the MoU.2.Operational Risks: Pratham could face challenges in terms of mobilization due to lack of willingness of rural youth to join employment or their families to allow them to seek employment. Challenges could arise from resistance of employers to provide employment or food & accommodation to trainees under an on-site model. Trainees could also dropout from course mid training or not opt for job post training due to personal or family problems.Mitigation steps:  Mobilization: Pratham will work towards creating awareness about the program through digital content to educate the community and youth about the intricacies and realities of the program in order to augment mobilization efforts.Employer Support: Pratham will consistently engage with placement partners by inviting them for interviews, and guest lectures at the residential training centres or through virtual sessions to convince them on Prathams pedagogy of teaching and training model. This will enable the placement partners to understand the quality of training provided and the skills of the trainees, thereby getting their buy-in to come on board for the onsite model.Drop-Out: With an on-site model, there is daily interaction through virtual classes with the Pratham team, in-person interaction during counseling sessions conducted weekly/fortnightly. Trainees are also personally attended to in case of any issues or difficulties they come across during the training.
GAF_A_Pratham_Education_Foundation_Vocat.11. ADDITIONAL QUESTIONS/ Future Plans: 11.  ADDITIONAL QUESTIONSPlease use this space to respond to any specific questions from your Oak programme officer. If none were received, please leave this section blank. Oak Application Form     17a. What are the systemic level changes that may be achieved in the long run? The programme needs to evolve from a service delivery mode to a more systemic change mode that will position the programme as a replicable and scalable model for adoption in the skilling landscape in India.On a national level, India has taken a Public-Private-Partnership (PPP) approach to fulfill the skill development mission in partnership with industry sectors. The PPP model offers the public sector potential cost, quality and scale advantages in achieving service targets.Since inception in 2015, Prathams delivery model of community mobilization, residential training at the center with industry vetted curriculum and job placement as an end outcome has scaled from 1 to 130 centers across 15 states in India. Since the pandemic, Pratham has pivoted to a hybrid skilling model integrating familiar technology and tracking systems to provide skill training and help youth sustain in employment.The reach and scale has become 3xmore than what was possible through door-to-door physical mobilization. In tandem with the national approach excluding public entity involvement at the delivery stage, Pratham leverages its strong community engagement initiatives making the model sustainable in the long-run.The hybrid skilling model can be easily replicated through capacity building of teams on digital tools & data-driven approaches.Can you please try to elaborate on the benefits for the community and how the programme can be positioned in the donor landscape for generating more funding traction?The skilling program of Pratham is currently aligned with Goal 8 of SDGs. The Skilling program not only imparts vocational skills to the youth but also has multifold impact on the entire community. To begin with the direct beneficiary, the youth themselves receive an holistic education when ongoing training (including life skills, financial literacy, and many more). This prepares them for the outside world learning to manage themselves away from the family. As our model demands them to stay out of home for a certain period of time this allows them to become more confident about themselves.Necessary awareness of other available employment opportunities will help provide direction with regard to proper skilling of the youth in reference to their profession of choice. Financial literacy skills (inculcated within the skilling programs) will help foster fiscally sound decisions with regard to their money. Moreover, financial literacy has a significant impact on families as this knowledge helps balance family budgets, ensuring proper utilization of funds for household necessities, health insurance, childrens education, retirement etc.Seeing this, the community is encouraged to send more youth to such programs.Pratham evolved its approach of training when the pandemic hit. From a residential model Pratham moved to a hybrid model using the center, community spaces and placement partner properties as a space for practical training. This enabled Pratham to enter communities and Oak Application Form     18interact with the people directly. This shift in strategy allowed Pratham to reach out to more villages and increase its presence.As most of the funding is received from CSRs and Foundations with an objective to promote livelihood and sustainable economic growth, the Pratham skilling model ensures visible indicators of impact, focussing on employability status, income generation and industry absorption. As most of Prathams work focuses on skilling of youth these programs allow interaction with organizations in a capacity of volunteering and employee engagement. Direct interaction through motivational speeches, life skills, work ethics, etiquette, interview preparations are possible in this model. b. There is a scope to align the cross-sectoral impact of this programme on reducing instances of unsafe/distress migration and trafficking, education attainment and collectivization of youth. These may therefore be further elaborated with clear objectives which can uniquely position the programme as a skilling programme with multi-dimensional impact.  You can try to include this as one of the project objectives and state the collaboration that can be attained with the other Oak grantees working in the North Bengal tea garden space. Prathams model of skilling not only imparts vocational skills to the youth but also has multifold impact on the entire community.1.Alternative income source: Additional income inflow into families through youth taking up formal jobs will help improve the overall standard of living of these communities, aiding in better healthcare facilities  and schooling opportunities for children.2.Counseling support: Physical presence of a training center will serve as a hub for all kinds of information support for skilling and employment opportunities. The team will  be instrumental in counseling youth and young children towards available career pathways and help mitigate trafficking activities in the vicinity.3.Boost to local economy: Youth who wish to opt for self-employment will be guided to start their own enterprises.4.Financial Literacy: Imparted to youth during the skilling programs will help foster fiscally sound decisions with regard to their money. Such knowledge will help balance family budgets, ensuring proper utilization of funds for household necessities, health insurance, childrens education, retirement etc.5.Building youth community volunteers: A unique Education for Education model will be linked to the vocational training program for the youth. The intent is to make the youth a key stakeholder in the learning curve of children of the community. In exchange for the vocational training modules, youth will be trained to deliver short interventions for the children of the community to build and enhance their basic foundational skills of reading and arithmetic. Oak Application Form     19     c. Since the vocational training programme will be launched in a new geography, it will be good to document the evolution (programme launch, challenges, opportunities and risks and success) of past training programmes in similar geographies characterized by skills gaps, location remoteness and technological limitations. Have such programmes yielded positive results? If so, what have been the contributing factors?  Can you therefore state the experience of Pratham in launching such programmes in new geography and the overall experience and the successes/challenges? Every geography represents a unique culture and has its own advantages and constraints. Pratham has always adopted an inclusive approach, tailoring the model based on the needs of a specific region. Prathams vocational training initiatives in Gadchiroli, a tribal region in Maharashtra started in 2012 in collaboration with the forest and police departments. An inclusive counseling approach and facilitation of transportation for tribal youth to training centers in Maharashtra helped increase receptiveness among the tribal population. 5000+ youth have been trained so far from Gadchiroli in hospitality, construction and automotive trades who went on to pursue formal entry-level jobs post training. This approach was also recognized through the PMs award for public administration awarded to District Administration for the innovative partnership with Civil Society.Some factors that are unique to Prathams model and have been successful  across different states in India have been illustrated below: 1.Strong Community Engagement: Prathams mentors ( community mobilizers) engage extensively with all community stakeholders- sarpanch, self-help groups, community leaders and households on a regular basis. Community meetings, fairs, rallies, learning activities with children are some of the mediums through which members of the community are engaged and informed about Prathams education and skilling interventions. Together with the education programs, Prathams presence is spread across 20,000 communities in 17 states across the country. Pratham has built strong volunteer networks within these communities who form an integral part of the intervention and help sustain the initiatives in the long-run.2.Detailed Need Assessment Survey: Pratham conducts needs assessment surveys within the community and with industry partners of the region before initiating a new program. The survey helps understand the demographic profile and  aspirations of youth in greater depth along with industry demand for different job roles in the region. This helps in designing the program and adopt an inclusive approach considering region specific challenges. The team also visits and interacts with local stakeholders and organizations working in the region to understand the local context in more depth.3.Counseling : Prathams experience over the past decade has re-affirmed the importance of counseling time and again- not only of the skilling aspirant but of his/her family and the community in general in Oak Application Form     20the entire skilling value chain. The process of counseling is therefore deeply embedded at every step of the skill training, placement and alumni engagement levels. There are different stakeholders involved at each level and the nature and approach is customized to suit the need of the time. Overall, 10 hours worth of counseling is done beginning from mobilization, training and placement. Alumni engagement involves periodic contact with the graduates with the frequency varying based on the need of the hour in addition to the structured group events held at each location.4.Practical Hands-on Training: 15 days of the Level 3 course module is based on practical training which offers a unique opportunity for youth to learn real-life application of trade specific skills. This helps trainees get a first-hand experience of a work-place scenario helping them transition smoothly into formal work environments as soon as they graduate.5.Content Innovation: Pratham has digitized all its training content and reading material and uploaded the entire package on Pratham Open School Platform for ease of accessibility by trainees. Youth can visit the site and refer to the content at all times. Further, Prathams trainers themselves have created interesting videos taking inspiration from real-life situations which are uploaded on the open school site and shared with trainees as well. These help to create more relatable experience for youth helping them grasp technical knowledge faster.6.Data-driven systems: Every program is designed based on evidence from data and decision-making at every step is highly data-driven.Challenges:The project may entail the following risks.1.Timeline: Project may not be implemented as per timeline/schedule mentioned in the MoU due to operational challenges, unexpected holidays, local festivals, Government elections, environmental stresses.Mitigation steps:Pratham will deploy monitoring checks at the center, state and central level at regular intervals to ensure that the proposed implementation timeline is adhered to. The teams are committed to complete the project on time as per the schedule of activities mentioned in the MoU.2.Operational Risks: Pratham could face challenges in terms of mobilization due to lack of willingness of rural youth to join employment or their families to allow them to seek employment. Challenges could arise from resistance of employers to provide employment or food & accommodation to trainees under an on-site model. Trainees could also dropout from course mid training or not opt for job post training due to personal or family problems.Mitigation steps:  Mobilization: Pratham will work towards creating awareness about the program through digital content to educate the community and youth about the intricacies and realities of the program in order to augment mobilization efforts.Oak Application Form     21Employer Support: Pratham will consistently engage with placement partners by inviting them for interviews, and guest lectures at the residential training centers or through virtual sessions to convince them on Prathams pedagogy of teaching and training model. This will enable the placement partners to understand the quality of training provided and the skills of the trainees, thereby getting their buy-in to come on board for the onsite model.Drop-Out: With an on-site model, there is daily interaction through virtual classes with the Pratham team, in-person interaction during counseling sessions conducted weekly/fortnightly. Trainees are also personally attended to in case of any issues or difficulties they come across during the training.  d. The possibility of increasing the co-funding during the course of the programme. Since there is an increasing amount of funding that is being directed to skilling programmes in India, there should be a clear goal in generating more interest among other donors for funding the skilling programme for youth of the tea gardens.  Can you state (the source may not be mentioned immediately, if not decided) on how Pratham intends to leverage co-funding for this programme and also state any avenues which may be explored jointly by Oak and Pratham to generate funding availability for the skilling programmes? Pratham is expanding presence in the Eastern part of India. Pratham actively approaches existing and new CSRs and Foundations for expansion in newer regions. With the support of Oak, Pratham skilling will be able to show presence in the tea garden belt attracting the current and the new CSRs to support programs in this specific belt.Usually when ventured into a new geography, Pratham announces its expansion to donors via emails, newsletters, referrals, social media posts, further application for proposals, etc. This usually generates interest in donors fleshing out to a partnership.Pratham also plans to leverage on the existing networks of Oak with other non-profits or funding organizations to expand the scope of funding. This will allow Pratham to expand its network and create financial or knowledge based partnerships as required.     Oak Application Form     22

Summarise the projects ultimate goal(s) (maximum 200 words):( NOT REQUIRED FOR CORE SUPPORT GRANTS)Grant Application Form, July 1 20134Nazdeek envisions a world where communities are legally empowered and have access to tools and mechanisms to demand and secure their rights. Through training of trainers, community legal education, and consultation on policy, we aspire to amplify voices of the most marginalised. We also believe in robust accountability mechanisms and their strategic use in the fight for justice. This project aims to strengthen the capacity of tea plantation workers on socio-economic rights, labour laws, and entitlements in South Asia. Using our legal empowerment model, we aim to: 1) increase and deepen understanding of rights among tea plantation workers; 2) strengthen legal capacity and collaboration among workers collectives, community paralegals, unions, and civil society organisations (CSOs) for high impact; 3) increase use of worker-led rights monitoring and grievance mechanisms in Assam for government and corporate accountability; 4) strengthen legal capacity of local CSO partners in Barak Valley (Assam) andin West Bengal through trainings and consultations; 5) increase labour law engagement through Forum for Rights of Tea Workers (FRTW) with sustained advocacy and networking efforts at the local, state, national and South Asia levels; 6) amplify the voices of tea plantation workers on business and human rights issues at international levels.
GAF_Nazdeek__Inc_EnsurAccesToSocioAndLab.4. GEOGRAPHY: 5.List the major countries where your activities take place. If this is global policy work, list as worldwide:India  (South Asia)
GAF_Nazdeek__Inc_EnsurAccesToSocioAndLab.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 6. Context (The context section should not exceed two pages.)6a. Describe the organisation (include information on leadership, governance, structure and staff) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):Nazdeek is a women-led legal empowerment organization founded in 2012 by Jayshree Satpute, Sukti Dhital, and Francesca Feruglio. Throughout their previous litigation and field-work, they realised that marginalised communities were being denied knowledge and access to crucial administrative and non-Grant Application Form, July 1 20135judicial grievance redressal mechanisms. Therefore, Nazdeek was founded to ensure community agency and access to justice.Nazdeeks current Board: Sukti Dhital (President and Treasurer) Pragya Nair, Taryn Eckstein, Jameen Kaur, and Trusha Mehta (Directors) Board members are offered a two-year position with the possibility of extension. Since our founding we have cycled off two former board members. These positions were filled by our current board members. In September 2021, we plan to invite Co-founder and Advisor, Francesca Feruglio, to join as a Director.Board members provide critical guidance and strategic support. They connect Nazdeek to potential funding opportunities, strategic partners, and review financial and strategic plans. Certain members have additional responsibilities, e.g. the Treasurer reviews balance sheets, 990 tax filings and signs relevant agreements, and the President liaisons closely with Nazdeeks team, organizes board meetings and reviews other documents.Jayshree guides Nazdeeks overall strategic planning and management. Team Nazdeek: Director Senior Program Officer Senior Litigation Officer Program Officer Two Program Associates Three Community Mobilisers Office Assistant Additionally, there are other support staff including accountants, consultants, and interns. Our network of 55 community paralegals and grassroots organization partners  informs our project strategies, and leads community-level organizing and advocacy efforts. When strategically required, Nazdeek utilizes the support of pro bono lawyers. We are divided into three project teams: Delhi, Assam and Tamil Nadu.Nazdeeks management and decision-making process is participatory. Team leaders, teams, and paralegal volunteers collaborate on strategies and interventions. Nazdeek encourages its teams wellness and professional development by providing relevant opportunities.     Grant Application Form, July 1 201366b. Describe the financial situation (include information on annual operating costs, fundraising strategy, reserves and debts) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):Operating costs and funds: Nazdeek started in 2012 through crowdfunding. Since 2014, we successfully secured long-term funding, and periodic short-term grants. Nazdeeks organisational budget for 2020-2021 is $250,000, including grants from various funders since: Amplify Change, in partnership with Swadhikar- May 1, 2016Every Mother Counts (core funding)- May 15, 2014 Laudes Foundation- January 1, 2021 Namati- November 15, 2020 The Fund for Global Human Rights (core and project funding)- May 29, 2014 These funders have made long-term commitments to legal empowerment work, and have aided in strengthening Nazdeek. We also receive approximately  $15,000-20,000 annually through individual donations towards programs. Fundraising strategy:Our fundraising needs are identified based on Nazdeeks organisational vision and mission, and an annual strategic assessment of organisational priorities, combined with community, partner organization, and paralegal needs. While no one staff member is dedicated to fundraising, all co-founders, board members, and staff members play a key role in fundraising, including identifying potential donors and writing and pitching proposals.We are occasionally forwarded opportunities by our existing funders. We approach individual donors through fundraising campaigns to account for contingencies. Reserve Funds and Debts: Nazdeeks current reserve is approximately $75,000 and there are no outstanding debts. Expected Changes: The Oak Foundation Grant will enhance our organisational budget significantly, enabling us to realise our vision of introducing our model to other Indian states; undertaking national-level policy advocacy; elevating FRTW from an Indian to an international coalition; and expanding our team. These goals align with the objectives and strategies in our grant proposal. Nazdeeks organisation budget is expected to reach $715,000 by the end of 2024 due to expanded support from one of our current funders and being in an advanced stage of a long-term funding application process.NOTE: The proposed project will be undertaken in partnership with host organisation/s. Grant Application Form, July 1 201376c. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):Nazdeek has successfully worked towards bringing access to justice closer to marginalised communities across South Asia. Since 2012, working closely with Adivasi worker communities, we have conducted numerous trainings to expand workers knowledge of socio-economic, labour, and maternal health rights. Our training aided activists in their fight for a higher minimum wage for tea plantation workers, securing a historic 77% increase in daily wages for 800,000 tea plantation workers in Assam. Following our efforts providing training, conducting community meetings, and advocating for workers, the Assam governments Minimum Wage Advisory Committee recommended another wage increase of 110% (from Rs. 167 to Rs. 351) in 2018.Evidence from our human rights fact-finding investigations and monitoring, such as EndMMNow, supported successful filing of complaints by workers to secure their rightful food, health, housing, and labour benefits. Nazdeek also amplified community voices nationally and globally through published reports: No Time to Lose: Fighting Maternal and Infant Mortality through Community Reporting (2015), A Matter of Life and Death: Surviving Childbirth on Assams Tea Plantations (2018), Hidden Traumas: Uncovering Experiences of Obstetric Violence (2020), and Rising Stronger: Security Strategies for Women Defenders (2020). Our research in Assam and greater South Asia was also critical in our founding of the FRTW in 2019, a first of its kind forum for advancing the rights of tea plantation workers. In Delhi, working with 6 socio-economically marginalised communities, Nazdeeks 35 presently-active paralegal volunteers have ensured basic entitlements such as community clinics and Anganwadi Centers, and housing, water and sanitation rights for over 15,000 residents. Since 2020, Nazdeek and partners have provided COVID-19 humanitarian relief to over 25,000 individuals in Assam, Delhi, and Tamil Nadu. Nazdeeks work was recognised with the Namati Grassroots Justice Prize in 2015 and World Justice Prize in 2019.6d. Describe the current strategy of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):Nazdeeks legal empowerment model places the communities we work with at the center of our work. We aspire to build leadership among women for greater participation in decision-making at the community, state, and policy-making levels. Nazdeeks sustainability strategy creates an advocacy and outreach model owned by the community, which thrives without our presence. Strategy:1. Identifying communities after detailed scoping, assessment, and needs-Grant Application Form, July 1 20138mapping. Through community meetings and partnerships with local organizations, we explain our model and invite participants for trainings. We prioritize outreach in communities marginalised on the basis of social identities like caste, class, religion, migration, and work status. 2. Training participants, predominantly women, to be community paralegals and equipping them with administrative and judicial tools for addressing rights violations. Using participatory methods, we ensure inclusive and safe training spaces for participants. 3. Assisting paralegals in using grievance redressal, policy advocacy, and strategic litigation tools. 4. At every stage, paralegals and communities decide their priorities and initiatives. We assess risks and identify mitigation strategies collectively, prioritising their safety and security. 5. Eventually, paralegals undertake community meetings independently, strengthening their human rights documentation and advocacy skills. Nazdeek then moves to an advisory role. 6. To support the long-term work of paralegals and connect community action to regional initiatives, we facilitate formation of coalitions. 7. Paralegals work on a voluntary basis and are not paid an honorarium. This aligns with Nazdeeks objective of building community leadership, agency,  and ownership of initiatives. Nazdeek does provide them certificates and supports them by sharing opportunities, relevant government schemes, and needs-based communications reimbursements.Since early 2020, due to the pandemic, we have employed several tools to continue engagement remotely. While we prioritise in-person visits, we have now developed novel modes of outreach and maintained our strategy despite the crisis. 6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):Tea plantation workers across South Asia experience dismal living and working conditions, earn meagre wages, and face ineffectual labour law protections. In India, where tea plantation workers are predominantly Adivasi (indigenous) and women, these conditions have led to an intergenerational cycle of oppression and poverty. Key issues faced: Currently, corporations function in the roles previously held by colonial powers, and are primarily responsible for the poor housing, wages, health care, food, water, and sanitation experienced by tea plantation workers. Workers are not paid a legal minimum wage, sufficient to ensure basic necessities for themselves and their families. Women do not receive sufficient medical care, especially pre- and post-natal maternal healthcare, leading to extremely high rates of anaemia, and high Grant Application Form, July 1 20139maternal and infant mortality on tea plantations.Nazdeek, with its partner organizations, has aided workers in addressing these problems and issues. However, recent circumstances have worsened this situation. Challenges: Due to the current political situation in India, organisations and individuals doing cutting edge rights work face a higher risk of coercive actions. Plantations have become inaccessible due to greater surveillance by their management. While the pandemic has opened up new ways of communicating for the rest of the world, our project communities have very limited access to electricity, gadgets, and the internet. The Central government has repealed and replaced 29 previous national labour laws with just 4 labour codes. While the previous laws did not provide robust worker protections, certain laws such as the Plantations Labour Act, did ensure specific protections for workers on tea plantations. Employers have taken advantage of the current legal ambiguities, wherein old laws have been repealed, but the new laws are not yet in force, further limiting the rights of workers on tea plantations. Additionally, the COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in an even more dire situation for tea workers, as the pandemic-induced lockdown has created food scarcity as government-run ration shops and health centers remain closed or under-operational. Conversely, tea workers continue to be forced to work despite the pandemic and minimal safeguards on plantations. Opportunities: Addressing both the long-standing issues experienced by tea plantation workers and the new issues created by the pandemic is a struggle in the current legal and policy climate. However, this also makes it an increasingly important time to mobilize workers and assist them in their advocacy, as workers have the opportunity to comment on proposed laws and shape local policy in an effort to strengthen their legal rights. To overcome communication challenges, Nazdeek, its paralegals, and communities are adopting innovative methods. For example, we recently conducted 12 intensive online training sessions on labour laws with tea workers in Assam. With Central and State governments currently drafting rules to the labour laws, an opportunity has arisen for tea workers to engage in this process and to effect policy and legislative change. Nazdeek has therefore been facilitating their participation through trainings, consultations, and FRTW, resulting in submission of 5 comments to draft rules. This has allowed wider stakeholder representation, and workers have gained confidence to engage in similar processes in the future. Due to the aforementioned threats, now is a critical time for tea plantation workers advocacy. Enhancing their advocacy skills will not only address the immediate needs, but will also shape the future of tea workers rights. Legislative and policy changes now will combat negative effects of Indias new labour laws, as workers will have stronger legal protections and better avenues for demanding adequate wages, maternal health benefits, and improved living and working conditions.Grant Application Form, July 1 201310

GAF_Nazdeek__Inc_EnsurAccesToSocioAndLab.8. COOPERATION: 8. CooperationDescribe the level of cooperation with other organisations and networks and explain how this cooperation helps achieve your goals (maximum 300 words):Nazdeek strongly believes in collaborative work and collective action. To this end, Nazdeek has significant and longstanding partnerships with several community organizations, movements, and coalitions in Assam and other tea-growing states of India (including West Bengal). These groups include tea plantation workers, unions and union representatives, Adivasi community members, and activists, such as: An Adivasi women tea plantation workers collective, whose members have been trained by Nazdeek on socio-economic and labour rights since 7.5.b. Objective 5 Expected results/outcomes and timeframe (maximum 300 words):Outcomes (timeframe: 3 years)a. Increased collaboration, culminating in a national-level rights and advocacy strategy for Indian tea workers representatives, organisations, collectives, movements, and unions, thereby strengthening their collective voice and tea workers representation at the national level.b. Increased engagement, collaboration and knowledge sharing between tea workers representatives, organisations, collectives, movements and unions at an international level.Grant Application Form, July 1 2013152017. Furthermore, Nazdeek has supported the collective in advocating before government officials to bring awareness about rights violations and ensure grievance redressal. Promotion and Advancement of Justice, Harmony and Rights of Adivasis (PAJHRA) is a community-based, Adivasi-led organization based in Assam. PAJHRA promotes the rights of the Adivasi community, and frequently partners with Nazdeek in their advocacy. Nazdeek also collaborates with and provides technical support to civil society groups and unions based in West Bengal, especially through FRTW. FRTW, which Nazdeek facilitated the founding of, is also a crucial partner for this project. FRTW members will be the main leaders of national-level advocacy, as they will directly engage with workers collectives, unions, movements, and government bodies. Nazdeek also collaborates and partners with international CSOs, coalitions, and advocacy groups, and has various technological support partners. By working with these organizations, Nazdeek has gained greater insight into the specific needs and priorities of workers on tea plantations, which has shaped Nazdeeks training and advocacy work in this sector. These partnerships remain critical to our proposed goals, as these organizations and their members will be the ones shaping the course of our legal empowerment training and advocacy around the new labour laws.
GAF_Nazdeek__Inc_EnsurAccesToSocioAndLab.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. ImpactWhat is the change you want to achieve from the overall project? (maximum 300 words):The key changes and results we want to see from this project include: Tea plantation workers in Assam are paid Rs.525 (current demand) daily wage with improved working and living conditions. Significant reduction in maternal and infant deaths on the plantation due to preventable causes or lack of services. Tea plantation workers have the knowledge and support to demand and access their socio-economic rights. Tea plantation workers actively participate in the rulemaking process both at the national and state levels, and have in-depth understanding of proposed laws and their demands. Tea plantation workers ensure state accountability towards the implementation of their laws and policies with a robust and responsive grievance redressal mechanism. Tea plantation workers are able to hold companies accountable for labour Grant Application Form, July 1 201316law violations, thereby ensuring rights of workers. Further expansion of Nazdeeks strategic work in other major tea growing regions of India to build capacity of stakeholders on the changed labour law regime.Strengthened national level movement of tea plantation workers for cross learning, collaboration, and to have a consolidated voice. Tea plantation workers in India have faced increased threats to their socio-economic rights. The changing labour law landscape has weakened the rights previously granted to tea workers, and the COVID-19 pandemic has created food and health crises on the plantations. We aim to strengthen the capacity of tea plantation workers to advocate for their rights, and thereby ensure access to these rights. 10. EvaluationHow will progress be monitored and evaluated? (maximum 300 words):Nazdeek will undertake two kinds of monitoring and evaluation exercises during the course of this project: A. Ongoing monitoring of our project indicators during the project period, which will include: a. Post-session evaluations of our training programs and other relevant activities, using tools such as surveys and feedback mechanisms. Based on the feedback, we will revise future training and activities, in order to best serve project beneficiaries and achieve the most impact. b. Through activity-based indicators, we will undertake continuous project assessment. Team-level monitoring will take place through regular team assessments, meetings and updates, during the course of the project.c. Reliance on a monitoring tool to assess progress of socio-economic rights in our partner communities. We are currently working with a partner organization for developing this tool. This tool will indicate the effectiveness of our strategies in achieving the project goals. B. A formalised, external and independent Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) exercise, to be undertaken with an expert consultant at the end of Year 1 as a preliminary analysis, and final M&E report within 6 months of the final conclusion of the project. These M&E exercises will assess:  a. Implementation of the project plan and programmes. Grant Application Form, July 1 201317b. Assessment of access to socio-economic rights for our partner communities. As mentioned above, this will indicate overall project effectiveness.
GAF_Nazdeek__Inc_EnsurAccesToSocioAndLab.11. ADDITIONAL QUESTIONS/ Future Plans: 11. Future PlansHow will the grant influence the organisation and future plans? (maximum 300 words):For over a decade, Nazdeek has been a key partner to workers collectives and CSOs in the rights movements of tea plantation workers in India. The four new labour codes, and related rules and policies, will have long-lasting effects on the rights of tea plantation workers. Nazdeek intends to continue working with organizations in Assam and replicate its legal empowerment model in West Bengal, and across India through FRTW. This grant opportunity will enable Nazdeek and our partners to affect the drafting and implementation of these new laws across states. This will have a positive impact on workers rights in the future. This grant will ensure that the communities Nazdeek works with will be in the best position to defend their rights, as they will have developed the skill sets necessary to advocate for themselves and will have strong legal protections on which to rely. Aside from Nazdeeks significant advocacy work in India, we have also conducted scoping assessments of the rights of tea plantation workers in Bangladesh, Nepal, and Sri Lanka. Nazdeek is dedicated to supporting tea plantation workers in their advocacy, and it is critical that workers are organized at the national, regional, and international levels to ensure that the industry does not move from one state or country with stronger labour policies to another state or country with weaker ones. A regional or international coalition and movement focused on protecting the socio-economic and labour rights of tea workers is necessary to accomplish this. Nazdeek plans to continue our work in strengthening and expanding the FRTW, to conduct national, regional and international advocacy. This grant would allow Nazdeek to make significant progress in developing this Forum, and further, will bring Nazdeek closer to our goal of ultimately supporting a strong, international FRTW.Grant Application Form, July 1 201318Additionally, as Nazdeek scales up its legal empowerment model, we are also keen to further build our consultant's capacity and professional training on international complaints mechanisms, cross-country/regional learnings on grassroots empowerment models, subject area expertise, workflow management, psychosocial issues and stress management. We hope that the proposed grant will assist in achieving this goal as well.
