GAF_A_ICLEI_South_Asia_CommuLedClimaResi.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT 5a. Tell us about your governance and leadership structures, as well as staff and volunteer base. Highlight any significant recent or expected future Oak Application Form     5changes. If you have an explicit approach to increasing diversity and/or advancing race equity within the organisation, please tell us. (300 words):ICLEI South Asia is registered under the Indian Trusts Act 1882. The organisation is guided by a Board of Trustees. The Executive Director reports to the Board and seeks consent for any issues that need the Boards approval. The Operational Manual and any modifications to the same are approved by the Board of Trustees. The Board of Trustees comprises three representatives. The current members are Ms. Hansa Patel (Chair), Prof. A. K. Maitra (Vice-Chair), and Mr. Emani Kumar (Secretary and Administrator, who also serves as Executive Director of ICLEI South Asia, as per resolution approved by the Board). By rotation, every year one trustee appointed by the Board will resign and the vacancy filled; resigning trustees may be reappointed. The Board of Trustees holds an Annual Meeting every year; in addition, any trustee can call for a meeting of the Board. Under the Board of Trustees falls the Senior Management Committee, which comprises three members  - Mr. Emani Kumar (Executive Director), Mr. Ashish Rao Ghorpade (Deputy Director), and Ms. Soumya Chaturvedula (Deputy Director). Currently there are 75 staff in ICLEI South Asia (spread over India, Nepal and Bangladesh) of which a majority are permanent staff, and about 12 are contractual staff and 3 are consultants. The organisation is non-discriminating and encourages women in leadership positions. In all, there are 54 male and 21 female staff. Out of the 4 main thematic areas in which ICLEI South Asia functions, 3 are led by women (sustainability, energy and biodiversity). For project implementation, a Project Manager is assigned to all projects, who is responsible for the overall coordination and management of the project and reporting to the donors in conjunction with the Executive Director. Project Managers are based on functionality and not necessarily linked to position hierarchy.   5b. Summarise the organisations history.  In addition, highlight 2-3 key achievements.Please keep this brief and list up to 3 key achievements as bullet points. Even though you may have many achievements, please share what is most relevant to the proposed grant. (300 words)ICLEI- Local Governments for Sustainability is the leading global network of 2500+ cities, towns and regions committed to a sustainable future. ICLEI South Asia - the South Asian arm of ICLEI - is a not for profit organization, with the head office, located in Delhi, operational in India since 2005. There is a regional office in Hyderabad, state offices in Tamil Nadu (Coimbatore) and Gujarat (Ahmedabad), and several smaller project offices in different cities. We also have staff based in Bangladesh and Nepal. Three major achievements of ICLEI South Asia are:1.    Over 18 years, office staff strength has increased from 3 to 75, its Oak Application Form     6turnover increasing steadily over the years from about INR 7 crores in 2010 to more than three times the value currently, and it has established itself as a reliable technical support partner for several donor agencies such as GIZ, SDC, IDRC, ADB and others, with multiple projects implemented with their support over time. Its area of work has expanded from primarily energy related projects in 2005, to a wide variety, including climate resilience, water, waste, urban mobility, urban biodiversity, knowledge brokering, gender and environment, among others. 2.    ICLEI South Asia is empanelled with the National Water Mission of Ministry of Jal Shakti as a field agency to undertake work on water conservation, minimizing wastage and increasing water use efficiency through awareness and capacity building, encouraging local planning and participation. ICLEI South Asia is also an empanelled consultant for the Government of Indias other flagship programmes such as the Swachh Bharat Mission (national government empanelled consultants and state level committee member and facilitator in Rajasthan), Smart Cities Mission (empanelled consultant in 5 states) and HRIDAY Scheme (empanelled city anchor in 3 cities). 3.    ICLEI South Asia has developed and implemented replicable, adaptive local government specific tools that can be implemented collaboratively by local governments and communities. In project cities, ICLEI forms stakeholder groups of local NGOs, community representatives, private sector, institutions, etc for better community participation in local governance, and these groups continue their function beyond the project lives.  5c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and decide your approach? If you have undertaken a theory of change exercise, or if you are influenced by research, policy or your own organisations experience, please tell us about this.  Have you consulted with relevant stakeholders, including your communities and others experiencing the problem? Is there an intention to address equity, diversity and inclusion? (600 words):There is intense research on the pressing challenge of access to water and sanitation for tea estate workers and their families in Darjeeling and Kurseong. The situation is also aggravated due to climate change. Climate impacts of decreased rainfall and increased temperatures in the northern part of West Bengal are well recorded in the Indian Network for Climate Change Assessment (INCCA), 2010 and the West Bengal State Action Plan on Climate Change (SAPCC), 2017. Both reports suggest a decrease in overall rainy days and an increase of minimum and maximum temperatures for the region. Such changes are not conducive for tea cultivation, and has resulted in increased dependency on local water reserves, natural streams and reservoirs. A Central Ground Water Board report from 2014 and a study by Rai et al., 2016 suggest natural springs and their watersheds are inefficiently managed and facing degradation. Excessive extraction, coupled with limited recharge or rejuvenation of natural reserves is leading to scarcity of water. The scarce resource is also subject to degradation through extensive use of Oak Application Form     7fertilizer, pesticides, and agrochemicals by the tea gardens and indiscriminate disposal of waste along the mountain slopes and often into the streams. Since some sources of water are available seasonally, there is greater likelihood of them being degraded during the dry spells. Apart from quality and quantity, reliable access to water is challenging as well, with tea estates, hotels promoting tea tourism, the managerial staff of tea estates, tea estate workers and local indigenous communities outside the tea estates all competing for the same scarce resource.  Even though it is evident that the tea estates play a pivotal role as major stakeholders in the water resources of the region, there appears to be a noticeable lack of engagement between the tea estates and the ongoing initiatives of the government. This discrepancy underscores the critical importance of collaboration among different stakeholders. There are a number of schemes of the West Bengal government that are looking at access to water, such as the Jal Dharo, Jal Bharo scheme, the Jaltirtho schemes that are supporting micro-irrigation technologies, as well as water harvesting or storage structures. Some development schemes such as the Kanyashree, Lakshmi Bhandar or Chai Sundari schemes look at housing, education or general social development. The current budget has allocated INR 823 crores for North Bengal development and more than INR 1500 crores for water resources development for the fiscal year 2023-24. In addition, more than INR 1300 crores have been allocated to technical training and skill development.More often than not, access to water is subject to an unwritten hierarchy wherein the indigenous community and the tea estate workers are at the bottom rung. Time and labour-intensive practice of fetching water from faraway places, impacts women in particular from these communities. There are reports indicating that consumption of poor quality water or inadequate water has impacted overall health and adaptive capacity of the workers and marginalised local communities. ICLEIs experience in the region also reflects these findings. Previous work in the region, including in Kurseong, has shown that local communities are rarely involved in the critical aspect of water resource management by local governments. This results in lack of ownership of water related projects and subsequent lack of support by local communities. This means that eventually projects may fall into disrepair, if local communities do not use them properly and carefully. More importantly, the linkages of water resource conservation and solid waste management needs to be highlighted and dealt with effectively to keep water resources clean and safe. Gender aspects of water use and management is also not considered in the planning and implementation of water projects.  This project intends to tackle the water crisis faced by the local communities by using traditional knowledge and community led practices for rainwater harvesting, spring revival, reuse and upcycling of wastewater through coordinated and collaborative efforts of the communities, the local governments and the private sector involving the tea estates and hotels. The project envisages the crucial involvement of local communities, particularly women, right from the development of action plans, their implementation and monitoring as well as replication and scale up. A cadre of barefoot hydrogeologists will be trained from among the local communities, focusing on local women and youth, giving them the necessary wherewithal to Oak Application Form     8prepare basic water conservation plans and manage their resources in collaboration with other stakeholders.
GAF_A_ICLEI_South_Asia_CommuLedClimaResi.7. OBJECTIVES: 7. OBJECTIVESThis is the most important part of your application, as it is your opportunity to explain what you want to achieve and what will be different because of your work. We understand that social and environmental change is complex and there are a multitude of factors that contribute to change. We want to understand how you define your role in the overall change you hope to make. You may find it helpful to discuss this with your Oak Programme Officer, and others in your own organisation.   7.a. ObjectivesList here up to 3 main objectives for this grant (one sentence per objective). Think of objectives as goals that can be achieved within the lifetime of the grant.  We encourage you to think of objective(s) that are ambitious but also achievable.  The project aims to create and institutionalize a replicable model for community-led Integrated Water Resource Management (IWRM), to develop and implement Water Security Plans for tea estates that will help to improve the quality, quantity, access and reliability of water for local communities. The specific objectives of the project include: - To mobilise and build capacity of local indigenous community and migrant tea estate workers as barefoot hydrogeologists, who are able to assess water issues as well as design and implement locally-owned interventions that promote water conservation and rejuvenation, in collaboration with local governments and tea estate management. - To improve overall water availability and equitable access to water, thereby enhancing the adaptive capacity and resilience of local communities.- To create an institutional platform consisting of local governments, community representatives, and tea estate management, for overall management and robust monitoring of the implementation of water security plans, and ensure potential scale up and sustainability. 7.b. Expected Outcomes (bullet points):What do you expect will change because of this grant? What does success look like? List here the main outcomes you hope to achieve or make significant contributions towards with this grant, and for whom.  If you have concrete targets, please also list them here. Outcomes describe significant changes for people, communities, organisations or systems. Some Oak Application Form     9examples are changes in policies and legislation; changes in knowledge, awareness, attitudes, beliefs, behaviours or social norms; changes in capacities, level of influence, agency or access to services. Please refer to the guidance for additional examples.The expected outcomes of the project are: - community led and managed water security plans institutionalized in at least 4 tea estates, and adopted by the local governments in the region. - a cohort of barefoot hydrogeologists including women, formed and institutionalized in the region who can eventually not only identify local water issues, but also design and implement interventions to address such issues and act as local ambassadors for water resource management. At least seven to ten  barefoot hydrogeologists in each tea-estate  to be trained and capacitated. It is also envisaged that at least 50 percent of these barefoot hydrogeologists will be women.- locally responsive water conservation measures implemented collaboratively by local communities, local governments and tea estate management.- creation of a societal platform for local communities and tea estate management to engage and influence the local governments for safe and sustainable water resources.It is well acknowledged that enhancing water security positively influences various socio-economic and environmental aspects. In the project region, women typically are responsible for collection of water and enhanced water security will reduce the workload for women, providing them with more time for education, income-generating activities and community participation. Therefore, it is envisaged that the larger impact of the project will extend  beyond access to water, and will lead to improved health of women in particular but also their families, better access to sanitation, improved solid waste management to clean up water resources, enhanced livelihoods, and, in general, lead to resilient communities.  7.c. Activities and timeframe (bullet points):List in bullet points the main types of activities that you plan to to carry out to achieve your expected outcomes. Please keep these at a high level and and dont include the full list of every activity you plan to carry out, instead, concentrate on the type of activities this grant will fund. If your Programme Officer wants more information, we will ask you separately for a work plan. Examples might include: (1) Research; (2) Provision of legal advice to...; (3) Training on movement building for...The project activities and their timelines are outlined below: 1. Regional scoping and selection of target area of work (M1 - M4)- Selection of 4 target tea estates where the project will be implemented. This will be based on several factors such as:-    Water resources: availability of basic information about water resources and associated issues, watershed area covered by the tea estates, perenniality etc.-    Tea estate: whether owned by the government or private; size of the tea estate; commitment and support from the tea estate management; support from the tea estate unions, proximity and connectivity among others.Oak Application Form     10-    Local communities: size and type of the population, socio-economic conditions, marginalized and disadvantaged population especially women (e.g., migrant laborer, indigenous population), cultural and traditional practices among others-    Presence of Oak/non-Oak partners: opportunity to enhance the synergies between the existing organizations in the tea-estate to ensure maximum impactA list of tea estates will be prepared and analyzed considering the above-mentioned parameters, and will be shared with the Oak Foundation for their review and final selection. 2. Baseline assessment (M2 - M8) - A baseline data assessment of water resource related data, hydro-geological mapping, demography, water use, will be conducted to get ground level information through secondary data collectionThe project team will conduct focused group discussions (FGDs) to verify the secondary information collected from different resources. 3. Gap identification and vulnerability assessment (M6 - M15) - Identification of local issues and climate vulnerability of the regional water resources as well as vulnerability of the local population will be studied. Through FGDs and stakeholder consultations, interventions will be identified to address the water related issues of local communities, with emphasis on traditional practices to address issues on water conservation and management in the region.  4. Training and capacity building of barefoot hydrogeologists (M10 - M30) - Selection of interested community members, including women and youth will be conducted based on the interest of the local communities shown in the FGDs or other consultations. They will be trained as barefoot hydrogeologists and hand holding support will be provided to help them institutionalise the process of local water management.5. Development and government ratification of water security plans (M12 - M22) - Community led and managed water security plans will be prepared by involving all stakeholders including local communities, tea estate management and local governments to identify possible interventions. Opportunities of funding the plans through government or private fund sources will be identified to facilitate its implementation.6. Identification and on ground implementation of pilots (M20 - M30) - Based on local needs assessment, pilot projects will be selected by the local communities and barefoot hydrogeologists from the region for implementation. The selected pilot will be determined from a range of options identified in the water security plans developed. The local communities and barefoot hydrogeologists will identify traditional methods of water conservation and use, through FGDs that can be adapted and replicated as pilot projects. The project team will facilitate the selection by providing technical inputs.7. Institutionalisation and monitoring (M25 - M32) - A framework will be developed for monitoring and used to monitor the implementation of the pilots and the water security plans developed by the barefoot hydrogeologists and societal platform of different stakeholders 8. Dissemination (M32 - M35) - Dissemination of the work and identification of replication opportunities will begin from the training phase, and continue through the project, but will be strengthened at the later stage of the project.9. Reporting and publication (M35-M36) - Some publications are planned during the project, particularly for recording the training process of the Oak Application Form     11barefoot hydrogeologists and the community level interventions implemented; final reporting of project activities will be carried out at the end of the project.
GAF_A_ICLEI_South_Asia_CommuLedClimaResi.8. COOPERATION: 8. COOPERATION  How will you involve others in your approach to achieving change? If you are planning to engage in partnerships with other organisations, communities, people with lived experience, academics or secure the support of key individuals, please tell us about this.  Why are these the right partners to engage with?  Is there anything new about how you are choosing to work - for example, new partnerships or an approach that is different to how you usually work? (300 words):The project proposes to develop a collaborative platform to bring together different stakeholders from government, private sector, NGOs and local communities (particularly women from indigenous and migrant communities) to develop, implement and monitor locally led and managed water security plans. The platform will facilitate interaction between the stakeholders to implement and monitor actions on ground that promote water security that can be scaled up regionally.The information from the gap analysis in the water and sanitation systems and climate vulnerability assessment of the indigenous community, migrant workers and existing water resources will be analysed to develop a climate resilient and equitable Community Led Water Security Plans (WaSP) through this platform with full involvement of the local communities, particularly the cadre of trained barefoot hydrogeologists. ICLEI SA will consult with the local communities (particularly women), migrant workers, tea estate owners and local authorities through workshops and focused group discussions to develop a list of possible interventions, both infrastructural and non-infrastructural. The plans will be ratified by the local governments through their councils to ensure government support, both through supportive policies and possible funding programmes.The Water Security Plans will be developed with particular focus on women, who are largely responsible for household level management of water, but not often engaged in the planning or management of the resources. In addition, tea estate management, being responsible for all actions within their estates, will be involved in the process for greater transparency and engagement. Local governments, responsible for water supply,will be engaged to collaborate and partner with the communities so that all actions are legitimate and acceptable to all parties. ICLEI South Asia regularly works with different stakeholders, governments, communities and private sector to prepare and implement plans. Usually, most of the focus is on engaging local governments, but in this case, the focus will be on the local communities and enabling them to take responsibility of their resources in collaboration with the government.  Oak Application Form     12
GAF_A_ICLEI_South_Asia_CommuLedClimaResi.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING This section is twofold. Please tell us:a) Monitoring and evaluation. How will you know if you are achieving your objectives? Please describe briefly how you will know if you are making progress and if what you are doing is working. If you have a formal monitoring and evaluation system and if you plan to collect indicator data or conduct an external evaluation, please provide details here.b) Learning. Please tell us if there anything in particular that you are hoping to learn more about or test through this grant.(300 words):A design and monitoring framework will be formulated to monitor the project progress and success, clearly articulating the links between issues, interventions, outputs, outcomes and ultimate impact in the context of ensuring water security. The framework will have clearly specified, measurable, achievable targets such as number of households with improved access to water/sanitation, amount/quality of water harvested, number of community engagement events, number of barefoot hydrogeologists (especially women) trained, etc. The framework will articulate the ultimate impact of the project on a larger scale such as improved public health, increased environmental sustainability, and overall well-being of communities. The progress against each indicator will be monitored depending on its objective, either monthly, bi-annually or annually.  The framework will include elements to assess the gender and social inclusivity throughout the project cycle. A stakeholder group, composed of key representatives from marginalized and indigenous populations, especially women, will be formed to act as a voice for the larger population. The  stakeholders group will be involved throughout the planning and implementation of the project. They will provide inputs to the formulation of WaSP, identifying potential interventions to enhance access to water as well as during the implementation and finally operation and maintenance. Open dialogues will be conducted with the targeted population to build trust and ensure that selected interventions are responsive to the needs and aspirations of the community.The process will include quantitative and qualitative information gathered from the beneficiaries through participatory methods. Such qualitative information from the beneficiaries and communities can provide valuable insights and contribute to a more comprehensive assessment of the project success.In addition, a methodology will be identified that can be used periodically by the platform of stakeholders to assess the implementation of the water security plan and monitor it over time. The barefoot hydrogeologists will also be trained on relevant and high-quality data collection for better monitoring. The project will introduce and institutionalize a feedback loop mechanism where community feedback will be incorporated into ongoing MEL processes. Participatory workshops or Focus Group Discussions will be Oak Application Form     13organized semi-annually to get their inputs. By integrating a monitoring framework into Water security plans, stakeholders can make informed decisions, allocate resources effectively, and continuously improve strategies to ensure water availability and access for all while safeguarding the environment.The project will embrace adaptive management principles to ensure that the plan remains relevant and effective in a dynamic environment. Regular review meetings are planned with Oak Foundation to monitor progress and outputs and based on the findings, the team will make necessary adjustments to the project plan by modifying strategies, reallocating resources, or revising targets.
GAF_A_ICLEI_South_Asia_CommuLedClimaResi.10. RISKS AND CHALLENGES: 10.  RISKS AND CHALLENGESWhat are the risks or barriers that might prevent you from achieving your outcomes and how will you address these?  What are your opportunities?We understand that achieving long-lasting and meaningful change is hard and we expect that the work you want to do will mean taking risks.  We encourage you to be open to telling us these, as well as how you will address these risks.  If some of your outcomes are risky, are there any incremental achievements that you could identify? (300 words):The major risks identified for the project include: 1. Non-cooperation by the tea estates: Lack of awareness, common interest, competing priorities or simply no interest towards the larger cause of enhancing water resilience can lead to non-cooperation by the tea estates. Since the project interventions are planned within the boundaries of selected tea estates, it is imperative to bring them on board. The project team will select tea estates that are open minded and interested to improve the water resource situation during the initial assessment. Continuous engagement from the beginning throughout the project  will build their trust and sensitize them toward the issue. 2. Non-cooperation by the local communities: Building trust in external people coming in to resolve local issues is not easy. The project team plans to extensively engage with the communities, including having local staff around for continuous communication, so that trust can be built over time. 3. Political changes: Changes in political leadership, lack of political will or competing priorities can impact the project implementation. Local governments will be engaged right from the beginning and a nodal official will be identified for continuous communication. ICLEIs presence in the region and previous connections will also be useful in this matter.4. Data and information gaps: Insufficient or unreliable data on water resources, usage, and quality can impact informed decision-making and planning. In such a case, state or regional level data will be extrapolated.5. Financial constraints: Lack of funding or budgetary constraints can hinder the implementation of necessary infrastructure and interventions for improving water security. ICLEI is already making plans of applying for Oak Application Form     14funding from other sources and will also explore local government budgets, or state government schemes such as Jal Dharo, Jal Bharo or Jalatirtho will be explored for possible funding. It is to be noted that most of the centrally-sponsored schemes and programmes are not well-supported and implemented in the state of West Bengal, so stress will be on state schemes.

GAF_A_Indo_Global_Social_Service_Society.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT Oak Application Form     55a. Tell us about your governance and leadership structures, as well as staff and volunteer base. Highlight any significant recent or expected future changes. If you have an explicit approach to increasing diversity and/or advancing race equity within the organisation, please tell us. (300 words):Indo Global Social Service Society (IGSSS) has been a prominent social service and development support organization in India. It was incorporated in 1960 and, since its inception, it has supported a variety of social development projects all over the country. Its vision has been to create a humane social order based on truth, equity, freedom, and justice with special emphasis on women, children, and the vulnerable sections of society. Right from its inception IGSSS focuses on social equity and economic justice. And we continue to work with the communities in marginal territories. In the last 63 years, IGSSS has gone through various transitions. Till recently, we used to fund small NGOs but for the last two years, we have become a full-fledged implementing organisation. And right now we are going through on organizational development process focusing on State based approach enabling state units as independent units.IGSSS is guided by an eminent board which meets every quarter to review and guide the organization. The Board also sets policy directions and reviews the impact we are making. The staff team is headed by the Executive Director and organizational leadership is provided through the ED and the senior management team that comprises the Organization Program Sustainability (OPS) Leads, Finance Leads and Thematic Leads. This team collectively shapes ideas for future actions and steering organizational efforts. The interventions are anchored at the state level where State coordinators direct and execute state-level actions. IGSSS comprises over 200 staff now, with over 30% of staff being women and IGSSS promotes gender diversity and inclusion of different marginal spectrum groups in hiring and promotion.For additional details please visit: http://igsss.org/  5b. Summarise the organisations history.  In addition, highlight 2-3 key achievements.Please keep this brief and list up to 3 key achievements as bullet points. Even though you may have many achievements, please share what is most relevant to the proposed grant. (300 words)The organization in the 1960s evolved as a financial grant-making agency with a mandate to work against hunger and poverty. It initially began its operations as Indo-German Social Service Society working with the funds received through funding partners in Germany. In the 1980s the focus shifted to support projects in food production, health care and education, vocational training, employment, and rural development. The renowned Smile Programme (Student Mobilization Initiative for Learning through Exposure) was also started as a national program by IGSSS in 1985. By the 1990s, IGSSS expanded its presence from Delhi to pan India, opening Oak Application Form     6regional offices. It moved from being a funding agency to a supporting organization with collaborations with other NGOs. In the post-2000s era, IGSSS turned a new leaf and adopted a more rights-based approach, underwent an organizational development process, and changed in name, with a renewed vision and mission and strategic thrust areas identified. The organization's name had evolved into the present Indo-Global Social Service Society to reflect the association with global donors. It was in this phase that the homeless program was initiated as a direct implementation. IGSSS in the 2010s decade evolved as a leading grant-making organization in India supporting smaller grass-roots NGOs across the length and breadth of the country. Since 2019 onwards, IGSSS has remodelled our work as an implementing agency, with a new HR structure with state offices and digital strengthening for a people-led global and grassroots action for a just society.IGSSS has been concerned with urban poverty since the turn of the Millennium. Working in over 35 cities, more than 200,000 families have benefitted through 2015  2020. IGSSS now has extensive experience in urban poverty interventions in India and is widely networked with existing CSO actors and movements. In our actions since 2018, we have gradually developed our understanding of sustainability in the urban context and since 2020, through Satat Shehar Programme (2020  ongoing), we have through climate vulnerabilities and impact lens started to mainstream climate action with 260 urban poor communities leading the change. We are having internal organizational experience working with rural climate change actions for many decades and that is helping us immensely in the existing work. This intervention is spread across 13 cities in mostly north, central, and eastern Indian cities with a focus on slums and community development for Unnat Bastis (developedmodel slums). We also have a climate change thematic, that closely works with urban thematic to address urban poor / worker climate change issues in the project actions. IGSSS is also working with governments across scales to push climate action and resilience building, some efforts in Jharkhand, Kashmir, and Odisha are noteworthy. Aside from Satat shehar intervention, in December 2021, IGSSS embarked on initiating a new project for informal workers under the title of Punarnirman (Build back better) (2021-ongoing) for informal workers and their issues of insecure livelihoods, especially in the post  COVID phase in 160 worker collectives. This intervention is spread across 8 cities in mostly north, central, and eastern Indian cities.Climate resilience building for informal sector workers has been completely missed in the state-led interventions till now. Our engagement with worker groups shares the need for an increased focus on developing an understanding of climate impacts and building capacities to deal with them will be critical for informal workers in India. We have made sufficient progress on climate actions since 2020 in urban when we brought in climate action as part of urban interventions. In urban, we are working with the urban poor in behavioural aspects, as well as to secure their settlements. And are already collaborating with numerous experts and organizations on the same.[1]  IGSSS is also increasingly taking up the role of policy development for climate actions through its participation in COP 26 and other national/international platforms to amplify the needs and requirements of urban poor constituents. Lately, we have pushed climate action for informal workers in our national networking meeting under the Punarnirman project action and have just initiated small studies to assess the loss and Oak Application Form     7damage of informal workers; and propose/ frame actions/ policies for different workers to deal with climate impacts.IGSSS interventions in the last many years have seen dozens of policy changes at the state and national levels and successful model interventions  including the successful policy contributions that transformed into guidelines through NULM-SUH, welfare measures for urban poor - homeless during COVID, PMSVANIDHI, and other numerous policy improvements.  Recently IGSSS along with informal worker leaders and federations of hawkers, met representatives of ILO and NitiAyog to push the climate impact agenda of informal workers into policy action. In April 2023, IGSSS was also made a task-force member for NULM 2.0 redrafting process. by MoHUA. It is needed that urgently, in this phase of Indias policy development towards climate resilience, urban informal workers and their impacts, and loss are highlighted to make the policy framework inclusive.  [1] IGSSS through its much older rural work on climate change, and now increasing work on urban climate action is already in collaboration with organizations like CANSA, TERI, INECC and so on. 5c. (600 words):ContextInformal workers form the mainstay of the Indian economy. They constitute a significant portion of the Indian workforce, estimated to be around 90% of the total workforce.[1] Yet they face a lack of job security, low wages, and poor working conditions. They are also not eligible for benefits such as pension, insurance, and paid leave, which are available to formal sector workers. The live-work conditions of informal workers, especially in cities are an ignored reality wherein the formal state-led (exclusionary) urban vision has neglected the settlements that house the informal workers. Whilst there are initiatives taken by the state to bring the workers rights under a broad umbrella of reformed legislations to provide social security to informal workers, the coverage is still limited and restricted, and not holistic.[2]The COVID pandemic has ruptured the status quo and lifted the veil on the fault lines in our society. The crisis uncovered the sheer lack of security  social and economic  and the mere reach that the state extended on its vulnerable people. The pandemic began in the cities in India. The hardest hit is the most invisible poor  informal workers, migrant workers and marginal groups living in slums and other makeshift dwellings, across urban geographies.  As the economy is gradually returning to normalcy, in the post-pandemic era, numerous initiatives with a climate resilience perspective are being undertaken at a national level including dovetailing existing Oak Application Form     8developmentinfrastructure programs into climate change discourse. Unfortunately, very less of this is concerned with urban informal workers' livelihoods and life in the city.Situation Analysis: Assessing the situation of workers in the Kolkata Metropolitan AreaThe Kolkata Metropolitan Area is a metropolitan area in the Indian state of West Bengal, centred around the city of Kolkata (also known as Calcutta). It is the largest urban agglomeration in the eastern part of India and the third largest in the country, housing over 14.85 million people, as of the 2011 census. The Kolkata Metropolitan Area is comprised of the city of Kolkata, its suburbs, several neighbouring towns (including 4 municipal corporations, and 27 municipalities) and adjoining rural areas. It is the economic, cultural, and educational hub of eastern India and hosts several major commercial and industrial centres, making it one of the most important economic zones in India.[3]Informal workers like street vendors, domestic workers, construction workers and waste pickers are expected to be around 20 - 25 lakh (over 2 million) in a similar situation as other parts of the country, without much social security and living in the margins of the current developmental discourse. The KMA also has a large informal sector that employs a significant number of migrant workers, particularly in construction, domestic work, and small-scale industries. These workers face compounded challenges such as low wages, long working hours, and poor working conditions. Many of them live in makeshift housing and lack access to basic amenities like clean water, sanitation, and health care. Migrant workers face social challenges, such as discrimination, isolation, and limited access to education and health services. It is estimated that around 50% of the informal workers (1 million) are migrants, with an equal percentage from other districts of Bengal and migrants from other states like Bihar, Odisha, Jharkhand, and Assam. An equal or similar share of outmigration is reported as well.[4]The Kolkata Metropolitan Area is also located precariously. Like many other coastal cities in the world, is facing a range of impacts from climate change and is listed in the top eight megacities to be first impacted by climate change. The city is in the deltaic region of eastern India, which makes it vulnerable to sea level rise and increased frequency and intensity of extreme weather events such as tropical cyclones, heavy rainfall, and heat waves.[5] The changing climate is leading to an increased risk of coastal flooding and erosion, as well as water scarcity, particularly during the dry season. The city's infrastructure and public services, including transportation, energy, and water systems, are also vulnerable to the impacts of climate change, which can strain these systems and result in economic losses. In addition to the physical impacts, the changing climate also has social and economic impacts on the people of the Kolkata Metropolitan Area. The most impacted areas overlapping directly with the informal worker settlements in the region are vulnerable to displacement, loss of livelihoods, and increased poverty because of climate change.To address these challenges, the government in the Kolkata Metropolitan Area, led by the Kolkata Municipal Corporation are taking steps to increase the region's resilience to climate change. This includes implementing flood control measures, improving disaster preparedness and response, investing in climate-resilient infrastructure, and preparing climate action plans for Oak Application Form     9their cities.[6][7] The major concern in the slew of positively directed actions is that informal workers, their live-work settlements and their livelihoods as of now are not a major focus area of the climate resilience actions pushed by the state and authorities. Thereby ignoring the most vulnerable, impacted informal workers from the climate resilience action plans for the region. Also straight-jacketed approaches of focusing on the urban infrastructure building, without focusing on capacities and linkages ignoring migration from climate-impacted rural regions is another gap amongst many in the climate resilience actions. This approach requires a change: in perspective and in action.  That is what PARIVARTAN intervention sets to achieve  CHANGE that is for and led by the empowerment of the most vulnerable informal worker communities.The situation analysis and approach have been developed in discussion with experts on climate actions and informal workers, existing secondary sources, IGSSS urban teams' experience and previous consultations organized by IGSSS. The project aims to keep inclusion, equity and diversity of informal workers along with gender concerns at the core of project interventions.[1] In India, informal workers are those individuals who work in unorganized sectors and are not covered by labour laws or social security measures. This segment of the workforce includes self-employed individuals, casual labourers, street vendors, domestic workers, and other unorganized sector workers.[2] The labour codes in India refer to a set of laws and regulations that govern various aspects of employment, including wages, working conditions, social security, and industrial relations. In 2020, the Indian government introduced four new labour codes, namely, the Code on Wages, the Industrial Relations Code, the Occupational Safety, Health and Working Conditions Code, and the Social Security Code.[3] https://kmda.wb.gov.in/[4] https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/more-migrants-to-city-from-other-states-than-districts/articleshow/70354414.cms[5] https://www.downtoearth.org.in/news/climate-change/disaster-deaths-sinking-unprepared-kolkata-face-multiple-climate-risks-warns-ipcc-report-82004[6] https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/kolkata-set-to-get-own-climate-action-plan-2nd-city-after-mum/articleshow/92049423.cms[7] https://www.downtoearth.org.in/news/governance/cop27-kolkata-presents-climate-action-roadmap-announces-city-level-summit-86026

OBJECTIVESOak Application Form     10This is the most important part of your application, as it is your opportunity to explain what you want to achieve and what will be different because of your work. The Objectives & ResultsProject GoalNetworks of enabled Worker Collectives, Civil Society Organizations (CSOs), and select local authorities in the Kolkata Metropolitan Region actively promote access to secure dignity, social security, self-reliance, and climate resilience for sustainable livelihoods & settlements for informal workers.Objective 1: Strengthen the capacities of 100 worker collectives by enabling 100Shramik Mitras (literally  worker friends) as Social Change Agents (SCA) to facilitate 20,000 shramik (informal workers, migrant workers) to access their social security  entitlements, social protection, climate adaptation awareness and skills in the local for self  reliant worker collectives.Objective 2: Promoting disaster risk reduction and enabling resilient infrastructure in 50 worker settlements through awareness - capacities, by developing local area plans, mobilizing resources and collective action of worker collectives & 30 worker settlements to secure community services, infrastructure, and climate resilient worker settlements/work sites.Objective 3: Enabling informal workers collectives to transform into federations of membership-based organisations (MBOs) as self-reliant, and resilient livelihood collectives that are community-run and managed to work in collaboration with CSO networks, ULBs, government agencies and private sector enterprises for mainstreaming informal worker issues and forging safe-migration networks with urbanrural linkages.7.b. As an approach to look at the urban-rural continuum for interventions, the migrants will be treated as a special category to ensure safeinformed migration to the KMA through gradually evolved networks.  It is to be noted that there is also a special gendered marginality within these groups, where women's participation and vulnerability are increasing. Aside from the four population groups of informal workers, future informal workers (gig workers) and climate-impacted refugee migrants will be closely worked with, special attention will be given to vulnerable-dependent groups within workers like women, single women, elderly and so on.The main set of actions for building resilient worker collectives is the following:At the local/micro level1. Developing ruralurban linkages through 8 campaigns by CSO networks and worker leaders for migrant workers.10. 8 federation buildings of informal sector workers in KMA, West Bengal & sharing at the National level.Oak Application Form     13The main set of actions for building resilient worker collectives is the following:At the local /micro level1.Building self-reliant worker collectives: Informal workers access their identification, entitlements, and basic services through community-managed WRCs (worker resource centres) in the local and collectives formalize as membership-based organizations for self-reliance. In year 1, community mobilization will be the focus, in years 2 & 3 gradually the focus will shift towards self-reliance and local-level resilience, in year 4 there will be a focus shift towards worker collectives sustainability and formalization of collectives.2.Climate-resilient livelihood capacity building and training: Providing training and capacity-building opportunities to informal workers on climate-resilient livelihood practices and techniques can help them to better adapt to changing conditions. Year 1 actions will be directed at understanding the issues of workers through a climate lens, making action plans and acting on them. At the outset, there will be PLA workshops organized with different workers themselves and through those exercises, the nuanced nature of impacts will be mapped and then the resilience practices will be developed accordingly. The practices will differ for each population group as their nature of work differs dramatically. Years 2 & 3 will lead to more focused capacity building on climate resilience. Year 4 will document  formalize the impacts, success, and challenges of capacity-building actions. To address the gender aspects sub-group worker workshops will be hosted to and through facilitation will the gender issues be noted and an action plan developed. Years 2 & 3 will lead to more focused capacity building on climate resilience. Year 4 will document  formalize the impacts, success, and challenges of capacity-building actions.3.Providing education and skills training: Workers, especially, women and migrant workers can benefit from education and skills training programs that can help them upgrade their skills/ upscale actions and find better-paying jobs. Baseline mapping and needs will be assessed in year 1, and support/ training initiated for skilling. Year 2 will focus on assessing the impacts and improving the modules. Years 3 & 4 will scale, document, and share the impacts, successes, and challenges of skilling workers.4.Access to finance and initiating collective income generation actions: Providing access to finance, including microfinance services, can help informal workers in Kolkata start new businesses or diversify their income streams, making them more resilient to the impacts of climate change. NULM - SHG funds are expected to be a resource for such program actions. Or programs like PMSVANIDHI that were introduced by govt. post covid for street vendors. This is especially critical in post-COVID times. Like other capacity-building actions, year 1 will assess the needs and initiate income generation skilling and designing project actions, and years 2 & 3 will be about piloting them and documenting their impacts. Year 3 will scale, document, and share the impacts, successes, and challenges of income generation modules.Oak Application Form     145.Special focus on inclusion of women workers and migrant workers: As a practice and strategy, the aim will be to focus on the most vulnerable workers like women workers and migrant workers for all actions to ensure their inclusion.At the community/ meso level6.Disaster risk reduction education and preparedness in worker settlements/worksites: Informal workers should be educated on disaster risk reduction measures, including evacuation procedures, early warning systems, and proper storage and handling of goods. This is to be executed both at informal workers' livelihood sites as well as their living settlements. Year 1 will be aimed at simplified understanding and mapping of climate impacts, disaster risks and threats on maps documenting them. Year 2 will be focused on acting on them and developing preparedness in communities and engaging with authorities for executing them. Years 3 & 4 will repeat the process and refresh preparedness plans and task force teams from communities will be ready for any disasters.7.Improved and resilient infrastructure in worker settlements/worksites: Improving the infrastructure in informal worker communities, such as street vendor markets and in their living settlements - slums, can help to reduce their exposure to extreme weather events and improve their overall living/ working conditions. Starting from preparedness and evacuation maps in year 1, in year 2 community-led planning for improved  resilient settlements and worksites will be initiated and submitted as Local Area Plans (LAPs) to the authorities. In years 3 & 4, the exercise will be undertaken further to improve the condition of the settlement to a model settlement that can be upscaled later. With the last year to focus on documentation and scaling of resilience-building practices. In Year 1,2 along with CSO support worker communities will be supported for sociallegal assistance. Year 3 practices and methods will be documented during implementation. Year 4 impacts will be assessed, practices improved and actions scaled.  9.Policy engagement for inclusion of workers: Policy engagement efforts can help to address the systemic issues that contribute to the vulnerability of informal workers in Kolkata, including promoting decent working conditions and strengthening labour laws. Year 2 will work on the implementation of collaborative actions and Years 3 & 4 will focus on the formalization of actions and collaborations.11.Developing ruralurban linkages through CSO networks and worker leaders for migrant workers: Building community support networks: Migrant workers can benefit from community support networks that provide them with emotional and practical support. These networks can also help them access resources and services that they might not otherwise be able to access. Year 1 will focus mostly on sharing practices and experiences. Years 2 & 3 on piloting engagements and exchanges with networks, and communities. Year 4 will document, upscale and formalize the interventions, vis--vis migrants.12.Federation building of informal sector workers in KMA, West Bengal & sharing at the National level: The worker collectives, CSOs and networks will work together to mainstream informal workers' concerns in emerging issues of urban development and climate resilience building. There will be a workers federation emerging in KMA, and through networking at the state level and national levels, the worker's issues will be mainstreamed with climate resilience actions. As per the collectives strength, guidance and support will be offered from year 1 onwards. With a special focus to scale efforts in year 2 and on building formal institutions in years 3 and 4.Strategies for the Interventions1.Vision for Sustainable Cities & Resilience Building as the overarching framework for Interventions for IGSSS: The changed context of Indian cities is the key reason for the proposition of an overarching framework of sustainable cities that addresses not only the issue of inclusivity but equity along with the issues of sustainability, resilience, urban governance and participation in the city making process. The vision for sustainable cities developed in 2020 still holds good and needs to be furthered with the resilience building of informal worker communities. IGSSS has since 2020 moved beyond sustainability, but also is in the process of developing a holistic organizational process for resilience building. The ongoing churning also forms the basis for the interventions proposed in the proposed intervention.2.Demystifying climate resilience for enabling localized actions: To enable localized actions, it is important to demystify climate resilience by breaking it down into more manageable components. It will be expected that IGSSS collaborates and partner with technical agencies with expertise in climate action, but the project will strive to develop community expertise in addressing the resilience needs.  By taking steps to demystify climate resilience for informal workers, Oak Application Form     16localized actions can be taken to support these workers in adapting to and building resilience against the impacts of climate change. This can help ensure that the most vulnerable members of society are not left behind in the face of this global challenge.3.Planned interventions in all levels and scales  The proposed interventions are imagined to be at the level of local/ micro level, community/ meso level, city, state, and national/ macro level. The local/micro will focus mostly on informal worker collectives and their needs in the local like capacities, training, access to identity, entitlements and so on. At the community level/ meso level, the focus is more on developing resilience at their working and living sites and will involve engagements with the wider community. At the city, state, and national/macro levels, the focus will be on policy change and network building. This differential level intervention has worked well in the previous IGSSS actions and suits well for an informal worker climate resilience project, and we hope to improve the same in the coming interventions.4.Gradual/strategic development of project actions led by worker collectives starting from micro to macro:  Since the focus of the project is community mobilization leading to resilience building, the focus initially (year 1) will be on building capacities of the collectives, starting with initial low hanging fruits like entitlements and identity documents, then going on to engage on meso level issues of developing the worker settlements, then with support from CSO network groups could influence and reach out to government and private players accountability. As we move towards year 2 and year 3, the focus will shift from collectivization to collective action on objective2 (community level) and 3 (city/state federations). Objective 1 actions will be led by worker leaders themselves in the long run and are imagined to be sustainable in a span of two project cycles.5.People (worker) led development in the micro, meso, and IGSSS-led action in the macro level: The worker and community collectives in the local are expected to take complete ownership of the actions at the local and community level. Training and mobilization of worker collectives will be the prerogative of IGSSS local staff. The state staff will focus on networking// federation at the city/ state level for collaborative actions. The IGSSS Thematic will steer networking at a national level and contribute to the policy discourse on climate change, informal workers and urbanization in India and Global South from a resilience lens.6.Developing peoples institutions and organizations: The proposed program envisages that community collectives/ peoples organizations do not just remain as community-based initiatives in the project period but sustain and continue to work as bulwarks of local democracy and urban resilience for worker communities. This will be attempted through a host of capacity building and handholding of the worker collectives. Alongside this, the key strategy will be to work at their personal level on life skills, building resilience and developing a mechanism for reporting violations and abuses to key points for address and preservation of dignity in their lives, also by supporting Oak Application Form     17the community collectives to adopt sustainable and resilience building initiatives in their local and community level.7.Building networks and sustaining established ones  The terrain from the national level policy engagement has shifted to the state and ULB levels. It is in this context that the premise of community federations into a larger critical mass is foundational to having larger-level policy engagement. Community collectives, extremely successful locals, need spaces and opportunities to collaborate and learn from each other to raise bigger demands for more inclusive city spaces and participatory decision-making. This underlying theme forms the other fundamental assumption in the project design. Consequently, such spaces for forming city-level and state-level federations are provided for in the project intervention that will go a long way in engaging with the state and mainstreaming the informal workers and climate justice discourse in policy circles. It is also expected that these networks that develop will be composed of middle-class groups, and private agencies/ bodies as well, with a common consensus developed with the informal workers to demand climate resilience and sustainable cities for all.8.Policy engagement, as well as collaboration with the different levels of the government  Engagement and working with the state, is put forth as the only way to better the development of communities and cities. Especially for informal workers in the context of climate resilience building. The reason why the different levels of state and bureaucracy fail to function as expected is because of the lack of engagement, access and proximity to the urban poor issues, it is this gap that the project wishes to address between the communities and the state, through multifarious engagements from the local community development plans to the state - national policy level discussions. The state, especially the ULBs are looking for collaborative opportunities with organizations for climate action and that space needs to be utilized. Existing Oak Foundation partners with networks will also aid in the process of building collaborations, especially with the private sector.9.Thematic Hub of Urban Poverty Reduction contributes to national-level policy discourse: The last phase has initiated the development of the Urban Poverty Thematic Hub in IGSSS, it is in now a steering position to direct the national discourse on sustainable urbanization, wrt to informal workers and their inclusion in urban resilience  climate actions. With a good number of partners and networks, it is expected that a strong national network will emerge to keep a close watch on policy development and aid in developing the understanding of urban poor and climatic justice discourse with the CSOs and wider public nationally, and internationally.10.Research and documentation will be integral to the project and would strengthen the engagement initiatives. The city and state-level situations/ datasets of the target groups will be consolidated at the national level for effective engagement. The information from cities and states shall also help in building/contributing to campaigns, collaborations, and policy engagement at the state/national level.Staff structureOak Application Form     18The staff structure is to suit the implementation reality. There will be more focus on rooting the interventions with the community mobilisers, who will be leading the interventions in the communities mostly under micro-level actions. The community mobilisers will be supported by a community coordinator who capacitates communities for meso actions and supports networking at the city/state level. The capacity building and training officer will be entrusted with training communities, and leaders through IGSSS city & local staff and developing and executing the training modules. The project coordinator will be the executing in charge of the project. The thematic leads on urban and climate change will lead the overall envisioning and coordination of key actions in the project.
