GAF_A_Indo_Global_Social_Service_Society.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING This section is twofold. Please tell us:a) Monitoring and evaluation. How will you know if you are achieving your objectives? Please describe briefly how you will know if you are making progress and if what you are doing is working. If you have a formal monitoring and evaluation system and if you plan to collect indicator data or conduct an external evaluation, please provide details here.b) Learning. Please tell us if there anything in particular that you are hoping to learn more about or test through this grant.(300 words):Monitoring plan of IGSSSAll projects implemented by IGSSS begin with the bassline and sets the targets to be achieved. Both the project implementation and financial accounting are investigated at the time of the monitoring visit by the teams. PME unit and Programme Management teams also visit the field and provide support to ensure that implementation/operations are on track. Half-yearly review meeting with teams is also conducted regionally for result tracking and cross-learning.Management Information System (MIS)The project level MIS begins with - 1. Analysis and benchmarking of a baseline study of any project before its inception at the project level. Thereafter 2. refinement of the project indicators based on RBM and IGSSS strategic plans may be carried out. In discussions with funding partners and organizations. 3. Setting up performance tracking tables at the project level with targets and baseline figures to be finalized. 4. Setting project-level tools for recording results. We use e-tools like the Kobo collects app to collect and record data at the field level. Then, 5. periodic data collection and compilation are executed. Usually, this is in sync with the reporting cycles and data is assessed every quarter. Afterwhich 6. Analysis of data generated and reporting is shared with funding partners and within IGSSS as well.  At the organizational level, where project level MIS feeds into. The monitoring and evaluation unit of IGSSS helps the project level actions with 1. setting up of indicators based on IGSSS strategic plan and objectives. 2. pooling out the information from individual projects. 3. periodic data collection and compilation and 4. aid the respective thematic team with reporting as well. Internal Reporting:Within IGSSS, reporting is on a project-to-project basis. IGSSS state units submit their progress reports to the thematic leads. The state coordinators verify the reports and forward them to the thematic with their recommendations and observations. This is vetted and supported by the Urban Poverty Reduction Team. Regular program-related and financial feedback is provided by the grants team, based in Delhi. Technical inputs are also provided on MIS by the M&E working under the grants team. Thematic and financial management support is actively provided to each state to smoothen coordination processes. The yearly audit is carried out on the completion of the Grant period. The state teams prepare timely reports, based on the work done in communities, taking stock of the activities that have been undertaken during that time. The quarterly activity updates and six-monthly reports are submitted to the respective thematic offices of IGSSS. The thematic offices submit a six-Oak Application Form     23monthly report to the Programme Management & Grants team based at IGSSS Delhi. The team reviews the report and verifies the information from other sources and reporting tools. Appropriate feedback is provided to the state offices, where course correction or supportive inputs are required. The urban thematic unit drafts the report, which is then finalized and shared with funding partners.
GAF_A_Indo_Global_Social_Service_Society.10. RISKS AND CHALLENGES: 10.  RISKS AND CHALLENGESWhat are the risks or barriers that might prevent you from achieving your outcomes and how will you address these?  What are your opportunities?We understand that achieving long-lasting and meaningful change is hard and we expect that the work you want to do will mean taking risks.  We encourage you to be open to telling us these, as well as how you will address these risks.  If some of your outcomes are risky, are there any incremental achievements that you could identify? (300 words):Risks, Outlook, Prospects and Sustainability of ActionsThere is an increasing amount of distrust of the authorities towards NGOs and the changed legal rules that discourage networking is one such perfect example. Going forward in the coming years it will be increasingly tough to work on policy engagement and recommendations, it is better to adopt a more  model-based approach. There are also similar locational issues that are bound to impact the interventions. The project proposal rests on the premise that climate-resilient model building and scaling with collaborations with state and non-state actors is the best way forward. And will address the mistrust with some of the authorities. The pandemic has resulted in the state and administration retracting a lot  with respect to the budgets and attention to the urban poor and worker needs. It is expected that the welfare state and policy provisions are bound to shrink in the coming years. Thereby recognizing that policy-level engagements become further complicated. The silver lining though is that the concept of climate resilience for informal workers may be the most suited to this urban poverty team and its interventions for informal workers at this stage of the intervention. As the issue is of prime importance to the state and authorities and will be more receptive to ideas and suggestions for improving the same.Operational challenges: technical financial and partner-related risks.The change in the laws related to Foreign Contribution Regulation in India: The NGOs cannot use 20% of funds in administrative expenses, thereby putting further restrictions in the manner where collaborative and joint interventions will now be restricted or must be strategically reduced to adhere to the guidelines. These factors have been accounted for in the project design.The program design is based on network building and its challenges:  Due to the changed law, the project intervention has been Oak Application Form     24now conceived wholly to be directly implemented by IGSSS. The erstwhile partners and networks of IGSSS in the form of CSOs, CBOs and networks will remain as joint actors for engagement and campaigns, and specific support will be extended to local CSOs who will be engaged with and if needed capacitated to address the issues of climate resilience. Thereby imagining partnerships from the earlier formal project-based collaborations to more organic issue-based non-financial collaborations to allow for the transfer of knowledge and domain knowledge of emerging challenges of urban through networking at levels and scales.  Stressing innovative approaches and income generation for COVID realities: post  COVID economic slowdown and lack of livelihoods are going to be a reality for the next five years. To kick-start the interventions and to ensure the project aims for sustainable practices innovative models have been dovetailed into the proposals. Like  Worker resource centres, will ensure more accessible locations for communities to get access to and resolve their livelihoods concerns. These centres will be run by trained community volunteers. To propagate climate resilience for informal workers practice models will be identified, documented, and scaled with support, and shared for wider implementation across CSO networks. Also, the COVID-19 pandemic has brought a livelihood crisis that will be only ameliorated with income generation and community institution/ membership models that this intervention aims to support and nurture for the long term. The following actions/ strategies are thought to ensure the viability of the project: People-led actions and change: The principle of a rights-based approach is at the core of all programming under the proposed initiative, where the focus is on capacitating the workers belonging to the marginalised sections of the urban to access their rights to identity, entitlements, and habitats and livelihoods. The focus on creating a capacitated community leadership and cadre to lead the interventions will also go a long way to ensure that the community efforts remain sustainable. Institution/ capacity building of worker collectives and structures to ensure that the community owns and invests in all development actions planned and implemented in their contexts. This would include worker collectives, CBOs, Self Help Groups, and City level federations that are formalized and transformed to peoples organizations and institutions. The networks and alliances created at the local, state, and national levels with diverse stakeholders and actors will lead to capacitated CSOs working on informal workers and climate resilience. Thereby far outliving the project duration. This will also popularize the informal workers and their climate resilience discourse amongst the many networks and in the development sector in India.   Convergence and collaborations with state and non-state actors: Convergence and collaboration with resources and entitlements from the government have been a central strategy underpinning the work with communities. This will be promoted in this project as well  through linkages with the already listed policy engagements, implementation of existing laws and acts, as well as with the line departments and ULBs of the urban areas. Expenses will be made on the least cost basis without Oak Application Form     25compromising quality. Low-cost meetings, workshops, exposures, conventions, etc. will be arranged so that these can be continued even after the project period with minimal external financial support. Low-cost and climate-conscious project actions: Exploring new ways of working together with minimal resources  for example, collaborations with alliances and networks, sharing of knowledge/know-how with like-minded institutions, and building up a strong case for evidential engagement through joint research and action. The activated communities and networks will be hoped to continue the development work that they learned during the project time. Any support offered in the name of model building and initial grounding of climate resilience models and income generational activities will be left with the community itself. At an organizational level, it is further decided that all meetings and gatherings hosted by IGSSS will avoid the use of plastic. And travels between cities will be promoted through rail only. Only in case of large distances will air/flight will be considered.Phasing of project interventions: IGSSS has imagined and designed this phase of work with informal workers and climate resilience for the 2023-26 phase. IGSSS's understanding of informal workers, and sustainable cities have further improved in the last five years, and we hope to continue with our sustainable  resilient cities framework that the urban team has devised for interventions. The proposed phase will have its evaluations carried out and the strategy for further actions and interventions will be decided in consultation with stakeholders and actors. It is expected that the program will be continued in at least one more phase of interventions in the same area with the constituent groups
GAF_A_Indo_Global_Social_Service_Society.11. ADDITIONAL QUESTIONS/ Future Plans: 11.  ADDITIONAL QUESTIONSPlease use this space to respond to any specific questions from your Oak programme officer. If none were received, please leave this section blank. First Set of Questions responded on 17.02.2023The request is heavy on reaching out and collectivizing the workers and their families for claiming entitlements and services and less so on government and private players accountability towards them beyond ensuring the entitlementsComment taken and accepted; this could be tweaked in the proposal if required. But most of the focus initially (year 1) will be at building capacities of the collectives, starting with initial low-hanging fruits like entitlements, then developing the worker settlements (which is very tough), then with support from CSO network groups could influence and reach out to government and private players accountability in year 2. As we move towards year 3 and year 4, the focus will shift from collectivization to Oak Application Form     26collective action on objective2 (community level) and 3 (city/state federations). Objective 1 actions will be led by the worker leaders themselves.Government will be easier, but private players will be a challenge. As shared by you earlier as well, we can reach out / collaborate with jan sahas or other oak foundation partners who are working with private players, that will make the engagements easy to begin with. Please share any other suggestion that you might have.Is there a plan to collaborate with technical organisations on issues like mitigating impact on migrant  workers from heat stress, air and noise pollution ? in other words, build their resilience to the changing climate ?Yes, we have made sufficient progress on climate actions since 2020, when we brought in the climate action as part of urban interventions. Rural interventions have long had climate resilience building programs. In urban, we are working with workers in behavioural aspects, as well as to secure their livelihoods and settlements. And are collaborating with numerous experts and organizations on the same. Like CANSA, TERI, INECC and so on. But we are also clear that it is only worker/ community collectives plus the technical support partners, who can combine think of innovative ways of addressing climate action for workers. As sometimes, it is easy to get stuck in the technicalities and workers lose the connection with the climate impact issue, and solutions are not accessible, easy to scale and replicate. Lately, we have pushed climate action for informal workers in our national networking meeting and have just initiated small studies to assess the loss and damage; and propose/ frame actions/ policies for different workers. I will keep you in loop and posted of the same. Also, we with support frm hawker federation leaders are engaged in policy engagement and advocacy, and recently met ILO and NitiAyog to push climate impact agenda of informal worker into policy action.  Which they have agreed to incorporate.To what extent will the design be drawn based on inputs from primary communities?Oh, very much. I think I answered this question above. It has to be based and led by primary / impacted communities. Or else climate action of mitigation, adaptation and resilience will not succeed. Mitigation might, but other two will not. This is our experience of working on climate change in urban since 2020.What is the expected cost of the project? do you have any committed /potential funding? what is the amount expected from Oak?We have not calculated the expected project costs in detail but are looking at tentatively around 4 Cr for a 4-year intervention. We can think about raising local resources from other donors and existing programs / projects but will be an expecting or seeking Oak to fund majority costs of the same. Will be better to discuss this and the scale of the program as well before arriving at a figure.Explain what is IGSSSs experience on this broad topic? How will you provide key advisory to government bodies to reduce climate impact on workers who have to be in the open to carry out their work  like work Oak Application Form     27with the pollution control board and department of health? Who do you see as the key ecosystem players?IGSSS is having extensive experience of over 12 years of urban poverty interventions in urban. And increasingly, since 2020 we have through climate vulnerabilities and impact lens started to mainstream climate action with communities leading the change. We are having internal organizational experience of working with rural climate change actions for over many decades and that is helping us immensely in the existing/proposed work. We also have a climate change thematic, that closely works with urban thematic to address urban poor / worker climate change issues. We can prepare a note on the measures taken by urban team on climate change actions. IGSSS is also working with governments across scales to push climate action and resilience building.For impacting policies, the first step will be document the impact, calculate the losses, place the requirements  demands from the community into policies and laws for informal workers so to address the damages caused by climate change. We are at this stage of the development and with urban poor communities we have carried out strong  successful pilots in 13 cities. With informal workers taking examples from 8 cities, we are undertaking studies and engaging with policy makers to reframe climate policies wrt to urban poor and workers. The second step shall be to engage with the respective players, the welfare boards, the ULBs, the climate change ministry and other policy think tanks of the state. Thereafter the next step will be to take it to the implementation departments like PCB, health, and so on. The second and third step we wish to undertake in this year.Please share some documents about IGSSSs organogram and board in India. Last information on the FCRA status of IGSSS will be useful.Last information on FCRA status is that it is awarded till March 2023. We have not had any queries and the process was smooth. We are hopeful to have the same approved very soon. Organogram and board details I will be sharing in the mail.  Second Set of Questions responded on 28.03.2023Questions from the Director  India Programme and the President:References where IGSSS's work has been recognized by the policy andSome of the policy impacts are as follows:IGSSS contribution to NULM-SUH in 2011- 2012  IGSSS model shelters for women/ livelihood program for homeless in Delhi 2011-15Notification of holistic response for homeless during COVID outbreak MoHUA - 2020Notification for vaccination for homeless MoHUA  2020Notification of world homeless day in AP, MH, DL  2018 - 2022Notification for winter response and shelters for urban homeless by MoHUA  2021Oak Application Form     28Rules for transgender welfare board in Madhya Pradesh by Social Justice department - 2022Simplification of guidelines / operational manual for working with communities during COVID outbreak & contribution to NDMA NGO coordination group  2020  21National draft policy and acceptance by BMC for city level policy  2021 - 22Allocation by BMC for homeless shelters in Mumbai Development Plan 2014-34 & Allocations in BMC budget  2015 & onwardsFirst set of byelaws for street vendors presented to AMC  2022Policy improvement for slums on railway land  Surat Slum dwellers right to housing recognized.  2022IGSSS part of select organization to assist MoHUA in transformation of NULM 2.0 especially for NULM-SUH  2023If you wish, we can prepare a set of annexures on the policy impacts that we have had in as urban team. The annexures could be in the form of publications, correspondences, and orders.In the proposed request, what are the different levels in the government that IGSSS plans to engage ?In the proposed project, it is expected that the closest engagement will be with the ULBs, and state government. Through the other existing project action and the CSO networking in the proposed there will be engagements with the central level ministries and agencies. The most focus will be with ULBs and state government, ministries and departments.What is the expected timeline of support from Oak beyond the four years' of this request ? what kind of sustainable funding sources does IGSSS have that may be invested in this programme?The request is for 4 years for this project. We are heavily invested in informal workers and urban poor communities and are hoping to continue our key flagship projects of satat shehar & punarnirman for urban poor and informal workers in the coming years. And as a development agency, we have committed to our long-term engagement with urban poor and worker communities as constituency. It is also requested that at least one more cycle of project funding be supported, if possible, by oak with the same constituency to ensure the sustainability of actions and wider impacts.Given the similarity in challenges faced  by informal sector workers in other growing economies such as India, it will be useful to know whether IGSSS will draw examples on  how government and not-for -profits in those countries are dealing with such challenges.Yes, it is something that we are already are embarking upon. Especially exchange with global south countries/ cities and as well as more closely with south Asian / south east Asian partners. As many countries and cities are leading the discourse on climate resilience and we will benefit from working with them. Like Bangladesh for example. We have already established connections with networks there and hope it will help initiating a good exchange of thoughts, policies, experiences and practice.Oak Application Form     29Is there any engagement planned with the National Disaster Management Authority which is yet to fully apply climate-lens in dealing with disasters?Yes, it is planned and included in the scope to broaden the understanding of working on the issue of urban disasters that are ignored as of now. Especially the climate change related ones that are impacting informal workers and urban poor communities. Also, we were part of the NGO coordination group set by NDMA during COVID and contributed to the discussions then. Therefore, hopeful about converting some ideas/ interventions into policies.Given the large number of small and medium-sized entities that employ informal workers, they may find it difficult to adapt the action plans that may require capital investments   would you address this directly/indirectly?Yes, I think there is an increased state support required for recognition of action plans, only through that eventually will entities and/or communities be able to address the challenges faced by them. This intervention proposed by IGSSS is not based on capital investment, but to facilitate that through collectivization and convergence.  But this project may wish to show models/ pilots that might need small supports to communities to facilitate the creation of examples that can be upscaled by the state.

GAF_A_Global_Greengrants_Fund_UK_SuppoGr.1. ORGANISATION: 1. ORGANISATIONOrganisation Name:Global Greengrants Fund UKStreet 1: WeWork Unit 1 Provost & EastStreet 2:Street 3: 145 City RoadCity: London State: LondonCountry: United Kingdom Postal Code:EC1V 1AZTelephone No.:Extension:Mobile:Email: info@globalgreengrants.org.ukWebsite: www.globalgreengrants.org.ukWhat is your organisations mission statement?Oak Application Form     2Global Greengrants Funds mission is to mobilise resources for communities to protect our shared planet and work toward a more equitable world. Our work is rooted in a theory of change built around the power of social movements to leverage systemic changes. It posits that movements based in the grassroots are necessary for social and environmental change because: 1) they represent local agendas and are comprised of the people with the greatest knowledge, experience, and stake in protecting their environment; 2) they have greater moral authority to question and change systems that adversely affect them; and 3) they serve as the roots from which larger movements for social change gain the motivation and inspiration to grow.Global Greengrants Fund was established in 1992, and over nearly three decades has built a decentralised and participatory decision-making model, in which a network of 200 volunteer activist advisors sets our strategies and makes grant recommendations, in addition to accompanying grassroots partners in their work through mentoring and other non-financial support. These advisors, organised in 25 advisory boards, sister funds and strategic partner organisations, are responsible for identifying grassroots actors who are working to change the systemic causes of climate change, environmental destruction and social and economic injustice; and to strengthen these actors through flexible, responsive and strategic funding and accompaniment. This advisory network collectively represents our most powerful asset.Since 1992, Global Greengrants Fund has supported over 15,000 grassroots initiatives around the world, almost 1,000 of them since 2013 through Global Greengrants Fund UK, the younger, independent sister charity and applicant. Globally, between the US and UK sister organisations, we now support 1,000 grassroots groups per year with small grants funding, advisor accompaniment and networking opportunities.Financial year start date (dd/mon):

GAF_A_Global_Greengrants_Fund_UK_SuppoGr.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT 5a. Tell us about your governance and leadership structures, as well as staff and volunteer base. Highlight any significant recent or expected future changes. If you have an explicit approach to increasing diversity and/or advancing race equity within the organisation, please tell us. (300 words):Global Greengrants Fund UK is an independent charity registered with the Charity Commission in England and Wales (1151527). The charity is governed by a Board of Trustees, as outlined in the charitys Articles of Association, which set out the Trustees responsibilities, including ratification of grants made. Rose Longhurst is the current Chair of the Board, replacing Stephen Pittam, who retired from the Board in 2022 after three terms. The Trustees have delegated day-to-day management to the Executive Director, who is supervised by the Chair.The US sister entity Global Greengrants Fund is governed by a separate Board of Directors (the Global Board). As stipulated by a Memorandum of Understanding, the two Boards reach decisions through collaborative, deliberative and constructive dialogue. The MoU sets out that the Global Board shall appoint at least one UK Board member to each of the Finance and the Grants Policy Committees of the Global Board; and that the UK Board shall appoint the President and CEO of Global Greengrants Fund US as an ex-officio trustee of the UK Board.The Executive Director and Director of Philanthropic Partnerships for the UK entity are part of a global senior leadership team which determines overall strategic direction and ensures the effective operations of the Funds two sister entities. This team is also responsible for driving the organisations Diversity, Equity & Inclusion initiative across the global network.The applicant, Global Greengrants Fund UK, currently has 5 FTE staff (this will increase to 5.5 by August 2022) and is led by Greg Hilditch, Interim Executive Director. Recruitment to the permanent Executive Director post is underway and the process is expected to be completed by October 2022. Our US-headquartered sister organisation Global Greengrants Fund has 26 FTE staff, and is led by Laura Garcia, President and CEO. The organisation works with a global network of over 200 volunteer advisors, organised in 25 regional and thematic advisory boards, sister funds and global partners; Oak Application Form     6decisions on who should receive Greengrants' grantmaking support and accompaniment are made by this network (see 5b and 7 below). 5b. Summarise the organisations history.  In addition, highlight 2-3 key achievements.Please keep this brief and list up to 3 key achievements as bullet points. Even though you may have many achievements, please share what is most relevant to the proposed grant. (300 words)Global Greengrants Fund was established in 1993 to channel direct funding and support to grassroots civil society actors working for environmental and social justice across the world. We do this through a decentralised, participatory grant-making model in which our network of over 200 expert local advisors identify grassroots movements; channel small, flexible grants funding to them; and provide ongoing mentorship and accompaniment to them as they deliver their self-determined initiatives. In 2013, Global Greengrants Fund UK was registered as an independent charity in England & Wales, with the first staff member joining the organisation in 2016.The global organisation has grown significantly in recent years, and currently funds over 1,000 initiatives per year (including 217 through the UK entity in 2020-21). The UK organisation has grown its revenue and staffing resources substantially, and is on track to exceed $5m income for the current fiscal year.Global Greengrants Funds India Advisory Board was established in 2001 to support grassroots environmental protection and rights-based development work through small grants and advisor mentorship. The Boards work covers a diverse set of issues, from forest rights to water and sanitation, but with a cross-cutting focus on the most marginalised groups, including Adivasi and Dalit communities; women; transgender people; and rural and remote populations. The Oak Foundation has been the Boards longest-term and largest donor since its inception, supporting the Board since 2012. This support from the Foundation has been critical to the Boards evolving strategy: as one of the Boards only funders providing multi-year support, the Oak Foundation has enabled the Board to develop relationships, networks and more in-depth understanding of the specific challenges facing the group it supports.While the growth of our support to grassroots movements is a major achievement of the past two years, the achievement we are most proud of is our advisory networks ability to continue strengthening grassroots movements within the extraordinarily challenging context of Covid-19; in India, with the support of the Oak Foundation, the Advisory Board was able to rapidly mobilise emergency grants to 11 local initiatives on the frontline of Covid response during the countrys deadly second wave, and continues to provide additional support to all its grantees affected by the pandemic as required.Oak Application Form     75c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and decide your approach? If you have undertaken a theory of change exercise, or if you are influenced by research, policy or your own organisations experience, please tell us about this.  Have you consulted with relevant stakeholders, including your communities and others experiencing the problem? Is there an intention to address equity, diversity and inclusion? (600 words):ContextOver twenty years on since the inception of the Global Greengrants Fund India Advisory Board, marginalised communities in India continue to face a complex, interconnected range of social, environmental, health and rights challenges, all of which have been exacerbated significantly by the immediate and longer-term impacts of the Covid-19 pandemic and of the climate crisis.Rural women and marginalised communities, including Adivasis, Dalits and migrant workers, have been disproportionately affected by the immediate health risk from the virus and by the effects of lockdown measures, including loss of income, food insecurity and exposure to violence; an estimated 75 million people in India were pushed into poverty during the first wave of the pandemic alone. The effects of the pandemic have been especially pronounced for the Adivasi communities supported by our Advisory Board; many of the casual labourers who returned to remote rural communities at the beginning of the pandemic have remained there, putting additional pressure on already highly stretched local resources. Logging, mining and other activities harmful to the environment  both officially sanctioned and illegal  have increased, representing a major challenge to communities reliant on natural resources for their livelihoods, food, shelter and medicine, despite the protections set out in the Forest Rights Act.Simultaneously, climate-linked disasters such as Cyclone Tauktae in 2021, flooding and landslides across multiple states particularly including the north-east, and the major heatwave of spring 2022, are destroying the livelihoods of thousands of farming and fishing communities already facing extreme poverty and food insecurity as a result of the pandemic. As well as the immediate threat to lives and property from disasters of this kind, climate change is driving increased water scarcity, crop failure, soil erosion and the loss of biodiversity including fishing stocks.Both before the pandemic and during it, local organisations and movements across India have been the frontline responders to the intersecting health, social and environmental crises they face: identifying local challenges, designing solutions and mobilizing communities to carry them out. Through its grant-making and accompaniment work with emerging civil society actors, the India Advisory Board aims to strengthen these locally-led initiatives, enabling them to become more effective in achieving their self-determined goals while also promoting a rights-based, inclusive approach to social and environmental justice work that is rooted in local agency, autonomy and dignity.This grant-making and accompaniment work is also how we have identified the specific challenges affecting marginalised groups in India: with the support of the Oak Foundation, our advisors have developed an analysis which is rooted in the perspectives and experiences of our grantee partners. Oak Application Form     8The proposed work is informed by this analysis and by Global Greengrants overarching theory of change, which posits that movements based in the grassroots are necessary for social and environmental change because they represent local agendas and are comprised of the people with the greatest knowledge, experience, and stake in protecting their environment; because they have greater moral authority to question and change systems that adversely affect them; and because they serve as the roots from which larger movements for social change gain the motivation and inspiration to grow.Our partnership with Oak Foundation and recent highlightsAs mentioned above, the Oak Foundation has been supporting Global Greengrants Funds India Advisory Board since 2012, with over 200 grassroots initiatives funded and accompanied by our advisors in total through this partnership.In the most recent phase of our partnership  the 2018-22 grant to which this proposed work links directly  we set out the following objectives:1) To support a total of 40-50 grassroots civil society initiatives in Jharkhand and West Bengal with small grants to enable action on environmental justice and climate change, aiming to strengthen their ability to effectively advocate for their rights and implement viable solutions to local challenges; and in the medium to long term, to strengthen their organisational capacity.2) To foster stronger networks among local civil society organizations in Jharkhand and West Bengal, as well as across India, through a series of grantee workshops and through grant-making to network organisations, with the aim of grantees having increased resources including knowledge, skills and financial support to carry out their work.3) To promote womens rights, safety, well-being, and economic security through small grants to women-led and women-focused environmental justice activities (30% of all grant-making), as well as through advisors working with grantees to support the incorporation of a gender lens in their work, with the aim of securing an increased leadership role for women in environmental justice initiatives. Examples of the types of activity supported through this objective include women-led initiatives addressing forest rights and agriculture.During this most recent phase, 55 grassroots initiatives were supported with small grants to implement solutions for environmental justice and in response to climate change. The majority of projects focused on raising awareness of the importance of natural resource conservation, especially for women and youth, and orienting the communities towards organic and sustainable agriculture to improve livelihood opportunities, food security, and health. Projects also focused on strengthening grassroots institutions and local governance, supporting minority groups in obtaining and implementing Community Forest Rights in the context of FRA2006, empowering Gram Sabha, and providing equal access to water and sanitation.Key learnings from this most recent phase of work include:Thirty-one percent of grantees who have reported have been able to access additional funding as a result of the grant provided through the Oak Foundation support. This includes funding from international foundations such as Keystone Foundation, Foundation for Ecological Oak Application Form     9Security, 350.org, Action Aid and AJWS, but also national government administration (e.g. Forest Department of Jhrakhand, NABARD (National Agriculture Bank And Rural Development), Krishi Vigyan Kendra (Agriculture Research Centre), and other national NGOs and international NGOs including MOCICC (Movimiento Ciudadano frente a Cambio Climtico, a Peruvian NGO). In addition, forty-two percent of grantees have told us that thanks to GGFs support, they have been able to benefit from new networking opportunities, increased recognition and trust from the wider community, and general support. In some cases, it was observed that the visibility gained is a gateway to additional funding opportunities.Overall, groups observed a general inclination toward learning from - and helping - each other; forums and district-level meetings were organised to exchange lessons learned, experiences, and best practice. Some organisations have started to hold interactions with district-level NGOs, have been given opportunities to take part in stronger networks with other grassroots groups, and have been invited to join international conferences.Several of the grants made also went to network organisations; for example, one network organisation based in Karnakata is organising a series of twelve national and regional level meetings to develop and present an action plan regarding forest rights to policymakers. Access to these types of networks is critical for many of the grassroots organisations we support, who are often unable to access other sources of information and advice, and are able to share resources and strategies as a result.57% of grants made have been to women-led organisations or to initiatives focused on womens rights, wellbeing, and economic security. Women are more prominently represented in the leadership of their organisation and have been able to develop their leadership skills through the seminars or workshops offered by the projects. In some projects, women's participation grew so much that they now represent one-third of the forest rights committee at the Gram Sabha level, where they often assume prestigious roles (secretariat, presidency, vice-presidency). In some cases, women are taking a crucial role in decision-making and lead the negotiations with local authorities.Eighty percent of the grantees who have reported have said that thanks to the Oak Foundations support they have been able to improve environmental conditions at the local level. Organisations could measure an overall increase in the awareness and responsibility of local communities towards improving environmental conditions and safeguarding natural resources, for example, through the set-up of Forest Rights Committees, Village Forest Management Committees, or through campaigning. Benefits reported by the grantees include: increased wildlife protection; restoration of water channels; farmers shifting to organic agriculture/ agroecology and no longer using chemical fertilisers and pesticides; regeneration of wastelands, and the return of birds, animals, and plant species.Themes in our grant-making to date, and emerging prioritiesOak Application Form     10While the Boards strategy focuses on the most marginalised groups, a number of cross-cutting themes have emerged across its work with these groups across the different geographies within India where it works. The proposed work aims to leverage the Boards existing networks and expertise, and with the support of the Foundation to also develop new approaches, resources and capacity which can make it more effective in addressing these specific themes and challenges. These themes include:Food systems and sustainable agriculture. Food security has become an even more urgent challenge for poor rural communities in the context of both Covid and rising temperatures driven by the climate crisis, with the continuing dominance of industrial agriculture threatening the economic independence of family farmers as well as impacting local biodiversity and soil conservation and acting as a major contributor to carbon emissions. Three of our advisors are specialists in this area, with one living as part of a collective farm run by Adivasi community members. For the proposed work, we anticipate that this theme will continue to be an important one across all of the geographies in India where the Board operates.Access to forest rights, especially for Adivasi communities. The Board has supported multiple Indigenous groups across India to exercise their right to protect, make decisions, and make a living from their traditional forests in the face of extractive interests. Several groups have been supported for a number of years in this work, such as one organisation in Jharkhand (funded by Oak since 2016) working to secure forest rights, survey forest produce and trees, and promote womens involvement in the Gram Sabha. Two of our advisors have strong links to Adivasi community movements and this theme will continue to be prominent in the proposed work.  Addressing the impacts of climate change and industrial pollution on small-scale fishing communities. Fishing communities, like farmers, have been deeply impacted by climate change in India as cyclones hit coastal areas with increasing intensity and frequency and sea level rise changes coastal ecosystems. One group supported by Oak Foundation via Greengrants in West Bengal has been working to restore and protect mangroves in three villages affected by Cyclone Yaas, for example; others are especially focused on building the leadership, organisation, and economic independence of women in fishing communities.Waste and sanitation issues, especially in relation to Dalit women and youth and to transgender people. Waste picking and manual scavenging (cleaning human waste) generally falls on the most marginalised people in India, especially Dalit women and youth who are frequently unpaid and often suffer severe health impacts and abuse; this work is an increasingly prominent theme in the Boards grant-making, and recent grants have supported the organising, education on rights and health, and registration of manual scavengers in informal settlements of Bangalore; another grant has funded work with transgender waste pickers in Kolkata to improve health conditions and connect them to broader environmental justice movements.Oak Application Form     11In the context of the pandemic, the Board has adapted its approach to ensure maximum flexibility and support to groups on the Covid frontlines, including with the support of the Oak Foundation. Our grantee partners have shown enormous resourcefulness and resilience throughout this crisis, whether by adapting existing activities to ensure the safety of community members, or by developing new lines of work such as Covid prevention and awareness activities, providing PPE or addressing the food security implications of the pandemic.The next phase of our partnership with the Oak FoundationAs India begins to move into the post-pandemic recovery phase, the Board is looking ahead to the next phase of its existence and aims to continue scaling up its support to marginalised communities across India, building on the Boards experience to date and also on the findings of the evaluation conducted on the previous phase of our partnership (attached separately).  The strategy for this proposed next phase of our partnership includes, firstly, exploring opportunities to support groups which the Board has had less engagement with to date  whether in new geographies, or those affected by additional dimensions of disadvantage such as trans or intersex identities. With one of the newest Board members from a Dalit background, the Board also aims to deepen its engagement with Dalit and other marginalised communities in the next few years, including by ensuring its own composition reflects that of its grantee partners in terms of gender, age, caste status, religion and geographical background. This need for enhanced focus on Dalit and other marginalised groups is one of the key recommendations of the evaluation of the previous phase of our partnership (see 4.1.3, paragraph 101 and 4.3 in the evaluation).Secondly, the Board aims to strengthen its support to existing partners, recognising there is scope in its work to support emerging civil society to become more established organisations with enhanced capacity to address social and rights challenges and to be more resilient and sustainable in their work. In particular, this includes two changes to the Boards grant-making approach: increasing the size of the average grant made from $7,000 to $10,000; and moving towards providing multi-year funding commitments to trusted partner organisations. This longer-term approach to funding will also strengthen our grantees accompaniment work, enabling advisors to develop their relationships with grantee partners and to support them in becoming more sustainable and effective organisations over time; it follows the recommendation of the evaluation that the Board consider extending the size and duration of grants made (paragraph 4.1.1). These changes will also be complemented and strengthened by the Boards participation in Global Greengrants Funds emerging global learning strategy, which aims to connect the different parts of our global grant-making network more effectively to foster improved learning and communication; in part this also responds to the recommendation in the evaluation that the access of our grantees to expert advice be supported (4.2.1).Finally, whilst individual Advisory Board members usually identify and support grantee partners in a specific state or cluster of states, an important aspect of the Boards strategy for fostering a stronger civil society network in India is to develop and share expertise on these cross-cutting themes across different geographies within India. This is reflected in the grant-Oak Application Form     12making budget lines of the proposed work, which include a split of 60% grant-making for local initiatives in West Bengal, and the remainder for work in other states. We recognise that the Foundations strategy for India is strongly focused on West Bengal, which is a critical state for our advisors work; by requesting some support to be earmarked to other states, our objective is to ensure that grantees participating in grantee workshops and other engagement activities have the maximum opportunities to benefit from the work of allied and aligned civil society organisations across all of India. For example, as mentioned above, in the current phase of our partnership several network organisations based outside of West Bengal have been supported, enabling grantees within West Bengal and outside the state to benefit from resources, strategies and information through this peer support; examples of these organisations include DISHA (the National Fish-workers' Forum); the Save Our Rice Campaign (through PPUS); the Asia Pacific Transgender Network; and the North Bengal Forum of Forest People and Forest Workers (through Bajkul). Our objective is to continue strengthening this wider ecosystem of grassroots peer support with the Foundations support. This approach also follows a key recommendation from the evaluation conducted on the previous phase of our partnership, that supporting strategic networking will be key for improving environmental conditions (see 4.1.2 and 4.2.2 in the evaluation attached separately).Funding contextThe proposed renewal funding from Oak Foundation would represent a major contribution to the India Advisory Boards evolving approach to supporting grassroots civil society in India over the next three to four years. The Advisory Board has continued to be successful in growing its engagement with other funders, including new multi-year commitments from several foundation sources in the UK, Europe and North America; through Global Greengrants Fund UK this includes renewed contributions from Stichting SED Fund and the Human Capability Foundation, as well as portions of larger grant commitments secured in the past six months from three large foundation donors. Cumulatively, the India Advisory Boards annual budget for FY21-22 (closing 30 June 2022) stands at $600,000  a large increase on the initial budget of $332k for the first year of the most recent phase of our partnership in 2018-19. The Advisory Boards budget for FY23 and FY24 is $744,000 per year. (To set this into the wider context of GGF UKs overall financial situation, GGF UKs overall budget is projected at $6.3m for the current fiscal year, and $6.2m for the next fiscal year.)If approved, the currently proposed work would mean that the Oak Foundation would remain a significant funder of the India Advisory Board (though still well below 30% of the total India Advisory Board budget), but within a more diversified portfolio of restricted funders, as well as unrestricted support from Global Greengrants Fund. The global organisation has also significantly grown its unrestricted revenue in the past year, meaning that if the Boards work expands during the reporting period the organisation will be well placed to increase its budget further.The proposed funding would enable the Board to provide 45-60 grants of up to $10,000 per grant to emerging civil society groups in West Bengal and other states in India, including a number of multi-year funding commitments. As well as testing the viability of this new Oak Application Form     13approach, the proposed funding will enable our grassroots partners to directly impact tens of thousands of beneficiaries through their initiatives, and to become stronger, more autonomous and better resourced organisations.With the support of the Oak Foundation, the Global Greengrants Fund India Advisory Board aims to work towards an overarching objective of supporting emerging civil society actors in West Bengal and other states in India to become stronger, more resilient against external shocks, and more effective in carrying out their self-determined activities to address the social, environmental and rights challenges they face. As a result of this work, we expect to see our grantee partners become better connected, resourced and networked; more effective in mobilising community engagement and in ensuring the participation of women, youth and marginalised community members such as Dalits, Adivasis and other disadvantaged groups; and better able to access funding from other sources, decision-making spaces, and media coverage.

Examples might include: (1) Research; (2) Provision of legal advice to...; (3) Training on movement building for...Building on the previous phases of our partnership with Oak, through the proposed support the members of the India Advisory Board will continue to proactively identify emerging civil society initiatives working towards social and environmental justice outcomes. Prospective grantees will be identified through the advisors existing and new networks within Indian civil society, with advisors approaching new and emerging groups who may not have previously encountered Greengrants or received funding from external funders; advisors will also conduct scoping visits and meetings to understand the strategies and needs of prospective grantees and assess their alignment with Greengrants model and priorities, as well as supporting them to develop funding applications where appropriate (in particular for the most nascent initiatives which may otherwise lack capacity for completing an application). This initial scoping and grantee identification will also reflect the Boards focus on individuals and groups affected by intersecting forms of marginalization (see also Objective 3).Grants will be awarded through meetings of the India Advisory Board, which will continue to meet between three and five times per year to consider applications received against its strategy and criteria, and to award small, flexible grants funding of up to $10,000 per grant, representing an increase from the Boards previous average grant of $7,000 per grant. This higher grant amount is intended to reflect the increased challenges affecting civil society organisations in India with mobilizing resources; to reduce administrative burdens; and to enable local actors to become more effective in planning longer-term initiatives. For this proposed work, this will for the first time include multi-year funding commitments of up to three years for grantees who are known to the Board, and who have the capacity to manage Oak Application Form     15these funds and to become stronger as a result, with the aim of building stronger and more resilient grassroots civil society organisations in West Bengal and the other states in India where grantee partners operate. Our advisors will play a critical role in supporting this capacity development, accompanying organisations to identify and address gaps in their skills, resources and infrastructure; for some (though not all) organisations supported, this will enable them to secure additional funding from external parties, while other movements will have more specific and time-limited goals.60 percent of the projects grantmaking budget will be channeled to groups in West Bengal, and 40 percent to the rest of India and to national networks, to allow facilitation of connections and learning across states, both by funding network organisations and through the work of our advisors to connect grantees working on related challenges across several states.While the specific focus areas and activities of the funded initiatives will be determined by the grantees themselves, with the support of our advisors, it is expected that the following themes and activities will continue to be prevalent in this work, based on the key trends identified under the previous phase of our partnership with Oak:- Issues affecting the rights of Dalit and Adivasi communities and other marginalised groups, such as access to forest rights and government entitlements; participation in Gram Sabhas; and access to water and sanitation. (See also evaluation section 3.3.)- Issues affecting the rights of fishing and forest communities, again including access to the provisions of the Forest Rights Act; food security and agriculture; and the impact of extractive industries and pollution on traditional livelihoods and health.- Climate change mitigation and adaptation, particularly in relation to sustainable agriculture and food security and resilience against the effects of climate-linked disasters.- Environmental justice, particularly including advocating for the rights of communities affected by extractive industries and deforestation.- Sustainable development, livelihoods and agriculture- Womens environmental leadership, incorporating an intersectional lens (see objective 3 below), including participation in decision-making spaces, womens leadership of movements and local initiatives, and addressing the rights of trans women, women from Indigenous and Dalit communities, and other women who are affected by multiple dimensions of disadvantage.7.2.a. Examples might include: (1) Research; (2) Provision of legal advice to...; (3) Training on movement building for...This objective links to the ambition set out in the previous phase of our partnership with Oak, in which we aimed to deliver a series of annual workshops to connect grantees with each other, to exchange information, resources and learnings, and to foster a culture of mutual support between emerging organisations working on similar issues and challenges. With the pandemic having prevented the workshops scheduled for 2020 and 2021, our goal is to revitalise this work through a series of grantee meetings in West Bengal and other parts of India, which will also incorporate a focus on strengthening organisational resilience in the context of the pandemic and a Oak Application Form     17changing operating environment for many organisations; examples of this could include training sessions on assessing risk, managing regulatory requirements, and standardising operations, depending on the specific needs identified by our advisors in discussion with grantees. By designing workshops based on grantees own identification of their needs in discussion with advisors, our aim (which has been successful in previous years) is to incentivize and support grantee partners to participate in and shape a community of civil society movements that has lasting impact beyond the lifespan of this grant.As with the previous phase of our partnership, a portion of the grantmaking budget will be used to support network and infrastructure organisations working to build capacity for grassroots civil society in India.Our advisors will also continue to provide accompaniment and mentorship to grassroots initiatives, including those funded in earlier stages of our partnership with Oak, as well as newer and emerging civil society initiatives. Advisor accompaniment can include several different types of activity, but is always provided where it is welcomed by grantees and never imposed on them. Examples of the types of support our advisors provide include supporting grantees to identify and tackle specific challenges in implementing their projects; assisting them with developing relationships with key external stakeholders, such as by facilitating introductions to relevant officials or to media spaces; and strengthening leadership, particularly of women, through fostering external connections or participating in capacity-building work, such as identifying resource needs, reviewing a funding strategy or supporting systems strengthening. Both the grantee workshops and the advisor accompaniment will be critical to fostering stronger connections within and between the movements supported by Greengrants, linking disparate actors and influencers and creating collaborative spaces that are informed by grantee partners own priorities and goals.As one of the Greengrants networks largest advisory boards, the board will also play a key role within Global Greengrants evolving learning and evaluation strategy, which includes a focus on disseminating resources, tactics and information across the global network between advisors and grantees working on related issues, but who may otherwise lack opportunities to learn from one another. This includes, for example, connecting advisors and grantees around issues of safety and security, ensuring that they have a good understanding of the mechanisms they can access to support the rights of community members facing threats to their safety, such as through the Environmental Defenders Collaborative (hosted by Global Greengrants Fund); sharing expertise on topics including disability inclusion and trans rights; and exchanging examples of how advisors have been able to support grantees in addressing specific technical or legal issues in their work.  Our advisors in India, as with the rest of our global advisory network, will be supported in this work by the Global Greengrants Fund Programmes team. Subrat Sahu, the Board Coordinator, will continue to liaise with Programmes staff to ensure that the advisors are supported to identify and resolve challenges in their grant-making and other work; as well as linking the Board to Greengrants global learning, evaluation and network-strengthening work. Peer support forms an important part of Greengrants advisory model, and Oak Application Form     18the regular advisor meetings included in the budget will serve as forums for advisors to share their experiences and learnings, troubleshoot, and devise strategies for addressing new challenges.7.3.a.
