Examples might include: (1) Research; (2) Provision of legal advice to...; (3) Training on movement building for...This objective directly links to and builds on the goal within the previous phase of Global Greengrants Funds partnership with the Oak Foundation. Gender remains a fundamental component of the India Advisory Boards Oak Application Form     19analysis and strategy; through the proposed work the Advisory Board will seek to further strengthen its support to local initiatives led by women, who continue to bear a disproportionate burden from social and environmental harms, now including the impacts of the pandemic and the increasingly apparent effects of climate change. Overall, we will continue to channel at least 30% of all of our grant-making to initiatives either led by women, or focused on womens rights, safety, wellbeing and socioeconomic status; prioritizing womens leadership in environmental justice movements remains a long-standing strategic objective for Global Greengrants Fund.We will complement and deepen this commitment to strengthening womens rights by also incorporating an explicitly intersectional approach within our grant-making, including channelling greater support to initiatives led by women, LGBTQI+ people and trans people, especially including those who also identify as belonging to other groups which have historically been marginalised, including Dalits, Adivasis, migrant workers, Safai Kamancharis, and members of religious minorities. The India Advisory Board will identify opportunities to explore and learn from the specific challenges of intersectional grant-making in India through the grantee workshops and will also seek to adapt its own practices where necessary to ensure that its grant-making and accompaniment work reflect intersectional approaches and concerns, for example by agreeing that a minimum percentage of grants made will be to initiatives led by women who also identify as Indigenous, Dalit, LGBTQIA, or as having a disability. This is also expected to include work to ensure that the Board includes members whose gender identifications, sexuality, religious affiliations, socioeconomic background, caste status and indigeneity status reflects a diverse range of lived experiences that mirrors those of the Boards grantees, with the objective of ensuring that these grantee partners are supported by our advisors in a way which upholds their dignity and independence.The India Advisory Board will work to address this objective in their work with the support of the Coordinator, Subrat Sahu, and the Greengrants staff Programme team, including Greengrants Director of Gender and Equity, Ursula Miniszewski.
GAF_A_Global_Greengrants_Fund_UK_SuppoGr.8. COOPERATION: 8. COOPERATION  How will you involve others in your approach to achieving change? If you are planning to engage in partnerships with other organisations, communities, people with lived experience, academics or secure the support of key individuals, please tell us about this.  Why are these the right partners to engage with?  Is there anything new about how you are choosing to work - for example, new partnerships or an approach that is different to how you usually work? (300 words):The most important partners for this work are the Global Greengrants Fund India Advisory Board members; the Boards membership currently comprises five Advisors, including one in West Bengal. The Board is supported by a Coordinator and an Administrator. The Advisors are all experts in their fields Oak Application Form     20with deep connections to local communities and civil society. They are responsible for identifying grassroots actors who are working to change the systemic causes of environmental destruction and social and economic injustice, and work to strengthen these actors through flexible, responsive and strategic funding and accompaniment. Through this model, Global Greengrants and the Advisory Board seeks to ensure that the lived experience of our community grantee partners is central to the social, environmental and rights initiatives the Board supports. Advisors are also themselves deeply embedded in networks of support for grassroots civil society, including through links to Adivasi and Dalit organisations, as well as farmer cooperatives and academia.As in the previous phase of our partnership with Oak, we will continue to work in partnership with other regional and international organisations such as Prospera International Network of Womens Funds as a partner in the Global Alliance for Green and Gender Action, as well as 350.org, Earth Island Institute, International Rivers and Pesticide Action Network. We will also continue to identify other potential partners internationally and within India who are able to support our grantees work, potentially including local philanthropic actors; within India Greengrants already has good connections with intermediaries, philanthropic organisations and implementing organisations including AJWS, Holdeen Foundation, Fund for Global Human Rights, Azim Premji Foundation, and aims to build on and deepen these relationships and others during the proposed grant period. This work will also be supported through Greengrants global fieldbuilding strategy, which seeks to work with existing and emerging philanthropic actors globally to unlock additional resources for grassroots movements; while this global strategy is still nascent we look forward to keeping Oak updated on our progress, and appreciate the input that you are already providing to shape the strategy.
GAF_A_Global_Greengrants_Fund_UK_SuppoGr.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING This section is twofold. Please tell us:a) Monitoring and evaluation. How will you know if you are achieving your objectives? Please describe briefly how you will know if you are making progress and if what you are doing is working. If you have a formal monitoring and evaluation system and if you plan to collect indicator data or conduct an external evaluation, please provide details here.b) Learning. Please tell us if there anything in particular that you are hoping to learn more about or test through this grant.(300 words):The proposed works approach to M&E is guided by an organisational learning and evaluation framework designed on the basis of our theory of change and our understanding of how environmental justice movements create and leverage social change. This incorporates tools including reports from grantees and advisors; grant-tracking systems; grantee surveys; learning exchanges; participatory action research; grant strategy reviews; network mapping; and in-depth regional case studies, to gather information about the impacts of our funding on individual grantee organisations, Oak Application Form     21broader movements, and environmental and social conditions, and evidence of change. In-depth and longitudinal studies help us to map what long-term accompaniment and strengthening of a movement looks like.Each community group in receipt of a small grant and advisor support is asked to report on the progress of the project one year after receipt of the funding. The reporting form asks for assessments and learning related to eight indicators which align with Global Greengrants Funds evaluation framework and help us assess impact:1. Any evidence of improved environmental conditions since receiving funding2. Strengthened organisational capacity3. Increased community awareness or involvement4. Increased involvement of women, youth, and indigenous leaders in the work of the initiative5. Impacts on policy or policy implementation6. Increased media interest in the grantees work, if this is something that the grantee seeks7. Increased access to spaces for decision-making and advocacy and networks8. Increased access to additional funding from sources other than Greengrants, or other forms of support (for example, expertise).In addition, the report asks for a description of what the partner assesses to be the most significant change, any changes in the external environment, and any lessons learned from the work. The reporting process invites our community partners to reflect on their work and draw lessons. Reports also help advisors to analyse trends, inform the strategy-setting, and collate stories of success and learning; this data is collected by the Advisory Boards Administrator with the support of the Coordinator, and analysis is conducted jointly by the entire Advisory Board.The framework set out above is designed to be as flexible and appropriate as possible for Greengrants portfolio of grassroots, emerging civil society groups who are highly likely to lack capacity to conduct monitoring and evaluation activities, and whose aims and approaches vary significantly depending on the local context. Recognising this, Greengrants does not currently provide a more detailed framework for grantee partners to define, for example, parameters for improved environmental conditions; the framework seeks instead to place grantee partners own perceptions, rather than externally imposed definitions, at the core of Greengrants evaluation and learning work.Findings will be reviewed by Global Greengrants Fund staff and discussed with advisors on a regular basis, including during virtual and (where possible) in person meetings, focusing on the impacts of individual and aggregated grants, the challenges our partners face, and wider trends.All advisory boards receive disaggregated data relevant to their grantmaking, to help influence their future strategy-setting and decision-making, and improve the quality of support Global Greengrants Fund provides. For the proposed work, we additionally plan to commission an Oak Application Form     22evaluation in the final 5 months of the grant which will assess progress against the objectives outlined above, particularly including the degree to which the board has been able to incorporate an intersectional approach to its work, and any learnings from this which can be used to strengthen the boards future grantmaking and accompaniment work. We will welcome the input and feedback of the Oak Foundation in developing the terms of reference for this evaluation to ensure that it meets the Foundations expectations, particularly in terms of including grantee partners perspectives.The proposed work also links to Global Greengrants evolving learning strategy. This emerging piece of work, which will also intersect with the organisations ongoing Strategic Journey, aspires to decentralise learning across the Greengrants network and facilitate shared learning between advisors and grantees across disparate geographies and themes. This will also include evaluating the existing monitoring and evaluation framework to identify opportunities for strengthening our approach and developing additional insight that can strengthen our advisors and grantees work; this could potentially include working with our grantees to strengthen their monitoring and evaluation capacity.
GAF_A_Global_Greengrants_Fund_UK_SuppoGr.10. RISKS AND CHALLENGES: 10.  RISKS AND CHALLENGESWhat are the risks or barriers that might prevent you from achieving your outcomes and how will you address these?  What are your opportunities?We understand that achieving long-lasting and meaningful change is hard and we expect that the work you want to do will mean taking risks.  We encourage you to be open to telling us these, as well as how you will address these risks.  If some of your outcomes are risky, are there any incremental achievements that you could identify? (300 words):External high-impact risks identified for the proposed work include the ongoing effects of the Covid-19 pandemic on communities with which we work, and on the ability of our advisors to continue their grantmaking and mentoring support. The pandemic has had an enormous impact on our grantees in India: lockdowns and travel restrictions represent a major barrier to frontline community actors ability to campaign, coordinate and build successful coalitions. To mitigate against these challenges, Global Greengrants has carried out several scenario planning exercises throughout 2020-21 to help us navigate the impacts of the pandemic on our partners, and through our advisors we continue to apply maximum flexibility in our support to the activists and communities we work with.Another external risk to highlight is the increasing frequency and severity of threats to environmental defenders across the world. Global Greengrants is managing this risk by providing rapid, flexible and discreet emergency funding to environmental defenders at risk identified by our advisory boards in Africa. We also house the Environmental Defenders Collaborative (EDC), a pooled fund of 14 funders, which supports environmental activists by Oak Application Form     23increasing access to funding and strategic resources. We further work with other actors in the environmental space to increase understanding and implementation of prevention and protection strategies, including in partnership with the Funders Initiative for Civil Society. Within India, we will continue to ensure that all the work supported complies with the requirements of the FCRA and all other relevant laws and regulations.Internally, one risk with potentially major consequences is the risk of advisors lacking capacity to deliver their work and / or facing burnout through stress, especially given the highly challenging external context and the impact this is likely to have on advisors. To mitigate this, Greengrants is investing in an organisation-wide Organisational Care Initiative (OCI), currently being led by independent consultant Ishita Chaudhry, and which will be coordinated by our new Director for People & Culture (starting September 2022). The OCI aims to minimise the risk of staff burnout but also to actively promote a culture of care across the wider network, including among our advisors. The work of our Learning Consultant, Mateo Martinez Abarca, who is responsible for delivering our learning strategy and ensuring our advisors are connected with learnings and insights from across our advisor network, will also be key in mitigating this risk.Global Greengrants Fund UK also maintains a risk register which has identified key governance, compliance, financial, external and operational risks as well as mitigation measures. The charitys trustees regularly identify and review the major risks to which the organisation is exposed. Both manual and automated checks are regular invoked, particularly those relating to the operations and finance of the charity, including through a finance sub-committee of the Board, chaired by the Treasurer, which is responsible for financial governance and risk management.In addition to managing these internal and external threats, Global Greengrants Fund UK has in place a safeguarding policy, and jointly with our network-wide Diversity, Equity and Inclusion working group has developed an internal code of conduct which aims to enable individuals engaged with Global Greengrants to uphold and safeguard the dignity, freedom and liberty of all people, in line with our commitment to developing and strengthening an enabling environment, and a culture of communication, trust and empathy, where the health, safety and the dignity of all persons associated with our organisation, directly or indirectly, is given primacy.
GAF_A_Global_Greengrants_Fund_UK_SuppoGr.11. ADDITIONAL QUESTIONS/ Future Plans: 11.  ADDITIONAL QUESTIONSPlease use this space to respond to any specific questions from your Oak programme officer. If none were received, please leave this section blank. There was mention of several of GGFs grantees maturing to the next level of funders, can you provide exact information on how many and Oak Application Form     24how much funding have been leveraged by the grantees independently and/or with GGFs support?27% of our grantees supported by the Oak Foundation have reported that with Global Greengrants support they have been able to access additional funding. Grantees have been able to secure funding from sources including Association for Indias Development; ActionAid; The Asia Foundation; Both ENDS; UNICEF; Millenium Alliance; Paul Hamlyn Foundation; Keystone Foundation; Oxfam India; and others.Our grantees typically havent reported on the specific amount of funding leveraged from other sources, but the information that we have received indicates the following:Unspecified amount from Bosu Bigan Mandir for indigenous people development.Unspecified amount from Yuva Manthan Sanstha.Unspecified (small) amount from government administration to train youth members for a livelihoods initiative.Unspecified small grant from Foundation for Ecological Society for capacity building of community forest rights management committees at the district level.INR10,00000 from Keystone Foundation.Unspecified additional funding to address the problems of food insecurity due to COVID-19: from APPI for ration distribution in the Barwadih block of Latehar; from UHHIP to distribute rations in the Bargarh, Bhandariya and Ranka block of Garhwa and from NCDHR to distribute rations in the Mahaudand block of Latehar.Unspecified amount from AJWS for collaboration to further strengthen the work of the campaign.Unspecified individual donations for things like construction of drinking water wells, distribution of clothes, and solar lights distribution etc.In addition, 23% of our grantees support by the Oak Foundation have reported that with Greengrants support they have benefited from new networking opportunities and increased recognition from the wider community. Organisations have been able to create more linkages with like-minded change players and access opportunities for further engagement and dialogue on issues pertaining to partnerships, collaborations, and funding. This boosted organisations' capacity for knowledge-sharing and increased opportunities to access similar projects and mobilise government schemes for action. Organisations also benefited from increased recognition and appreciation, exemplified by an increase of positive views towards the grantees from the broader community. For instance, two organisations were consulted by the national government and a UK-based organisation to provide specialised pieces of training and knowledge on issues such as human trafficking, millet cultivation, and livelihood systems.Given the ten-year long relationship with Oak, it will be good to know the significant accomplishments/lessons drawn over these years. In other words, information on the impact GGF could make and the changes brought about since their time of their association with Oak.Oak Application Form     25The funded work has strengthened individual organisations and the overall civil society in India. Although not all have been able to access additional funding from elsewhere, many have, and the majority report strong relationships within and outside their communities and with organisations and individuals carrying out similar work in other regions. Through the networks they are a part of, grantees have been able to engage with state and national level bodies regarding forest rights, food security, and fishing rights.The annual meetings arranged by Greengrants are a source of expert knowledge, in addition to being eagerly awaited solidarity events. The sources of the expert advice vary  from networks that they are part of (civil society, social movements) to academia and think tanks.  The critical support provided by Greengrants is instrumental in access to more network meetings which are a source of information and knowledge. Some organisational grantees are themselves experts in their own fields (and are recognised as such by the state) and provide expert advice to the community (from accessing entitlements, to access to larger networks, to plantations). While it has not been possible to carry out these meetings during the pandemic years, we are now starting to hold workshops again and look forward to sharing the outcomes of these with the Foundation.The vast majority of grantees report that they have been able to make a tangible difference to their local environments thanks to the support of Greengrants and the Oak Foundation. There is a huge range of environmental improvements, from nurseries to organic farming led by transgender people, to forest and mangrove protection and rejuvenation.In all cases, communities are increasingly involved in and aware of the issues facing them and the initiatives to combat them. Their skills and knowledge are increasing, and they have a strong understanding of the means at their disposal. For example, some are using the Right to Information Act (RTI) 2005 to get information and engagement with the state. In some of the forest villages in Jharkhand, they were conversant with even the nuances of the Scheduled Tribes and Other Traditional Forest Dwellers (Recognition of Forest Rights) Act, 2006, (popularly FRA), and used mapping for claiming rights.The issues that the grantees are engaged with (livelihoods, forest rights, indigenous concerns, LGBTQIA+ rights, and access to urban housing and water) are being covered more in the media.Almost all the groups in Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh, Odisha, and Madhya Pradesh work with the indigenous peoples. Other marginalised communities covered are small scale traditional artisanal fish workers (Maharashtra and West Bengal), farmers (West Bengal, Tamil Nadu), and trans-persons (West Bengal).Most of the grantee organisations were women majority or women oversaw the project. One organisation was transwoman-led, and majority trans-person. Women were articulate and present in substantial numbers during most grantee field visits by our evaluator. In a few cases, women were a majority. In some cases, the women were more articulate even when outnumbered by men. The focus on livelihoods, housing, water, and womens empowerment enables the participation of women even in adverse Oak Application Form     26circumstances. These are legitimate basic rights and entitlements that can, most times, still rise above divisive local politics.There has been formal recognition and inclusion in state decision making/ consultative processes for some of the grantees at the local (village, gram panchayat) level. One grantees work has been promoted as a model by the district administration. The networks that grantees are part of (right to food) have been able to influence policy even at the union level  a significant achievement in the present environment.How the mentoring helped organisations to create opportunities for sustainability strategies, including through securing other funding, developing alternative income sources, or scaling up their solutions.See above re other funding secured. The other way in which opportunities have been created for increased sustainability is through the general strengthening of networks and movements as a whole; organisations and individuals are able to share learning, information and strategies as outlined elsewhere in this proposal.

Core Support  Yes:_/No:_ No4b (ii)?. Project involves Contact with Children  Yes:_/No:_Yes4c. Grant period:Start date:(dd/mon/yy)End date:4d. Currency: USD4e. Total Project Cost:1013121 4f. Summarise the projects ultimate goal(s) (maximum 200 words):( NOT REQUIRED FOR CORE SUPPORT GRANTS)The projects ultimate goal is to improve the sexual and reproductive health (SRH) outcomes of young women and adolescent girls of Jharkhand and West Bengal by creating a sustainable model of community empowerment and youth responsive SRH services in the public health system. Ipas Development Foundation (IDF) will be Ipass lead partner in implementing the project. The project addresses multiple components of a sustainable abortion ecosystem taking a comprehensive approach to reduce barriers and improve health and lives of the most vulnerable and marginalized populations. Our approach utilizes a range of efforts with an eye on innovations and sustainabilityawareness building among individuals, sensitization of families and communities, health system strengthening, local advocacy for action and support, state-level engagement for ownership, and national-level initiatives for policy and legislation. All our current strategies are adapted within the context of the COVID-19 pandemic so that they are both feasible to implement and designed to meet community needs. Leveraging IDFs strong partnership with the state governments, the project will strengthen the availability, quality, and utilization of SRH services by young women and girls. The complementary health system strengthening efforts, including in Sundarbans, will be supported by IDFs core funds.
GAF_IPAS_EnhanAgenImprSRH_202310310856.p.4. GEOGRAPHY: 5.List the major countries where your activities take place. If this is global policy work, list as worldwide:India  (South Asia)
GAF_IPAS_EnhanAgenImprSRH_202310310856.p.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 6. Context (The context section should not exceed two pages.)6a. Describe the organisation (include information on leadership, governance, structure and staff) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):Founded in 1973, Ipas is a pioneering global health and rights organization focused on amplifying, defending, and advancing access to safe abortion and contraception. We work in 29 countries across Africa, Asia, and Latin America to shape the sustainable abortion ecosystemthe context around an individual who seeks to terminate an unwanted pregnancy. Ipas is governed by an 18-Grant Application Form, July 1 20135member international Board of Directors of international professionals, medical providers, and academics in the fields of health, SRH, and finances. The board includes an Executive Committee, Finance and Investment Committee, Audit and Risk Committee, and other committees that set policies and review and approve Ipass long-term plans and annual organizational budgets. Board officers are Sandeep Prasad (Chair and former Executive Director of Action Canada for Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights), Monica Oguttu (Vice Chair and Executive Director, Kisumu Medical and Education Trust), Trish Karlin (Treasurer and Executive Vice-President of Elizabeth Glaser Pediatric AIDS Foundation), and Carlos Plazas (Secretary and Chief Operating Officer of Planned Parenthood of Maryland). Senior leadership provides strategic and management leadership to Ipas staff. Directors and Managers of Ipass regional and country programs design, implement and monitor programs, and Directors of technical and operational departments support technical innovation, development, and administrative functions.   Ipas is defining and implementing a system of shared leadership that shifts more power and some central functions to our country teams. The Ipas Country Directors are leading on planning and implementing an Ipas Road Map to start using the shared leadership approach. An example of this shift is the lead staff for our Quality-of-Care work across the world, is based in Kenya. This organizational shift is part of Ipass commitment to break down harmful power structures, particularly the neo-colonialism present in so many INGOs and global health organizations headquartered in the global north. 6b. Describe the financial situation (include information on annual operating costs, fundraising strategy, reserves and debts) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):Ipass FY22 organizational budget anticipates annual operating costs of USD 42,240,000. We have confirmed support from European governments (including from Finland, the Netherlands, Sweden, and the United Kingdom), the Canadian government, and many private US foundations. The structure of funding varies by grant award or contract, with many multi-year grants, some one-year grants, and contracts with partners to perform scopes of work or collaborate on projects. Ipass foundation and government grants are a combination of core and restricted funding, with approximately 30% for core funding. In addition, Ipas has an individual and major gifts program that exceeded its annual goals since 2020. We have estimate reserves totalling USD 49,031,000 and no debt. The largest change in Ipass financial situation is due to changes in strategy of our large anonymous donor (LAD) that began in 2020 that negatively impacted Ipass budget as well as those of other INGOs dedicated to sexual and reproductive health and right (SRHR)support from LAD changed from $29.9 million in FY20 to $13.2 million in FY21 and has resulted in an organization restructure of our US office, including a staff reduction (41 positions). Leadership worked to streamline operations, combining some departments and subcontracting out some Grant Application Form, July 1 20136information technology functions. This has required scaling down and re-planning programming, and we are being mindful to carefully navigate these shifts to preserve critical safe abortion programming, as we also improve collaboration with partners. We have been moderately successful at increasing funding from some of our existing donors and identifying new sources of funding. IDF was one of the recipients of a multi-country grant from LADwithdrawal of support from LAD negatively impacted IDFs operating budget by 40%. Like Ipas, IDF also mitigated this through strategic resizing and program changes and has now successfully secured additional funds to overcome the impact of this and continue efforts to improve the abortion ecosystem in its program states and at the national level.  6c. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):Ipas has worked for nearly 50 years to ensure that women and girls have improved access to safe abortion and contraceptive care, which we consider crucial for improved reproductive rights, health, and gender equality. Our efforts on four continents have improved SRHR for women living within a range of restrictive abortion settings. Areas of expertise include implementing evidence-based initiatives to improve safe abortion access with governments, health providers, and community organizations, expanding health workers capacity and commitment to provide abortion care, and conducting action-oriented research to advance reproductive rights, with a focus on centering the perspectives and needs of those seeking abortion care. Guided by a commitment to human rights, innovation, and sustainability, we are skilled at building relationships with diverse stakeholders at every level of society, including within governments, institutions, and communities. Ipas Development Foundation (IDF) is Ipass implementing partner is India. IDF began work in India in 2001 to address the SRH needs of Indian women and girls, specifically to reduce the incidence of unsafe abortion which continues to be the third major cause of maternal mortality. IDFs presence in 10 states and women-centered approach ensures that women and girls have improved knowledge, agency, and access to SRH care, including abortion and contraception. Partnerships with governments to achieve sustainability has resulted in: sustainable allocation of resources to support abortion care; consistent availability of essential equipment and supplies; increased numbers of trained providers to provide high quality care; and strengthened national policies and technical standards and guidelines to support a strong national abortion care program. As a result of IDFs interventions, training, and advocacy, over 2,000,000 women and girls have accessed services from over 5,000 public health care facilities (with over 84% of these at the primary level). IDFs interventions in Jharkhand and West Bengal in previous projects supported by the Foundation have resulted in positive outcomesparticularly in improving SRH knowledge among young women and girls, increasing service utilization and greater recognition of SRH as an important health issue (please see Annexure 1). Grant Application Form, July 1 20137In Jharkhand, the endline evaluation shows statistically significant improvement in overall SRH indicators for knowledge, attitude, practices as well as stigma reduction, with the range of variation higher in the intervention group than in the comparison area  the findings are supported by an upward trend in SRH service uptake in public health facilities. In West Bengal, qualitative assessment of our intervention reveals an overall positive impact in improving SRH of adolescent girls (10-14 years) and young women (15-24 years)adolescent girls and young women reported increased confidence and ability to discuss SRH issues and facility records show increase in utilization of SRH services in intervention facilities. While the results are encouraging, there is a continued need for nurturing an overall enabling environment for adolescent and youth SRH in the two statessome specific gap areas are mentioned in 6e.6d. Describe the current strategy of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):Ipass programmatic strategy is based on the Ipas Strategic Framework which was rolled out in FY20. Ipass Strategic Framework offers a vision and strategy for progress on abortion access and rights that lead to programs that are fully grounded in the local contexts of the countries in which we work. Ipass Strategic Framework is based on our model for a sustainable abortion ecosystem. Ipas defines the sustainable abortion ecosystem as a dynamic condition in which resilient local stakeholders and systems are actively accountable and committed to abortion rights and responsive to everyones abortion needs. Ipass Sustainable Abortion Ecosystem model recognizes that a single approach (legal reform, health system strengthening, community education and engagement) will not alone create real access for women and girlsthe full ecosystem needs to be addressed. Using a human-centered approach with women at the center, our approach acknowledges that sustainable abortion care requires flexibility and prioritization on how to collaborate with partners to achieve goals, and how to strike a delicate balance across many factors. Our ecosystem model and strategic framework recognize that sustainable abortion care must be driven by local stakeholders and address multiple programming components to meet womens abortion needs. The Sustainability Framework identifies eight programming components that must be understood for each local context to accurately assess needs, develop and implement strategies, and monitor effective interventions. Underpinning the Strategic Framework is a continued commitment to a human rights and gender equality. Ipas articulates our work within a human rights analysis, and we partner across movements to advance the bodily integrity of all people.6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):Young Indian women and girls face tremendous challenges and stigma in meeting their SRH needs and the COVID-19 pandemic has made accessing information, counselling and support, and services even more difficult. Young girls who marry Grant Application Form, July 1 20138early are more likely to experience extreme social pressure of proving fertility and bear their first child before their body is ready for childbearing. As per latest NFHS-5 (2019-20), 42% of young women in West Bengal aged 20-24 years got married before the legal minimum age of 18 years, while among men around 20% aged 25-29 years got married before the legal minimum age of 21 years (IIPS 2020).  A similar trend is observed in the intervention district of 24 Parganas (South)42% got married before 18 years (IIPS 2020). The situation is somewhat similar in Jharkhand. As per NFHS-4 (2015-16), 38% of women aged 20-24 years got married before the legal minimum age of 18 years, while among men around 31% men aged 25-29 years got married before the legal minimum age of 21 years. Early marriage further leads to high teenage pregnancyin West Bengal 16% of women ages 15-19 years were already mothers or pregnant at the time of survey, this was 13% in 24 Parganas (South). Given these, young women constitute 30% of total maternal mortality in the country. The highest maternal deaths (34%) in India are also recorded for young women ages 20-24 years (RGI 2019). More than 33% of the disease burden and almost 60% of premature deaths among adults can be associated with behaviour or conditions that began or occurred during adolescence (GoI 2014). Ipass partner in India, IDF, implements community-focused interventions in Jharkhand and West Bengal to address this, while also addressing specific gaps that were revealed during the evaluation of the previous grant. JharkhandIDFs work under previous grants from the Foundation has yielded positive outcomes (please see Annexure 1); however, some key gap areas from the previous grant include:  1) Womens agency around SRH-related decision making, negotiation skills with family members, and personal mobility is limited2) Socio-cultural barriers including gender norms that impede womens self-efficacy for SRH3) Men involvementIDFs work through male youth leaders has improved mens attitudes towards womens SRH needs and interspousal communication, but more work is needed to improve their acceptance of contraceptives and strengthen their ability to support their spouses in negotiating SRH discussions within families/communities4) Need to decentralize SRH services for improved access Opportunities:Strong foundation for a favourable SRH ecosystem established in the communityCommunity-based evidence to guide strategies on addressing continuing SRH gaps and evolving needs of young womenhealth system interventions for holistic impact (through separate IDF funds) Challenges:Grant Application Form, July 1 20139Potential government COVID-19 restrictionsResistance from the community due to fear of the pandemic West Bengal (WB) existing intervention areasThe often-overlooked SRH needs of adolescents and young women  particularly young adolescents (10-14 years)  are unique and critical, as early intervention lays the foundation for positive SRH outcomes. IDFs targeted, age-appropriate SRH community outreach has led to encouraging results; (please see Annexure 1) while also revealing some gaps:1) Support for SRH and improved communication within family  especially men (spouses), mothers of adolescent girls and mothers-in-law of married young women2) Need to foster community-level support systems for sustaining a positive SRH ecosystem3) Need to sensitize and strengthen the public health system for continued provision of adolescent/ youth-friendly services, especially to unmarried young girls, and for provision of services closer to the communities at lower-level facilities. Opportunities:IDFs ongoing memorandums of understanding with the government of WB for increasing access to comprehensive abortion and contraceptive servicesInitiation of contraceptive services at Health and Wellness Centres (HWCs)Established rapport with the community, health facilities and Anwesha counsellors Challenges:COVID-19 restrictions and government regulations may hamper the pace of proposed workLegal barriers to providing SRH services for adolescentsSchool shutdowns hampering outreach to adolescents West Bengal  Sundarbans (proposed new intervention areas)The Sundarbans region is characterized by poverty, chronic deprivation and acute suffering from climatic adversities. Communities are hard to access and economically vulnerable and ensuring access to basic healthcare services is challenging. Access to SRH  especially for adolescents  is not a priority and existing SRH services are insufficient. This project intends to build awareness on fundamental SRH topics among young women, sensitize communities on the importance of SRH, expand service availability, and strengthen linkages to enable access and improve care-seeking pathways. Opportunities:IDFs ongoing interventions in selected health facilities and good rapport with relevant officialsGrant Application Form, July 1 201310Huge need and scope for improving SRH awareness and service availability for young women and adolescent girls Challenges:The project may require approvals from several departments, including health, Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) etc.Unavailability of health workers/counsellors/doctors for trainingLack of acceptance from the community due to low priority to SRH compared to more essential needs, including livelihood/employment

GAF_IPAS_EnhanAgenImprSRH_202310310856.p.8. COOPERATION: 8. CooperationDescribe the level of cooperation with other organisations and networks and explain how this cooperation helps achieve your goals (maximum 300 words):As Ipas's lead partner in India, IDF will implement the project with state-based NGOs, contributing to sustained capacity building and community-level ownership for SRH. In two other states  Bihar and Uttar Pradesh  IDF mentors a voluntary network of state-based CSOs to drive local advocacy and action and strengthen the grassroot SRHR movement. These partnerships have been crucial for IDFs learning  they have revealed how mentoring local NGOs can generate impactful community-based evidence and lead to successful advocacy with local authorities. This complements IDFs work of health system strengthening, community outreach and evidence-based policy making. At the national level, IDF is part of various networks, like the Pratigya Campaign and closely works with a range of partners, and academic and professional organizations on SRH issues. These partnerships allow a two-way exchange of experiences and learnings to improve SRH in the country. IDF also benefits from close international associations that expose the organization to global learnings that we leverage for our on-the-ground efforts. In the proposed project, IDF will explore learning partnerships with relevant organizations on social aspects, including the proposed collaboration for creating sustainable supply of low-cost sanitary napkins. Ipas will contribute expertise and global resources to develop IDFs capacities especially around emerging concepts and methodologies related to agency-building and changing social norms in communities. IDF will also explore collaboration with partners, like CREA, for sharing of resources and internal skill building. In West Bengal, IDF will explore networking and alignment with other Oak Foundation grantees, particularly FPAI to ensure synergies and complementarity.     As mentioned in Objective 3, the project aims to expand IDFs work in the Sunderbans region. IDF will gain enhanced understanding about the challenges and needs of the region  including through secondary research  and explore learning collaborations with other relevant grantees of the Foundation.Grant Application Form, July 1 201321
GAF_IPAS_EnhanAgenImprSRH_202310310856.p.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. ImpactWhat is the change you want to achieve from the overall project? (maximum 300 words):The projects anticipated impact is improved agency of adolescent girls and young women to make their own reproductive health decisions and access services they need for better reproductive health outcomes. Specifically: In Jharkhand, the project aims to establish sustainable, youth-friendly SRH services and a supportive environment for young womens SRH. The following changes are envisioned:Agency of young women improved, particularly decision making, self-efficacy and communication skillsMens role strengthened as beneficiaries (as contraceptive acceptors) and allies facilitating young womens SRHSocial capital built to sustain enabling environment for young peoples SRHDigital SRH pathways seeded for continued access to information and counsellingYouth-responsive, SRH service availability expanded, with emphasis on decentralization In existing intervention regions of West Bengal, the project will consolidate gains, build on previous learnings, and focus on building sustainability by nurturing an enabling environment for adolescent and youth. The following will be achieved:Empowered adolescent girls and young women who are equipped to make their SRH decisions, and have interface with community structures to raise their concerns/SRH issuesImproved support for adolescent girls SRH facilitating improved access to information and servicesEnhanced social capital in the communities to sustain a favorable environment for young womens SRHStrengthened availability of adolescent/ youth friendly SRH services   In coastal blocks in Sundarbans, the project will adapt and implement a youth-SRH model. With a phased expansion, the objective is to establish a strong foundation for future community-level interventions and achieve the following:Improved understanding of specific gaps in knowledge and services and needs of the community.Customized community outreach strategies (for adolescents and young women and men) co-created with young people of the area.Strengthened health facilities to initiate provision of adolescent and youth-Grant Application Form, July 1 201322friendly SRH services.Improved enabling environment in the communities for young peoples SRH.10. EvaluationHow will progress be monitored and evaluated? (maximum 300 words):Ipas will monitor the progress and efficacy of facility-based interventions through routine data collection from all intervention health facilities, including HWCs, in both Jharkhand and West Bengal. Monitoring data will be collected and analyzed to review: trends of utilization of SRH services; age-disaggregated data of young women and girls receiving services, including abortion; referral support provided, and quality of services offered. Results will be shared with providers, community intermediaries, and youth leaders for continued improvement in quality of information and service provision to young women. We will also conduct joint analysis sessions with service providers to transfer data-related skills of data disaggregation and analysis. Field-level monitoring of community outreach work will be led by the state-based Program team in close collaboration with the youth leaders and their supervisors  the teams will conduct quarterly meetings to review data on community meetings and outreach activities, assess progress, and modify strategies as required. In existing intervention areas, pre- and post-exit interviews with young women accessing SRH services at intervention facilities will reveal the perception of quality of services by adolescents and young women and attributes of accessing SRH services at public health facilities. Community-based endline assessments will demonstrate the impact of our community outreach in improving the overall ecosystem for SRHR (scope and methodology to be decided by the end of Year One). In new intervention areas in West Bengal, community-level evaluations will examine the initial effectiveness of our interventions. Using a quasi-experimental design baseline research will assess knowledge, attitudes, and practices towards SRHR issues, as well as agency and gender equity-related aspects among young women. Partners of young married women will also be surveyed to assess their role. In addition to setting benchmarks for selected output indicators, the baseline study will help identify barriers and facilitating factors to SRH services. In contrast, the end-of-grant research will assess initial effectiveness of the intervention for refining future strategies.Grant Application Form, July 1 201323
GAF_IPAS_EnhanAgenImprSRH_202310310856.p.11. ADDITIONAL QUESTIONS/ Future Plans: 11. Future PlansHow will the grant influence the organisation and future plans? (maximum 300 words):Learnings from the project will significantly contribute to Ipass and IDFs organizational knowledge and influence future strategies, including organization strategic planning to be initiated in early 2022. More specifically, this grant will greatly influence IDFs technical priorities and future fundraising capacity. Work under the previous grants from the Foundation has significantly expanded IDFs technical expertise and resources for community outreach for young women  adolescent and young womens SRH is now one of IDFs key thematic areas of work. The proposed grant will further augment IDFs organizational learning and generate evidence on additional concepts  especially enhancing agency of women, facilitating gender-equitable norms and nurturing a supportive environment for young womens and adolescent SRH. The proposed community-based work in the Sunderbans closely aligns with IDFs priorities around reaching the most marginalized populations and will lay the foundation for future work in the region. Along with support from the Oak Foundation, IDF continues to benefit from diverse donor support, including from Ipas Inc., Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, David and Lucile Packard Foundation, Grand Challenges Canada and AmplifyChange. IDFs projected organizational budget for FY22 is 6 million. To broaden their donor funding base, IDF is now increasingly focused on raising domestic funds; IDF has recruited a Director of Corporate Partnerships who will join the organization in September 2021. The work under the proposed grant is critical for IDFs fund-raising plans  we believe that work on this key component will have maximum traction with donors in India and will therefore be in the forefront of IDFs domestic fund-raising efforts. IDF has had preliminary discussions with HCL Foundation, CIFF and recently begun exploring crowd funding to support youth-focused SRH initiatives. Please Grant Application Form, July 1 201324click here to access IDFs GiveIndia profile.

(scale up our current work) or (provide continued support to) (75 words)The Fund for Global Human Rights (the Fund) aims to build on the success and learning from previous work and to sustain and strengthen its support to local groups and communities working on the management of and rights to natural resources in West Bengal. Our proposed work aligns strongly with the Funds strategic priorities to shift more resources to grassroots environmental activists and solutions in India, to build indigenous communities resilience and power around environmental issues, to support intersectional approaches, and to help nurture a grassroots climate justice movement that has indigenous communities, women and youth at its heart and helm.4.
