GAF_A_Fund_For_Global_Human_Rights_Suppo.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT Oak Application Form     55a. Tell us about your governance and leadership structures, as well as staff and volunteer base. Highlight any significant recent or expected future changes. If you have an explicit approach to increasing diversity and/or advancing race equity within the organisation, please tell us. (300 words):The Fund was founded in 2002, initially with a registered office in the US and then in the UK in 2013. Until late 2020 the Fund was led by its founding CEO, Regan Ralph, who stepped down after 20 years of inspirational leadership. In May 2023 the Funds new CEO, Gabriela Bucher, joined. During this leadership transition the Funds Deputy CEO, Brandee Butler, has been Acting CEO. The Funds leadership team is currently five members who collectively provide leadership and guidance to over 60 full-time Fund staff based all over the world.  Our Program staff are based in the regions where we have a program presence. In addition, each regional program has a part-time or full-time consultant based in a different priority country who serves as an essential member and key advisor within the team.The Funds global board of directors currently has eighteen members, and is comprised of high-profile human rights experts, frontline activists and committed human rights grant-makers and donors.  Board terms are three years, and the Funds bylaws state that the Board cannot include more than five directors who have served over three terms.  According to the Funds by-laws, at least one-third of the board members must be of or from the regions served.  The Funds board meets in person twice a year and virtually twice a year, and additionally has several standing board committees that meet throughout the year. As required by law, the Funds UK entity also has a small board of trustees which also sit on our global board.The Fund is committed to advancing diversity, equity and inclusion within our organization. We strive to maintain a board and staff that are reflective of the diversity of its work. We value diversity in all its forms  of thought, background, identities, and lived experience  in the composition of our teams and our recruitment of new staff. Specifically in relation to advancing race equity, in recent years the Fund has made concerted efforts to further diversify its board and leadership team, one example being that during the process of hiring our new CEO the Fund deliberately worked with a global recruitment consultancy to support us in our search, with a priority focus on candidates who would bring race diversity to our leadership. 5b. Summarise the organisations history.  In addition, highlight 2-3 key achievements.Please keep this brief and list up to 3 key achievements as bullet points. Even though you may have many achievements, please share what is most relevant to the proposed grant. (300 words)The Fund is well positioned to remain a critical funder and ally to activists, groups and movements on the frontlines of human rights struggles in the region. The Fund began working in India in 2003, choosing to focus on the human rights dimensions of poverty and funding a combination of national and state-level groups that worked with the most marginalized populations (Dalits, Oak Application Form     6Tribals, informal sector workers and women across all marginalized groups). Since then, the Fund has disbursed nearly $20million in grants to around 200 groups across India. Over the years, with Fund support, these grantees have made a significant impact on the human rights landscape in areas such as land rights, labor rights, and sexual rights, and in particular for extremely marginalised communities (Dalits, Tribals, etc.). The Fund typically supports a strategic cohort of 35-45 groups in India with an annual budget of roughly $1.2million. When strategic funding opportunities arise we are able to expand our grantmaking portfolio and reach, as our previous support from Oak has enabled us to do.The Funds India Program currently has a grantmaking portfolio of around 40 grantees, including a few groups based outside of India who are some of the most impactful actors able to advance international advocacy and media efforts as those based in India simply cannot due to the security risks and hostile environment.Our three key achievements related to our India programming include:1.The Fund remains a key ally and lifeline to activists: the Fund is now one of a few human rights funders still able to work in India and channel resources to the grassroots level, in part due to our deliberate efforts to operate under the radar and with grantee security and confidentiality remaining our top priority. In the context of India, this is a major achievement. The Funds critical support to frontline activism includes our continuing support to the Legal Defense Fund, one of the only mechanisms of its kind in India  created to provide urgent resources to HRDs and organizations in emergency situations in India, especially related to cases of criminalization. This unique rapid response fund was set up four years ago in collaboration with Holdeen and American Jewish World Service, first incubated at the Fund and for security reasons now housed at the Robert Kennedy Centre in Washington DC. Requests for support are peer reviewed by leading activists. In the last three years almost 70 HRDs at risk have received emergency grants through this initiative for urgent legal assistance, emergency medical care, relocation, etc. Almost 70% of HRDs supported so far by this mechanism have been those working on environmental issues. 2. A major priority of the Funds programming in India is to support newly formed grassroots groups who are able to use the flexible, general support funding we provide to build a strong foundation for their work. For some, our funding  often seed grants  can be transformational. The majority of Fund grantees in India are also led by those who are from the same constituency that they work with (including women, Dalit, Muslim and Adivasis). The Fund strives to support activists and groups working innew and creative ways to advance human rights and social justice and to broaden their constituencies, in particular to youth. For example, the Funds support has extended to activists using arts and culture to help shift public narratives, such as in 2018 we partnered with Marathi YouTube channel BhaDipa and the media and arts collective Maraa. Together, we Oak Application Form     7helped underrepresented voices break into Indias booming stand-up comedy scene. On our 16-city tour of Maharashtra, comics from some of Indias most marginalized communities shared their personal stories, laughs, and important messages of social change with new audiences across the state. Another example is the Funds recent support to a collective of artists (incl. painters, writers and actors) that are working to amplify the voices of marginalized communities affected by the climate crisis and environmental hazards and to raise awareness on and mobilize community-led ecological conservation. This includes a cultural festival on World Water Day, and community -led cleaning of the Nonadaanga pond - a part of the East Kolkata Wetland under threat from urbanization which is the only Ramsar site in the world whose rich biodiversity has the ability to recycle the citys sewage into profitable agriculture and fishing that could help feed the city at low cost.5c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and decide your approach? If you have undertaken a theory of change exercise, or if you are influenced by research, policy or your own organisations experience, please tell us about this.  Have you consulted with relevant stakeholders, including your communities and others experiencing the problem? Is there an intention to address equity, diversity and inclusion? (600 words):Problem AnalysisThe consequences of climate change in India - including eroding coastlines, destroyed ecosystems, catastrophic weather events and poorly designed climate mitigation and development projects - are deepening existing inequalities. Climate change is a threat multiplier, and populations in India that already are vulnerable because of factors such as geography, poverty, gender, indigenous or minority status, national or social origin, birth or other status, and disability, continue to face its harshest effects. The nexus of the climate crisis and socioeconomic and political inequalities is at the root of various types of climate injustices in India, and this is particularly pertinent in the state of West Bengal.West Bengal is a very unique state in India that is still grappling with the effects of its contested history under British rule, and the post-independence political and economic stagnation that followed after years of being one of the richest regions in the world. Today, West Bengal has a fragile economy and is one of the poorest regions in India, attributed, in part, to years of communist rule that shunned industrialization and modernization, and the growing effects of extreme weather  such as flooding  that together are leaving many families destitute and are driving people to migrate to other states. Yet at the same time, West Bengal is home to some of the richest biodiversity and natural resources in India, including pristine forests with diverse fora and fauna, much of which have been carefully preserved and protected by tribal communities and other forest-dwelling communities who have lived there for centuries and are highly dependent on the forest for their livelihoods and food sovereignty.However, West Bengals ecology and pristine forests, as well as the lands, livelihoods, culture and identity or the many indigenous communities that reside in them are increasingly under serious threat from a growing turn Oak Application Form     8towards major investments in development, natural resource extraction and highly urbanized practices. One of the recent examples is the proposed Deocha-Panchami- open cast coal mining project of West Bengal State which supports the eviction of many communities. Furthermore, whilst there are solid laws in India to protect the community rights of indigenous groups, as well as the land they inhabit  such as the Forest Rights Act (FRA)  implementation of these laws remains poor, and recent amendments in laws related to forests and the environment at both state and central government level have been contradictory and difficult for communities and civil society to predict and respond to. Majoritarian governance is also eroding constitutional democracy and the rule of law, and disempowering communities. Recent policies and actions have supported corporate mining and other interests, such as in 2021, Indias Ministry of Environment issued an order to help some mining projects avoid public environment clearance hearings which are a critical tool for good governance and an important process for mining-affected communities, who may be suffering from non-compliance of mandatory environmental safeguards in mining projects. Indias Wildlife Protection Act has also been responsible for the large-scale relocation of tribal communities, and an increased criminalization of forest communities, as documented in this recent report by Centre for Police Accountability.This deeply concerning trend is intensifying and happening within a broader context of civic space and activism being severely curtailed across India as the state seeks to silence all dissent; today, India is one of the most dangerous places in the world to be a human rights defender (HRD), especially for those advocating around environmental issues who are easily labelled as threats to national security. The Funds Response & LearningThe Funds work related to environmental issues in India is currently focused in Gujarat, Tamil Nadu, and West Bengal and more recently expanded to Chhattishargh and Jharkhand. However, the Fund has deepened its strategic focus and investment in West Bengal in recent years considering the needs on the ground and the critical window of opportunity the current moment presents in this state as it is on the cusp of major development and greater demands on its land and natural resources. The Fund knows that in the face of these growing threats it is imperative that local communities, particularly indigenous and forest-dwelling communities, be supported now to elevate their voices and power to demand their constitutional rights to land and access to natural resources, before private sector interests and deforestation take hold.Over the last few years, thanks to Oaks support, the Fund supported a number of community-led efforts in West Bengal to promote and protect the rights of indigenous and forest-dwellers affected by environmental issues, large development projects, land displacement, and forced evictions. We have gathered important learning about the most effective strategies to help counter and navigate the growing threats outlined above, which have informed our strategic priorities in the years ahead and for which we are seeking Oaks continued support and partnership.Oak Application Form     9As many climate solutions are inextricably linked to social and economic justice in India, the Fund has supported advocacy and lobbying efforts with the government to ensure indigenous communities identities and culture are protected, as well as on promoting food sovereignty and sustainable agricultural practices.From our experience we have learnt that climate change can be mitigated, and environmental justice facilitated when communities are economically resilient, women have equal and equitable access to resources and to power, younger people feel stronger community connectedness, and citizens are collectivized and have the knowledge of laws and policies that impact them and their environment.The Fund is pleased to report that through Oaks current grant for work in Jhargram, West Bengal, local groups and activists have made significant in their work over the last few years, and the results of this are extremely encouraging, and on which we are seeking to build. Over the last few years:Targeted communities in Jhargram, Purulia and Bankura have demonstrated increased capacity to self-organize and claim their community/individual forest rights.Perhaps most notably, at the time of writing this, up to now communities have been supported to form 15 Gram Sabhas - 9 in Nayagram Block and 6 in Binpur II Block - and so far 8 are in the process of claiming community forest rights, with others are in the process of preparing their claims for submission. These 8 claims in process represent the rights of a total of 584 families and land 1,597 hectares in size, which demonstrates the huge reach and potential impact of community-level institutions like Gram Sabhas and their collective action.Another inspiring outcome has also been that some leaders of Gram Sabhas took initiative to form a platform/network of local Gram Sabhas - Banadhikar Gram Sabhas Mocha  which has since held two annual convenings of local Gram Sabhas, involving local leaders and forest rights activists from a number of villages. The last convening, held earlier in 2023, was attended by 200 people which demonstrates the appetite for such platforms and spaces. The convening included rich discussions. Banadhikar Gram Sabhas Mocha has also been able to successfully liaise with and advocate with the District Magistrate and other District officials in instances where Gram Sabhas claims are not being responded to, helping to amplify communities voices and concerns. Another positive development is that the organizers of this Mocha are now engaging themselves in discussing livelihood issues. The potential of this platform is extremely promising.One of the most important achievements noted by our grantees has been the change in attitude of government departments towards the forest rights campaign and work in Jhargram. When they started the work and helped Gram Sabhas to submit claims after meticulous preparation, none of the government departments showed any interest, rather they were actively discouraged from filing submissions. After two years of hard work and regular engagement with District officials, they are now publishing a booklet about the FRA, Gram Sabha and forest rights claims, publishing and circulating claim forms. The District Magistrate is now also promising to look into claims submitted and giving Oak Application Form     10instructions to his subordinate officers on the same and most importantly, the Forest Department is acknowledging the process and sending Forest Officers to talk about FRA claims in a gathering organized by the very same community, with whom they share a contentious relationship. This is a major shift and step forward for State recognition and action in relation to community forest rights. Key learnings from our work in West Bengal so far have shown that:- the most important and effective way to engage and mobilize indigenous communities to claim their rights to land is to equip them with greater understanding of the connection between their cultural identity, traditional practices and customary laws, to the protection of and access to land. We have seen through our grantees work that focusing on this intersection  helping people to see that land is not just a resource but part of indigenous cultural identity  is the most powerful and successful way to empower and mobilize communities for action.-equipping communities with a greater understanding of their constitutional rights and legal provisions is critical- supporting efforts to strengthen the forest governance structure through people centric conservation practices through constitutional remedies such as the PESA, FRA etc. allows communities to demonstrate the meaning of conservation and protection of their natural resources- supporting communities to mobilize, form Gram Sabhas and process collective claims takes considerable time, accompaniment and trust-building, but is an essential process in empowering communities and ensuring the realization of their rights- communities need sound legal aid in order to claim their rights and respond to emerging threats, including criminalization by the state. Support from OakThe Fund seeks a new 4-year partnership with Oak and a grant of $575,000 to help bring the resources and actions needed in this critical moment for grassroots level organizing on land and resource rights issues in West Bengal. With Oaks support the Fund would build on the success and learning from previous work and support a cohort of 4 local groups working on their communities management of and rights to natural resources in West Bengal, likely focused in Jhargram, Purulia, Paschin Bardhaman, Bankura, Alipurduar and Cooch Behar Districts. The Fund would continue to support 2 existing grantees and seek to expand support to 2 new grantees. With Oaks support grantees will receive the resources and support to build on their work, progress and learning so far, with a deepened focus on building community awareness of the power in their cultural identity and heritage, its connection to land, and in pursuing their constitutional rights to land ownership and access. Grantees will be able to continue supporting communities to claim land titles, to scale up their outreach and mobilization efforts into new areas, and to advocate for West Bengals Forest governance structure to be strengthened, ensuring communities have the power and voice in the process through building grassroot mobilization of community-based organisations Oak Application Form     11such as Banadhikargram sabha morcha and Uttar Banga Vanjan Shramajeevi Manch.As far as our grantees liaising with the government departments, this will happen to some extent, especially with district administration, forest department, and nodal agencies such as the Department of Backward class welfare who is primarily responsible for the implementation of Forest Rights. However, grantees likely will not lobby or advocate directly with these departments since the Gram Sabha Morcha  an important peoples network/forum- will take the lead in having direct dialogue with government departments on behalf of its communities. Similarly, North Bengal groups will engage with such departments since they are already working on forest rights although it is not directly supported by our funds.Our proposed work would align strongly with the Funds strategic priorities to shift more resources to grassroots environmental activists and solutions in India, to build indigenous communities resilience and power on environmental issues and their rights, to support intersectional approaches to activism, and to help nurture a grassroots climate justice movement that has indigenous communities, women and youth at its heart and helm.
GAF_A_Fund_For_Global_Human_Rights_Suppo.7. OBJECTIVES: 7. OBJECTIVESThis is the most important part of your application, as it is your opportunity to explain what you want to achieve and what will be different because of your work. We understand that social and environmental change is complex and there are a multitude of factors that contribute to change. We want to understand how you define your role in the overall change you hope to make. You may find it helpful to discuss this with your Oak Programme Officer, and others in your own organisation.   7.a. ObjectivesList here up to 3 main objectives for this grant (one sentence per objective). Think of objectives as goals that can be achieved within the lifetime of the grant.  We encourage you to think of objective(s) that are ambitious but also achievable.  Objective #1: To support community groups and institutions in West Bengal - those embedded in and led by indigenous and forest-dwelling communities - to strengthen their work, leadership and resilience.Objective #2: To promote and protect the dignity, autonomy and resilience of indigenous communities in West Bengal to live and enjoy their individual and collective rights  with a particular focus on land and natural resource rights - without fear or persecution.Oak Application Form     127.b. Expected Outcomes (bullet points):What do you expect will change because of this grant? What does success look like? List here the main outcomes you hope to achieve or make significant contributions towards with this grant, and for whom.  If you have concrete targets, please also list them here. Outcomes describe significant changes for people, communities, organisations or systems. Some examples are changes in policies and legislation; changes in knowledge, awareness, attitudes, beliefs, behaviours or social norms; changes in capacities, level of influence, agency or access to services. Please refer to the guidance for additional examples.Key Outcomes:Objective 1 outcomes:1.1 Grassroots groups - those embedded in and led by indigenous communities - have access to flexible funding to advance their work and goals and build their resilience. 1.2 Community-level institutions like Gram Sabhas and Forest Rights Committees (non-registered community forums/ village councils as per the mandate of the Forest Rights Act) are formed and are functioning well.1.3 Communities demonstrate increased knowledge and awareness around indigenous knowledge and forest governance.1.4Intergenerational leadership of indigenous communities, especially of women and youth, is strengthened.Objective 2 outcomes:2.1 Indigenous communities demonstrate increase knowledge and understanding of their rights and laws in place like the Forest Rights Act 2.2 Communities are mobilized, and community-level institutions like Gram Sabhas have advanced community-led processes of claiming their forest rights.  2.3 Communities have increased ownership of over forest resources. 2.4 Communities are not displaced or forced off their land.  7.c. Activities and timeframe (bullet points):List in bullet points the main types of activities that you plan to to carry out to achieve your expected outcomes. Please keep these at a high level and and dont include the full list of every activity you plan to carry out, instead, concentrate on the type of activities this grant will fund. If your Programme Officer wants more information, we will ask you separately for a work plan. Examples might include: (1) Research; (2) Provision of legal advice to...; (3) Training on movement building for...Oak Application Form     13Key Strategies/Activities will include (and are not exhaustive):Direct grantmaking and accompaniment to 4 grassroots groups in Jhargram, Purulia, Paschin Bardhaman, Bankura, Alipurduar and Cooch Behar Districts of West BengalCapacity-building support to selected villages to form Gram Sabhas (goal of 10+ per year): including training Gram Sabhas leaders and activists on procedures of the Forest Rights Act and advocacySupport Banadhikar Gram Sabhas Mocha  a network/platform of all local Gram Sabhas in the area that was organically formed by some Gram Sabhas leadersCapacity-building workshops for community members on the Forest Rights Act and other allied laws and awareness-raising of indigenous communities around their constitutional rights and indigenous knowledgeSupport to Gram Sabhas to pursue their claims to the State for community forest rights  aim to support claims related to at least 3,000 hectares of landSupport for gram panchayats (village councils) of Sundarbans  to support extremely vulnerable and marginalized widows of tiger attack victims to seek compensation they are entitled to from the State  aim to support 125 cases annually (expanded from currently around 45 p/a)District level awareness campaigns organized involving local communities, forest rights groups and activists.
GAF_A_Fund_For_Global_Human_Rights_Suppo.8. COOPERATION: 8. COOPERATION  How will you involve others in your approach to achieving change? If you are planning to engage in partnerships with other organisations, communities, people with lived experience, academics or secure the support of key individuals, please tell us about this.  Why are these the right partners to engage with?  Is there anything new about how you are choosing to work - for example, new partnerships or an approach that is different to how you usually work? (300 words):The Fund identifies and supports efforts to tackle the deep root causes of injustice and inequality in India. Our carefully selected cohort of grantees is typically diverse and includes many emerging, youth-led groups, groups that are led by people with lived experience from the marginalized communities they are representing, and those using an intersectional approach to their work.With Oaks renewed support, the Fund aims to sustain support to 2-3 existing grantees  enabling them to build on and strengthen work previously supported and expand into new areas - as well as identify and support a further 1-2 new grantees. The Funds process of identifying new grantees would draw on our existing mapping of potential partners, our ongoing Oak Application Form     14learning, and our continued priority to support a diversity of groups and voices, and meet Oaks requirement of supporting FCRA approved groups. Under this new grant the Fund would also seek to provide targeted technical assistance and ongoing accompaniment to enable grantees to realize their goals and objectives under this project, and where possible, and if of interest to grantees, to support and facilitate some learning and knowledge exchange, taking the steer from grantees, as mentioned in the following section, and depending on the resources available. The Fund would also work with grantees to support them to strengthen their leadership - promoting second line leadership  as well as the intergenerational leadership of the communities they are working with. The Fund has learned from its twenty years of grantmaking globally and within India that this is also vital for the sustainability, vibrancy and effectiveness of local groups and the human rights movement more broadly.
GAF_A_Fund_For_Global_Human_Rights_Suppo.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING This section is twofold. Please tell us:a) Monitoring and evaluation. How will you know if you are achieving your objectives? Please describe briefly how you will know if you are making progress and if what you are doing is working. If you have a formal monitoring and evaluation system and if you plan to collect indicator data or conduct an external evaluation, please provide details here.b) Learning. Please tell us if there anything in particular that you are hoping to learn more about or test through this grant.(300 words):a. Monitoring and evaluation:The Fund has developed a strategic framework for each country that guides the Funds allocation of its resources and provides a means for evaluating its grant-making over time. Each grantee will be required to submit a proposal every year outlining their proposed work and goals for the year ahead and proposed qualitative and quantitative indicators to track developments and progress. The Funds program staff in India will then speak with each grantee to jointly set indicators  aligned to what we have outlined in this proposal - that they will use to determine whether their efforts are moving in the desired direction.The assessment of these indicators is done typically through six monthly narrative reports.  Alongside these grantee reports, the Funds program staff in India will maintain regular communication with grantees  likely every quarter - as an important part of building strong relationships rooted in trust, and to help maintain open discussions on progress and challenges on their work and strategies. Fund staff will also visit grantees regularly to accompany them in their work, to deepen discussions around strategies, and to encourage ongoing reflection and learning.The Fund recognizes that no work happens in isolation; it can have planned and unplanned impact, just as the emerging social, cultural and political context can impact the work in foreseen and unforeseen ways. During its discussions with grantees, the Funds major role is as a thought partner who Oak Application Form     15can help the grantee understand the role and impact of their organization not just in its own silo, but also in the context of the broader eco-system of organizations. The Fund also provides guidance, and where possible additional support and resources, to also support grantees to build their capacity, leadership and ensure their sustainability. In India, the Fund does this with a particular focus on promoting the development of second line leadership within its grantees and ensuring the younger generation of activists are elevated.b. Learning:The Fund is increasingly nurturing a learning culture and sees learning as an ongoing and self-reinforcing process. Through the ongoing monitoring and evaluation efforts mentioned above, the Fund would seek to deepen its learning on the most effective strategies to build communities resilience and power to claim their rights related to access and management of land and natural resources in West Bengal, as well as on the intersection with protecting indigenous cultural identity. We would then use this reflection and learning to apply a sharper focus to our grantees and our own programming strategies going forward.
GAF_A_Fund_For_Global_Human_Rights_Suppo.10. RISKS AND CHALLENGES: 10.  RISKS AND CHALLENGESWhat are the risks or barriers that might prevent you from achieving your outcomes and how will you address these?  What are your opportunities?We understand that achieving long-lasting and meaningful change is hard and we expect that the work you want to do will mean taking risks.  We encourage you to be open to telling us these, as well as how you will address these risks.  If some of your outcomes are risky, are there any incremental achievements that you could identify? (300 words):Challenges of disbursing funding: the Fund has sound expertise in navigating restrictive funding spaces, particularly in India, and remains nimble and under the radar by grantmaking in creative ways, including using fiscal sponsors if neededGrantees supported face threats to their work or safety, especially related to criminalization: the Fund will provide flexible support so they can respond, as well as emergency funding (Legal Defense Fund) and other support when needed to help grantees respond to immediate or emerging threatsThe Fund needs to remain under the radar: we will limit communication and sharing of info on our work in India to secure channels, including avoiding naming grantees, secure comms with Fund staff on the ground, and not exposing Fund staff in India to further risk through public-facing communications. The Fund will continue to audit its own security and draw on its in-house expertise on digital security and civic space issues.Oak Application Form     16

GAF_A_Durbar_Mahila_Samanwaya_Committee_.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT 5a. Tell us about your governance and leadership structures, as well as staff and volunteer base. Highlight any significant recent or expected future changes. If you have an explicit approach to increasing diversity and/or advancing race equity within the organisation, please tell us. (300 words):Durbar Mahila Samanwaya Committee (DMSC) is a collective of sex workers (male, female and transgender) based in West Bengal, India. It has been active since 1995 to remove different socio-cultural and structural barriers in the lives of the sex workers and other marginalized communities. Since last 27 years, Durbar is continuously fighting for the protection and promotion of the fundamental rights to the sex workers and other marginalized communities. It has an Executive Committee of 9 persons who are elected from the General Body every three years. The Executive Committee is Oak Application Form     5responsible for all decisions on policy, staff matters, fund raising, budgeting etc.DMSC will be receiving these funds on behalf of the Right to Food and Work Campaign West Bengal (RTF&W Campaign WB). The RTF&W Campaign WB is a network of about 75-80 NGOs, peoples organisations and individuals, of which about 22 are fairly active. They have come together to address the issue of food security and rural employment in West Bengal. A Secretariat facilitates communication between partner NGOs to keep them informed about State and National level activities. Presently, the Steering Group, consisting of four partner organisations, Durbar Mahila Samanwaya Committee, Udayani Social Action Forum, SEWA Bharat and Paschim Banga Khet Majoor Samity, which has only one full time staff member and a part time legal consultant. Everyone else works for the Campaign on a voluntary basis.During the coming year, the Secretariat will expand to include some more staff members to undertake various other activities as mentioned later. On a need-based basis, it may also take on other consultants.   The Steering group will also be expanded to include other interested partner organisations.The Campaign has attempted to establish a North Bengal based network in the last few years which is partially functioning. This still needs nurturing in the next few years before it can function effectively. 5b. Summarise the organisations history.  In addition, highlight 2-3 key achievements.Please keep this brief and list up to 3 key achievements as bullet points. Even though you may have many achievements, please share what is most relevant to the proposed grant. (300 words)A vertical HIV intervention program was launched in 1992 following a base line study conducted by All India Institute of Hygiene & Public Health (AAIH&PH), a Central Govt. institute. The objective was to initiate STD and HIV prevention program in Sonagachi, a red light zone in Kolkata, India. The intervention programme started with three principal components: provision of health services including STD treatment; information, education and communication (IEC); and condom programming. It was in the year 1995 out of felt need by the community members followed by several discussions and consultations, a unique body of the fallen women was formed;  Durbar Mahila Samanwaya Committee (DMSC) came into existence. This is a forum exclusively set up and managed by sex workers and their children with the objective of creating solidarity and collective strength among the sex worker community and other marginalized groups.1. The success of DMSC run HIV intervention program is known as Sonagachi model being the most successful intervention among sex workers globally. This has helped National Govt. to articulate a strategy called Targeted Interventions for the high risk communities like sex workers, Transgender, MSM population. Based on the Lesson Learnt from Sonagachi Project, NACO (National AIDS Control Oak Application Form     6Organization) articulated the concept of Creating Enabling Environment and Community organizing and Ownership building what became the budgeted and integral component of HIV intervention program. The principles of Sonagachi model was taken to build the foundation of .Bill and Melinda Gates supported HIV intervention program in India spending $350 Million. Both these strategies were also accepted by all UN agencies including big donors like the Global fund DFID etc. in their programmatic approach.2. Durbar is a founder member of All India Network of Sex Workers which at present represent 85 community based organizations of sex workers and TG spread across 18 states in India.3. Durbar is part of numbers of National networks and campaign movements like Rights to Food campaign, Rights to education campaign, the Pension Parishad, NREGA Sangharsh Morcha and many others.4. We are register member of National Trade Union Initiative [NTUI], a national level trade union in India. The forum  of informal sector women in the state of  West Bengal which represent voices of around one hundred thousand women workers belonging to 18 different occupational group is jointly headed by a sex workers representative from Durbar5. Durbar is part of many women networks who are fighting against gender discrimination, violence against women e.g. Maitreyee, Sramajibi Swikriti Mancha in West Bengal.6. Durbars cultural wing has been very successful who are selected to perform in the Opening Ceremony of International AIDS Conference held in Geneva as well as they were invited in the last two ICAAPs held in Bangkok and Dhaka respectively. The cultural team of Durbar also took part in the India Got Talent program and reached to the finals of the said program.7. In the arena of sports, 8 kids from Durbar were selected for various age group national level tournaments. Two of them have represented the country and one was selected to take training in Manchester United, a well-known club from English Premier League. A team from Durbar took part in Dana Cup in Denmark which is the biggest adolescent group football tournament. They became Group Champions in the said tournament. Durbar is also taking part in the ongoing Sub Junior and Junior Level I-league.8. Durbar is able to prevent the negative amendments of the Immoral Traffic (Prevention) Act through a successful protest march to the Parliament of India in 2006. More than 1000 sex workers were participated in that protest march.9. Conceptualizing and establishing the Self-Regulatory Board which has not only been successful from the strategic point of view but has also been endorsed by the Honble Supreme Court constituted Panel to replicate this model of intervention to curb trafficking in all major cities in India.10. Usha Multipurpose Co-operative Society, a sister organization of Durbar is the example of a sex-workers co-operative which make the Oak Application Form     7sex workers economically empowered At present there are more than thirty thousand members of the said co-operative run by the board of sex workers which has annual turnover of 25 crores of Rupees. Usha was selected as one of the best models in the co-operative movement in West Bengal in 2016.11. In the field of education DURBAR fought a bitter battle to enroll children of sex workers in formal school. In early days they were denied admission, with a tenuous effort based on advocacy and negotiation we succeeded admission of children, since last three years on an average one hundred and fifty children per year could complete schooling. We also run a hostel for 6these kids which accommodate eighty childrenThe Right to Food and Work Campaign West Bengal that has been in existence since 2001. In the last seven to eight years with the financial assistance from the OAK foundation it has made the following major contributions to the issue of food security: -It has been able to strengthen its network and spreads its network in 20 districts in the state.In number of cases unpaid wages under the MGNREGA has been paid by the government due to strong intervention of the Campaign. In the year 2017  18 due to intervention of the campaign about 881 persons were paid their due wages and the approximate amount is Rs.17919540/-Several times, teams on behalf of the Campaign conducted studies in the tea gardens in North Bengal. Through the studies and fact findings, the campaign prepared a number of reports and calculated dues of the workers from the management. From time to time these reports were submitted to the both the central and state government as well before the Honble Supreme Court of India. And finally on 4th April, 2018 Honble Supreme Court in a contempt proceeding of a case filed by Paschim Banga Khet Majoor Samity and other unions directed the government of West Bengal to pay Rs. 15 Cr. to the workers as an interim relief.The campaign organized  training programs for the tea garden workers regarding the procedure of filling claim forms also members of the campaign are consistently monitoring the proper implementation of the order passed by Honble Court on 4th April, 2018 and to find out the problems of the workers to fill the forms.The Supreme Court in 2020 constituted a one-member committee headed by retired Supreme Court judge A.M. Sapre to inspect and verify the claims of workers. The hearing by Justice Sapre's Committee was delayed due to Covid-19 and subsequent lockdowns. However, on 15.09.2021, the Committee passed an order stating that all the workers of these 29 gardens would have to submit their claim forms and which is an ongoing process till date.Fact finding in to the starvation deaths at Bhatpara, North 24 Parganas, Purulia and Lalgarh, Jhargram have been conducted. This has led to relief programs for the victims and sometimes their communities. In the recent case of hunger death in the district of Oak Application Form     8Jhargram the state government is made accountable and a complaint has been filed to NHRC.Right to Food and Work Campaign have successfully supported a seminar of beneficiaries which was a long due plan. In the said seminar around 300 delegates from 17 districts of Bengal and 36 other organisations came together at Rammohon hall. The objective was to involve beneficiaries in the campaign to monitor the implementation of NFSA, MGNREGA and this seminar is a significant step towards this objective.As per state food security scheme in West Bengal RKSY-I & RKSY-II (Rajya Khadya Suraksha Yojana) are the two ration card types under which wheat and rice is given to poor people through Public Distribution System (PDS) / Fair Price Shop (FPS). The RKSY (I & II) ration cards are issued to the most financially weaker section of the state who are left uncovered under National Food Security Act, 2013 (NFSA). Under the state food security scheme, the entitlements as well as the subsidized price differs to get dry rations from Public Distribution system. The RKSY-I beneficiary gets monthly 5KGs of ration (3 KGs of Wheat per month at the FPS price of ?2 per KG and 2KGs of rice per month at the FPS price of ?2 per KG). Whereas, RKSY-II ration card beneficiary gets 2 KGs of ration (1 KG of Wheat per month at the FPS price of ?9 per KG and 1KGs of rice per month at the FPS price of ?13 per KG). The entitlement of ration under RKSY-II was already less and was pricier than RKSY-I,the Campaign had advocated for the increase in allocation of the PDS entitlements and to ensure equal benefits for RKSY-II card holders. As a result of which, the campaign claims that RKSY-II (Rajya Khadya Suraksha Yojana-II) ration card holders had got 5 kgs of rations per card per month from PDS at no cost for the initial phase lockdown, but in the later lockdown phases, the original entitlement of 2 KGs of ration per card per month was restored for RKSY-II ration card holders at free of cost. And till date the RKSY-II ration card holders are receiving the ration as per their entitlement at free of cost throughout the state.The strength of our partner organisations has grown due to adequate knowledge of the scheme and laws. As such, they can make the government officials function to implement various schemes.During the induced lockdown and post lockdown the campaign has conducted two research studies to understand the hunger status and the findings of which has been shared with the state government for the proper implementation of food security in the state.The campaign has able to capacitated more than 40 individuals as community leaders identified by the partner organisations.Coordination amongst partner organisations has improved and we have learned how to work together.Oak Application Form     95c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and decide your approach? If you have undertaken a theory of change exercise, or if you are influenced by research, policy or your own organisations experience, please tell us about this.  Have you consulted with relevant stakeholders, including your communities and others experiencing the problem? Is there an intention to address equity, diversity and inclusion? (600 words):RTF&W Campaign WB is addressing the problem of food security, focusing especially on hunger deaths and malnutrition. It is working especially on the rights to food and work.  Its work is at various levels. For example, at the grass roots level, it works to ensure that people know about existing rights such as the Supreme Court orders on Right to Food, the NFSA and the MGNREGA. It also understands through the experience at the grass roots about lacunae in the implementation of these rights and mobilises and campaigns to deal with these lacunae at the administrative level. In addition, it also defines and lobbies and campaigns for an expansion of these rights at the State and National level. Civil society activists and local leaders are actively participating in the movement to add momentum and influence the policy makers to be pro poor in nature. The emergent leaders and the CBOs are taking up issues at the micro level and challenging the Panchayat, Block and District administration to be accountable and transparent in their execution of these rights.The challenges facing the Campaign are as follows:-The groups, individuals and the community leaders face difficulties related to pressure from local goons. Besides threats from the local leaders, the administration sometimes creates hindrances in effective implementation. Red tapism and too many bottlenecks related to documents and evidential proof takes more time in actual initiation of the actions to be taken.Organisations are at various levels of understanding of issues and in capacities to deal with such issues. A big challenge is that there are large stretches of blocks and districts where our work has had no impact so far and where we do not have any partners.A big challenge is to maintain communication and co-ordination amongst member organisations of the campaign. The North-South divide in the state in terms of distances as well as issues and even language means that the Campaign will have to have parallel activities for different areas.Similarly, another challenge is to convince member organisations to move out of the project mode (where food security issues are taken up only when there are funds for a project) to the movement mode where these issues become part of their work on a long term basis.This in fact would be the main focus of the project i.e. building capacities and understanding to go from viewing right to food as only a three year project to a view that it is an essential part of each partners work in the long term and that work continues even when the project ends. For this, we will focus on trainings to build capacity, but also give partners practical experience in doing studies, in campaigning and in lobbying. A preclude to such activity will be to actually do an assessment of where the partner is in terms of capacities and understanding of issues.Oak Application Form     10An important focus is also the use of instruments like litigation, studies and publications to bring about public focus on the rights to food and decent employment.The network is learning from its past experiences and incorporating the learnings to the future strategies as and whenever required. For instance, the network is focusing on capacity building of the young generation of the target communities and building them asset to the communities. Also, inclusion of partners and community members in conducting studies helps the network to understand the depth of issue and to collect evidences of negligence/loopholes at the implementation of the social schemes. These documentations support the campaign to file strong litigation to the court. The network is going to emphasize on capacity building and inclusion of communities in these processes. The network will also emphasize on modular group formation as per capacity of the grassroot emerging leaders & existing partner organisations and link such groups on the existing groups at village level, at panchayat level, at Block level, at district level and to state level.
