GAF_American_Friends_of_Edelgive_Foundat.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 6. Context (The context section should not exceed two pages.)6a. Describe the organisation (include information on leadership, governance, structure and staff) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):American Friends of EdelGive Foundation (AFEF) is a Delaware-based nonprofit organisation set up with the mission to invest in programs that provide solutions to deep-rooted social inequalities and build the capacities of credible grassroots organizations in India that work towards that goal.AFEFs leadership includes Mr. Ranganathan Purushothaman as President alongwith Mr. Pranjul Srivastava as the Secretary and Mr. Jeffrey Heller as the Treasurer.AFEF Board Members comprises of five individuals from diverse backgrounds with a keen interest in philanthropy, who will objectively make decisions on grant awards and provide critical inputs on operations and functions. The Board members include Ms. Shailaja Akkapeddi, Mr. Fergus Fleming, Mr. Deven Waghani, Mr. Pranjul Srivastava and Ms. Rajul Kadakia.Rajul Kadakia and Deven Waghani in their respective fields are highly appreciated individuals with over 20 years of experience. Both as successful entrepreneurs with their own startups, equipped provide entrepreneurial expertise, technological inputs, corporate strategy and investor relations experience.Shailaja Akkapeddi as an independent consultant specializing in non-profits development and capacity building, therefore understands the sector and the need of the sector.Pranjul Srivastava and Fergus Flemming bring years of experience in finance, marketing & asset management. They are a valuable addition in providing critical and valuable feedback/suggestions in the Foundations operations, strategy and financials.With regard to the expected changes - As AFEF grows further, the aim is to continue on the path of diversity, building a team and partners who can bring in a blend of thoughts and experiences to enable cross learning, and strengthen the organisation from within.Grant Application Form, July 1 201356b. Describe the financial situation (include information on annual operating costs, fundraising strategy, reserves and debts) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):AFEF looks to support credible small to mid-sized organisations in India doing impactful work with a focus on three critical segments of society; children, women and vulnerable communities. AFEF will be the anchor funder for all foreign grants to the grantee partners in India, will review grant applications and determine whether the requested grants will be made towards these reputable charitable organisations in India within the meaning of Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Governed by its funding eligibility criteria, AFEF may accept or refuse to grant award to the applying organisations.Annual operating costs, which include staff salaries, fixed costs, service charge etc., will be proportionately accounted for through donor grants as management cost by mutual agreement with the donor.AFEF intends to connect with potential foundations, corporations and individuals by networking through peer engagement, events and research  to enhance outreach, build credibility and appeal to the larger Philanthropic ecosystem towards supporting credible organisations in India.For the next 2-3 years, AFEF has visibility of a few funders who are anticipated to contribute medium to high volume of funds; estimated to be approx 5-6 million USD who are looking to support organisations in India inclusive of GROW.6c. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):AFEF was incorporated in June 1, 2020 and has recently started operations. Currently AFEF is managing grants of ~USD 3.5 mn supporting programs in COVID 19 aid, migrant and disaster relief, education and women empowerment grassroots initiatives in India.These funds have been directly provided to the identified implementing partners working in India such as Goonj and Jan Sahas who are catering to communities pan-India, Samaritan Help Mission, Sanjog,and SOVA in West Bengal and Orissa , etc.AFEFs primary activities includes identifying and creating relationships with reputable charitable organizations operating in India that provide services and programs consistent with the charitable purposes of the Foundation. AFEF as an anchor funder to the implementing partners in India, has currently identified EdelGive Foundation as an advisor and grants manager in India.AFEF plans to act as a gateway for individuals and various institutions/organizations who are looking to provide grants to credible organizations operating in India.EdelGive Foundation who is the reference partner, advisor and grants manager of AFEF, will be responsible for the overall implementation, management and monitoring of grants in India.EdelGive has over the decade committed and influenced close to INR 3.3 billion into Grant Application Form, July 1 20136social development, partnered with more than 150 Non-Government Organisations (NGOs) across 14 districts in India, impacted more than 1.7 million lives, and provided pro bono support of over 40,000 hours of skilled volunteering. EdelGive is currently part of 6 big collaboratives in diverse domains; in critical capacities.6d. Describe the current strategy of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):India is home to 1.4 billion people from diverse communities with each community having its own distinct challenges.  Despite Government intervention and policies over the years, there have been gaps in addressing community needs, leaving some unaddressed and unheard.Grassroot organisations role hence is fundamental to addressing social needs from a microscopic lens. Although, India receives the highest foreign aid from across the world, philanthropic efforts are unreachable/inequitably distributed towards the rural marginalized sections or urban poverty pockets within cities.Hence, AFEFs mission was born out of this realization to support small and mid-sized organisations in India who understand the dynamic development dilemmas of the communities, their immediate needs and provide sustainable solutions. AFEF aims to fulfil this by focusing on:Education  With a belief that every child has the right to attend school and learn in school, AFEF seek to address the systemic gaps that impact childrens access to quality education.Women Empowerment  Adopt a rights-based approach to support women in society, free them from violence and discrimination, build awareness and accessibility to their rights and entitlements, make them economically independent and build grassroots leaders.Livelihoods  Work with vulnerable communities affected by unemployment, failing agriculture and natural calamities through interventions targeted towards building the resilience of the rural and tribal populations.AFEF will scope/invite proposals from organisations implementing critical initiatives in India, and through a thorough due diligence process will award grantees with AFEFs multi-year grants approach. AFEF has also partnered with EdelGive, to assist with the scoping process, monitoring and fund management in India.AFEF with EdelGive joined its first collaborative, to support the GROW Fund as an anchor funder to help sustain 100 organisations for 2 years whose operations have been impacted owing to the pandemic.6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):Grant Application Form, July 1 20137ContextThe rapid spread of COVID-19 has resulted in devastating consequences for economies, businesses, and communities across the globe. In India particularly, lockdowns have more deeply affected migrant and vulnerable communities who are grappling with loss of income, livelihood, food, healthcare and resultant uncertainty and helplessness.Grassroot organisations have been at the forefront of addressing these problems but have also become casualties themselves owing to extreme financial distress that is likely to leave a lasting, negative impact outliving their capacities to mitigate them. Studies done during the COVID-19 period have reported that NGOs are facing lack of access to basic technology, salary cuts, lay-offs, inability to pay rent or source basic supplies for daily sustenance are already prevailing issues.Of the 388 NGOs that responded to a Bridgespan survey on Building Strong, Resilient NGOs in India: Time for New Funding Practices:54% had less than 3 months of reserves in Sep20, 50% NGOs never had an operating surplus61% NGOs based in non-metro areas are worse off than in metros others with less than 3 months of reserves60% NGOs led by leaders from historically disadvantaged communities (DBA-Dalit, Bahujan Adivasi communities) have lower financial resilience with less than 3 months of reserves, against 53% of non-DBA led NGOs.The Impact of Covid-19 on India's Nonprofit Organisations report by CSIP based on survey responses from close to 300 NGOs and 52 interviews reported the following insights on challenges being faced:Operating in accordance with social distancing norms (61%)Dealing with financial insecurity (55%)Managing staff including remote work and ensuring staff well-being and safety (70%).Burnout and exhaustion given that many NPOs worked at capacity and beyond with limited staff strengthSuspension of programs owing to discontinued funding and limited or absent resource mobilisation capacity.Given the above realities and facts, the possibility of breakdown of this cadre of organisations whom Foundations like AFEF rely on to deliver last-mile relief to communities, is worrisome.Opportunities:As funders and grantmakers, AFEF and EdelGive deem it our responsibility to ensure the grassroots sector sustains through:Recognition of grassroots work and of the risks that will be encountered if it were to ceaseAcknowledgment of challenges that threaten to derail this workReadiness to arrive at urgent, practical and longer term solutions to address these challengesAs proponents of collaborative rather than siloed approaches having experience of anchoring multiple Coalitions, we were among the first partners to join Bridgespans Pay What it Takes initiative which is committed to building stronger, Grant Application Form, July 1 20138more financially resilient NGOs. We have conceived the GROW Fund as part of our mission to strengthen small and medium NGOs to emerge stronger and stay sturdy to overcome crises like COVID-19.The GROW Fund brings together like-minded Indian and international funders in a collaborative model (in line with PWIT tenets) to collectively address the challenges facing grassroots NGO in India. The Fund will demonstrate a new future of funding model that will ensure two-year support 100 vetted organisations, cover their core cost, provide capacity building (CB) support and organisational development support for future readiness (FR).The GROW Fund has currently received commitments covering ~50% of its total budget and is in the process of initiating the call for proposals by August end.The success of the GROW Fund 2021-2024 is anticipated to pave way for similar initiatives/subsequent rounds of GROW to shape the narrative of philanthropy in and for India.Challenges:We anticipate certain natural occurrences, which may hamper the projects timelines/focus such as recurring relapse of COVID-19 that may lead to nationwide lockdowns and threat to lives.The challenges to organizational resilience are multi-fold and we will adopt a multi-dimensional approach to address them through common as well as customized alternatives for grantees
GAF_American_Friends_of_Edelgive_Foundat.7. OBJECTIVES: 7. Objectives (maximum 2,200 words)For a core support grant, state the purpose of this grant request and complete the objectives.  After consultations with an Oak PO, you may decide to summarise your mission as one broad objective. In this case, it is still necessary to specify activities and results/outcomes for this objective.For project support grants please list your objectives for this project in bullet point format. (You may use additional space if you have more than three objectives)?. Under each objective describe the activities that your organisation will undertake to achieve it, including time frame and the results or outcomes you expect to achieve.7.1.a. Objective 1 (maximum one sentence):100 grassroot NGOs are identified and shortlisted from across four zones in India through a thorough application and screening process, and are supported for core costs for 24 months.7.1.b. Objective 1 Expected results/outcomes and timeframe (maximum 300 words):Grant Application Form, July 1 201397.1.c. Objective 1 Activities and timeframe (maximum 300 words):ActivitiesThe support from Oak grant will enable AFEF and EdelGive to institute a robust team who will be oriented for executing the GROW Fund processes. To ensure an objective screening process AFEF will be leveraging EdelGives expertise of grantmaking to craft a screening framework but will work with expert third-party agencies to deploy it to avoid any unreasonable bias and maintain neutrality.The requested grant will therefore help build this core team of GROW and execution partners for the following processes:1.Identification of organisationsAFEF and EdelGive aim to identify and invite applications from credible organisations across India guided by a clearly outlined and operationalized selection criteria. The organisations will be scoped through:a) Outreach through networks  Invite for applications will be initiated through large networking platforms like Give India, Milaap, NGOBOX etc. This may help ensure eligible organisations from all corners of the country to apply for the grant.b) Peer engagement and funder groups - With the combined support of EdelGive, we aim to reach out to network of peers, funders, sector experts, institutions for referrals and recommendations to ensure maximum outreach.2.Screening and shortlisting to identify the credible organisations that meet the eligibility criteria and are representative of four zones of India (South, West, North and East+North East) a. A clearly articulated RfP, with guidelines will be shared with the organisations to capture information on their needs.Expected Results:The following are broad outcomes that is envisioned under Objective 1AFEF and EdelGive are able to:Institute a core team that execute/oversee all processes and partnerships for GROW and grow as a robust Project Management Unit / GROW Secretariat that will manage this Fund and others to follow.Outreach grassroot NGOs from across the country including states like West Bengal, Jharkhand, Southern states, North Eastern states etcIdentify their core costs needs and determine their criticality to the organisations survival and operationsScreening and shortlisting 100 NGOs and preliminary needs assessment through their applicationsMore details on envisaged outcomes will also be available post grantee selection after individual organizational plans on grant utilization are finalized; and we will be able to identify common and/or custom outcomes.Timeframe:We will monitor the progress of the outcomes bi-annually and expect the results to be visible at the end of the 2 year commitment with the NGOsGrant Application Form, July 1 201310b. Needs identification and assessment of critical needs for any support like the following as well as any other aspect for support that may emerge during the process:Salaries for staff, especially field staffRents for officesTechnology Solutions.Operational CostsRelief Measures3. Selection Parameters: EdelGive will invite proposals through an open application process. All organisations will undergo a rigorous selection process in a phased manner as per the given parameters below.  Each application will be judged objectively based on both the qualitative and quantitative information submitted.1.     Overall financial strength and fundraising capacity2.     Compliance as per government regulations3.     Reach, impact, and coverage4.     Critical gaps in funding5.     Critical capacity building needs6.     Impact of Covid-19 on programmesTo maintain a neutral, unbiased and inclusive approach to identify the cohort of 100 GROW investees, the application process unit and grant management unit will be managed by Grant Thornton (GT) who have been selected amongst other agencies after thorough due diligence, review and referrals. Grant Thornton will oversee the shortlisting of NGOs basis the pre-determined criteria and evaluation matrix set by EdelGive who will supervise the entire operations alongwith GT.Timeframe:The selection process is estimated to begin in September-21 and end by December-21.Overall duration is expected to be 3.5-4 years from pre-grant to post-grant phase to monitor overall learnings post the grant cycle.7.2.a. Objective 2 (maximum one sentence):Operational capabilities of GROW Fund execution team are strengthened to identify and execute unique as well as common capacity building initiatives for grantees for meeting immediate needs and for long-term institutional sustainability and programmes.7.2.b. Objective 2 Expected results/outcomes and timeframe (maximum 300 words):Grant Application Form, July 1 2013117.2.c. Objective 2 Activities and timeframe (maximum 300 words):Given the magnitude of GROW and our vision to create a series of GROW-like funds in the future, we are very aware that we need to enhance in-house capabilities as well as build strong partnerships with external agencies who brings in the experience and expertise in the field they know best. We will require support on ensuring that these competencies are either internally or externally developed for our future sustainability. ActivitiesAFEF-EdelGive will utilize this grant support to execute the GROW Fund:Identify CB experts, experienced sector experts or well-established organisations as resource partners for implementation of organizational support (capacity building and future readiness) to enhance our learnings on capabilities on attributes such as analytics, technology, stakeholder management, partnerships, compliance, etc.Enable a strategic hiring process to onboard experienced personnel and sector experts who can effectively execute the GROW initiativeCollaborate with other peer funders, senior leadership and seasoned Expected ResultsEdelGive will be able facilitate capacity building for addressing immediate needs and future readiness support on a need basis for long-term sustainability focusing on cultivating and institutionalizing the best practices within the organisations in the 3 focus areas/components which are Finance, HR and Technology.The AFEF and EdelGive team is equipped to:Implement/facilitate short-term engagements for need-based capacity building and addressing needs common to several grantees.Execute future readiness support to organisations who are equipped with basic tools/processes to prepare them for long term sustainabilityCollective Branding - The 100 GROW grantees will be collectivised and will be jointly promoted, campaigned and a positive branding will be built on them. Their stories will be highlighted and celebrated in all our communication, thereby, their growth will be easily comprehensible by other funding organisations who are otherwise unaware of their work.Enhanced visibility- By bringing the cohort together, enabling peer learning and building a positive message around the work that they excellently do, a stronger proposition will be formed for the organisations for future funding with funders. We hope to nudge them towards financial sustainability through this thus enhancing their capabilities.Improve outreach for networks of peers, funders, sector experts etc for resource diversificationIdentify deterrents which prevents the grantees to grow and solutions to mitigate themTimeframe:We will monitor the progress of the outcomes bi-annually and expect the results for Capacity Building to be measurable at the end of the 2 year commitmentGrant Application Form, July 1 201312ecosystem players to enable peer learning and cultivate the best practices within the core teamLeverage knowledge and evidence generation, communication, and advocacy tools and avenues for collective, positive branding for grantees and GROW partnersThe above will equip AFEF-EdelGive to facilitate capacity building and future readiness interventions wherein the GROW team through partners will:Identify capacity building needs (application stage, post selection, need assessment and diagnostics)Craft a roadmap and provide end-to-end CB and FR support (addressing common challenges and customized solutions for smaller cohorts of specific grantees) on a need basis on aspects like Finance and Sustainability, Human Resources and Communications, Processes and Technology.Timeframe:The timeframe for the above activities is estimated to begin in quarter January 22 onwards once organisations have been onboarded.7.3.a. Objective 3 (maximum one sentence):AFEF-EdelGive demonstrates a future of funding model through primary evidence aimed at influencing funder behavior in stabilizing the GROW Fund outcomes7.3.b. Objective 3 Expected results/outcomes and timeframe (maximum 300 words):AFEF and EdelGive are able to:Demonstrate the value of investing in core costs, capacity building and future readiness and encourage Indian and international funders to fund such initiativesProvide need-driven and long-term solutions to the funder fraternity to support grassroot NGOs in IndiaStrengthen networks, visibility, and enable outreach to help the GROW Fund multiply and benefit more NGOs beyond this initial 100.Influencer funder behaviour to Pay What It Takes to ensure resilient last-mile organisations and therefore resilient communities they serveSecure more support for organizational development as a funding theme and institutionalization of the GROW Fund or initiatives like the GROW Fund as a good practiceOrganisations are able to:Make visible and address the needs of their communitiesBuild the required infrastructure to strengthen and stabilize their operations and functions for sustainabilityGrant Application Form, July 1 2013137.3.c. Objective 3 Activities and timeframe (maximum 300 words):EdelGive aims to demonstrate through the GROW Fund that a blended approach of grantmaking and organisational development can enable organisations and their work grow stronger and effective.For this, we will be collaborating with Bridgespan as knowledge partner to document the benefits of GROW as a case study on the model. At the end of the two years of GROW, we will have furnished a strong value proposition of supporting core costs and organisational development for increased resilience and greater output. This will act as an evidence on why a collaborative funding model like GROW works and encourage the philanthropic ecosystem to have an inclusive lens on capability building and organisational development of organisations and involve other funders to consider/adopt this as a viable and impactful model of philanthropy.Timeframe:The timeframe for the above activities is estimated to start by September/October 2021 upto the end of the project to collect evidence post the project.
GAF_American_Friends_of_Edelgive_Foundat.8. COOPERATION: 8. CooperationDescribe the level of cooperation with other organisations and networks and explain how this cooperation helps achieve your goals (maximum 300 words):EdelGive conceived GROW with a goal to strengthen the grassroots organisations that are working closely on key development issues, and with some of the most Ensure retention of staff, field workers, management etcImprove quality of work and deliver high-impact results with maximum reachEquipped with strong strategies, processes and team for long-term institutional sustainabilityAchieve greater visibility of their work and devise programme monitoring with higher degree of confidenceCultivate the best practices for sustainable institutionalizationAdoption of principles on cost rationalization and resource mobilizationStrengthening organizational leadership for effective strategic thinking and decision makingTimeframe:We will monitor the progress of the outcomes bi-annually and expect the results to be made available after 3- 4 years commitmentGrant Application Form, July 1 201314disadvantaged communities. The four key stakeholders we will partner with to make GROW a success, and a demonstrable future-of-funding model are funding institutions and individuals, small and medium sized NGOs, EdelGive and AFEF. Each will bring in diverse strengths to the collaborative working towards a common objective and goal.AFEF will play the role of an anchor funder and EdelGive as Secretariat to manage, monitor & evaluate the portfolio and liaison with each of the stakeholders, partners and experts to ensure successful implementation of the programme. It will also be responsible for raising funds for the collaborative from institutional funders, corporations and individuals.NGO Partners will be our source of evidence on the criticality and effectiveness of GROW support in building their organizational resilience. As implementers of projects on ground who have the first-hand experience and understand the ground realties especially through the current challenges, they will also bring a validation of this initiatives success in indirectly benefitting communities  While GROW is expected to directly build capacities of organisations, this benefit is anticipated to enable the organisations to continue and strengthen their projects and last-mile workFunding Partners as equal stakeholders with their years of experience will bring in their learnings, thought process and diverse knowledge to the collaborative. In addition to channelizing funding, EdelGive will also facilitate each funder to engage and lend their expertise as they deem fit.Bridgespan will support EdelGive to document the learnings from GROW and present it in an coherent, cohesive form to the funder community, as a tool to influence funder behaviour. Other communication agencies and experts will assist to strengthen and fortify GROWs outreach and voice through podcasts, convenings and communiques.EdelGive believes that each stakeholder critically contributes to deepening the entire collaborations potential and strengthens its ability to create lasting social change. Therefore, we aim to provide many prospects for each stakeholder to connect and co-operate with each other through events and other various platforms.
GAF_American_Friends_of_Edelgive_Foundat.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. ImpactWhat is the change you want to achieve from the overall project? (maximum 300 words):Through GROW, we aim to support 100 small and medium grassroot organisations who have been exemplary in extending assistance to disadvantaged communities during the COVID-19 pandemic; but in the aftermath are themselves struggling to survive and continue their work.We aim to handhold these organisations throughout the 2-year period and build their organizational capacities so that they will be able to strengthen their functions and operations to serve their communities effectively, enhance their visibility and outreach, generate and communicate evidence of their impactful work, and have access to more funders to secure funds.Grant Application Form, July 1 201315Further, we expect that organisations will institutionalize and cultivate the best practices within the organisation to anticipate and prepare for contingencies (like relapse of COVID, change in legislation etc.).With a large and diverse portfolio under GROW, we aim to learn about the different challenges that each organisation struggle with, especially owing to the diversity of challenges organisations may be facing from different geographical locations and communities they serve. GROW gives us an opportunity understand these challenges better and may enable us create the most effective approach and solutions.We hope to instill confidence, ownership and stability in these organisations like finances, processes, outreach, best practices, exposure to the larger philanthropic ecosystem through existing funder base, events and workshops, etc.We want to institute a committed, coached, confident GROW Fund team who will be instrumental in making GROW Funds execution efficient and effective. This team will evolve into a model Secretariat/Project Management Unit that will not only anchor GROW but also be equipped to anchor other similar or subsequent initiatives like GROW.We also want to demonstrate through leading by example, and validating with evidence, the significance of collaborative philanthropy in addressing existential challenges like survival and resilience of civil society. Additionally, demonstrating GROW as a future of funding model, encourage other funding partners to support non-programmatic core institutional funding for operational costs and capacity building of NGOs.10. EvaluationHow will progress be monitored and evaluated? (maximum 300 words):The project will be monitored through the following framework for the said objectives-OutputsObjective 1Competent staff hired and PMU setup for efficient management of GROWCore team of EdelGive and PMU develops GROW implementation/execution plan including NGO eligibility criteria, selection criteria, needs assessment, etc. Objective 2A robust tool for identification of NGOs capacity building needs developed, EG also adopts it for its regular CB activitiesCapacity Building plan (for centralized offering) to all 100 GROW grantees designed (pre-identified themes)Grant Application Form, July 1 201316Objective 3Network/Visibility for GROW grantee organisations strengthenDocumentation and dissemination of learnings from GROW developed through partnerDissemination of evidence/learnings generated through GROWOutcomesObjective 1100 competent and impactful NGOs selected as granteesNGOs supported with needs identification to take-up programs on their ownObjective 2Evidence based centralized CB plan implemented through identified agenciesExperienced pool of agencies empaneled to delivering CB inputsObjective 3A narrative built in the sector for importance of NGO level support for impact optimization and strengthening of ecosystemReporting of the progress to donors will be done on a six monthly basis and field visits (physical/online) will be organised on request.

(maximum 300 words):Grant InfluenceThe grant will contribute to the realisation of AFEFs first flagship project - GROW. A partnership with and grant from Oak will also help harness and strengthen partnerships with key international and domestic funders who are looking to invest in credible organisations in India.AFEF in partnership with EdelGive aspires to mobilise USD 10 mn for GROW and Oaks grant will be instrumental in helping AFEF build its grantmaking and philanthropy advisory portfolio. It will help AFEF to identify and deepen support to more small to mid-sized organisations doing stellar work in India.Future Plans1. Deepening and broadening core collaborations with EdelGive from an impact and funding point of view such as their existing coalitions; Collaborators for Transforming Education (CTE), Coalition for Women Empowerment (CWE), Migrants Resilience Collaborative (MRC), etc, which will help, create more visibility and credibility of the organisation. 2. Identifying and deepening support to more small to mid-sized organisations doing stellar work in India and creating a diverse portfolio to enable a larger ecosystem building. 3. Strengthening existing and building new partnerships with key international and domestic funders who are looking to invest in credible organisations in India.

Core Support  Yes:_/No:_ No4b (ii)?. Project involves Contact with Children  Yes:_/No:_Yes4c. Grant period:Start date:(dd/mon/yy)End date:4d. Currency: INR4e. Total Project Cost:78660869 4f. Summarise the projects ultimate goal(s) (maximum 200 words):( NOT REQUIRED FOR CORE SUPPORT GRANTS)The projects ultimate goal is the realization of sexual and reproductive health and rights of poor, young and vulnerable people, especially women, girls and key populations, in a gender-just world, free from stigma or discrimination. In an endeavour towards this goal, FPA India proposes a four-year intervention for the disempowered populations in selected high-need areas of West Bengal to expand access to sexual and reproductive health and empower individuals and communities to exercise their sexual and reproductive rights towards gender equality, economic empowerment and poverty alleviation.Barriers to realizing sexual and reproductive health and rights are rooted in unequal gender power relations, stigma and entrenched social norms, with ripple effects at individual, household, community and policy levels. To achieve a sustainable, transformational change, a four-pronged, overlapping approach will be adopted  Increasing the demand and supply of comprehensive SRH information and services, fostering partnerships to promote SRHR, imparting life-skills training and alternative livelihood opportunities to the young and vulnerable populations with limited means.All actions will contribute to the overall SDG goals of ensuring healthy lives and promoting the well-being for all at all ages SDG3) and achieving gender equality and empowerment of all women and girls (SDG5).
GAF_Family_Planning_Association_of_India.4. GEOGRAPHY: 5.List the major countries where your activities take place. If this is global policy work, list as worldwide:India  (South Asia)
GAF_Family_Planning_Association_of_India.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 6. Context (The context section should not exceed two pages.)6a. Describe the organisation (include information on leadership, governance, structure and staff) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):FPA India is a voluntary organization that works on a wide range of SRH issues encompassing family planning, comprehensive sexuality education, maternal health, child survival, adolescent care, HIV/AIDS, safe abortion, reproductive tract cancer screening and prevention and mitigation of gender-based violence (GBV).Key strategies include ensuring access to high quality SRH information and services; capacity building of health care providers and community volunteers on SRHR issues; engaging with communities and individuals to change gender disparity and promote SRHR; and advocacy for policy change at the national and state level. Through its various programmes, FPA India reaches a population of Grant Application Form, July 1 20135more than 30 million annually, on an average, supported by more than 3000 community based volunteers and more than 1000 staff.FPA India is an accredited Member Association of the International Planned Parenthood Federation (IPPF) which has 152 member countries working in 172 countries, across the globe With its HQs in Mumbai and 44 Branches/Projects across 18 states of the country Family Planning Association of India (FPA India) follows a functional organizational structure.The Governing Board at the apex comprises of a group of Volunteers following a democratic process of elections which involves the two governing board representatives of the Branches. The representatives are a part of the Branch Executive Committee and are elected through Branch Level elections. The Governing Board oversees the Management functions both at the Centre and at the Branches. The board reviews the annual performance of the Association in relation to its strategic goals, Associations Annual budget and approve it, oversee the implementation of policies adopted by All India Council etc. All Branches and the HQ adhere to the governing and management requirements as laid down by the Constitution for the Association.The governing board, known as the Central Executive Committee serves for a three-year term following which a new governing board is elected to the office by representatives of the All India Council of FPA India. The present CEC has been recently elected in February 2021. Women constitute 50% and youth constitute 20% of the governing board membership.6b. Describe the financial situation (include information on annual operating costs, fundraising strategy, reserves and debts) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):Operating cost  for Year 2021Personnel cost  USD 33,05,198, Program  USD 10,24,633, Admin  USD 15,11,423Operational cost for year 2021 : -  USD 10,24,633/-Local & foreign fund  ratio -  61 : 39% of the FCRA money will be spent on admin  - 29%Fundraising strategy :List of funding source for Year 2021: -IPPF Core Grant - USD 13,17,568Restricted Income  USD  9,85,435Other Sources  USD 33,11,810Local income from Service Delivery  USD 93,677Bank interest  USD 1,32,764Current level of reserves:  In our organization we do not have Reserve Fund Grant Application Form, July 1 20136investment.  However we are allowed to keep 10% of Core grants received from IPPF  as working capital i.e. for year 2020 it is USD 131757.Current Level of debt: N.A.Recent history:  N.A.IPPF core funds constitute about 25% of the total income of the Association. Nearly 85% of this fund supports priorities under outcome 4 viz governance, man, accountability, efficiency functions. Another 5-7% of the fund is earmarked for resource mobilization and the remaining 10% supports programmes. Programme costs within this fund are distributed towards activities under the first three outcomes, with a provision for contingency expenses towards contraceptive stock-outs or humanitarian crises.To ensure a steady in-flow of resources, Association will continue to invest in strengthening the building blocks, viz: capacity building of staff, continuous scoping of the donor environment, increasing visibility and leveraging the credibility as an expert in the field of SRHR advocacy and specialized clinical service delivery,  staying contemporary and adaptable to change and thus maintaining relevance, nurturing relationships and building new ones to ensure a long bid pipeline and a steady funding stream. With increased competition for limited grant resources in sexual and reproductive health, the focus would be on tapping into multiple funding streams to attract, create and sustain new resources, with an emphasis on innovative approaches, corporate involvement and non-conventional methods.Expected significant changes to the financial situation :Core grant reduced by 10% in year 2021 over the Year 2020.GCACI project grant reduced by 38% of the sanctioned budget in Year 2021GCACI project will be close in Dec 2021.The operational costs for 2021 have been worked out as per the reduced project grant.Impact of the changes in managing core costsWith reduction in the core grants, it is likely that HR costs, especially new recruitments under Core positions may be affected. As far as possible, these reductions are absorbed by the Hqs, under programme costs and HR costs are protected.6c. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):Family Planning Association of India was established in 1949 to successfully advocate for the inclusion of family planning in the First Five Year Plan of the newly independent India.  The International Planned Parenthood Federation (IPPF) was founded in 1952 in Mumbai with FPA India as its Founder Member.FPA India has grown since, with each decade marked by pioneering work to advance sexual and reproductive health and rights of all, including men, women, young people, key populations, underserved, marginalized poor and vulnerable groups.Grant Application Form, July 1 20137FPA India was represented in the Shantilal Shah Committee which was instrumental in providing a framework for the legalization of abortions in India in 1964 that led to the formation of the MTP Act 1971. Recently, the MTP Act has been amended and FPA India has been invited by the MoHFW to be a part of the committee to formulate the rules and regulations needed to implement the amended clauses.Other major projects and successesoFounder member of a large national coalition of civil society organizations, Advocating Reproductive Choices (ARC) and held the secretariat of ARC for more than 6 years (2008-2014).oMember of the Technical Advisory Group of the Pratigya Campaign on Safe Abortion in India.oServed as Regional Resource Centre, entrusted by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW) to support the implementation of the RCH programme through Mother/Field and Service NGOs to mother NGOs, field NGOs and Service NGOs in a few states of India ,oFPA India runs 19 Urban Family Welfare Centres to provide family planning and maternal and child health services funded by the State Government in Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh and Haryana.6d. Describe the current strategy of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):FPA India is currently implementing a 7 year Strategic Plan (2016-2022) focused on Strengthening Sexual and Reproductive Health (SRH) Services, Advocacy, Gender, Empowerment, and Young People, and Organizational Efficiency. The Strategic Plan envisions all people empowered to enjoy their sexual and reproductive health choices and rights in an India free from stigma and discrimination.Mission - A voluntary commitment to SRHR to advocate for and enable gender equality for all including the poor and vulnerable people, ensure information education and services powered by knowledge, innovation, and technology towards sustainable development.FPA India has deployed different models of programming to expand and deepen the service delivery network, deliver and enable comprehensive sexuality education to adolescents, implement inclusive and targeted interventions for the SRHR of key populations, address gender disparities and gender-based violence.Some of the recommended actions proposed during the mid-term review of the strategic plan conducted in 2019, that have a bearing on the expansion plans proposed  under this project:1. Enable representation of FPA India in committees formulating block level and district level action plans to contribute to the State PIPs, through as many Branches of FPA India as possible for creating a synergy between Youth, women empowerment, and health service delivery programme of FPA India and the corresponding programmes and schemes implemented by the government bodies in those blocks and districts (Such as the RKSK, the RMNCH+A, MHM, AEP) Grant Application Form, July 1 201382. Form consortia for identifying specific priorities (Such as Access/Agency/Entitlements), building consensus, and driving collective action3. Focus on economic empowerment of women through entrepreneurial skill-building4. Enable services through partner clinics Private and NGO facilities as well as government health facilities to expand outreachDrivers of the Strategic Plan relevant to this project-The unmet need for family planning and SRH services continues to be high. According to NFHS 4, the percentage of the Unmet Need for Family Planning (currently married women age 1549 years) is found to be 12.9%. Of 37% of contraceptive demand among adolescents (15-19 years) in India, only 15% have been met leading to 22% of unmet need (NFHS 4). The unmet need for spacing methods is much higher (26%) among adolescents in India compared to the unmet need for limiting (2.5%).[1]Inequalities-gender & poverty continue to impact health and empowerment outcomes; Stigma and discrimination of age, marital status, class, gender, caste, sexuality other markers pose major challenges to the implementation of SRHR.Availability of government schemes: a large number of schemes are currently being implemented by the government for young people, women, and vulnerable groups related to health, livelihood and rights. These pose as opportunities for a strong referral system and partnership building that can enable FPA India and its various associates including clients to avail the schemes thereby affecting long-term SRHR outcomes.Wide and varied provider base: There are a large number of registered, formal, and non-formal health care providers across the country. Opportunities exist in partnerships in integrating SRHR and in task shifting will ensure a wider pool of providers at all levels.  6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):The project attempts to address sexual and reproductive health and rights issues faced by individuals and communities due to gender, age, caste, and socioeconomic differentials.Our ongoing work in the operational areas of Kalchini and Kolkata has demonstrated an increasing demand for comprehensive abortion care, family planning, cervical cancer screening and management, maternal and child health services, gender-based violence screening and continuum of care for survivors, comprehensive sexuality education for adolescents and for some FGDs with key stakeholders conducted in 2017, regarding their perspectives on family planning. Additionally, there is a report of an intervention in the Buxaduar area of Kalchini that underscores the high need for SRH services for the high-need satellite clinic intervention in Kalchini and Kolkata that needs to be sustained.As per NFHS-4 data for India, the percentage of married women aged 15-49 years Grant Application Form, July 1 20139who use any modern contraceptive method stands at 47.8%. Of these, women in the age group of 20-24 who were married before the age of 18 stand at 26.8%. Also, women in the age group of 15-19 who were already mothers/pregnant before 18 years is significantly high in the state of West Bengal (16.4%).Data also shows that adolescents and youth have limited awareness about sexual and reproductive health matters. For instance, only 15% of young men and women (1524 years) reported receiving any family life or sex education.Home to nearly 18% of the worlds population, India also has the largest number of people living below the international poverty line of USD 1.90 a day. The socio-economic disparities in India increased further during the COVID-19 pandemic. Around 140,000,000 (14 crores) Indians lost employment during the lockdown. More than 45% of households across the nation reported an income drop as compared to the previous year.Situated near Indo-Bhutan International Border, most people from the operational area of Kalchini are dependent on Tea Gardens. These tea garden workers are deprived of their daily wages as per the government protocol. The health-seeking behaviour among the Tea Garden workers is also found to be very low due to the lack of easily accessible health facilities in the villages of remote and forest areas. The tea estates are located deep in the interiors with no Government or private health facilities available nearby. There is a lack of good means of transport and the roads leading up to the tea estates/gardens are in a bad condition. This makes it even more difficult for healthcare professionals to get there to render health services to the workers and families. An assessment of the needs of the tea garden community during an intervention led by FPA India in Darjeeling district showed a high need for SRH and general health services. The findings suggested a need for an integrated SRHR intervention for the health and well-being of tea garden workers and high demand from the community for continuation of the intervention, as they experience improved access to health care and an improvement in their health-seeking behaviour.The second wave of covid-19 has further exposed the potholes in the healthcare systems. Given the restrictions on movement during the lockdown, peoples ability to access health care services was severely impacted. Sexual and Reproductive healthcare services, including maternal and child healthcare, safe abortion services & Gender-based violence services were among the most severely impacted, with the lack of access to ante-natal care & GBV care leading to a rise in preventable deaths. A surge in gender-based violence cases particularly domestic violence showed the gendered nature of the pandemic and the need for sustained intervention. The COVID - 19 pandemic has given an opportunity to FPA India to expand the service coverage in Kalchni and Kolkata by engaging government and private players to utilize and explore the digital health solutions into practice & build infrastructure capacities to facilitate telemedicine & teleconsultation models to address the SRH needs of communities, without fragmenting the existing landscapes of service delivery of care. FPA India Kalchini Branch covers a population of more than 10 lakhs across Kalchini and Madarihaat blocks and Madarihaat municipality. Besides serving a large population of tea garden workers and their families, the branch reaches out to the most vulnerable and marginalized groups that include female sex workers at Grant Application Form, July 1 201310Jaigaon (Indo Bhutan Border) and Alipurduar, Persons Living with HIV AIDs (PLWHA) in Alipurduar. The Branch is also associated with 380 CBOs, SHGs and youth groups that can be mobilized for community-based interventions. In recent months, the Branch has also started conducting Rapid Antigen tests for COVID-19 for all clients with symptoms/history of exposure who visit the clinic for non-COVID essential SRH services. The local district authorities rely on the FPAI team in Kalchini to deliver last-mile contraceptive supplies and immunization services to needy populations in hilly terrains where there are no motorable roads or government health facilities. FPA India Kolkata Branch covers (Urban, peri-urban, rural and slum-based populations of more than 18 lakh, in Howrah, Hooghly, and North & South 24 Paraganas. The Branch has initiated interventions in the high need areas of Canning, Kultoli, Shason, Bhangor, Shamnagar, Icchapur, Champdani, Shreerampur, Watgunge, Tollygunge, Raidighi, Songachi, Sheoraphuli, reaching out to the most vulnerable communities including female Sex workers, transgenders, men having sex with men (MSMs), Injecting Drug Users, migrants and the elderly. A network of 47 Self Help Groups, 60 Youth Groups and 6 CBOs work closely with the Branch, to enable community-based interventions. Thus FPAI has been continually responsive to the community needs as well as the requests from health authorities to bridge the gaps in the SRH services, leading to an organic evolution of the programme from a family planning intervention in the early years to a more comprehensive SRH programme.With support from Oak, FPA India will be able to conduct capacity building and advocacy interventions to energize the public health system and build community networks of vulnerable groups for sustained demand generation. Thus, the intervention will bring about a transformational change in the community, from being beneficiaries of the programmes to stakeholders in the process of development. FPAI will also invest in partnerships such as with Ipas, to make inroads into newer geographies, for example, in the SundarbansFPAI will expand focused SRH work in the high need Sundarbans areas through the FPAI Kolkata branch, specifically in Kultali, Hingalganj, Canning, Gadkhali, Basanti and Gosaba in south 24 parganas. This will be a new operational area.

GAF_Family_Planning_Association_of_India.8. COOPERATION: 8. CooperationDescribe the level of cooperation with other organisations and networks and explain how this cooperation helps achieve your goals (maximum 300 words):FPA India recognizes the significance of collaboration among diverse stakeholders to bring about lasting social change.  Sustainability of health and empowerment interventions in particular, call for individual and community participation, fostered in an enabling environment.   FPA India works in close partnerships with central and state governments, NGOs, UN agencies, national and international funding agencies (such as European Commission, AusAID, Government of Netherlands, DFID), and corporates to create social impact.FPA India coordinates at every level to ensure connectivity from grassroots to the health system at the block, district, state, and the highest level of policy making at the national level Intersectoral convergence across agencies implementing education, sanitation, menstrual hygiene, women and child development, and livelihood initiatives to augment health and empowerment initiatives.The key actors involved to advance the SRHR outcomes by shaping the health interventions in Kalchini and Kolkata are the representatives of Tea Garden Authority, MPs & MLAs, D.M/SDO/BDO/Councillor from local government administration, opinion leaders and parliamentary representatives, O.C/I.C of local police station, members of PRI, CMOH/DY-CMOH-2 & 3 BMOH of local government health department, ASHAs, AWWs, ANMs, DNMs of government health service providers, local political leaders/trade union, SHGs, rural medical practitioner/informal health providers and chemists/druggists, local NGOs/CBOs, local youth volunteers, peer educators, community mobilizers/link workers, school principle, head teachers, tutors and media representatives. The project team will work towards forging convergence in the implementation of various programs and schemes by each of these stakeholders.
GAF_Family_Planning_Association_of_India.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. ImpactGrant Application Form, July 1 201318What is the change you want to achieve from the overall project? (maximum 300 words):FPA India proposes to work in coordination with all partners to consolidate interventions in existing geographies and to invest in a need-based expansion to additional geographies in North and South Bengal over a period of four years.The long-term outcome of this expansion plan is to contribute to a shift in the key indicators of health and empowerment for a larger cohort of vulnerable populations.The proposed interventions are expected to energize the existing health system. Sub-optimally functional tea garden hospitals in the expanded intervention area (Kumargram block in Alipuduar District) identified during the baseline will be revived through a public-private partnership to deliver quality assured family planning and SRH services. Increased allocation and utilization of available resources from the district PIPs for family planning will expand the trained provider base and equipped facilities for delivering FP and SRH services in intervention blocks.At the end of 4 years, the total population covered will increase by 50% from the baseline.Short-term outcomes, measurable across the project span will be the number of persons by type of vulnerability availing critical SRH services such as comprehensive abortion care, institution-based safe deliveries, cervical cancer detection and treatment, and continuum of care for surviving gender-based violence.Socio-behavioral change in the community will be measured by assessing the change in the proportion of men and boys accessing SRH services, including family planning and the proportion of youth groups actively involved in peer training and support to keep their neighborhoods safe from GBV.Process documentation to capture successes and challenges in the course of implementation will guide replication of the project interventions in other geographies and serve as a tool for advocacy and resource mobilization for evidence-based programming.10. EvaluationHow will progress be monitored and evaluated? (maximum 300 words):Monthly service statistics on the defined set of indicators are being collected from all service delivery points online DHIS2 (District Health Information System). Apart from this, programme activities-related information will be periodically collected through descriptive reports, case studies, and other documents. Through a monthly/quarterly tacking system, service statistics, and other processes, indicators are monitored at the grassroots level up to the HQ level. Client Exit Grant Application Form, July 1 201319interviews are conducted routinely with the purpose of improving the quality of services provided in a manner that is more acceptable to community members and clients. Regular monitoring visits, observations, clinic audits,s and self-assessment of QoC checklist will be carried out. This enables monitoring progress and makes evidence-based decisions for programme implementation. The performance of the project will be monitored systematically at all levels to review progress being made and to make necessary key decisions at the right time. At the branch level, the program is overseen by the Branch in In-charge. At the HQ level, programme team reviews the performance, and feedback is given to the Branch. Programmatic decisions will be taken both at the Branch/Project and HQ levels during monthly/quarterly review meetings. The best practices/lessons learned from the project will be disseminated through social media, meetings with stakeholders, workshops, seminars, national/international conferences, and other such forums as well as through the Associations publications.The baseline study will be conducted to capture current estimates of defined indicators upon which the project will strategically improve over the project cycle. Further, to track the performance This will enable us to improve the programme design based on the learnings. We envisage the important evidence generated through the intervention will be captured through an End-line evaluation study. This will feed into the documentation of learnings and successful strategies for extension, expansion, and replication. To understand the equity and inclusiveness of the interventions, FPAI will generate social-economic disaggregated informationCase studies on net impact from SRHR/livelihood/violence-prevention interventions will be shared  to establish direct evidence on the correlation.
GAF_Family_Planning_Association_of_India.11. ADDITIONAL QUESTIONS/ Future Plans: 11. Future PlansHow will the grant influence the organisation and future plans? (maximum 300 words):The current Strategic Plan of FPA India is applicable until the end of 2022. Preparations for the new framework will begin by next year. The proposed project will be initiated at the critical juncture when an end-line assessment of the current Grant Application Form, July 1 201320strategic plan will be conducted. Support from Oak Foundation will give a head-start to this assessment in West Bengal. Through advocacy initiatives implemented through the project, FPA India is likely to have a representation in important decision-making bodies appointed by the district and/or state government such as Medical Boards for authorizing medical termination of pregnancies for certain categories of women, beyond 24 weeks of gestation under the MTP Act (Amendment) 2021.A strong coalition of like-minded stakeholders formed in the course of the project will continue to work in partnership to protect the interests and rights of vulnerable groups, with equitable participation from community representatives. The service delivery network will be widened with an increase in the number of private medical practitioners and health facilities collaborating with FPAI to make SRH services accessible round-the-clock and even through remote access   A grant from Oak Foundation will help leverage other grants by demonstrating the value of shared resources for the strategic expansion of the programme to other districts and the replication of this model in other States.The project will be showcased during issue-based stakeholder consultations within the districts, the State, and at National and International events. Key milestones and event photos will be displayed on the official website of FPA India and through print and social media.In the course of 4 years, FPAI will develop a sustainable model of service delivery and capacity building through the Kalchini and Kolkata Branches, that will support the expansion of SRH interventions in high-need areas of West Bengal.

GAF_A_Environment_Conservation_Society_E.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT 5a. Tell us about your governance and leadership structures, as well as staff and volunteer base. Highlight any significant recent or expected future changes. If you have an explicit approach to increasing diversity and/or advancing race equity within the organisation, please tell us. (300 words):Our governance and leadership structures are designed for effective decision-making and strategic guidance. The ultimate authority lies with the Governing Oak Application Form     5Board, which is reconstituted every three years during the Annual General Meeting. Comprising 9 experienced individuals, the Governing Board plays a pivotal role not only in the core decision-making processes of the organization, but also in fundraising and networking. The board members meet on quarterly basis.At organizational level, the Managing Director assumes responsibility for providing overall guidance and support. Drawing upon their extensive experience and expertise, they steer the organization towards achieving its goals.We have a dedicated workforce of approximately 151 staff members, with 34% representation from women, across various departments. Our team of Field Staff, including Trainers, Operation Officers, and Project Coordinators, ensures the high-quality execution of projects on the ground. They receive support and guidance from Senior Operation Coordinators, who facilitate smooth implementation. Currently 10 regional project offices across 4 states are operational.Project Managers oversee the execution of projects and provide strategic guidance. They are mentored by Vertical Heads or Senior Project Managers, who contribute their expertise and leadership to empower the Energy-Water-Agriculture (EEWA) nexus and address environmental and climate change challenges.Additionally, we have a committed group of 50 volunteers, comprising adult students from educational institutions and members of cyclist groups. Their active participation strengthens our initiatives.Apart from this, various supporting departments are there to augment programmatic performances. They are -Program Monitoring Unit - Real time Monitoring through project based MIS.Research, Learning & Development Unit - Insights and findings from baseline studies, mid-term and impact assessments contribute to evidence-based decision making and program improvement.Human Resource Unit - Recruitment and Employee Grievance handlingAdministration Unit - Event management and office administrationFinance Unit - Maintenance of accounts and fundingIT Support Unit - System maintenance and Troubleshooting network issues  5b. Summarise the organisations history.  In addition, highlight 2-3 key achievements.Please keep this brief and list up to 3 key achievements as bullet points. Even though you may have many achievements, please share what is most relevant to the proposed grant. (300 words)The foundation of Environment Conservation Society (ECS) was laid in 2008 with a 1500 km long cycle ride across the coal belt of India to take the words Oak Application Form     6of climate change to the youth. The initial years of ECS were invested in spreading climate consciousness across educational institutions. Between 2010 and 2017, ECS spun off 3 social enterprises respectively to take decentralized energy solutions to the underserved, to address unsustainable agriculture through an alternative ecosystem around organic agriculture, and to incubate Green Entrepreneurs.ECSs current outreach is to over 5560 villages and urban agglomerations across nine states in India, ranging from Maharashtra in the west to Manipur in the east. One of the major projects in early days was on Capacity Building for Sustainable Access to Clean Energy in Eastern India. Since then, ECS has implemented 57 projects, with average duration of 18.75 months and average value of 7.8 million INR. This includes promotion of 60 FPOs within last few years. 50% of these FPOs are 15-26 months old, having average cumulative turnover of INR 19,64,786 and average annual turnover of INR 9,81,630 per FPO.Impact assessment of our program on Solar pump in Jharkhand revealed that 79% of Solar Pump beneficiaries enhanced their agricultural productions whereas 65% stopped using diesel pumps. In Chattisgarh, 65% beneficiaries enhanced their income through efficient irrigation systems.ECS received Pacesetter Award in 2016 by MNRE to encourage investment in off-grid clean energy development, and ICC Social Impact Award in 2020 in the area of Clean Energy. ECS is empanelled with MNRE for programs around energy access in rural India, empanelled and functioning as a training provider with PMKVY, Utkarsh Bangla-PBSSD, NISE etc. For affiliation of standard operating procedures, were associated with SCGJ (Skill Council for Green Jobs). 5c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and decide your approach? If you have undertaken a theory of change exercise, or if you are influenced by research, policy or your own organisations experience, please tell us about this.  Have you consulted with relevant stakeholders, including your communities and others experiencing the problem? Is there an intention to address equity, diversity and inclusion? (600 words):The key issues faced by the small tea growers of northern West Bengal include agro-technical problems (pest and insect attacks), lack of technical knowledge (early identification of plant diseases/pest attacks and their control measures), lack of irrigation facilities and associated dependency on fossil fuel to operate agri-machineries, lack of credit facilities. These reasons are leading to a higher cost of producing tea @INR 20 per Kg whereas the market is paying a price of INR 15-18 per kg, making it unsustainable. On the other hand, major challenges faced by tea garden workers in the region include low wages, poor working conditions, lack of land rights and housing, limited access to education and healthcare, seasonal unemployment, and exploitation and inequality. The proposed project aims to address these challenges and improve well-being of communities in 3 tea gardens and 2500 small tea growers across in Jalpaiguri, Kalimpong and Darjeeling districts in the following ways:Oak Application Form     7Limited access to clean cooking solutions: The project aims to promote the adoption of sustainable and clean energy sources and appliances to reduce the community's reliance on firewood. This will help conserve forests, protect wildlife habitats, mitigate climate change effects, and improve community's health. Inadequate lighting and electricity access: The project at one hand will focus on providing lighting in public spaces to enhance the security of women and children, and on the other hand will extend study hours, enable the utilization of smart devices, and enhance educational development for children in the community by ensuring energy access at household level. Lack of energy for clean water access: The project will implement renewable energy based solutions for clean water access towards reducing the prevalence of waterborne diseases, and improving overall health and well-being, and ensuring irrigation. Limited access to energy for livelihood activities: While in one hand the project willensure exposure, resource linkage and access to renewable energy based solutions to address agro-technical problems faced by the small tea growers, on the other hand it will promote diverse livelihood options beyond the tea industry focusing on the tea garden workers.Our approach to solve the aforementioned problems would involve a four-pronged strategy: conducting research for needs assessment, identification and sourcing of appropriate technologies, skill and capacity building around technology and process, and establishing an ecosystem that connects stakeholders across the value chain. We aim to empower these communities by promoting their self-reliance through access to financial resources, markets, and government schemes. Technology and innovation will drive sustainability, and a comprehensive research framework will inform evidence-based decision-making and policy.Oak's funding will be utilized through a comprehensive approach, including needs assessments in terms of energy requirement, market study/scoping study to identify appropriate technology solutions, study on potential of green jobs within and outside intervention area, capacity and skill development of community around tailored livelihood avenues and associated energy technologies, handholding support for community engagement across value chains through livelihood support centre, establishing resource linkages for renewable energy  driven infrastructure development, promoting community institution through technology and buyer expo for scale and market linkage, monitoring and evaluation, informing policy, and ensuring sustainability and replicability. It will also contribute to establishing partnerships, documenting best practices, and enable the replication of successful models.Identification of the problems and determination of our approach was based on consultation, research, and experience-based learning. We conducted situational analysis with tea-garden communities in Kalimpong (West Bengal), consulted institutions like local FPOs, Tea Board and The Oak Application Form     8Confederation of Indian Small Tea Growers Associations (Cista). Their insights and ground observations informed our understanding of the challenges faced by communities around tea industry as well as probable solutions.

GAF_A_Environment_Conservation_Society_E.8. COOPERATION: 8. COOPERATION  How will you involve others in your approach to achieving change? If you are planning to engage in partnerships with other organisations, communities, people with lived experience, academics or secure the support of key individuals, please tell us about this.  Why are these the right partners to engage with?  Is there anything new about how you are Oak Application Form     11choosing to work - for example, new partnerships or an approach that is different to how you usually work? (300 words):In order to achieve change, the project will involve following various stakeholders:a) Government Bodies: Partnering with government agencies like the West Bengal State Rural Livelihood Mission (WBSRLM), Tea Board of India, North Bengal Development Department, and Department of Power will ensure policy support, regulatory compliance, and potential funding opportunities. For example, collaborating with the Public Health Engineering Department can address water-related challenges.b) Financial Institutions: Collaborating with banks/microfinance institutions/impact investment firms can unlock financial resources for capital investment, support community-led enterprises, and provide access to finance for target communities.c) Tea Garden Management: Engaging and involving tea garden management will be crucial for the project's success. Their participation can facilitate access to resources, infrastructure, and support the implementation of sustainable practices within the tea gardens.d) Small tea growers association: Engagement with Small Tea Growers Association would bring together opportunities of collective effort, shared resources, and networking with influential person/agencies.d) CBOs/NGOs/FPOs: Collaborating with like-minded NGOs and community-based organizations (CBOs) that have expertise in addressing similar challenges faced by target communities will enhance project implementation and maximize its impact. These organizations can provide on-ground support, capacity building, and community engagement.e) Research Institutions: Partnering with research institutions can strengthen the project's evidence base, support field-based research, and provide technical expertise in developing context-specific solutions. Their involvement can enhance the project's credibility and ensure the adoption of evidence-based practices.These partners are chosen based on their expertise, resources, and influence in the relevant sectors. Their involvement brings diverse perspectives, knowledge, and support to address the complex challenges. The project's approach includes establishing new partnerships and leveraging existing networks. By working together with these organizations, the project can tap into their resources, technical expertise, and networks, ultimately leading to more effective and sustainable outcomes.

RISKS AND CHALLENGESOak Application Form     13What are the risks or barriers that might prevent you from achieving your outcomes and how will you address these?
