(300 words):Anticipated risks and challenges:1. Resistance to Change: Implementing changes and introducing new technologies and practices may face resistance from the communities, tea garden management, and other stakeholders. This resistance can stem from lack of awareness, or fear of disruption. To address this, we will prioritize community engagement and awareness-building efforts through conducting extensive consultations, workshops, and awareness campaigns to foster understanding, ownership, and acceptance of new technologies.2. Technological Suitability: Inadequate or ill-suited technologies may not deliver the desired impact or may pose operational challenges. To mitigate this risk, we will conduct thorough market studies and scoping assessments to identify appropriate technology solutions. We will involve the target communities in the selection process to ensure their suitability, affordability, and long-term sustainability.3. Policy and Regulatory Constraints: Inadequate policies, regulations, or lack of support from government agencies can hinder the project's implementation and scalability. We will actively engage with relevant government bodies, tea garden management, and policymakers to inform supportive policies and regulatory frameworks. Through project's impact and success, we aim to inform policy for seamless resource utilisation & market linkages.4. Access to finance- Lack of access to finances (through schemes & capital) is a major barrier for communities to install DRE technologies.Opportunities:1. Community Empowerment: The project provides an opportunity to empower communities by enhancing their access to energy, improving their livelihoods, and strengthening their capacity to sustainably manage resources.2. Innovation and Learning: Through tailored innovative financial, technology and incentive models, communitys access to technology will be enhanced. Creating an interface between external stakeholder and beneficiaries, facilitating sustained utilization of DRE technologies will lead to learning of successful models/practices.3. Partnership and Collaboration: Avenue for forging partnerships and collaborations with diverse stakeholders, including government bodies, financial institutions, tea garden management, and NGOs can unlock synergies, resources, and expertise, amplifying the project's reach and impact.Oak Application Form     14
GAF_A_Environment_Conservation_Society_E.11. ADDITIONAL QUESTIONS/ Future Plans: 11.  ADDITIONAL QUESTIONSPlease use this space to respond to any specific questions from your Oak programme officer. If none were received, please leave this section blank. Part A:1. Please summarise a few projects which are similar in nature. Provide details on project objectives, interventions, community reach, geography and the impact (specific metrics related to adoption of renewable energy, improvement in yield, returns, household level income).Project Name: Powering Agriculture-Community Based Solar Pump (Indo-U.S Pacesetter Fund)Geography: West Bengal, Jharkhand, and OdishaDuration: 2016-19Project Objectives:Unlocking financing for marginal farmers to install solar pumpsTest innovative business model interventions for solar pumps by setting up Guarantee FundRemoving barriers for clean energy adoption among low-income farming communities.Community Reach:Low income farming communitiesWomen Self-help group membersImpact:Farmers have witnessed a 1.6x rise in income through better productivity, water selling and crop diversification.On an average, each farmer has been able to save $50-$100 per month on irrigation.Decrease in at least 60 tonnes of CO2 emissions with every solar pump over the lifetime of the pump by replacing diesel pumps.Forex saving of USD 300 per annum per replaced diesel pump Project Name: Empowering Lives in East India (Good Energies)Geography: Purba Bardhaman district of West BengalDuration: 2018-20Project Objectives:Oak Application Form     15Integration of appropriate sustainable energy solutions in life and livelihood.To improve the productivity & profitability of farmersTo improve the environment and mitigate the harmful effects of climate changeCommunity Reach:Marginalized rural communitiesWomen-headed households and Women Self-Help Group membersFarmer Groups of communityImpact:Farmers of water group have witnessed a 1.66x rise in income through better productivity.An average farmer has been able to annex at least one additional crop in her/his agriculture profile.An average woman involved in agriculture has been able to save at least 3 extra hours per day.2.What has been the learning from prior projects of similar nature?Some key learnings include:1. The lack of an ecosystem for promotion of Distributed renewable energy solutions and the significance of awareness & capacity building of key stakeholders to address resource depletion and environmental challenges.2. The importance of engaging grassroots civil society organizations which leads to amplification of the impact and reach of initiatives.3. Adoption of the nexus approach between energy, water, and agriculture yields multidimensional benefits for both the environment and rural communities.4. Women as key stakeholders in natural resource management empowers them and leads to robust and sustainable outcomes.5. Building strategic partnerships with state nodal agencies, banks, and financial institutions leads to efficient project implementation and facilitates better access to financing & resources.6. Capacity building through training programs and knowledge dissemination strengthens the skills and expertise of stakeholders, particularly youth and rural women.7. Leveraging digital platforms, such as Learning Management Systems, creates active knowledge banks and expands the reach of educational resources to the communities at large..8. Promoting collective action and formalizing networks fosters collaboration and resource sharing among organizations working towards similar goals.Oak Application Form     169. Implementing climate-resilient agricultural practices and fostering innovations improves adaptation and resilience of disadvantaged communities in the face of climate change.Drawing from these learnings, ecosystem approach has been a by-default aspect of any project involving rural communities. Also, in our recent program regarding monitoring of groundwater and its recharge through watershed planning, rural women have been central players right from periodic groundwater monitoring. These successful approaches will guide the current project in achieving its objectives and maximizing its impact on just energy transition and sustainable resource management.3.If cap-ex for technology products is to be sourced from schemes, why is the budget component so high? There has to be a clear rationale on the budget.This is primarily due to the lack of an existing ecosystem that should encompass interlinkages between Technology, Scheme, Finance, Production Chain, and Market, which would be crucial for ensuring effective energy access and livelihood enhancement for the small tea growers and tea garden workers..To establish this essential ecosystem, it is necessary to engage a group of professionals who possess the expertise and experience in bridging the gaps between various stakeholders. These professionals will play a vital role in identifying suitable technology solutions, coordinating with relevant schemes for capital expenditure, establishing financial mechanisms, facilitating production chain integration, and creating market linkages. Cost covered for training and capacity building is a little less than half of the proposed grant. Also, extensive research during the first 6 months of the project and demonstration of DRE applications during the first two years of the project will require significant program expenditure.We believe that investing in the establishment of this ecosystem is essential to overcome the existing barriers and challenges faced by the these communities. By doing so, we can create a solid foundation for future projects, streamline the implementation of renewable technologies, and effectively leverage available schemes for capital expenditure on technology products.The estimated budget for the proposed project is USD 160 per beneficiary family. Out of this USD 107 per family is being sought from OAK Foundation. Out of this, an estimated cost for the whole package of training would be USD 42 per family during the tenure of the project. The cost for all 6 researches would be USD 6 per family. Developing ecosystem (Stakeholder meeting, buyer-seller meet, producer expo) would cost USD 11 per family. Maintaining MIS throughout the project period would cost USD 4 per family. A team of 9 full-time staffs (Capacity Building Manager, Communication Manager, Livelihood Expert, Energy Expert and 5 Tea-Garden Coordinators) would be involved right from inception till the completion of the project for handholding support to community throughout the journey. Individuals in this team will be paid a monthly average salary of USD 455 (Range of USD 377-566). Total cost to this team would be  USD 39 per family throughout the project period.4.What are the possibilities of enhancing the committed co-financing from the present USD 50,000?Oak Application Form     17Currently, we have secured a core grant of USD 50,000 from MacArthur Foundation. These commitments have been instrumental in enabling us to initiate the project and lay the foundation for its success.After careful consideration and exploring potential avenues, we have identified the possibility of enhancing the committed co-financing up to a maximum of USD 84,000.5.The solar cookstoves model has not been so successful till date. What are the strategies to be adopted towards mitigating this risk. What learnings can you factor in from other models implemented elsewhere. Please undertake a secondary research on the same.In Guatemala, the Solar Household Energy project effectively increased the adoption of solar cookstoves by providing tailored training, addressing cultural preferences, and ensuring affordability (Source: https://www.she-inc.org/). Similarly, in India, the Solar Cooking Project successfully promoted solar cookstoves by involving local communities in the design and promotion process, emphasizing health and environmental benefits, and facilitating access to finance (Source: https://www.solarcookers.org/work). For instance, Barli Institute has been successfully experimenting with solar cookers for over 22 years in Madhya Pradesh.  Since 1998 the Institute has developed its kitchen tailored to solar cooking, and has installed 3 large Scheffler parabolic cookers in this kitchen. It has an ongoing program on solar cooking and food processing where the institute prepares all its meals for 130 persons per day with solar cookers (for about 300 solar days a year), saving up to 12 cylinders of cooking gas (equivalent to about 900 kilograms of wood) each month. This program helps women to escape the daily, back-breaking work of fuel gathering, and preserve forest and woodlands and reduce air pollution. The institute provides training in maintenance of SK-14 & Prince-15 parabolic domestic solar cookers. The ex-trainees also introduce and demonstrate the benefits of solar cooking to their neighboring communities.(https://www.barli.org/english-brochure.html)Applied Science and Engineering was founded by Dr. Srinivasa Ravuri from Secunderabad in Telangana. Srinivasa created this organization to pursue research, design, and promotion of solar-thermal implements that can be used for cooking, heating, food drying, and for water desalination. The organization has been involved with solar cooking since 2008. By 2016 they had distributed 50 solar cookers and had taught over 200 people to solar cook with solar box cookers, parabolic cookers, and solar food dryers.(https://solarcooking.fandom.com/wiki/Applied_Science_and_Engineering)We dont have a mandated agenda to promote Solar Cooker in the intervention area. The approach would be to first test the technical feasibility of Solar Cooker in the region. Upon successful trial, we can set up pilot projects and demonstration centers in collaboration with local partners and organizations. This can include community meetings, demonstrations, and interactive sessions to address any misconceptions or skepticism. These initiatives can showcase the effectiveness of solar cookers, allowing community members to see the benefits firsthand and gain confidence in the technology. Our recent fact finding visit in Kalimpong shows that more and more households in the tea-garden communities are getting LPG gas connection and reducing dependence on firewood. However, considering the costs involved in LPG gas Oak Application Form     18connection, sharing the burden with Solar cook-stove in a hybrid mode would surely prove to be a cost-cutting model.6.There should be a clear market study/scoping study on available technological equipment (supply chain, maintenance, costs) and a study of the green jobs and entrepreneurship potential in the region. This should inform the training interventions for the youth and identify the sectors, businesses (locally and regionally) for placement of these youth. What are the types of entrepreneurship avenues possible related to renewables in the region?The market and scoping study will comprehensively analyze the existing technological equipment relevant to renewable energy solutions, including their supply chain, maintenance requirements, and costs. Additionally, the study will assess the green jobs and entrepreneurship potential in the region, identifying sectors and businesses suitable for youth placement. It will also explore various entrepreneurship avenues related to renewables. The study will gather data through surveys, interviews, and field visits, assessing market demand, local needs, and potential for sustainable businesses. Findings will inform targeted training interventions for youth and guide the development of a robust ecosystem for renewable energy adoption and entrepreneurship in the region. A few important aspects to be covered are as follows -Technology Assessment: The study will assess the availability, suitability, and cost-effectiveness of renewable energy technologies in the market. This includes solar cook stoves, solar pumps, and other DRE appliances.Green Jobs and Entrepreneurship Potential: It will identify potential sectors with growth opportunities for green jobs and entrepreneurship, considering the region's ecological and socio-economic context.Training Needs Analysis: The study will analyze the skill gaps and training requirements for youth to actively engage in the renewable energy sector and green job opportunities.Local and Regional Business Identification: It will identify and assess local and regional businesses that align with renewable energy solutions and green practices, offering placement opportunities for trained youth.Policy and Regulatory Analysis: The study will analyze existing policies and regulations related to renewable energy and identify opportunities and challenges for entrepreneurship.The study's outcomes will be instrumental in guiding the project's interventions and ensuring that youth are equipped with the necessary skills and knowledge to thrive in the growing renewable energy market while fostering entrepreneurship and sustainable practices in the region.7.SwitchON should consider narrowing down of the programme just focusing on meeting the energy needs (electricity, water, cooking fuel, lighting). The strategy for broadening the set of interventions should be well thought of and selective (youth training and employment, entrepreneurship, alternative livelihoods).While we understand the importance of selectivity and a well-thought-out strategy, we also recognize the need for a comprehensive approach to address the multifaceted challenges faced by the small tea growers and tea garden workers. By providing a basket of decentralized renewable energy (DRE) Oak Application Form     19solutions, there is opportunity to address the immediate energy needs of the target community while also promoting alternative livelihood opportunities. Based on the terrain of tea-garden and availability of land, a few environmentally compatible value chain options could be Eco-tourism and Hospitality (homestays, cultural experiences), Small scale organic farming (Spices, Herbs etc.), Beekeeping and Honey Production, Dairy and Livestock Farming, Making of Sal-Leaf plates, Mushroom Cultivation, Horticulture (fruit-bearing trees, mushroom, medicinal plants, herbal plants). However, choosing the combination of suitable livelihood would depend on a number of factors including availability of spare land, access to forest, marketability etc. We acknowledge the importance of thoughtful selection and prioritization of interventions based on local context, market demand, and community needs. Our team will conduct thorough assessments and engage in dialogue with the communities in 3 tea gardens and small tea growers across in Jalpaiguri, Kalimpong and Darjeeling districts to identify the most relevant and impactful interventions. While the central focus would be to help 2500 small tea growers and tea garden workers (3 tea gardens) meet the energy needs, the resources will also be invested in making the community aware of the scopes and possibilities around alternate sustainable livelihood option in an ecosystem approach to enhance their resilience to future challenges. Also among targeted 5000 families (including both tea garden workers and small tea growers), there would always be a few risk-takers who would come forward to learn and adapt new livelihood avenues in small scale with assured market. Their success will be the living demonstrations to boost the courage of a few others to come forward.A recent feasibility study conducted in northeast India's tea estates, a major tea-growing region, found a significant opportunity for adopting renewable energy systems. The study surveyed eight tea gardens (four from Assam and four from West Bengal) and seven tea processing industries. It revealed that tea gardens believe that installing large solar panels would not affect tea plant growth. Solar energy was preferred over other alternatives due to lower costs and easier installation. Most tea gardens (87.5%) have unused or barren land suitable for solar panel installation, while a few (12.5%) do not.(https://krishi.icar.gov.in/jspui/bitstream/123456789/71187/1/FeasibilitystudyonrenewableenergysysteminteaCamelliasinensis.pdf)(https://india.mongabay.com/2022/02/assam-tea-gardens-experiment-with-solar-for-reliable-power-supply-and-cutting-costs-emissions/)8.What about the geography? Kalimpong exclusively or layering on other tea gardens across the tea garden region.Environment Conservation Society has no pressing agenda of sticking to Kalimpong as project area. Strategically, it would rather be fruitful to extend this project to areas with prior presence of Oak Foundation and its partners. It is assumed that the prior rapport with communities in such area would ensure an initial thrust during the inception of the project. However, alongside Kalimpong, were targeting Jalpaiguri and Darjeeling to bring under the purview of the project. .9.Rationale behind initial 6 months of researchThe project shall be undertaking 4 initial researches within the first 6 months. They include Baseline Study on Program Indicators, Need Assessment on Oak Application Form     20Energy Requirements in Tea Garden, Scoping study on the potential of livelihood enhancement of small tea growers as well as diversified livelihood options for tea garden workers, and Market study to identify appropriate technology solutions. Each of these studies (except the last one) would involve survey with around 1000 Households. We are allotting 45 days (effective 37 working days) for each of these studies. This would involve finalizing research methodology, research tools, training of enumerators, data tabulation, data cleaning, data analysis, draft report, internal peer review and final report. We would insist that same group of researcher would be conducting all four researches to ensure interconnectivity in research findings and same standard in all four knowledge products. Thus, research would be conducted one after another and would require 6 months.10.What are the possible DRE technologies that can be adopted in this projectSolar Power Systems: Installation of solar panels for generating electricity and meeting energy needs in tea gardens and associated facilities.Biogas Systems: Implementation of biogas plants to convert organic waste from tea gardens and livestock farming into biogas for cooking and heating purposes.Improved Cookstoves: Introducing energy-efficient cookstoves to reduce fuel consumption and indoor air pollution.Solar Water Heaters: Deploying solar water heating systems to provide hot water for various needs, such as bathing and kitchen use.Solar Dryers: Utilizing solar energy to power drying systems for tea leaves, spices, and herbs, enhancing the efficiency and quality of the drying process.Solar Water Pumps: Installing solar-powered water pumps for drinking/small irrigation purposes, reducing reliance on grid electricity or diesel pumps.Solar Power Sprayers: This Is to support the existing agro-technical need of the small tea growers.Energy-Efficient Lighting: Promoting the use of energy-efficient LED lighting systems in tea garden households and community spaces.Part B: 1.Which are the financing schemes (central/state) that can be harnessed for this proposed project and what are the modalities for doing so? Since this is the tea garden community with the only identity of being labourers, their eligibility for these schemes should be considered carefully.Applicable for Small Tea Growers -Major Central Schemes/Agencies - Pradhan Mantri Mudra Yojana (PMMY), Swarnajayanti Gram Swarojgar Yojana (SGSY), Tea Development & Promotion Scheme, Tea Board of India.Major State Schemes/Agencies - Financial Support Scheme for Farm Mechanization (FSSM), Pradhan Mantri Krishi Sinchay Yojna (PMKSY), MIssion For Integrated Development of Horticulture (MIDH), West Bengal State Rural Livelihoods Mission (WBSRLM)-Anandadhara, Bangla Swanirbhar Karmasansthan Prakalpa (BSKP), West Bengal Swanirbhar Sahayak Prakalpa, Karmo Bhumi Prakalpa, Yuvashree Arpan SchemeOak Application Form     21Applicable for Tea Garden Workers -Major Central Schemes/Agencies - Pradhan Mantri Mudra Yojana (PMMY), Swarnajayanti Gram Swarojgar Yojana (SGSY), Tea Development & Promotion SchemeMajor State Schemes/Agencies - West Bengal Swanirbhar Sahayak Prakalpa, Karmo Bhumi Prakalpa, Yuvashree Arpan Scheme, Chaai Sundari Scheme. Samajik Surakshya Yojana To harness the mentioned financial schemes, the modalities can include identifying eligible beneficiaries, conducting training programs, facilitating loan applications, collaborating with relevant government departments, and providing guidance on accessing the benefits.2.How the proposed programme can be positioned for generating traction with the administration and philanthropic sector as a pathway for improved living conditions, economic opportunities and climate adaptation? What are the opportunities?The proposed programme can be positioned as a comprehensive solution with following opportunities -Highlighting the alignment of the programme with government priorities and policies related to poverty alleviation, rural development, and climate change mitigation. A few such policies are mentioned below-1.Policy Framework for developing and promoting Decentralized Renewable Energy (DRE) Livelihood Applications in Rural Areas2.Policy on Co-generation and Generation of Electricity from Renewable Sources of Energy.3.State Climate Change Action Plan (SCCAP)4.West Bengal Startup PolicyDemonstrating the potential for positive socio-economic impacts through case studies, success stories, and data on livelihood improvements, income generation, and greenhouse gas emissions reduction.Engaging with relevant government departments, local authorities, and philanthropic organizations through presentations, workshops, and stakeholder consultations to build partnerships and garner support.Showcasing the programme's potential for scalability and replication, emphasizing the long-term benefits and sustainability of the proposed interventions.3.Secondary information on the green jobs sector in West Bengal and elsewhere in India? Are there any strategic tie-ups with companies which produce these clean energy solutions for placement of youth?The renewable energy sector in India has witnessed significant growth, driven by government policies and initiatives like the National Solar Mission. Solar power has emerged as a major contributor to green job creation, with opportunities in solar panel manufacturing, installation, and maintenance. Also, National Clean Air Programme (NCAP) is being implemented in seven non-attainment cities in West Bengal. NCAP 2.0 is likely to create between 20,000 and 40,000 green jobs in West Bengal alone, opined experts at the India Clean Air Summit 2022 (ICAS 2022). As per a senior professor of IIT Kanpur, Oak Application Form     22an estimated 1 million green jobs are available within the air quality domain alone across India. Overall, India has the potential to create 35 million green jobs by the year 2047 in renewable energy, waste management, electric vehicles, green construction, and sustainable textiles in urban and peri-urban areas, according to a study launched by Skill Council for Green Jobs and Sattva Consulting and supported by J.P. Morgan(https://www.millenniumpost.in/kolkata/bengal-to-create-20k-to-40k-green-jobs-in-next-few-years-490996?infinitescroll=1)(http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/articleshow/100318337.cms?from=mdr&utm_source=contentofinterest&utm_medium=text&utm_campaign=cppst)On the other hand, The central government's focus on electric mobility has led to the emergence of green jobs in electric vehicle manufacturing, charging infrastructure development, and battery technology. Government initiatives like the Skill India Mission and the Ministry of New and Renewable Energy's skill development programs aim to bridge the skill gap and create a pool of trained professionals for the green sector. Additionally, programs like the Green Skill Development Programme (GSDP) provide training and certification in specific green job roles. According to available data, entry-level technicians in renewable energy sectors can earn an average salary ranging from INR 15,000 to INR 30,000 per month. With experience and specialization, the salary range can increase. The government's commitment to renewable energy and sustainable development, coupled with global efforts to combat climate change, will continue to drive demand for skilled workers in green industries. Mission LiFE (Lifestyle for Environment) is an indicator towards the same.Indias solar and wind energy sectors employed 1,64,000 workers as of FY22, showing a 47% increase from FY21. 84% of this workforce is in the solar energy sector.. Solar energy alone accounted for the largest share of green jobs in India, employing over 120,000 people in various roles such as manufacturing, installation, and maintenance. By 2030, it is projected that the EV sector in India will create around 10 million jobs across the value chain, including manufacturing, assembly, battery production, and charging infrastructure.As per a very recent Business Standard article this month, a study conducted by NLB Services claim that demand for green jobs in India is projected to grow at a rate of 15-20% annually over the next decade. This growth trajectory suggests that India has the potential to create 30-32 million green jobs by 2050. The increasing demand for green jobs is primarily motivated by India's ambitious goal of achieving net-zero emissions by 2070. (Source: https://www.business-standard.com/industry/news/demand-for-green-jobs-to-rise-15-20-every-year-in-next-decade-report-123060100451_1.html)ON Skills, a social venture spun off from Environment Conservation Society, has obtained empanelments with esteemed entities such as the Skill Council for Green Jobs, Agriculture Skill Council of India, National Institute of Solar Energy, and DDUGKY. The sectors where students have been trained are Retail, IT-ITES, Hospitality & Tourism sector, Solar PV Installer(Suryamitra) and Solar pump technician(Varun Mitra). Furthermore, ON Skills has established tie-ups with 12 companies (50% of them are  direct manufacturers of Clean Energy Solutions and rest 50% are placement companies associated with such manufacturers).4.What are the proposed indicators to assess the outcomes?Oak Application Form     23Qualitative IndicatorsEnhanced awareness of communities on knowledge related to renewable energy-based technology solutions and related utilities w.r.t. existing livelihood and living conditions (health, education, water, safety, and security)Augmented participation of communities for diversification plan for livelihood enhancement.Community institutions representatives have enhanced interaction with external stakeholders to facilitate resource (schemes, finance, and technology) linkage.Youths become more aware about and involved in suitable green job avenue, associated potential income, and their suitability for association.Quantitative IndicatorsGreater participation of women in adopting renewable energy based technology solution aided livelihood value chain through participation.Increased number of linkages with market traders established by strengthening community institutions.Enhanced uptake of renewable energy based technology solution to improve the living conditions and strengthen at least one livelihood value chain.Informed policy/implementation guidelines adapted by stakeholders at local, state and national level to facilitate seamless resource (schemes, finance, and technology) and market linkages for tea garden communities.

GAF_A_British_Asian_Trust_PromoSafeMigra.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT 5a. Tell us about your governance and leadership structures, as well as staff and volunteer base. Highlight any significant recent or expected future changes. If you have an explicit approach to increasing diversity and/or advancing race equity within the organisation, please tell us. (300 words):Oak Application Form     5BAT is governed and overseen by our Board of Trustees, sub-committees and Advisory Councils, with day-to-day management delegated to our Senior Management Team. The Board, which meets every two months, is led by the Chair and is made up of seven members with extensive experience from business, finance, civil society, international development, communications and government.  The Board sub-committees provide greater oversight and guidance in specific areas: the Programmes and Partnerships Committee (focused on BATs programmes); the Finance & Risk Committee; the Social Finance Committee; and the Governance, Nominations and Remuneration Committee. Each committee includes Board Members with key areas of expertise, as well as external experts.We have 50 full-time or full-time equivalent paid employees, based in the United Kingdom, India, Pakistan and Bangladesh. BAT is committed to encouraging an equal, diverse, and inclusive working environment where all individuals are treated fairly, with dignity and respect. We have an Equity, Diversity and Inclusion (EDI) policy, which guides our approach. Practically this means that BAT:    Seeks diversity of knowledge, background and experience in recruiting employees;      Values flexible working patterns;     Promotes a culture where all individuals are treated with respect and dignity and are offered equal opportunities;      Educates itself about EDI best practices     Reviews and monitors diversity as part of our aim of discouraging any discriminatory behaviour or practices. BAT has a robust set of policies which cover the following areas: Whistleblowing, bullying and harassment, code of conduct and safeguarding. We have an EDI Group with representation from our country offices which looks at how EDI is integrated into our work and policies.  In India, the team has registered significant growth over the past year and this trend will continue as we further develop our in-country Child Protection, Social Finance and Conservation portfolios. Additionally, the British Asian India Foundation, instituted in 2017 and registered as a Section 8 Company, has been set up with the aim to drive and further scale BATs impact in India. BAIF has an independent Board chaired by S Ramadorai.  5b. Summarise the organisations history.  In addition, highlight 2-3 key achievements.Please keep this brief and list up to 3 key achievements as bullet points. Even though you may have many achievements, please share what is most relevant to the proposed grant. (300 words)Oak Application Form     6Since BATs inception, we have pioneered a disruptive and non-traditional approach to development. Inspired by our sector leading social finance initiatives, all our programmes are focused on and driven by outcomes, which ensures that we deliver results at pace for the most underserved communities across South Asia. Through our child protection programme in India, BAT has successfully brought together the public, private and voluntary sectors to trial community-led, sustainable solutions, which have supported 486,000 vulnerable children and young women in 2021-2022. Some of our key achievements in this area include:BAT was one of the key partners at the heart of the Child Labour Free Jaipur coalition to address the prevalence of child labour. As result of our efforts, there was greater enforcement of child labour laws, which led to a 70% increase in the number of children rescued from child labour, and 15 convictions over four years  an unprecedented achievement, and a significant deterrent for traffickers.Our Prevention Model implemented in West Bengal has demonstrated impact in mitigating trafficking. We observed increased participation of young people and families - 4,000 young people in collectives, 1,091 active Community-based Institutions (CBIs); improved capacity among CBIs to support vulnerable children - 43% of child protection cases and 73% of at-risk cases of trafficking were resolved by CBIs; and improved living conditions through access to entitlements - 82% of beneficiaries people who applied for job cards saw an increase in monthly income.Through our work with the Jharkhand Anti-Trafficking Network, a coalition of 13 organisations, we have reached out to over 20,000 community members to promote safe migration and prevent trafficking.We have also recently launched a strategic partnership with the Childrens Investment Fund Foundation to develop an ambitious Child Protection Programme, which will leverage significant support to strengthen the child protection ecosystem in India and reduce exploitation of children by 30%.5c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and decide your approach? If you have undertaken a theory of change exercise, or if you are influenced by research, policy or your own organisations experience, please tell us about this.  Have you consulted with relevant stakeholders, including your communities and others experiencing the problem? Is there an intention to address equity, diversity and inclusion? (600 words):Evidence suggests that the tea garden districts of northern West Bengal are likely source and transit points along the migration and trafficking corridor. Alipurduar, Jalpaiguri and Darjeeling districts in particular, share porous borders with Nepal, Bhutan and Bangladesh, and with north-east India, making them likely hubs for trafficking and unsafe migration.There are nearly 250 tea gardens across the three districts employing over 2.2 lakh workers, around 10% of which have been declared sick or shut down. Tea garden workers have been systemically exploited, often denied the minimum Oak Application Form     7wage or entitlements such as provident fund and gratuity. Debt is offered in advance and offset against wages, trapping them in a vicious cycle. Child labour is rampant with many children being employed at 50% of the minimum wage for adults in peak season. Poverty, illiteracy, school dropouts, unemployment, under-employment, exploitation of workers (low wages, unpaid wages and benefits) are issues that are commonly seen. Poor implementation of social protection schemes further marginalises and disenfranchises them. As a result, the region witnesses high rates of out-migration, including that of young people to faraway destinations without the knowledge or support of their families, making them vulnerable to trafficking and exploitation. Between 1992 and 2015, over 2.5 lakh people migrated out of tea gardens.Within the state, 21.43% of the population is multi-dimensionally poor. The COVID-19 pandemic has further exacerbated the crisis, with many families deprioritising health, nutrition, and education. The Annual State of Education Report for West Bengal 2021 estimates that 3.5% of children aged 15 to 16 years have either dropped out of school or never been enrolled. The National Family Health Survey V also paints a sordid picture on the health and nutritional indicators for children, and points to a prevalence of early marriage and gender-based violence. From 2016-2020, 8,000 children were reported missing from the state every year, and children account for 75% of cases of victims trafficked and victims rescued in 2020. CHILDLINE data also points to a high number of trafficking cases  23% of cases in 2019-20 were reported from West Bengal. Due to the recent division of districts, child protection structures such as Child Welfare Committees, Anti-Human Trafficking Units, shelter homes etc. are inadequate. Grassroots structures such as Village-level Child Protection Committees are inactive as well. With tea gardens being privately managed and far from the district headquarters, it is also challenging for stakeholders to make inroads with the community for monitoring and vigilance. BAT in partnership with The Hummingbird Foundation has developed a Prevention of Trafficking Model that has demonstrated impact in mitigating trafficking in West Bengal. The premise is that collective action by key stakeholdersyoung people, parents, community-based institutions and local governmentleads to transformative community action and ultimately 'systems change to reduce the risk of trafficking. We believe that this model, with certain adaptations, can also serve to reduce the vulnerabilities that lead to unsafe migration.We seek to roll out an integrated programme in Jalpaiguri, Alipurduar and Darjeeling districts (selected after gathering secondary data and inputs from organisations, researchers and government stakeholders working in the region), that draws together children (6 to 18 years), young people (18 to 24 years), families, community-based institutions such as Self Help Groups, children and youth groups, School Management Communities, Tea Garden Associations, migrant workers and state actors; builds their capacity to take collective action; and bridges the gaps in convergence between stakeholders. We will engage with 3 lakh community members, including 1.2 lakh children across 8 blocks in 3 districts, and will leverage on their local knowledge and strengths to design interventions that are best suited to the local context. We will convene a safe migration and counter trafficking network of implementing partners and resource organisations who hold strong Oak Application Form     8community linkages and knowledge at different levels (panchayat, block and district), collaboratively working towards a common goal of mitigating trafficking and unsafe migration. Key interventions that are planned include community mobilisation; awareness generation; collectivisation and strengthening of grassroots child protection structures; empowerment of children and young people; facilitating linkages to entitlements; vocational training; and capacity building, engagement and advocacy with ecosystem stakeholders and government systems.  The recent notifications issued by the Ministry of Women and Child Development on the Mission Vatsalya Implementation Guidelines, and by the West Bengal Government on the Modified Guidelines for Child Protection Committees in West Bengal, also serve as proof that the conditions are favourable to work with grassroots structures. Additionally, one of the selected implementing partners, CINI, has been appointed by the West Bengal government as one of the nodal agencies responsible for implementing the modified guidelines.
GAF_A_British_Asian_Trust_PromoSafeMigra.7. OBJECTIVES: 7. OBJECTIVESThis is the most important part of your application, as it is your opportunity to explain what you want to achieve and what will be different because of your work. We understand that social and environmental change is complex and there are a multitude of factors that contribute to change. We want to understand how you define your role in the overall change you hope to make. You may find it helpful to discuss this with your Oak Programme Officer, and others in your own organisation.   7.a. ObjectivesList here up to 3 main objectives for this grant (one sentence per objective). Think of objectives as goals that can be achieved within the lifetime of the grant.  We encourage you to think of objective(s) that are ambitious but also achievable.  In the geographies that we are rolling out the programme, we will achieve the following Objectives:1. Reduce vulnerabilities that lead to trafficking and unsafe migration2. Reduce the prevalence of crimes against children (including child labor), and forced labor3. Reduce unsafe migration and violence against migrants(Targets for the Objectives above will be set once baselines have been undertaken in the fourth quarter of year 1)Oak Application Form     97.b. Expected Outcomes (bullet points):What do you expect will change because of this grant? What does success look like? List here the main outcomes you hope to achieve or make significant contributions towards with this grant, and for whom.  If you have concrete targets, please also list them here. Outcomes describe significant changes for people, communities, organisations or systems. Some examples are changes in policies and legislation; changes in knowledge, awareness, attitudes, beliefs, behaviours or social norms; changes in capacities, level of influence, agency or access to services. Please refer to the guidance for additional examples.In order to achieve the above objectives, the programme activities aim to drive the following changes at an individual, community and systems level:1. Increased awareness and strengthened capacity of community, community-based institutions (CBIs) and key stakeholders on mitigating human trafficking, unsafe migration, Gender-based Violence, and other forms of exploitation against children and young people2. Improved agency among children and young people to make informed decisions and challenge damaging social and cultural norms leading to personal and social change.3. Increased awareness among community members on safe migration practices4. Increased reporting of child protection concerns including child and forced labour and trafficking5. Increased retention of children in schools6. Improved access and linkages to social security, and increased livelihood security among vulnerable households7. Increased convergence and coordination between different stakeholders (Govt, CSOs and private organisations) towards the realisation of the rights of children and prevention of unsafe migration and trafficking.Overall, the programme aims to ensure children, their parents/families, and communities have the knowledge, resources and support structures to sustainably reduce their vulnerability to trafficking and unsafe migration. In addition, we aim to generate vital evidence and learning relating to the issue of child trafficking and unsafe migration in West Bengal, and strengthen the coordination between key actors around this issue, in order to sustainably scale up the intervention and impact across the state and other high prevalence states.(Targets for the outcomes above will be set once baselines have been undertaken in the fourth quarter of year 1)7.c. Activities and timeframe (bullet points):List in bullet points the main types of activities that you plan to to carry out to achieve your expected outcomes. Please keep these at a high level and and dont include the full list of Oak Application Form     10every activity you plan to carry out, instead, concentrate on the type of activities this grant will fund. If your Programme Officer wants more information, we will ask you separately for a work plan. Examples might include: (1) Research; (2) Provision of legal advice to...; (3) Training on movement building for...1. Baseline study, social mapping, stakeholder mapping to assess situation of and identify at-risk children and families, map available schemes and entitlements (Year 1  external agency)2. Research Study to study the causes, reasons, migration patterns and routes, networks and hotspots of trafficking and existing institutional mechanisms to combat existing systemic hurdles (Year 1 - external agency)3. Local area market study to identity opportunities for improving livelihoods security and vocational training (Year 1)4. Community mobilisation, formation of collectives among children and families, awareness generation on crimes against children and unsafe migration and their role in preventing the same (Year 1-4)5. Facilitating linkages to social security schemes and entitlements (Year 1-4)6. Activation and strengthening of Village-level Child Protection Committees and building convergence with government systems and child protection stakeholders at panchayat, block and district levels (Year 2-4)7. Capacity building of implementing partners, communities and stakeholders along the source-transit-destination corridor with a focus on mitigating crimes against children and unsafe migration (Year 2-4)8. Capacity building of children and young people on rights and laws, life skills, gender education (Year 1-4)9. Meetings with schools, School Management Committees and childrens collectives towards retention of vulnerable children and re-enrolment of out-of-school children (Year 1-4)10. Organising District level Task Force Meetings in coordination with district level committee on Anti-Trafficking (Year 1-4)11. Rescue, rehabilitation and repatriation of child and adult survivors of child and forced labour and trafficking, with support in navigating child protection and legal systems (Year 1-4)12. Engagement and advocacy with government departments, tea garden owners, trade unions/associations, community leaders, law enforcement, railway authorities and other key stakeholders to act promptly against trafficking and unsafe migration and for improved delivery of social security schemes (Year 2-4)13. Formation and strengthening of Tea Estate Child Rights Task Force (Year 2-3)14. Pre-departure counselling for potential migrants (Year 2-4)15. Orientation on entrepreneurship development, including skill/vocational training and support with market linkages to enable Oak Application Form     11access to access to additional or alternate livelihood options at source, and improve safe employability prospects at destination (Year 2-4)16. Engagement and advocacy with elected representatives to raise questions on the implementation of schemes and safe migration mechanisms in closed/sick tea gardens, and to include issues of tea garden workers in election manifestos (Year 1-4)
GAF_A_British_Asian_Trust_PromoSafeMigra.8. COOPERATION: 8. COOPERATION  How will you involve others in your approach to achieving change? If you are planning to engage in partnerships with other organisations, communities, people with lived experience, academics or secure the support of key individuals, please tell us about this.  Why are these the right partners to engage with?  Is there anything new about how you are choosing to work - for example, new partnerships or an approach that is different to how you usually work? (300 words):BAT will bring together a coalition of organisations comprising Child In Need Institute, Child Rights and You, FXB Suraksha and Nirmana, to build a collaborative model that will address vulnerabilities and gaps in service delivery at various points along the source-transit-destination corridor, with a common goal to prevent trafficking and other child rights violations and promote safe migration. The implementing partners have been selected based on their track record of working on issues on child protection and safe migration in the region, at different levels of governance (panchayat, block and district). Our selected partners have extensive expertise across a broad range of issues, including social protection, livelihoods and behaviour change, which will add value to the project. BAT will regularly convene our implementing partners and government stakeholders, to facilitate knowledge exchange and ensure that inputs from the grassroots are fed upwards to policy makers.BAT is committed to a bottom-up approach to all our programmes, to ensure that communities we serve have a voice in programme design. BATs partners will meet with communities on a regular basis, so that we can receive feedback and alter our approach as needed. We will establish a community-led safety net and build capacities of children and communities to empower them to take ownership of issues that affect them and hold state actors accountable, so that beneficiaries receive their entitlements.Given BATs partnership with the Childrens Investment Fund Foundation (CIFF), a grant from the Oak Foundation is likely to be matched 1:1 by CIFF. The matched funding will allow BAT to layer on complementary interventions that will add significant depth and scale to the activities supported by the Oak Foundation, thus achieving greater impact.
GAF_A_British_Asian_Trust_PromoSafeMigra.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING Oak Application Form     12This section is twofold. Please tell us:a) Monitoring and evaluation. How will you know if you are achieving your objectives? Please describe briefly how you will know if you are making progress and if what you are doing is working. If you have a formal monitoring and evaluation system and if you plan to collect indicator data or conduct an external evaluation, please provide details here.b) Learning. Please tell us if there anything in particular that you are hoping to learn more about or test through this grant.(300 words):Monitoring and Evaluation:The project will have a comprehensive Monitoring, Evaluation and Learning framework, in line with what BAT developed for the pilot of our Prevention of Trafficking model in West Bengal. We will layer outcomes and indicators related to safe migration onto this framework, so that change resulting from both the prevention and migration aspects of the project is adequately measured.BAT will work with an external evaluator to carry out the baseline and endline study. Targets and outcome indicators will be set post the baseline study and the endline study will be carried out in Year 4.Quarterly review meetings will be carried out with all partners to identify and troubleshoot any challenges faced during programme implementation. Progress of partners will be reviewed and plans for the next quarter will be drawn up during these meetings. Building on our current safeguarding policies and practice, we will ensure that all partners have appropriate policies and procedures in place to prevent and respond to any safeguarding concerns.We are also putting in place a Project Management Unit (PMU) in West Bengal which will be responsible for coordination with partners, monitoring for effective programme implementation and convening network meetings. The PMU will monitor the projects progress against outcomes, financial management, and cost-efficiency.Learning:BAT's PMU will have monthly and quarterly review sessions with Partner organisations. These review meetings also attempt to learn from the program's execution to identify what works and what doesn't, as well as the possibilities of scaling up this programme across the state of West Bengal.
GAF_A_British_Asian_Trust_PromoSafeMigra.10. RISKS AND CHALLENGES: 10.  RISKS AND CHALLENGESWhat are the risks or barriers that might prevent you from achieving your outcomes and how will you address these?  What are your opportunities?We understand that achieving long-lasting and meaningful change is hard and we expect that the work you want to do will mean taking risks.  We encourage you to be open to telling us these, as well as how you will address these risks.  If some of your outcomes are risky, are there any incremental achievements that you could identify? (300 words):Oak Application Form     13Risks:Changes in India's regulatory framework: Since Oak will be supporting British Asian Trust, which is registered in the UK, changes in India's regulatory environment will not have a bearing on our operations. We will also distribute monies to partners every six months to mitigate any impact from regulatory risk.Political environment: General elections are scheduled for 2024, and this may impact our work with government systems in the second year of the programme. Restrictions on gatherings during elections are also likely to have an impact on our work with groups and collectives. We will pivot our interventions based on the political context. Convergence between a consortium of groups with diverse ideologies: BAT will organise a series of strategy and network-building activities and workshops for partner organisations, which will allow them to work toward a common goal set collaboratively by everyone.Opposition from tea garden associations: BATs implementing partners have had previous experience of working with tea garden associations and will be able to facilitate meaningful dialogue and solicit cooperation from these associations.Safeguarding:  To mitigate against any safeguarding risks, BAT will train all our partners using BATs robust safeguarding policy. This will include ensuring communities and project participants are aware of communication mechanisms to highlight an issue and procedures are in place to effectively respond.Opportunities:Partnership with CIFF: BAT has partnered with CIFF to develop a pioneering new Child Protection Programme, with the aim of reducing exploitation of children in seven high prevalence states. Through trialling innovative solutions, scaling-up tested models and sharing best practice with key stakeholders, this partnership will contribute to creating a more robust and collaborative child protection eco-system across India.Strong connect with the West Bengal Government:  BAT has a good relationship with West Bengal's Ministry of Women and Child Development, which we will leverage to help implement the programme and scale-it up to other areas in the state.

GAF_A_American_India_Foundation_BigBetsC.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT 5a. Tell us about your governance and leadership structures, as well as staff and volunteer base. Highlight any significant recent or expected future changes. If you have an explicit approach to increasing diversity and/or advancing race equity within the organisation, please tell us. (300 words):About AIF: AIF is registered as a private, non-profit, nongovernmental organization under the section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code in the Oak Application Form     5US. We use a hybrid model of making grants to our partners directly from the US as well as implementing initiatives through our India arm known as the American India Foundation Trust (AIFT) duly registered under section 12A of the Income Tax Act as well as FCRA in India.US Board: Our US Board of Directors is a 21 membered diverse team appointed for a three year term period, co-chaired by Lata Krishnan and Harit Talwar, two senior leaders from the world of finance and technology. Our US and India Board of Directors/Trustees, consisting of highly accomplished individuals with representation of women of color in executive positions, provide governance and fiduciary oversight to programs and operations. A strong team of 10 finance professionals across the US and India offices led by COO/CFO, Ritu Prasad, in New York, carefully manages and monitors funds. The Finance Committee of the Board, chaired by Dr Tasneem Chipty (PhD in Economics from MIT and Managing Director, AlixPartners) ensures adherence to the highest financial management standards.Our Governance Committee, chaired by Diaz Nesamoney (CEO of Jivox Corporation) supervises all governance related matters. Our Finance and Governance Committees and the Board meet every quarter to review quarterly program and financial reports and to provide steer for the next quarters. We also have an informal Board Leadership Group consisting of the CEO and the two co-chairs and two vice-chairs of the Board that meets on the first Monday of every month to review any strategic governance and fiduciary matters on an ongoing basis. On all aspects of our operations, members of AIFs global Council of Advisors, co-chaired by Ambassador Frank Wisner and Pradeep Kashyap (ex-senior executive from Citi), provides guidance and mentorship to the leadership.  AIF also has 5 US Regional boards based out of California, Chicago, New England, New York Tri-State and Texas, respectively and it comprises 93 members. AIF has 3 Founders Circle based out of Chicago, Boston and San Francisco with a team of 69 members. AIF has 16 full time employees in the US.AIFT (AIF's India Arm) has 89 full time employees. We have a team of 1700+ contractual employees and 25 Banyan Impact Fellows (volunteers). The India Council of Advisor has 24 sectoral leaders to devise strategy on programs and the National Leadership Council has 22 members. The 4 membered India Trustee Board is chaired by Dr Nirupama Rao, Indias former Ambassador to the US and former Indias Foreign Secretary.For Big Bets Programme, AIF is the prime applicant and will act as an intermediary to a multi-agency collaborative called as Big Bets Collaborative (BBC) comprising of partner organizations namely, AIFT - Gurgaon, The Goat Trust - Lucknow, Switch On - Kolkata, Selco Foundation -  Bengaluru, Digital Empowerment Foundation (DEF) - New Delhi and Centre for Education and Communication (CEC) - New Delhi. In addition, BBC is committed to bringing on board specialist organizations to cater to specialized needs as they arise. Answered in section 8 in details. 5b. Summarise the organisations history.  In addition, highlight 2-3 key achievements.Oak Application Form     6Please keep this brief and list up to 3 key achievements as bullet points. Even though you may have many achievements, please share what is most relevant to the proposed grant. (300 words)AIF is a 20-year-old US-India bridge-building platform, committed to improving the lives of Indias underprivileged, with a special focus on women, children, and youth. AIF does this through high-impact interventions in education, health, livelihoods, and leadership because poverty is multidimensional. In 2015, we introduced gender justice and environmental sustainability as two cross-cutting themes in our program framework. Using our unique value proposition of convening communities, civil society, governments, and the private sector together in multi-stakeholder initiatives to create leveraged and sustainable impact, AIF has raised more than $118 million and impacted some 12.9 million lives from across 26 states of India.With offices in New York, California, and Delhi NCR, AIF is trusted by its partners for its commitment to the highest standards of governance, financial management, and accountability and transparency, testified by the GuideStar Platinum Transparency rating.Designed on the principles of innovation, collaboration, and a right-based approach, AIF brings people together to support communities and transform India into a more open, equitable, and vibrant democracy.Through knowledge sharing, advocacy and co-funding models, AIF leverages resources to amplify impact across 4 sectors - health, education, livelihood, and leadership. AIFs livelihood program envisions a world where poor and vulnerable communities have access to dignified work opportunities, empowering them with sustainable livelihoods. Since 2006, through a consortium-led approach, our livelihood program has served 1.2 million people, with a special focus on womens economic empowerment.Recent Achievements:AIF has a robust and efficient process for grant processing from the US to India programs. In the 12-month period of the calendar year 2021, we processed 119 transactions worth $22.28 million to 53 grantees.American India Foundation is the winner of the Dalmia Bharat- CSR Box 8 th CSR Impact Award. Under the Livelihoods (large) category at the 9th edition of India CSR Summit 2022 - South Asias largest CSR forum AIF was awarded this prestigious honour for the project Entre- Prerana: Rebuilding livelihoods of street vendors in a post-COVID era.The CSR Universe COVID Response Impact Award 2022.HUL 9 th Annual Prabhat AwardPartners Excellence Award 2018-19 by Hero MotoCorp.Our Work in Livelihood: Some of our notable coalitions managed by AIF in the livelihood space are as follows:Oak Application Form     7AIFs First Million is a $6 million partnership between 6 state governments, private hospitals, mobility partners, 10+ rural and urban NGOs, CSC, EY, and others to reach 1 million beneficiaries.The ABLE (Ability Based Livelihood Employment) coalition has a financial outlay of $3.05 million in last 5 years (2016- 2021) and has reached 18,670 beneficiaries through 30+ partners.AIFT along with all BBC partners as mentioned in section 8 has an active Foreign Contribution (Regulation) Act, 2010 which allows for regulation of the inflow of foreign contributions and ensures that the received foreign contributions are not utilized for illegal purposes.    5c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and decide your approach? If you have undertaken a theory of change exercise, or if you are influenced by research, policy or your own organisations experience, please tell us about this.  Have you consulted with relevant stakeholders, including your communities and others experiencing the problem? Is there an intention to address equity, diversity and inclusion? (600 words):The Problem: AIF along with BBC partners intends to address the problem of Low Female Labour Force Participation Rate (FLFPR) in Rural India: At a policy level, Ministries such as Women and Child Development have schemes like E-Haat, Rashtriya Mahila Kosh and Swayam Siddha Kosh project among others made a sincere effort to encourage women entrepreneurship. However, despite the positive conversations and concrete steps being taken around the issue, it has unfortunately not translated into a conducive entrepreneurship ecosystem for women. There are a multitude of barriers that are a hindrance to the social progress of women as entrepreneurs. These include but are not limited to the inherent bias against womens business skills, conventional gender roles rooted in patriarchal mindsets, and lack of access to finance and networks, among others. Refer detailed research report in the attachment. Deeply embedded gender norms among other sociocultural issues deprive women of access to information, market knowledge, finance, and most importantly, paid employment.According to a 2019 report by Google and Bain & Company, women were already worst hit by Indias unemployment crisis. While the overall Indian unemployment rate was at 7 percent before Indias March 2020 lockdown, it was already as high as 18 percent for women. Post the devastating impact of the COVID 19 on Indias economy and the widening job crises, the FLFPR of India dropped to a historic low of 16.1% during the July-September 2020 quarter, the lowest among the major economies. In 2021, as the COVID pandemic hit jobs and the economy, less than 16.1% of Indian women were part of the countrys labour force (Reuters, 2021). This is among the lowest rates of womens workforce participation in the world. Today, only Yemen, Iraq, Jordan, Syria, Algeria, Iran, and the West Bank and Gaza have lower FLFPR than India.Rationale for Formative Phase: BBC partners entered into the formative phase with a hypothesis that the micro, small, medium enterprise (MSME) Oak Application Form     8sector can play a significant role in accelerating rural women's entrepreneurship, such that they can leverage digital and climate-resilient technologies, access government schemes and provisions and lead inclusive value chains to demonstrate an increase in FLFPR. To do so, BBC partners main objective were to learn following broader aspects to design gender-sensitive programs via addressing following informational gaps:Identification of key enabling factors for the ecosystem to address systemic challenges, BBC partners will identify opportunities through research findings and strengthen networks for accelerating growth of mid-high impact, mid-high potential RWE.Approaches to strengthen and identification of best models to scale-up for viable and potential RWE and micro-enterprises. We intended to learn how and where in the value chain we can transform the lives of women by offering technical wherewithal, finance/market support, and network connections besides building and assisting strong narrative support to amplify RWE voices in policy discourse.Landscape analysis to identify new/existing opportunities as entry points for RWE through continuous engagement to build their product, value proposition, networks capacity, and building linkages for sustainable businesses.Identification of Problems through Formative Phase (8 months): From June 2022 to January 2023, Start-Up!, New Delhi a private consultancy, and Indian Institute of Bank Management (IIBM), Guwahati a premier institute conducted a mixed method primary and secondary research study to ascertain barriers to entry for women entrepreneurs, gender norms, policy frameworks, motivations and efficacy of government interventions. Start Up! designed and conducted In-Depth Interviews (IDIs) with 25 sector experts and dialogue sessions with a total of 166 rural women entrepreneurs (RWE) comprising of 96 RWE in Assam and 70 RWE in West Bengal. The RWE interviewed by Start Up! was largely in stages 0-3 (stage 0- seed stage, 1- self-employed or striving, 2-start-up, 3 - stable or steadfast) of entrepreneurship. Less than 5% of RWE were in stage 4 of scale and sector-shaper entrepreneurship. Given the current scenario, its relevant for BBC to uplift RWE struggling in stage 0-3. Please refer to page 4 and from page number 24 - 33 of the research report of Start Up! to know more about the various stages of entrepreneurship. IIBMs research (which is currently ongoing), includes both secondary and primary sources, across 5 districts in Assam (Kamrup Rural, Nalbari, Baksa, Goalpara and Sivsagar) and 3 districts in West Bengal (Coochbehar, Jalpaiguri and Darjeeling). There are 6 value chains that the research has focused on, namely, Mushroom, Piggery, Floriculture, Dairy, Handloom and Tea. IIBM has intensively engaged with a total of 300 Women Entrepreneurs (50 women entrepreneurs from each value chain) along with 20 stakeholder consultations which includes aggregators from Mushroom and Piggery value chain, Eri Silk producer company, Tea Board officials, company promoting floriculture, tea brokers, handloom designers and market aggregators, Micro Finance Institutions. At RWE level, our key research and findings from pilot suggests:Stereotypical gender roles: In the Edelgive Foundation study, 70% of the 1,235 women entrepreneurs admitted that domestic workload was Oak Application Form     9their primary responsibility. Most women felt that it was against their culture/values to let their husband/other family members partake in household chores.Top value chains for women: In the state of Assam and West Bengal there is a huge untapped potential for upward mobility of RWE in the following value chains : oIn Assam: Tea with a special focus on small tea growers (women) and handloom.oIn Assam and West Bengal: Livestock (pig, goat, poultry).oIn West Bengal: Dairy and agriculture.oEco-tourism and cultural tourism were identified as areas of huge potential in Assam.Access to information through digital skills: RWE do not have access to appropriate information or guidance which is specific to their business. It needs to be mentioned that most of the RWE are so involved in the operationalisation of their business that their attempts to seek additional information are rather limited. oIn Assam (92%) and West Bengal (87%) RWE strongly feel that lack of digital skill is an obstacle in expanding their business.Business skills for running an enterprise: Women usually run their enterprise as an informal entity and are not able to implement their business management skills in formalising their entities owing to lack of skills, mentoring and coaching support. oIn Assam (67%) and West Bengal (60%) RWE admitted that lack of business knowledge and financial constraints contribute to stunted growth of their enterprise.Risk taking aptitude with respect to finance and business expansion:  RWE do not demonstrate risk taking aptitude while managing their businesses. The average investment in starting their enterprise is INR 18,705 and almost 20% did not invest anything (Edelgive Foundation study). Further from this study, it was revealed that only 9% of them took some loan. Women revealed that they do not want to take loans because of the fear of inability to repay the loan, which would negatively impact their family and family pride. Since women do not have assets in their name, a large majority (83%) also feel that they cannot mortgage assets to secure loans, if required. This majorly deters women from taking loans. Further, 1% of women have availed of any government scheme and this is primarily because just about 11% are aware of any schemes. Less than a third (29%) of those who applied, could avail the scheme.  Considering a large proportion of women did not consider applying to the schemes even if aware (79%), they were asked the reason behind this. Major reasons cited by these women were: non-availability of required documents (17%), thought the process is complex (15%), did not feel the need for any support (13%), and believed that such schemes are only to support the rich (7%). oThe lack of financing remains the chief concern - 90 percent of women entrepreneurs in the country rely on informal sources of financing.Oak Application Form     10oIn Assam (83%) and West Bengal (60%), RWE are not aware of any financial linkage opportunities and an abysmal percentage (10-20%) in both states are aware of the government benefits for RWE (as per Start-Up study).Our Proposed Approach: Based on the reports, research findings and our collaborative partner's experience in the sector, we know that women's entrepreneurship is a significant tool of empowerment for women, and through BBC we want to create an urge within the stakeholders across the board to support this and contribute to the cause. We intend to do this through ecosystem transformation by shifting the mindset (where entrepreneurship become aspirational), infusion of innovation, establishment of formal-informal RWE associations/hubs, and creation of new evidence based knowledge products for dissemination at two intervention levels:At the 3P (Policy-Players-Processes) Ecosystem Design Level: We want to align our focus on bankers, financial, social, technology institutions and regulators to design and develop new products and processes for including women entrepreneurs from diverse socio-economic profiles in value chains.At an Operational Demonstration-Delivery Level: We seek investments for long-term training, coaching and mentorship of women entrepreneurs to build access to capital, markets, and technologies for women entrepreneurs to scale. This will help in the co-creation of multiplying social/ professional networks of grassroots business women and develop women entrepreneurs voices and capacity to influence economic and developmental agendas.At each level, as per the strength of respective BBC partner and collective effort, our findings confirmed that five thematic capitals most influence RWE on various stages of entrepreneurship lifecycle (seed, self-employed, start-up, stable and scale up) and are worth investing in:1.Personhood Capital : Autonomy or self/personhood. Celebrate and recognize rural women entrepreneurs locally, at district-levels and across states through running media campaigns to share stories of the true contribution of RWE.2.Knowledge Capital: Competencies or knowledge, skills. Non-conventional business management, mentoring and business leadership programs  programs that are local and accessible, rooted in the RWE context, with faculty that comprises technical experts as well as role model RWE.3.Financial Capital: Access and control over resources, or ownership of capital, assets tools and technology. Building narratives that build the confidence of bankers in RW as credit-worthy and sound investment opportunity.4.Social Capital: Relationships or personal and professional social networks for collectivization to organize trade fairs, summits to amplify voice and act as pressure groups to negotiate with family, market, government etc.Oak Application Form     115.Recognition Capital: Increase RWEs reputation capital in their locus of control and influence through stories, films and awards. In addition to this, BBC strongly recommends following value chain agnostic inputs are necessary for rural women to become entrepreneurs:1. Recognition for them that they are individuals who breathe life and have all the potential to do what they want.2. Access to awareness and knowledge on what are possibilities for them to do in their limited environments and unlimited responsibilities.3. Negotiations skill within the family to get time off to do what they choose to do.4. Enabling environment of women and others who will build and amplify the above.5. Working capital initially.6. Money management and financial literacy.7. Access to bank accounts.Using Oaks Funding: With this context, through BBC partners, we seek to boost the entrepreneurial spirit in women and plot womens entrepreneurship as one of the key pathways to advance womens economic empowerment in India. It also aims to get stakeholders across the board including the government, corporate, academia, think tanks, sector experts, philanthropy, investors, funding agencies, and not-for-profit sector together because we believe that it is only through synchronized efforts would we be able to create a thriving transformational ecosystem for rural women entrepreneurship. AIF in the capacity of an intermediary partner is requesting funds from Oak Foundation to commission:A planning phase (9-12 months) will focus on the following activities necessary towards effective implementation: a. Onboarding of program teamb. Conducting individual scoping studies by the individual partners to initiate their interventionsc. Formalization and constitution of the different committees and functions within the BBC. Further details on this maybe referred to in Page no. 44 in the BBC Strategic Program Design document, as enclosed with this proposal.d. A Resource Mobilisation Plan which will include a toolkit for the partners to refer to with respect to the different areas from where resources may be leveraged, different types of resources that can be leveraged, and what stages.e. A robust MEL plan will be owned by the Strategic Programme Management Committee (SPMC), and an agency will be onboarded for external evaluation of the program.6. An implementation phase (13 - 32 months) which will include demonstration and generating evidence from pilots covering select value chains; engaging with ecosystem players; Oak Application Form     12orchestrating mobilisation of RWEs within and across value chains; and design and roll out the communication strategy.7.Consolidation phase (33-48 months) : focus on the sustainability of the initiative. This will include documentation, dissemination and capacity building for greater adoption and promotion of successful strategies. Resource mobilisation to sustain and grow the outcomes will be a key focus area.During the implementation phase when BBC is able to demonstrate transformative change in a small (in relative terms) number of RWE in select value chains; during and after the consolidation phase, BBC would amplify the impact of its models through the following key allies:1. The MSME space2. Market systems3. Officers specific to the market systems4. Banks or rural credit facilities5. Large organisations in civil society like SEWA and others to see how they have cracked what they have6. NRLM kind of initiatives for linkage7. Mens groups in the village levelsEquity, Diversity, and Inclusion: Yes, AIF is committed to addressing it. All the BBC partners are chosen to bring equity in opportunities, diversity in choosing the target population, and inclusion of otherwise marginalized RWE. The unique value addition from BBC is that its designed to work at the intersection of finance and empowerment with an imperative to understand the economics behind entrepreneurship to create an enabling and conducive environment for women-owned enterprises. In other women-focused interventions, usually few elements are addressed that too in silos and more importantly, from a social lens only. For RWE to be successful, enterprises need to be nurtured where they are with skills relevant to the local context.
