GAF_A_American_India_Foundation_BigBetsC.8. COOPERATION: 8. COOPERATION  How will you involve others in your approach to achieving change? If you are planning to engage in partnerships with other organisations, communities, people with lived experience, academics or secure the support of key individuals, please tell us about this.  Why are these the right partners to engage with?  Is there anything new about how you are choosing to work - for example, new partnerships or an approach that is different to how you usually work? (300 words):Engagement in Partnerships: Every collaborating organization of BBC is committed to delivering a set of inter-connected and synergistic programs, which together lead to the shared outcomes and outputs of the initiative. To strengthen and sustain the collaboration, BBC will require a set of strategic and cross-cutting functions, which will be facilitated with CURIE (creativity, unity, respect, integrity and excellence) values embedded in the principles of result oriented transformational leadership  a leadership that is driven on achieving success through big vision thinking and intellectual stimulation to create a thriving, openly communicative work culture. The process is participative and inclusive of skilled sector experts/ competent organizations and professionals across sectors who may be outside existing BBC partners as the need arises and is committed to weave in cultural competency through involvement of local communities for better acceptability of interventions.Right Mix of Diverse Partners: One of the prime criteria for selecting partners has been their non-profit structure, strong roots in the local community through direct implementation of programs in close collaboration with local governance structures. The list of BBC members is not limited to the list and may continue to expand in the implementation phase based on synergetic alignment of priorities:1.AIFT, Gurgaon: Award winning non-profit. AIFT is committed to help create an India free from poverty, one in which everyone has access to affordable education, health care and livelihood opportunities.2.Centre for Education and Communication (CEC), New Delhi: Founded in 1982, CEC is a resource centre dedicated to research, campaign and support on key concepts, ideas and policies that enhance dignified and sustainable livelihood options of workers, in particular informal workers, and small producers.3.Digital Empowerment Foundation (DEF), New Delhi:  DEF is an integral digital action organization which creates information Oak Application Form     19empowerment, equitable communities by providing digital access to information, knowledge and contextual capacity.4.Selco Foundation, Bengaluru: Pioneer in delivery of sustainable energy to the poor in India in a manner that creates assets and results in long term poverty alleviation.5.Switch On Foundation, Kolkata: An award winning not for profit organization. Since 2008, SwitchON Foundation has led many innovative projects and incubated a number of highly successful ventures and initiatives in the areas of renewable energy access, agriculture and livelihoods, skilling and education and environment and climate change.6.The Goat Trust, Lucknow: The Goat Trust works across value chain of Goat based products. We promote small livestock (Goat/sheep/ Backyard birds rearing) based livelihood through demystifying production technology, building institutions and promoting standard of marketing and linkage.Newer Ways of Working Through Collaborative Building: To achieve the highly complex layered multi-stakeholder solution of uplifting women through economic empowerment at an ecosystem level in India, AIF is proposing to work through a collaborative as opposed to an individual organization. A collaborative is a temporary alliance or partnering of groups in order to achieve a common purpose or to engage in joint activity. Forming collaboratives with other groups of similar values, interests, and goals will allow AIF and BBC members to combine their resources and become more powerful than when they each acted alone and therefore increase their collective potential for success. AIF further believes that a collaborative can bring more expertise and resources to bear on complex issues, where the technical or personnel resources of any one organization would not be sufficient.

The SPMC will be responsible for anchoring outcomes, outputs and learning of the BBC and will own the larger MEL framework. Evaluation and learning at regular intervals would be undertaken by a third-party organization selected by the competitive Request for Proposal (RFP) process by AIFT in consultation with the SPMC to maintain objectivity and data integrity.Regular reviews will be held where the ToC, which is a dynamic document, will be reviewed to ensure that the BBC programmatic strategy is aligned and learnings are incorporated into the strategy on an ongoing basis.Additionally, a dashboard will be created which will be anchored by the SPMC and whose access will be provided to all BBC members. The Secretariat will be responsible for regularly updating and maintaining the dashboard and ensuring that data from the ground is captured effectively. Please refer page number 43 of the attached strategy document for the complete monitoring, evaluation and learning metrics, which will demonstrate signs of success.As the work progresses, BBC members will ensure the intended impact on the target population is occurring and adaptations are made to stay on course. For more details, please refer to page number 39 to 41 of BBC strategy document.Learning: BBC partners are entering into the implementation phase with a hypothesis that the micro, small, and medium enterprise (MSME) sector can play a significant role in accelerating rural women's entrepreneurship, such that they can leverage digital and climate-resilient technologies, access government schemes and provisions and lead inclusive value chains to demonstrate economic empowerment of rural women through entrepreneurship. To do so, BBC partners will learn the following broader aspects to design gender-sensitive programs via:Key enabling factors for the ecosystem to address systemic challenges, BBC partners will leverage on identified opportunities basis formative phase research findings and strengthen networks for accelerating growth of existing and potential RWE at various life cycle of entrepreneurship.Approaches to strengthen and identification of best models to scale up for viable and potential RWE and micro-enterprises. We intend to demonstrate how, where and what in the value chain we can bring transformational ecosystem change to impact the lives of women by offering technical wherewithal, finance/market support, and network connections besides building and assisting strong narrative support to amplify RWE voices in policy discourse.Landscape analysis to identify new/existing opportunities as entry points for RWE through continuous engagement to build their product, value proposition, networks capacity and building linkages for sustainable businesses.
GAF_A_American_India_Foundation_BigBetsC.10. RISKS AND CHALLENGES: 10.  RISKS AND CHALLENGESOak Application Form     21What are the risks or barriers that might prevent you from achieving your outcomes and how will you address these?  What are your opportunities?We understand that achieving long-lasting and meaningful change is hard and we expect that the work you want to do will mean taking risks.  We encourage you to be open to telling us these, as well as how you will address these risks.  If some of your outcomes are risky, are there any incremental achievements that you could identify? (300 words):1. Research suggests women who earn in rural areas are more prone to gender-based domestic violence as there is a constant power struggle as to who will own the money and spend it. The BBC program will have to allocate resources to enhance provision of social security services for existing and emerging RWE to minimize the impact of risk factors at the household level.2. Entrepreneurship development is a long-term resource-intensive game, besides in a collaborative-based partnership disagreement on a mutual goal and objective can threaten the success of the program. Therefore, rather than focusing on short-term quantitative outputs, the grant program could focus on longer-term outcomes over a period of 5-10 years since ecosystem players on the groundwork in fragmented ways.3. Working with governments is imperative, yet hard. Organizations would need time and capacity building to focus on systems change and engage other stakeholders in congruent ways. Mainstream adoption of models will not move unless backed by data and evidence. This would require investment in research, business case development, and creating a new and strategic narrative for RWE.4. At an operational level, forming and managing a collaborative can be a very time-consuming and bureaucratic process that can take away time from working directly on campaign issues and organization tasks. To mitigate this risk, AIF will encourage democratic decision-making and sustained action by managing power dynamics within the group through transparent communication and appreciative inquiry for best practices, strategic planning, and organizational culture to increase the momentum of initiatives.5. At a socio-political level, a high turnover rate among government officials in the strategic positions of influence will hamper the advocacy agenda at the ecosystem level. This is beyond BBC partners' locus of control; however, efforts will be made to strengthen partnerships at multiple levels to sustain relationships.

Summarise the projects ultimate goal(s) (maximum 200 words):( NOT REQUIRED FOR CORE SUPPORT GRANTS)Grant Application Form, July 1 20134To empower the forest dwelling communities of North Bengal in exercising their right to conserve, protect and live sustainably on their land. This project will help communities claim their rights under Forest Rights Act (FRA), develop sustainable livelihood options and build youth leadership. AID initiates and promotes sustainable, equitable and just development across India by partnering with marginalised communities and groups working in agriculture, gender and environmental justice, health and education.

GAF_Association_for_Indias_Development_S.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 6. Context (The context section should not exceed two pages.)6a. Describe the organisation (include information on leadership, governance, structure and staff) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):AID is a volunteer driven organisation based in the US with thirty chapters and about 400 volunteers. There is a Board of Directors with six members currently. All board members are long-time volunteers with ten to twenty years experience within AID. There is an elected Executive Board (EB) consisting of nine to ten members and elected for a term of two years, responsible for operation and coordination across chapters. There are two full time Development Coordinators based in the US, who spend a few months working with the partners in India as well. Another full time person works with our partners in eastern India and is based in Kolkata. There are five Jeevansaathis who work full time on various issues and across India. They were long-time AID volunteers in the US who have gone back and started work at the grassroots decades ago. AID works with close to 75 grassroots organizations across India on agriculture, health, education, gender and environmental justice. Currently AID has a part time accountant based in India helping us. AID is looking to hire a part time person in the US as well within the next 2 months. About 37% of the leadership is women. There is a conscious effort to increase diversity along the lines of faith, gender and caste.Grant Application Form, July 1 201356b. Describe the financial situation (include information on annual operating costs, fundraising strategy, reserves and debts) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):6c. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):AID was started in 1991 as a volunteer-based organization at College Park, Maryland by students from India interested in community development and social justice. Over the years the idea behind AID appealed to many and interested people formed chapters in many cities in the US. Today there are 30 chapters with about 400 volunteers. AID began by supporting grassroots NGOs working in under-served areas. As AID grew, so did its network at the grassroots in India. We understood the interconnected nature of the problems and the need to work with the most marginalized communities on health, education, agriculture, gender and the environment. Today, along with its partners, AID reaches out directly to several million people and strives to strengthen communities under their own leadership. A few prominent efforts:1. The Eureka educational program in Tamil Nadu was designed to improve the quality of education, particularly math, science and language, in marginalized communities. This program works with 80,000 children through 1,000 village educational centers throughout Tamil Nadu.2. In 2009 Cyclone Aila inundated the islands the Sunderbans in W Bengal with saline water. During initial relief efforts, AID realized that reviving agriculture was critical to the communitys well-being. Starting with 25 farmers in 2009 today AID has worked with 25,000 farmers and helped them adopt sustainable organic agriculture. It has also facilitated sales of the organic produce in Kolkata.In 2018, AID initiated a community based program on watershed development in 4 tribal districts of Jharkhand, bringing together grassroots groups and a resource organization. The project had a tremendous impact in its first year itself bringing water and greenery to some of the drought stricken villages and over the last two years. There has been a lot of demand from the neighboring villages but we are limited by funds. In these 2 years we have treated close to 3000 hectares of land Grant Application Form, July 1 20136and planted about 3000 trees and hope for it to scale.6d. Describe the current strategy of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):AID works with marginalized communities and groups across India to address issues they currently face. Through experience over the last two decades, AID has learnt that the issues are cross-cutting and its support should not be limited to single issues, but rather towards an overall dignified life for the communities. Agriculture: The majority of Indias population still has livelihoods based on agriculture and yet, farmers have been in distress for over a decade. AID has been addressing the agrarian crisis in India by -1. By providing relief to farmers in crisis: AID helps families of farmers who have committed suicide and those affected by natural disasters, by providing immediate support as well as logistical support to interface with the administration. AID has worked with farmers after several natural disasters helping them reclaim their land and restart agriculture. AID is working in Sunderbans as we speak to revive agriculture after Cyclone Amphan.2. By promoting sustainable practices:  AID helps to train farmers to move away from chemical farming towards ecologically sustainable and economically viable techniques. AID also works with landless families and tribal communities to improve food security through the practice of nutrition gardens.3. Advocating for farmer friendly policies:  AID works with advocacy groups to make governments implement farmer-friendly policies.AID works with about 50,000 farmers mainly in West Bengal, Telangana, Andhra Pradesh, Maharashtra and Tamil Nadu. Health: AID works with several partners across India to improve health equity and making quality and affordable healthcare accessible to all.1. AID works with physicians and health workers in remote areas without access to healthcare - innovating in extremely low resource settings, training village health workers and developing appropriate technologies and understanding social determinants of health.2. AID supports groups demanding access to affordable healthcare as a right by organizing people to hold the public health system accountable.3. Along with its partners, AID understands that food insecurity is a major cause of illness and undernourished children face irreversible damage before the age of 3. AID supports nutritional programs for children under 3 and works to improve the Government run Anganwadis.AID works with healthcare partners in Chhattisgarh, Maharashtra, Odisha, Tamil Nadu, Madhya Pradesh and Karnataka reaching out to at least 120,000 people. Grant Application Form, July 1 20137Education: AID works to make culture appropriate education accessible to all.1. Developing Curriculum:  Activity-based lessons with interactive materials motivate children to explore concepts from multiple angles rather than by rote.  Government, non-government schools as well as after-school centers use these methods and materials.2. Strengthening Public Schools: AID partners engage with government schools to improve teaching methods and see that all children have a right to meaningful, quality education.3. Reaching the Unreached: In underserved communities, AID partners run schools and bridge courses to help students in remote and tribal areas prepare for and adjust in mainstream schools.  AID also supports model schools implementing effective innovative techniques in rural areasAID and its partners reach out to 330,000 children through its education programs. Gender Equality:  AID works with women's groups towards a gender just society. It supports education of women young and old, advocating for their rights and encouraging leadership by women and access to independent livelihoods. We also partner with groups providing support to survivors of violence. We have been working with transgender groups advocating for their equality in society,  striving for access to a dignified livelihood and equal access to healthcare. Environmental Justice:1. AID empowers communities to take action to defend the environment by equipping communities to measure/monitor pollution of land, water and air and raise it with the officials.2. AID promotes community control of natural resources helping communities gain their rights under the Forest Rights Act.AID engages with communities for watershed restoration and afforestation efforts.6e. GAF_Association_for_Indias_Development_S.8. COOPERATION: 8. CooperationDescribe the level of cooperation with other organisations and networks and explain how this cooperation helps achieve your goals (maximum 300 words):The tropical forests of sub-Himalayan Bengal in India contain rich biodiversity and anthropogenic wealth. Several indigenous communities, such as Rava, Mech, Dukpa, Garo and many Jharkhandi adivasi groups (Oraon, Kheria, Santhal, Munda, Baraik) live here. Lepcha, Limbu, Rai, Tamang, Sherpa and other ethnic groups now being generically termed as Gorkha  also live here. Many of these people were brought in from surrounding states and forced to stay in the ghettoized settlements of forest villages set up by British foresters as labor colonies in the late 19th and early 20th Century.Colonial laws passed by the British Government made it unlawful for forest tribes to even live within the forest or source their daily needs. The British also converted forest land to monoculture commercial timber plantations destroying the forest ecosystem in the process.After Independence the Indian Government too, created policies with similar goals. Even laws passed ostensibly for conservation targeted forest communities as destructive to the environment and evicted them. Illegal timber harvesting continued and contributed to heavy deforestation, often also victimizing forest communities. Today, the timber industry takes advantage of poverty among these communities and employs them to harvest timber from the forest thus adding to ongoing environmental degradation.The Forest Rights Act (FRA), passed in 2006, gave joint ownership of forest areas to both the Government and indigenous forest-based communities. It empowered these communities to form governing institutions that would administer the forest together with the Forest Department. Currently, it suffers from inadequate implementation due to lack of awareness among the affected communities.The main actors involved in the larger context of the work are the peoples social movement, an NGO, the forest communities and solidarity groups. Another stakeholder is the Forest Department.People from the community are involved in every step of the process from site selection to forming the groups to participate in agriculture. The learning centers on the other hand will be open to all youth of 12-18 years in the community. Gram Sabhas will be the main agency involved in the filing of the CFR as well as mapping the community forest areas.
GAF_Association_for_Indias_Development_S.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. ImpactWhat is the change you want to achieve from the overall project? (maximum 300 words):Grant Application Form, July 1 20131410. EvaluationHow will progress be monitored and evaluated? (maximum 300 words):A monitoring team will be formed for each project site, consisting of community leaders and project coordinators. This team will meet the communities each month and hold review meetings every 2 months. Gram Sabhas will also be monitoring the work at their respective sites. At the inter site level, the existing secretariat of the group will do the monitoring on a monthly basisAdditionally, for the learning centers, the monitoring and evaluation team will include civil society members and solidarity groups who will support in developing the learning modules. There would be 2 evaluations in a year for the learning centers. The first year would be focussed on understanding the efficacy and acceptance of the learning modules. The feedback will be used for modifications and adjustments.AID volunteers will also carry out an annual evaluation by being on site as they have for the past 5 years.The evaluation questions for the livelihood part would be to see how the community is bonding and making decisions, if they have been able to operationalize and start agriculture and how many times they are meeting and interacting with their respective Gram Sabhas.For the learning centers, the regularity of the centers and the attendance in them would indicate the acceptance of the learning modules. Further on in the program, interactions with the youth will give an idea about their understanding of the local environment and care for it. Beyond that, it would be important to eventually see the youth participating in the Gram Sabha meetings and playing an active role in it.For the Forest Rights component, we will need to see how many resource maps are developed for the community forests, followed by how many CFRs are filed. Finally, it would be important to see if the community is using the community forest land in a way that is beneficial to them.To understand the impact, we would look at the following:Number of people participating in agriculture, learning at each siteChange in the production of vegetables over the years at each siteObserving the increase/decrease in the participation of women and out migrantsChange in the mortality rate of the plantationsForest area mapped and the number of Community Forest Rights applicationNumber of learners in each centerGrant Application Form, July 1 201315

Summarise the projects ultimate goal(s) (maximum 200 words):( NOT REQUIRED FOR CORE SUPPORT GRANTS)The MRC (Migrants Resilience Collaborative) is Indias largest grassroots-led initiative steered by our Indian organisation partner, Jan Sahas. Initially, the program has a period of three years and will span over 100 districts, of which 15-20 have high apparel-based migration, to sustainably impact 10 million migrants over five years. We aim to enable systemic improvements that build socio-economic resilience for over 139 million migrants.The MRC has a strong affinity with Oaks commitment to address global, social and environmental issues, particularly among the disadvantaged. The MRC enables the Oak Foundation to advance these goals both systemically and at scale, whilst leveraging the commitment of large institutional funders such as Omidyar Network, Dell Foundation, H.T. Parekh Foundation, and Godrej Group, at a time of heightened need.More than 95% of migrants that we support belong to Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and other backward classes. We aim to address the inequalities within these communities.In addition, several components of MRCs strategy and approach are aligned, including but not limited to:  1) Building agency of migrant families and safeguarding labour rights.2) Working with migrants specifically engaged in the construction and textiles sector.3) Working with industry including the textiles industry to build an inclusive economy.4) Focusing on systemic improvements.

GAF_Dignity_Alliance_International_Suppo.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 6. Context (The context section should not exceed two pages.)6a. Describe the organisation (include information on leadership, governance, structure and staff) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):Dignity Alliance International (DAI) is independent UK based charity but also part of Jan Sahas family. DAI is committed to end all forms of forced labour and violence against women and children across South Asia through the partnership with local organizations. The Proposed program will be implemented by Jan Sahas*. Jan Sahas is a 20-year-old community centric organization working intensively in 78 districts across eleven states of India. Jan Sahas is working with the most excluded social groups on safe migration and workers protection; and prevention of sexual violence against women and children. At the time of its inception in 2000, Jan Sahas worked in one district of Madhya Pradesh with a staff strength of 12 volunteers. Today, we have grown to a strong workforce of 1882 (523 full-time and 1,359 part-time) staff and 640 volunteers spread across 18,000+ villages and towns across the country.At Jan Sahas, we are committed to ensuring that our staff and projects operate within the framework of diversity, equity, inclusion and we actively promote and expect gender-sensitive behaviour. In line with best practice, we aim to have a 50% representation of women among the project staff, preferably in leadership roles and four of our seven Board members are female. Our organisational structure comprises cross-functional teams. However, the board of Directors are the main governing body of the organisation, followed by the Chief Executive Officer. Each team (Fundraising, Finance, Programme, Research, Partnerships, Strategy, Technology) has a Director followed by the Managers, who are the thematic leaders of each field. Among the team are associates and programme coordinators, followed by the officers and field staff. Please refer to the organogram for a pictorial representation of the structure (Uploaded as attachment in downloads).The team members have been divided into different management groups, each with their own roles and responsibilities:1. Governing Board: responsible for driving forward the strategic direction of the organisation, setting organizational plans and priorities and managing risk and accountability. 2. Senior Management Team: responsible for organizational decision-making and strategic planning. Leaders from key departments represent the concerns of their thematic areas.3. Program Development Team: responsible for tracking the progress and challenges of each program, whilst sharing their learnings among each other.4. Organizational Development Team: comprises full-time and part-time staff and includes partners and Board members working with Jan Sahas. * DAI will charge 4% overhead cost to Jan Sahas.(Board members bio attached as Annex)Grant Application Form, July 1 20136  6b. Describe the financial situation (include information on annual operating costs, fundraising strategy, reserves and debts) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words): Our major operating expenditure is designated to salaries and programme costs, at 41.34% and 46.86% respectively. The remaining 11.8% is divided across fixed (1.70%), flexible expense (5.90%), research (2.25%) and service costs (1.95%). Funders such as Omidyar Network and Ford Foundation have invested significantly in Jan Sahass core support, with Omidyar Network, Michael & Susan Dell Foundation, Skoll Foundation, and Godrej providing unrestricted support, enabling us to build capacity and scale quickly. Within the next year, we wish to raise funds from the Indian organisations, shifting our current funding status.We have secured funding (under MRC alone) from the following sources:1. Michael & Susan Dell foundation: $ 2,000,0002. Omidyar Network: $ 1,000,0003. Skoll Foundation: $ 150,0004. Godrej Group: $ 346,6675. Tata Trusts: $ 480,0006. UNDP: $ 200,0007. HCL Foundation: $ 104,0008. Karuna Trust: $ 150,0009. Macquarie Foundation: $ 531,00010. HT Parekh Foundation: $ 666,66711. Fidelity Asia Pacific Foundation: $ 400,00012. Laudes Foundation: $ 2,400,00013. Multiple donors from UK: $ 600,000Total: $ 95,28,334Beyond 5 years, our target for sustainability and scale is adoption by the government boards (such as BOCW) and the private sector, thus moving away from the need for further philanthropic funding and more towards an 80% adoption by the private companies.We have a separate reserve of 1 Cr (INR) dedicated to MRC and no material debts as on date.Grant Application Form, July 1 201376c. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):Jan Sahas has been working with the most excluded communities for over two decades, providing support on issues such as prevention and response to gender-based violence, forced labour, and caste-based manual scavenging. This includes: 1) Uniquely blending our grassroots-led approach with a focus on scale, facilitating direct support in ~60 districts across nine states of India, serving~2,000,000 women and girls across program areas, tracking >200,000 migrant workers, rescuing >4.2k bonded and child labourers, and delivering >128,000 entitlements to migrants. During the initial months of the COVID-19 pandemic, Jan Sahas worked with 42 non-profits across 19 states in India to address needs of >1 million migrant families through immediate relief support. There have been a few projects that have been instrumental in achieving this. These include: an Initiative to substantially reduce the practice of Forced and Child Labour (F&CL) in cotton production in Madhya Pradesh, India; Fighting Forced Labour with Adivasi and Dalit communities in South Asia; Nirmaan Mazdoor Sashaktikaran Karyakram (NMSK) and Bandhuaa Majdoor Mukti Abhiyan.2) With support from CBOs (Community Based Organisations), Jan Sahas has influenced key legislation (The Landmark Prohibition of Employment as Manual Scavengers and their Rehabilitation Act, 2013), and participates on various government working commissions (for example, Government of Madhya Pradeshs commission on migrant workers, NITI Aayogs Working Group for Social Justice and Empowerment to support on migration).  Jan Sahas promoted CBO, Rashtriya Garima Abhiyan and has influenced several initiatives at departmental and state level on the issue of manual scavenging and gender justice. Jan Sahas aims to address the issues faced specifically by migrant families at an unprecedented scale and crucially it has quickly emerged into new geographical areas. Thus, Jan Sahas believes in a collaborative approach, partnering with CBOs with similar values across the country to facilitate direct support through its interventions. 6d. Describe the current strategy of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):Our priority is to adopt a learning-based organic scale-up approach that focuses on quality and continues to ensure strong accountability to our communities. Based on our learnings from our projects in the space of migration, we have developed a detailed scale up model. Since October 2020, we have started working using our current operating model on the theme in 50 districts and supporting 40 additional civil society organizations to intervene in another 50 districts. We are also piloting innovations to work at greater scale and update our operating models over the next five years. The key to our success will be a unified technology system: a unified database of 10 million workers along with their information based on which of the three services (social security, responsible recruitment, and worker protection) they opt Grant Application Form, July 1 20138for. Our Jan Saathi social security entitlements application and national labour helpline will be at the top of our database. We are currently developing this technology system and intend to integrate these with government systems to radically simplify the delivery of benefits to workers.To achieve all of this, we have made our investments in technology, a second line of leadership, and strengthening internal systems give us confidence that we can build capacities that complement our strengths in grassroots reach, experience of large-scale programs, and commitment to excluded communities to anchor this initiative.6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):There are an estimated 139 million internal migrant workers in India. Despite being large contributors to Indias GDP, migrant workers face systematic disenfranchisement due to power imbalance & high vulnerability. As a result, they face three principal challenges: Non-recognition by states, & lack of social security leading to debt and poverty.Under the proposed project we intend to use the corridor approach (work at source & destination together). The proposed geographic focus is the West Bengal migration corridor. We have selected 4 high prevalence districts of migration in West Bengal (Murshidabad, Nadia, Bardhaman and Birbhum) as source districts & Mumbai-Suburban and Delhi-NCR region as destination areas.According to Census 2011, West Bengal ranks fourth among states from where people migrate to for work and employment. Approximately 80% of work-migrants from the state migrate to Maharashtra (45.3%) and Delhi-NCT (34%). Research shows that much of the migrant population in the country belong to lower-income quintile groups and are likely to be deprived of social security. In 2004-05, approximately 35% of workers in rural West Bengal were out of social security coverage and this increased to 50% in 2011-12. Furthermore, according to a study on the access to flagship programme benefits and public services in West Bengal, it was found that access to benefits was critically low due to lack of awareness, procedural complexities, harassment, apathy of state officials and opportunity cost being higher than benefit. The access to benefits is critically limited due to a lack of awareness, delay, procedural complexities, harassment, insensitivity of implementing officials and elected representatives, adverse selection & opportunity cost being higher than benefit. Given the high rates of poverty, out-migration and poor access to entitlement, it is critical that concerted efforts are placed into improving the social security coverage in West Bengal.We decided that launching the MRC now would have the most impact for the following reasons:Unprecedented political will and demand for Jan Sahas support on migrants issue: Post-COVID, migrant welfare has become a major political issue:1) Central and State governments have embarked on social security registration drives, several have set up migrant welfare commissions. The central government accepted $1 billion credit fund from the World Bank to create a social registry for Grant Application Form, July 1 20139strengthening social security.2) Jan Sahas has partnered with multiple governments (for example, Delhi, Madhya Pradesh, Telangana) and we are discussing partnerships with several others. Partnering with West Bengal and Maharashtra has been considered in the project plan.Unprecedented industry willingness to support migrants, including Jan Sahass mission: Industry bodies such as CREDAI and FICCI have taken up the cause of social security as a trust-building measure and to improve the value proposition for workers. Four of the largest Indian construction companies (L&T, Godrej, Lodha, Mahindra & Mahindra) co-signed an open letter with Jan Sahas, advocating for governments to deliver on its policies including benefits for migrant workers and committing to partner with government and civil society.Demonstrated interest from philanthropy and civil society to support migrant workers: Large funders such as Omidyar Network, Azim Premji Philanthropic Initiatives, Michael & Susan Dell Foundation, HT Parekh Foundation have recalibrated strategies to support migrant families. With both need and the potential for high impact, the MRC seeks to harness the opportunity to capitalize on opportunity and address systemic at scale. In the 6 months of operations MRC has registered 1,036,626 migrant households of which 424,400 were women led, filled 1,192,936 social security applications, ensured benefits received to 847,556 migrant individuals. While, the helpline received 2871 and 753 cases were registered through different sources (helpline and field). We are fully cognisant of the threats facing the program and have established a plan to address them:1) Current and future FCRA law amendments hinder sub-granting funds to partner CBOs.2) Reduced bargaining power of migrants and the industrys willingness to support reforms due to added vulnerability of migrants. Additionally, the impact of the pandemic has sparked a change in labour codes.
GAF_Dignity_Alliance_International_Suppo.7. OBJECTIVES: 7. Objectives (maximum 2,200 words)For a core support grant, state the purpose of this grant request and complete the objectives.  After consultations with an Oak PO, you may decide to summarise your mission as one broad objective. In this case, it is still necessary to specify activities and results/outcomes for this objective.For project support grants please list your objectives for this project in bullet point format. (You may use additional space if you have more than three objectives)?. Under each objective describe the activities that your organisation will undertake to achieve it, including time frame and the results or outcomes you expect to achieve.7.1.a. Objective 1 (maximum one sentence):Strengthening social security delivery system and increasing access to benefits and entitlements.Grant Application Form, July 1 2013107.1.c. Objective 1 Activities and timeframe (maximum 300 words):1. Facilitating social security through community-based volunteers, leveraging partnerships with government and industry: key barriers for workers include a lack of awareness, and a complex government system that is challenging to navigate, and a complete lack of a proactive delivery system. MRC has built a tech platform as a solution to profile (general information like name, residence, mobile, and intervention-specific information) and track migrants. All individuals supported across interventions and location are profiled at the first touch point, with subsequent engagements logged on, enabling MRC to track workers, their progress, enable simplified access to other services, while enabling MRC to understand most effective sales channels. The platform will be built to enable interoperability across government and other civil society systems to the extent possible, enabling sharing of information. In the long-term, this could substitute or supplement governments own data registrieTo overcome the barriers, we intend to train (on this tech platform) and leverage 59 Jan Saathis and block-level field workers, many of whom are from high-migration and historically excluded communities. In each district, we aim to build awareness, onboard workers onto our tech platform, conduct on-the-spot eligibility checks and provide support in accessing key social security benefits (e.g., land rights, insurance, education, and other key benefits). The Jan Saathis will register these workers on the platform and update progress after check in calls or follow up meetings. Jan Saathis/field workers will also train and draw support from village-based barefoot lawyers from the community, who will be trained to build awareness within their villages regarding entitlements and basic rights. With state and industry buy-in through MoUs, Jan Saathis / field workers will help to drive social security registrations at scale. 2. Innovations to improve efficiency and sustainability of social security delivery systems: Apart from the Jan Saathi model and continuous improvements therein, the MRC aims to design and implement interventions that enable the delivery of social security faster, better and more cost-efficiently. They will be measured and tracked through the MRC tech platform in pilot areas, prior to scaling. Potential and planned interventions include:Leveraging business correspondents for social security delivery. This is an ongoing activity.( Business Correspondents are deployed by banks to deliver basic banking services outside the bank branch. Migrant workers use their services to send and receive remittances and carry out other basic:a. Banking transactions. We believe the relationship will be mutually beneficial as the BCs will not only get an opportunity to earn additional revenue through provision of complimentary services (migrant registration and social security 7.1.b. Objective 1 Expected results/outcomes and timeframe (maximum 300 words):1) 4,00,000 workers and their families registered for, and aware of the key social security schemes in 3 years.2) 2,40,000 workers receiving key benefits in 3 yearsGrant Application Form, July 1 201311delivery) but also help to increase cross-sell opportunities).b. Integrating our social security technology with government systems through interoperable Application Programming Interfaces or integrating with Common Service Centres by leveraging MoUs for social security delivery with the state government. 7.2.a. Objective 2 (maximum one sentence):Enabling responsible recruitment. (this is consistent with the wording of Objective 1)7.2.c. Objective 2 Activities and timeframe (maximum 300 words):1. Advocate for responsible recruitment within industry, in partnership with financiers, brands and industry associations. We intend to partner and advocate with companies (both of construction and textiles), focusing on the largest companies to strengthen worker support. In particular, we intend to leverage financiers (e.g., HDFC Bank), brands (e.g., C&A, H&M, Arvind Mills), and industry bodies (e.g., CII, FICCI, ASSOCHAM, CREDAI), to strengthen their norms and expectations from members, and drive downstream improvements across their membership and supply chains. We will also advocate for adherence of norms that disproportionately affect women (e.g., implementation of POSH Act, equal wages for equal work, better sanitation facilities, and fair growth opportunities);2. Co-creating mechanisms for developing implementable solutions for responsible recruitment. We aim to engage with the financiers /investors, brands, industry association and companies to identify key priorities, opportunities, and gaps in the sector and within the value chain.  Ultimately, we would co-create a pathway for developing some of the solutions for building responsible recruitment practices within the company and its supply chain. The solutions may differ depending on the size and scale of the company and the region or geographies they operate in. Such partnerships and adoption by large companies in construction and textiles will strengthen worker welfare; likely improve worker retention at a time when companies are facing labour shortages and play a signalling role for other companies in the sector too. Our objective through such engagement is for industry to own such initiatives, including publicly owning its success.3. New model for placement support by leveraging government portal. We have partnered with the Quality Council of India to pilot the UNNATI portal, which aims to connect 200 million workers with job providers. Aside from leveraging this 7.2.b. Objective 2 Expected results/outcomes and timeframe (maximum 300 words): 1,00,000 workers responsibly recruited in 3 years by 15+ companies and industry associations.Grant Application Form, July 1 201312to influence government planning, we will use our learnings from this in year 2 to design a model that encompasses our database of migrant workers and the labour demand from large companies to support employment opportunities for migrant workers (e.g., in partnership with existing recruitment agents). 7.3.a. Objective 3 (maximum one sentence):Enabling protection. (consistent with Objectives 1 & 2)7.3.c. Objective 3 Activities and timeframe (maximum 300 words):1.  National, 24X7 migrant multi-lingual labour helpline: Our toll-free helpline will provide information to workers on their rights and entitlements and register complaints regarding forced labour. It will facilitate rescue support, where required in coordination with district authorities. Registering the worker on our tech platform also enables the MRC to reconnect with the worker over an outgoing call and provide information that allows them to connect to resource centres and Jan Saathis. 30% of the Jan Saathis and helpline staff will be women to ensure female workers and family members are comfortable to reach out to them and can better enable reach.2.  Remedial and legal support through lawyers initiative forum: the MRC will facilitate dispatch support for cases received over the helpline or through other touch points. This includes:a.  field workers in districts coordinating with local authorities to support/rescue workers in forced labour situations; in recent cases in Madhya Pradesh, MRC staff have advised local authorities, enabling them to deliver rescue efforts independently.   b.  legal aid through the Lawyers Initiative Forum (a Jan Sahas promoted, pro-bono forum of +1,400 lawyers), or part-time lawyers hired in each district.For dispatch services our approach has been to collaborate strategically with other civil society initiatives such as those by ILO, UNDP and Aajeevika Bureau and other prominent Civil society Organisations in order to drive systemic changes. In order to avoid delicacy of efforts we will transfer cases to network organisations with capacity and presence in the geography.Over the next 3-5 years, our goal is to establish the helpline and the field worker dispatch support as a standalone public good, adopted by Government, akin to ChildLine.7.3.b. Objective 3 Expected results/outcomes and timeframe (maximum 300 words):We aim to reduce forced labour by 60% (in the districts of project operation) by making worker protection support available to workers.Grant Application Form, July 1 2013133.  Agency and awareness building for self-protection: a.  At source, the MRC will scale Jan Sahass barefoot lawyer volunteer program which trains motivated, local youths to build awareness and agency in their own villages.b.  Prior to migration, each worker under the project will be trained at source on rights and entitlements at the destination, remedies available, best practices for them to adopt, and a pocket-sized handbook to keep their own record of work and financial transactions, along with key information such as the National helpline number.c.  At destination, field workers will engage migrants on rights, socialize MRC offerings and provide other critical support to them, including anything identified through the handbook. We will set up District migration resource centres, these district level units will facilitate personalized information services, advice and trainings for migrants and their families on availing benefits, legal rights, industry norms, and protective measures available. The resource centre will also act as a hub for worker protection outreach and dispatch services.4.  Research for worker protection:Evidence-based knowledge on sexual violence against female migrant workers across the textile and construction value chain, to enable informed strategy/intervention design and policy advocacy towards prevention of sexual violence. The study will identify the factors that enable sexual violence and amplify the experiences of female migrant workers including the root causes for non-reporting of such cases formally.
GAF_Dignity_Alliance_International_Suppo.8. COOPERATION: 8. CooperationDescribe the level of cooperation with other organisations and networks and explain how this cooperation helps achieve your goals (maximum 300 words):The MRC unites organisations and networks who will support the execution of the program. These organisations can be further categorized as Implementation Partners and Strategic Partners.Implementation Partners: these are organisations that complement Jan Sahass geographic reach and ability to provide direct support to migrant communities: We have currently partnered with 16 CBOs across 19 districts with a goal to work with ~40-45 CBOs across 40-45 districts. Jan Sahas held workshops and discussions with long-term partner CBOs (e.g., Yuva Vikas Mandal, Gramin Swavalamban Samiti, Progressive Society) to validate priorities and develop the MRC strategy. Leaders of long-term partner CBOs routinely join Jan Sahass internal workshops and meetings.Strategic partners: organisations which complement Jan Sahass strengths at the Project Monitoring Unit, include:Grant Application Form, July 1 2013141) Global Development Incubator (GDI): who helped co-create the concept of the MRC. Their expertise lies in building collaboratives and multi-stakeholder initiatives globally, including providing support on design and strategy. GDI has incubated or closely supported~40 multi-stakeholder initiatives, including the Global Fund to End Modern Slavery, Refugee Investment Network, Partnership for Economic Inclusion, and Co-impact. GDIs mandate is to co-develop and support operationalisation of the MRCs systems change strategy and pilots and provide support on governance and fundraising. 2) EdelGive Foundation: who bring expertise in anchoring cross-sectoral partnerships across the social, corporate, and government sectors. They have anchored collaborations such as The Collaborators for Transforming Education and The Coalition for Women Empowerment, and regularly facilitate cross-industry conversations on key social impact issues. Their mandate is to support partnerships, private sector engagement, fundraising, and governance. 3) Societal Platform: who bring expertise in developing public-good technology platforms for social causes. They have closely supported building technology platforms for Digital Green, Arghyam, and EkStep Foundation. Their mandate is to support the MRC in strengthening program structures and design using technology.
GAF_Dignity_Alliance_International_Suppo.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. ImpactWhat is the change you want to achieve from the overall project? (maximum 300 words):The change we wish to achieve from this project is reflected in our Vision and Goals:Vision: The MRCs vision is to end exploitative practices and dramatically reduce socio-economic vulnerability of migrant families across India.Strategic Goal 1: Social Security: strengthening inclusive social protection system and increasing access to benefits and entitlements for 2,40,000 migrant families and workers over 3 years.Implementation4,00,000 workers and their families registered for and are aware of the key social security schemes.2,40,000 receiving key benefits in 3 yearsSystems/advocacyDemonstrate a scalable, low-cost delivery model for governments to adopt. This would include stronger operations (e.g., reduced time for delivery, improved coverage, simpler registration) of key govt. agencies involved in delivery.Portability of key benefits across states.Establish clear ROI for large employers in terms of reduced cost of worker acquisition / retention through research. Grant Application Form, July 1 201315Strategic Goal 2: Responsible Recruitment: enabling responsible recruitment to improve living & working conditions of 1,00,000 workers over 3 years.Implementation1,00,000 responsibly recruited in 3 years by 15+ companies and industry associations.Systems/advocacyStronger compliance with key labour laws/norms (e.g., wages, living and working conditions) by 15+ large companies around worker welfare at sites and along the supply chain; setting an example for the rest of the industry. Strategic Goal 3: Worker Protection: building migrant workers agency, strengthening worker protection mechanisms and providing support to individuals suffering from labour and sexual exploitation to receive remedial and legal support, reducing forced labour by 60% in the region of project implementation in over 3 years.ImplementationWorker protection support available to 80% cases received on helpline and other modes of trackingSystems/advocacyEstablish a national migrant worker helpline that can be government/PPP-adopted.Improve state and central policies on safeguarding rights of workers, including textiles and construction specific policies10. EvaluationHow will progress be monitored and evaluated? (maximum 300 words):The process monitoring flow will consist of the following steps: 1.  Data entry / collection and analysis: Field Officers, MIS coordinators will collect and enter data. Monthly, Quarterly, Annual and SWAT Reports will be generated with data and field visit insights, led by MEL Manager. Reports will include recommendations on further research, rapid assessments, training needs and adaptation of strategy, led by the MEL Manager.2.  Report Dissemination & learnings: MEL team will share monthly and annually with management; district team leads and partner CBOs. Monthly and annual meetings will take place to share learnings, understand challenges and troubleshoot. Training will be carried out with specific teams, when required and annual refresher training will be provided when necessary. 3.  Senior Management Team (SMT) meetings: based on MEL and team meetings feedback, SMT will discuss major roadblocks, challenges, progress-check, and Grant Application Form, July 1 201316share success stories and learnings, and re-align on the way forward. The SMT will then formulate rapid assessments, research and advocacy plans. Process/ Implementation Evaluation: leveraging internal strengths of technology-based tools and real-time dashboards, we will undertake self-evaluations towards improvement of our delivery model and tracking system. As described in the MEL framework, progress on KPIs and activities will be monitored monthly and annually, and further SWAT teams will be formed to address bottlenecks such as conversion time of entitlements and drive fast fails.In the past, such process evaluations have helped to improve program performance, implementation rhythm and in mid-term corrective action in a phased manner  that is, learnings from one phase helping in next phase activities. We strongly believe this adaptability in program strategies and ground operations has been the key in the success of our interventions with highly dynamic communities such as migrants. The systemic changes will be evaluated based on comparative analysis of the government database / reports with our Social registry and analytics and third-party evaluations to map relevance, effectiveness, efficacy, impact and sustainability, in reducing exploitation and socio-economic vulnerability of migrant families and facilitation of safe migration.
GAF_Dignity_Alliance_International_Suppo.11. ADDITIONAL QUESTIONS/ Future Plans: 11. Future PlansHow will the grant influence the organisation and future plans? (maximum 300 words):The MRC has brought together components to contribute to nation-wide system changes.  The MRC envisions a deep level of engagement with all key stakeholders  communities, industry and government, enabling depth of experience and learnings. We believe that assets (e.g., industry assessment tools, research products), learnings (e.g., from pilots and scaling of interventions), and networks (e.g., of companies partnering with the MRC, some of whom will have global Grant Application Form, July 1 201317presence) developed through the course of the project by the MRC and its partners have significant potential for sharing, translation, & potentially replication to other geographies.Currently, from Oak Foundation we are seeking a contribution for interventions in the West Bengal, Mumbai and Delhi Corridor for over 3 years. This contribution would make Oak Foundation one of the joint largest funders of the MRC. The MRC considers the Oak Foundation as a key funder due to its specific commitment towards migrant communities and driving systems change in the sector. As the duration of the MRC is over 5 years, we intend to allocate the remaining funding from funds already raised from donors like Omidyar Network and Michael & Susan Dell Foundation (MSDF) and additional fundraising. Beyond 5 years, our target for sustainability and scale is adoption by the government boards (such as BOCW) and the private sector. Thus, moving away from the need for further philanthropic funding and towards 80% adoption by the private companies. We believe that large companies will see financial and reputational benefits of facilitating social security entitlements for their workers and will be willing to cover the costs of delivery. As a part of the consortium, we have multiple donors (MSDF, Godrej, Omidyar Network, H.T. Parekh Foundation) who will support us as our strategic partners, and alongside them we hope to have Oak Foundation represented on the strategic Board.

GAF_A_Centre_for_Peoples_Forestry_SuppoT.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT 5a. Tell us about your governance and leadership structures, as well as staff and volunteer base. Highlight any significant recent or expected future changes. If you have an explicit approach to increasing diversity and/or advancing race equity within the organisation, please tell us. (300 words):CPF is headed by the Board of Trustees (BOT), who are experts on Forests, Livelihoods and Gender and work on an honorary basis. The Board has eight Oak Application Form     5members and the Managing Trustee is elected by the Trustees. The Director is an ex officio secretary & convenor of the BOT meetings. The Board formulates policies, direction to the organization. All new projects and Financial Statements are approved by the BOT. Few of the Trustees are members of Performance Appraisal Committee (meets once a year), Program Review Committee and Finance Committee (meets twice a year). Board meetings take place twice a year and special meetings are conducted as per the requirement.Director leads the team and responsible for the functioning of the organization. Development of different policies and project proposals, reviewing the projects are some of the key responsibilities of the Director. The Managing Committee comprising of senior team meets once in a month to take decisions on projects and other organizational matters.CPF has Procurement & Disposal committee, Gratuity Trust Committee, Internal Complaints Committee and Grievance Redressal Committee. It has Finance, HR, Operations and Governance manuals along with Child Protection, Gender and Anti Sexual Harassment Policies.The present Director took over the charge from 1st October 2021 on retirement of previous Director.West Bengal Project team1. SPO-1: responsible for project deliverables, liaison with government officials and other stakeholders, develop resource and other communication material etc.,2. Programme Officer-MIS-1: responsible for maintaining project database (soft & hard copies) and analysing data on monthly basis, training to project coordinator on MIS, visit field areas3. Project Coordinators-5: 4 coordinators will be responsible for implementation of project activities in Ranibandh and 1 will be based at SandeshkhaliProject Officer-Marketing-1: develop market linkages for the NTFP products with supply and demand chain understanding 5b. Summarise the organisations history.  In addition, highlight 2-3 key achievements.Please keep this brief and list up to 3 key achievements as bullet points. Even though you may have many achievements, please share what is most relevant to the proposed grant. (300 words)CPF was established in the backdrop of realising the goal of forest dependent communities in the management of forest resources as per the National Forest Policy 1988. CPF got registered in August 2002. The organisation has mandated to work on other natural resources as part of the landscapes and ecosystems in which forests are a part.CPF worked with Government and civil society organization in promoting the Joint Forest Management, and later the Community Forest Management Oak Application Form     6programs. It worked with 680 Vanasamrakshana Samithis in 32 Forest Ranges with 32 NGO partners. They were spread over 12 districts in the three regions of undivided Andhra Pradesh, representing 80,800 households and protecting over 1,00,000 (one lakh) hectares of forest.CPF understood that forest-based livelihoods alone not sufficient for enhancing the incomes and conserving the natural resources. It was also realized that tribal communities were unable to access basic services and social security schemes because of remoteness and apathy of officials. This led CPF to work with communities and government on entitlements and sustainable NRM based livelihoods through community-based institutions.Key AchievementsI.      Agro-Ecologcial Practices and Water resource development4065 farmers following agroecological practices in an extent of 3000 acresPromotion of horticulture plantations among 500 farmers in 500 acres16569 acres of land was treated with land under cultivation increasing by 11% and ground water availability by 66%II.     Access to Entitlements5711 individuals accessed social security schemes, 6640 availed Crop loans, farm machineries, and subsidies and 8357 Job card holders received workINR 5.44 crores leveraged in 72 habitations for community-based infrastructure development in past six years (2015-21)III.    Facilitation of securing Forest Rights9460 IFR titles received for 20045 acres covering 535 villages 1350 CFR claims submitted and 183 CFR management plans prepared by Gramasabhas5c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and decide your approach? If you have undertaken a theory of change exercise, or if you are influenced by research, policy or your own organisations experience, please tell us about this.  Have you consulted with relevant stakeholders, including your communities and others experiencing the problem? Is there an intention to address equity, diversity and inclusion? (600 words):Alienation of tribals from the forest has dwindled their livelihoods, food security and increased poverty. It reduced their involvement in sustainable forest management and harvesting practices of NTFP.  This led to adverse impact on conservation of forest eco-system. Lack of awareness and skills to have constructive and collaborative engagement with government reduced access to avail rights and entitlements.Over two decades, CPF worked with indigenous and other resource poor communities in Andhra Pradesh, Telangana and Odisha. The organization facilitated the communities to access rights on forest resources and supported Oak Application Form     7them in sustainable natural resource management through promoting community institutions. This enabled them to reap the collective advantages of sustainable extraction and value addition of NTFP, participatory natural resource management and access entitlements from government.CPF undertakes works that aligns with its vision. Before planning any intervention, action research is undertaken to analyze and identify the change and roles to be played by CPF and other stakeholders. The intervention is planned in a collaborative approach with defined objectives and outcomes involving community in planning, implementing and monitoring, enabling them towards sustainability.CPF strategically works with government to build rapport between communities and concerned departments for leveraging funds for community needs. It appraises them about its work for possible replication.CPF strives to ensure equity and equality in its functioning with women playing equal role in all its interventions. It facilitates in building their capacities, gain access and ownership over resources and become decision-makers.A scoping study was conducted in West Bengal, while interacting with relevant stakeholders to comprehend the prevailing policies, programs and their implementation in proposed project locations.Based on the observations from the scoping study, CPF proposes to work in Ranibandh block, Bankura district of West Bengal because of its dense forest and high tribal population (Savara-PVTG, Santhal, Munda, Singh Sardar etc) with 47.1 % (Census, 2011). The main source of livelihood is agriculture, livestock and NTFP and majority are small and marginal farmers depending on rain fed agriculture. Though the district receives around 1400 mm rainfall, yet cultivation of crop primarily depends on constricted period of erratic rainfall. Due to lack of proper water harvesting structures, water percolation to the ground is minimal and irrigation facility is low. The farmers are predominantly into mono crop cultivation i.e., paddy. The farming practices are inorganic leading to high input cost and negative environmental impacts.The Sundarban estuary with mangrove forest is inhabited by the resource poor and vulnerable communities. Owing to historical reasons coupled with climatic extremities and natural calamities, it remains one of the extremely underdeveloped places with 34 % below poverty line. Livelihood depends on agriculture (24.37%), un-organized labour (36.35%), house hold industries (4.86%) and others (34.42%) including fishery, forest resource collection [1]. The inhabitants of the region are also extremely vulnerable in various physical and socio-economic indicators.In Sunderban, CPF propose to work on enhancing access of entitlements to communities in Sandeshkhali-I Block of North 24 Parganas District due to the high social vulnerability of the region with 25.95% of the population belonging to ST and 30.90% belonging to SC communities.CPF vision and past experience of working with tribal and resource poor communities and Oak foundations focus areas to support the indigenous communities in West Bengal will bring in synergy in advancing the rights, availing entitlements and livelihood development in the proposed area of intervention.Oak Application Form     8Oak Foundation funding will be used for facilitating the communities to adopt crop diversification through improved agriculture practices, enhance livelihoods and enable the communities to access their rights and entitlements.[1] Census, 2011, West Bengal State Climate Action Plan, 2021
GAF_A_Centre_for_Peoples_Forestry_SuppoT.7. OBJECTIVES: 7. OBJECTIVESThis is the most important part of your application, as it is your opportunity to explain what you want to achieve and what will be different because of your work. We understand that social and environmental change is complex and there are a multitude of factors that contribute to change. We want to understand how you define your role in the overall change you hope to make. You may find it helpful to discuss this with your Oak Programme Officer, and others in your own organisation.   7.a. ObjectivesList here up to 3 main objectives for this grant (one sentence per objective). Think of objectives as goals that can be achieved within the lifetime of the grant.  We encourage you to think of objective(s) that are ambitious but also achievable.  Overall objective / GoalImproving livelihoods of tribals, resource poor and other vulnerable communities through promoting sustainable natural resource management and enhancing access to entitlements by building linkages with the Government institutions in 25 forest fringe villages of Ranibandh block of Bankura district and 12 villages in Sandeshkhali-I block of North 24 Parganas.Specific Objectives1. Formation and strengthening the village level institutions/groups while ensuring women leadership in these institutions2. Promoting agro-ecological practices, crop diversification and water resource development for food & nutritional security amongst male and female farmers3. Enhancing access to alternative livelihoods among landless, resource poor and other forest dependent communities while keeping with special emphasis on women farmers4. Enabling project communities to access and avail their constitutional rights and entitlementsBackground and ContextGiven the experience of working in watershed project locations, CPF propose to work in the watershed areas in Randibandh block of Bankura district Oak Application Form     9covering 25 villages of Ranibandh, Barikul and Rautora Gram Panchayats. The Integrated Watershed Management Programme, West Bengal was implemented in the proposed project locations in the year 2011-12 covering a total geographical area of 8819 ha of which the total treatable area was 5398 ha. It was observed that the benefits of creation of these watershed structures could not be sustain due to lack of emphasis on improved agriculture practices, creation and strengthening of farmers institutions and bringing in convergence of various government schemes for the benefit of tribal and other resource poor households.The present project aims to address the above-mentioned gaps. And it would demonstrate how the watershed projects in the forest fringe villages could be taken to the next level to reap the benefits and also sustain the initiatives through community participation.The Sundarban estuary with mangrove forest is inhabited by the resource poor and vulnerable communities, owing to historical reasons coupled with climatic extremities and natural calamities. The inhabitants of the region are also extremely vulnerable in various physical and socio-economic indicators including infrastructure, food security, healthcare, education, drinking water and sanitation. It was observed that, livelihoods based on natural resources alone will not effectively sustain the people of the region. CPF proposes to work on enhancing access to entitlements for communities covering 12 villages of Boyermari-I, Boyermani-II and Hatgachi Gram Panchayats of Sandeshkhali-I Block of North 24 Parganas District.Thus, the project has immense potential for scaling up and replication in other socio-economically vulnerable regions of West Bengal.CPFs RoleThe organization works with community institutions and capacitates them in appropriate skills as well as federates them at different levels for reaping collective advantages with regard to accessing their rights on forest resources and supports them in sustainable natural resource management including forest resources. Sustainable extraction of Non timber forest produce, value addition at the community level, participatory resource monitoring, water resource development, facilitating agro ecological practices in their lands, and helping them to access entitlements and proper services from the government departments are some of the activities the organization undertakes, to address the problems of the communities.While recognizing that women lack decision making and negotiation skills, mobility, identity and self -esteem and access to and control over resources and assets, CPF focuses on building their leadership through all its interventions.Primary stakeholders are the tribal and resource poor communities who mostly belong to the small and marginal farmer categorySecondary stakeholders are the various government departments, traders and other service providers (who are engaged to provide certain services to the community).1. Formation and strengthening the village level institutions/groupsa. Formation and strengthening of Tribal Farmers Service Centre (TFSC)Oak Application Form     10The Tribal Farmers Service Centres will be formed with two representatives from each small group as committee members. CPF ensures that 50 percent are women in these committees with leadership role in the committee. The centers are managed by the committee and they provide services viz., Knowledge services, information about government schemes, providing agricultural implements on minimum rental basis. The amount collected will be used to sustain the Centre. Major Implements will be purchased with minor contribution from the project farmers.b. Formation and strengthening of Village Coordination Groups (VCGs)CPF initiated a concept called Village Coordination Groups (VCGs) during the year 2016. In the VCGs, two members from each of the existing CBOs (one female and one male) are grouped at the habitation level along with Sarpanch and one ward member. The purpose is to facilitate to access entitlements to all eligible individuals and also seek support for community needs. Awareness regarding various new government schemes, policies for tribals including Forest Rights Act also discussed in the VCGs. VCG meets once in a month and discusses about the follow-up to be done with regard to the access/petitions submitted. It not only supports the individual CBOs on issues identified but also discusses about the community level issues and requirements such as  repair to PHC centre, approach road, drinking water etc.At each of the 37 project habitations VCGs will be formed. Women representatives from CBOs will become leaders in the VCGs formed. Thus, VCG will contribute in filling the gap between the communities, Panchayats and block officials.The VCGs provide services to all eligible households (as per baseline) access different government schemes of West Bengal like Khadya Saathi Scheme (RKSY-1 & 2), Duara Sarkar (campaign on 18 schemes with delivery at door step) etc., and Community level entitlements.Activities1. Formation of 25 Tribal Farmer Service Centre (TFSC) and 37 Village Coordination Groups2. Capacitating Village Institution members on their roles and responsibilities, book keeping, engagement with the government departments etc.3. Awareness building amongst project communities on importance of participation in Gram Sabhas and other decision-making process of local governing bodies.2. Promoting agro-ecological practices, crop diversification and water resource development for food & nutritional security.In 25 project habitations, demonstration plots will be established @ one per habitation. Farmers Field schools will be conducted to progressive farmers, who in turn will follow the practices in their fields and also motivate, teach and encourage other farmers to practice the methods learnt. In kharif season Farmers field schools will be conducted 4 times at pre sowing, sowing, during crop period and at harvest time. In the FFS both agro-ecological and crop specific practices will be taught and demonstrated. The main crop in the habitation will be focused.Oak Application Form     111000 farmers will be reached out and the extent covered will be 500 acres (@ 0.5 acre/farmer)Activities1. Establishment of the demo plots for promoting agro- ecological practices among the farmers 2. Provide training and support to the farmers in preparation and usage of bio pesticides and fertilizers3. Promotion of pulses, oilseeds and vegetables in kharif/ rabi seasons4. Promoting kitchen garden in project households5. Promoting SRI method in paddy cultivation.6. Capacitating communities to take up maintenance of the watershed structures3. Enhancing access to alternative livelihoods among landless, resource poor and other forest dependent communities.Activities1. NTFP value addition and marketing of Sal leaf plate making, etc.,2. Promoting backyard poultry4. Enabling project communities to access and avail their constitutional rights and entitlementsActivities:1. Building awareness and supporting project communities, in availing government services and entitlements2. Interface meetings between communities and line departments3. Building awareness on Forest Rights Act  2006 for tribal and other forest dwelling communities to protect their customary and constitutional rights, natural resources and traditional knowledge.  7.b.
