GAF_A_Centre_for_Peoples_Forestry_SuppoT.8. COOPERATION: 8. COOPERATION  How will you involve others in your approach to achieving change? If you are planning to engage in partnerships with other organisations, communities, people with lived experience, academics or secure the support of key individuals, please tell us about this.  Why are these the right partners to engage with?  Is there anything new about how you are choosing to work - for example, new partnerships or an approach that is different to how you usually work? (300 words):Participation and collaboration is central to the way CPF functions. CPF follows a constructive, critical and collaborative approach with Communities and CSOs for implementing all its activities and projects. Depending on the nature of intervention, CPF had sought / worked with experts, academic institutions and networks. This has helped in not only realising project goals but also established CPF as a transparent organisation.In West Bengal, CPF had already began its interactions with relevant stakeholders including government as it is paramount in the smooth grounding of project interventions. Through the scoping study, Pradan which is working in the Bankura district is identified as a possible collaborator for livelihood interventions and discussions were held with their team in this regard. Besides this, other CSO representatives were consulted extensively to understand the relevant issues and the proposal was vetted seeking their inputs. Consultations with various stakeholders will be continued.One of the major stakeholders in implementation of the project are the local governing bodies including the gram panchayats. The project envisions to engage gram panchayats at various levels of the project especially in providing access to rights and entitlements to the project communities. The various government departments especially the agriculture department, panchayat and rural development department will be engaged in leveraging the government schemes and programs that aligns with the project objectives. The project will engage with organisations providing research and extension-based services such as Krishi Vignana Kendra (KVK). Will take support of Ms. Raktima Mukhopadhyay-Ex Trustees of CPF and Prof. SB Roy-Chairman Oak Application Form     14IBRAD in conducting research in relation to the project such as environment, forest conservation etc.
GAF_A_Centre_for_Peoples_Forestry_SuppoT.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING This section is twofold. Please tell us:a) Monitoring and evaluation. How will you know if you are achieving your objectives? Please describe briefly how you will know if you are making progress and if what you are doing is working. If you have a formal monitoring and evaluation system and if you plan to collect indicator data or conduct an external evaluation, please provide details here.b) Learning. Please tell us if there anything in particular that you are hoping to learn more about or test through this grant.(300 words):Planning, Monitoring and Evaluation system of CPF are based on participatory approaches. The project monitoring system is built on expected outcomes and impact. It assists in tracing the project progress towards achieving the objectives and undertake mid-term corrections as required.Before grounding the project, baseline survey will be undertaken and MIS developed accordingly. The monitoring formats are designed as per outcome indicators. The project information is collected at regular intervals and maintained. The quality of data collection is ensured by the Project officers in the field and later analyzed by the MIS Officer. This is reviewed in a timely manner by the program team. The analyzed reports are shared with stakeholders.Qualitative indicators are captured and documented through regular monitoring visits by project implementing team and Senior Management Team. Monthly planning and review meetings are held at field office and also at Head Office for all the projects. Mid-term and end term evaluation of the projects are being done as per the donor requirement and also keeping in view long term vision of the organization.Learning: Over two decades, while implementing the projects, it was understood that forest-based livelihoods alone are not sufficient for enhancing incomes and conserving natural resources. CPF moved towards promoting agro-ecological practices, horticulture and water resource development. Tribal communities were unable to access basic services and social security schemes because of remoteness and apathy of officials. This led CPF to work with communities and the government on entitlements and sustainable NRM based livelihoods through community-based institutions.Through this grant opportunity from the Oak Foundation to work in the regions of physical and socio-economic vulnerabilities of West Bengal, CPF is hoping to establish that its approach of enhancing income, access to entitlements and promoting agro-ecological practices though community-based institutions in forest fringe villages can be replicated. Oak Application Form     17Questions raised by Programme OfficerRationale about the choice of these districts/ blocks over othersHow will the poor implementation of the FRA which is to a large extent driven by the resistance from the Forest Dept be tackled by CPF?Aside from the secondary literature review, did CPF conduct direct learning or scoping exercises to the proposed locations?What is the goal of the project?Can you give an idea about these interventions are built on what is existing? eg are there community institutions on the ground already?SHG groups are there but not strongWater User groups are inactiveFarmers institutions are to be established / constitutedPlease explain the feasibility of these interventions  eg what is the status of land ownership of these communities, water availability, access to agri inputs and markets?What is the present status of management rights of the communities on the community forests? is  this for Bankura ?In the Sundarbans, the tribal communities are often not regarded as indigenous  what will be strategy to enable them to have FR? In general, the FD is very powerful here  how would CPF facilitate the organisation of communities to resist this dominanceCan you describe the key indicators that would be studied during the baseline? Are you planning a direct baseline commissioned by CPF or would it be established through existing secondary data? Questions raised by Trustee, President and Director-India ProgrammeWhat were the factors that led to the collapse of the networks that existed in West Bengal 5-6 years ago?West Bengal has not been identified as a tribal state with the tribal population of about 5% of the total population. NGOs who are working with tribals are focusing on health, education and livelihoods in a welfare approach rather than rights approach. In Sundarbans area the government is focusing on development based on tourism and environment. Sundarbans area because of its porous borders with Bangladesh the cross-border influx of the population has become a security concern for the government and resulting in discouraging the civil society engagement in the region.What would be unique value add of Centre for Peoples Forestry in West Bengal? How will it contribute to the work of other organizations currently working in West Bengal on the same issue?The unique value addition of CPF in West Bengal is its collaborative approach in planning its   interventions involving consultations with all the stakeholders. CPF share its plans and budgets with the government and other stakeholders to mitigate the misconceptions that people have about the financial Oak Application Form     18transparency and in the process CPF gains the trust of the government and other stakeholders.  Depending on the nature of intervention, CPF works with experts, academic institutions and CSO networks. CSO representatives were consulted extensively to understand the relevant issues in West Bengal and the proposal was vetted seeking their inputs. Consultations with various stakeholders will be continued.  This approach helps CPF in realizing the project goals and also establishes CPF as a transparent organization ensuring the CSOs engage with CPF to achieve the common goals by sharing the collective as well as the specialized capacities of all involved stakeholders.CPF worked with 52 NGOs and Vanasmakhya - network of 680 Vana Samrakshana Samitis while facilitating Joint Forest Management and Community Forest Management in undivided Andhra Pradesh and Odisha.CPF would network with organization working for tribals and their entitlements in West Bengal also with the vast experience it has gained over the years.Why does CPF wish to work in West Bengal; how well is CPF placed in terms of connections with key departments, peers, staffing etc.? What are some of the factors you consider key for CPF to successfully establish the work in West Bengal?CPF has been aiming to work towards restoration of the forest ecosystem in the Eastern Ghats[1]. In the process, organization is expanding its operational areas and CPF chose to work in West Bengal for the same reason. Because of CPF work earlier with Forest Department, we could easily establish contacts with the Forest Department and also with other departments in West Bengal.While doing the scoping study, CPF contacted IBRAD, PRADAN, CRY, Oxfam  India, CINI, EKJUT, WWF, and researchers working in West Bengal to understand the tribal livelihoods and also the civil society and government engagement on entitlements.CPF has well experienced team to ground a project of this scale and nature in other states and who can mentor the new recruits and provide necessary hand holding support to them. CPF Trustees with varied experience in forestry, environment, climate change, livelihoods and entitlements will guide us in grounding and implementation of the project.Are you expecting other funders to co-fund during the four years of this request?Yes, but not in the first two years of the project. The present BftW supported project cycle is coming to closure by 2024. We will begin the dialogue with them to support part of our West Bengal work from now onwards. We are also planning to approach other donor agencies including government (NABARD) which have shown inclination to work with CPF.  [1] And to realise this goal, a proposal was submitted to HCL last year and CPF reached amongst the top 6 organizations in the bidding process in which 300 organizations participated.Oak Application Form     19

GAF_Baikunthapur_Tarun_Sangha_AmpliCommu.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 6. Context (The context section should not exceed two pages.)6a. Describe the organisation (include information on leadership, governance, structure and staff) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):BTS-Baikunthapur Tarun Sangha is a not-for-profit organization working for development support services including advancement of social equity and good governance practices in the society. Undertaking participatory action research, enhancing capacities for participatory development work and engaging with the state in advocacy of voices of disadvantaged identities are also some of core domains of BTS-work. Advancing social equity and good governance are two core interests in pursuit of its organizational mission of democratizing development processes. Established in 1982-03, BTS operates in the 30 coastal backward villages in the Sundarbans in the district of South 24 Parganas, west Bengal. The organization believes that equality of opportunities and the right to participation are essential to establish an inclusive society. In pursuance of its mandate, BTS engages in a different range of development initiatives, including participatory research, Grant Application Form, July 1 20135capacity building and direct engagement with the community in vulnerable situation to amplify peoples need in challenges for advocating rights of the excluded to live a sustainable life of dignity and choice.BTS is registered as a Society under Societies Registration Act 1961, bearing Registration Number S/39842 of 1982-83, registered with Registrar of Societies, Firms & N/T Corpns., Govt. of West Bengal. The Society is governed by a Managing Committee comprising 9 members: Mr. Kamal Ranjan Maiti (President), Mr. Susanta Giri (Secretary), Mr. Haradhan Sau(Asstt. Secretary) , Mr. Haripada Jana (Treasurer), Ms. Manju Rani Maity (Member), Mr. Ranjit Naiya(Member, Mr. Ajit Kumar Khatua(Member), Mrs. Pratima Naiya(Member and Mrs. Ashalata Das (Member).The staff includes 46 people, headed by the Chief Functionary/Secretary working as Executive Director. The organization has one Executive Director, one Program Advisor, 2 Field Project Operators, 3 Accountants.6b. Describe the financial situation (include information on annual operating costs, fundraising strategy, reserves and debts) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):The financial health of BTS has been relatively steady and stable over the last 25 years of its existence. BTS has gradually increased its turnover in accordance with the initiatives taken up. In recent years, the annual operating costs of the organization has been in the range of Rs. 1 - 2 Crores per year, commensurate with the revenue generated from various local fundraising efforts including CSR partnerships.BTS is a CBO (Community Based Organisation ) giving emphasis of local fundraising and resource optimization to have its sustainability in development journey.6c. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):In 1978, some young people established a club for recreational activities for the youth in Kultali block in the district of South 24 Parganas, West Bengal. Again, a major flood that hit the island in 1982 which made youngsters to undertake a series of relief measures, physically helping victims to reach safer places, pleading the government and administration for relief support and organizing the relief camps. This was the turning point in the history of the Club, Baikunthapur Tarun Sangha. The youngsters were struck by the extent of poverty amongst the people on one hand and total lack of apathy and support from other quarters. They realized the vulnerability of the people and the need to contribute towards organized community development. Thus, they resolved to work towards building better facilities for the Grant Application Form, July 1 20136people in need but who didn't know how to obtain. Gradually BTS realized the way it was functioning was not the proper one to make sustainable changes in peoples life. The pioneers involved in the organization had gone through a series of self-evaluation process and felt the concept of people-oriented development process. Next, BTS took up the policy to initiate interventions for community development ensuring peoples involvement and participation of other social institutions like local self-Government (PRIs), youth clubs, external support agencies and other ones. Thus, Baikunthapur Tarun Sangha, popularly known as BTS came into existence and got registration/certification from the Govt of West Bengal under West Bengal Society Registration Act, 1961; FCRA under MHA, Govt of India and IT Act. 1961.Child Care & Child Education through BTS-Path Bhavan School & Pre-School Centres (Creches) Child Sponsorship Program for poor school children in acute need. Quality Education for ICDS Children in 32 ICDS Centres of Kultali Block & Patharpratima block. Setting up Children's Resource Libraries & Computer Literacy Lab Organic /Bio-Farming initiatives among 15,889 farm-families in 30 coastal villages to check /reduce Chemical farming & promoting bio-fertilizers & Bio-pesticides, set up Community Seed Banks with Country Seeds etc. Promoted Renewable Solar Lights among 5000+ school Children to replace conventional Kerosene Lamps, electrifying 6 school hostels in 3 neighboring coastal blocks Kultali, Patharpratima, Namkhana in the district of South 24 Parganas, West Bengal. Post-disaster (Flood & Cyclone) reliefs to approximately 36,000+ victims in 3 neighboring island/coastal blocks like Kultali, Patharpratima & Mathurapur-II, Namkhana, Canning-I, Basanti S 24 Parganas District. Livelihood Supports to approximately 9250 poor women in need by promoting handicrafts, poultry, Goatery, Duckkery, etc. 922 Safe Institutional Deliveries at BTS-Rural Community Hospitals along with providing 10,000 people to OPD Clinic facilities(ANC, PNC, Pathological Tests, USG, Medical supports through Mobile camps and Mobile Boat Dispensary etc.Strategic Planning along with PVCA & MLP Process for a better tomorrow has initiated by BTS.6d. Describe the current strategy of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):The strategy undertaken by the organization is that Participation and involvement of all sections of the village community. Micro Level Planning is to amplify community voice towards sustainability planning and development of the vulnerable people living in the economically backward and ecologically fragile geographies in Sundarbans.BTS has been functioning through a community-led strategic planning process to place their basic needs along with security and sustainability. Through the Participation of micro level planning and its implementation, BTS has been giving emphasis on peoples capacity building towards need assessment to reduce their vulnerabilities. We have also developed a prioritizing list (Prioritization of alarming Issues, Targeted People with vulnerabilities, Proposed Solutions/Change, Potential Stakeholders analysis, Resources raising & utilization , impact studies/story telling or social reflection etc.).Grant Application Form, July 1 201376e. GAF_A_Aangan_Trust_Childproofing_Climate.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT 5a. Tell us about your governance and leadership structures, as well as staff and volunteer base. Highlight any significant recent or expected future changes. If you have an explicit approach to increasing diversity and/or advancing race equity within the organisation, please tell us. (300 words):Aangan is governed by an all-women 4 -member Trustee Board, including the founder, and current CEO. The Trustee Board meets quarterly and signs off on major decisions, internal policies, annual plans, and budgets. We have an Advisory Board of 5 women and 2 men who are subject experts and bring a wide range of expertise and experience  Strategic planning, finance and fundraising, communication, etc. This Board meets at least 3 times a year. We currently have an 11-member Senior leadership team, with 3 women at the Director level and 8 Program Heads (7 women and one man).  This year we do expect to expand our senior leadership team in keeping with our work expansion. We are currently a team of 60 people with diverse backgrounds, experience and expertise working in 6 States at present. Our full-time field teams are supported by community mobilizers who work on a part-time basis and are residents of the communities where we work. This number fluctuates based on team and program needs. Our community-based child harm prevention model is led by groups of women volunteers trained and supported by us. They are not volunteers in the usual sense of the word, since it is not the organization they align with, but rather the mission of child protection. This year we have 6000 women volunteers across our areas of work. Aangan is an equal opportunity employer. We dont discriminate based on gender, caste, religion, sexual orientation, age, disability, etc. either during recruitment or appraisals and promotions. We do practice affirmative action with regard to gender and hire more women than men across levels. We believe this is appropriate for an organization that promotes gender equity in its work and programming, besides being practical given most of our interface is with adolescent girls and with women.Oak Application Form     6 5b. Summarise the organisations history.  In addition, highlight 2-3 key achievements.Please keep this brief and list up to 3 key achievements as bullet points. Even though you may have many achievements, please share what is most relevant to the proposed grant. (300 words)Mission:Aangan strengthens child protection systems to ensure vulnerable children are supported to stay in school, protected from trafficking, child marriage, hazardous work, violence, and exploitation. Our 5-year goal is to make childrens safety a crosscutting issue across sectors. History:2002-2013: Working with child survivors in state-run rescue homes (CCIs). Using a first of its kind Monitoring Tool co-created with UNICEF India we audited CCIs across 16 states to provide strategic inputs on improving standards of care.  Here we understood the importance of preventing harm at the source and started shifting focus accordingly.2009-2015: Understanding that vulnerable children came from vulnerable families and communities, we initiated community-based programs for children, working with families and local authorities, starting in Mumbai and expanding across Maharashtra, Bihar, Odisha, West Bengal, and Uttar Pradesh.2015-2017: This culminated in PACT Parents and Children against Trafficking/Harm ) program that trained community women and leveraged their knowledge to prevent child harm in their communities with a 360-degree view of child safety.2018-2022: Building on PACT  Hotspot to Safe-spot was a district-wide demonstration model in 5 districts (Rajasthan, Bengal, Jharkhand, UP, Bihar), bringing community women volunteers and key authorities (police, education, urban administration) together to create regular dialogue platforms focused on child safety. These resulted in strategies like regular community safety audits shared with police; a family follow-up system for irregular/absent school children; maintaining migrating family registers with GPs. Achievements:Successful Advocacy with Government:oThe state-wide Suraksha Sakhi scheme launched by Rajasthan Police in 2021, is an expansion of Aangan's child-oriented community policing model demonstrated in Bharatpur.Child Safety through the HotSpot to Safespot ModelCommunity volunteers across 5 districts gathered hyperlocal child harm and risk data that informed targeted interventions implemented with authorities that led to ~19K school re-enrolments and averting ~1,600 child marriagesOak Application Form     75c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and decide your approach? If you have undertaken a theory of change exercise, or if you are influenced by research, policy or your own organisations experience, please tell us about this.  Have you consulted with relevant stakeholders, including your communities and others experiencing the problem? Is there an intention to address equity, diversity and inclusion? (600 words):Global evidence suggests that vulnerable groups such as children are at heightened risk of being exploited in the aftermath of climate disasters. According to ILO, 70 million children are impacted by climate disasters globally every year.[1] Losses incurred during disasters often push families towards dangerous adaptive strategies - migration, taking children out of school, marrying them off, sending them to work, etc. These survival measures, along with the impact of disaster itself profoundly impacts a child's life, exposing her to a plethora of immediate and long-term risks. Moreover, if the frequency of disasters is high, the cycle of risks perpetuates.  West Bengal, with a history of climate vulnerability and 15 districts susceptible to extreme climate events, has witnessed multiple risk cycles. The issue that was alarming to begin with has been exacerbated owing to rapid climate change. Since 2019, Bengal has faced three major tropical cyclones - Bulbul, Amphan and Yaas. Aangan has worked in N 24 Parganas since 2017, demonstrating a community-based child harm prevention model to address child trafficking, child marriage and child labour, issues already established as endemic to the area. We work closely with community women volunteer groups who gather hyperlocal data and information and work with stakeholders and families on finding solutions. We are therefore privy to how child harm and risks are exacerbated manifold because of the frequent recurrence of serious climate events in this region and have also worked with community groups towards solutions. Our experience shows: Medium to Long-term aftermath of disasters on families and children:oDegradation and salinity of agricultural land and coastal erosion has forced changes in livelihood and sustenance patterns and loss of livelihood leading to migration (sometimes leaving children behind) and increased child labour: In a joint initiative with GPs, 14744 families were identified by community groups as being forced to migrate for work and were provided with key information about safe practicesoChildren dropping out of school and a change in perception of the relevance of education: 7972 children at risk of dropping out were supported with remedial classes and re-enrolled in schoolOak Application Form     8oIncreased child marriages: community groups prevented 429 child marriagesoChild labour  children are entering the work force younger and are also in hazardous work: 10698 children in or at risk of child labour pulled out of child labour and linked back to schooloAnecdotal data from community women and from children (particularly girls) points to an increase in trafficking in the guise of offers for marriage and workoIncrease in the number of child-headed families: 589 child-headed families were identified and brought under the supervision of community groups State governments set operational priorities during disaster response which determine the allocation of resources and response strategies for the whole state. Within this its particularly important for the approach at the district-level to be sensitive to the needs of children.  Unfortunately, this is not the case. State and district-level disaster management plans in Bengal dont say much about children. In S24 Parganas plans there is mention of a need for psychological support to vulnerable groups including children, and the N24 Parganas plans briefly mention children as a group in reference to disaster awareness and preparedness drives at schools (pre-disaster) and food and clothing requirement at the relief camps (post-disaster). Child and women's safety are briefly referred to under Law and Order Safety Measures.  Our experience shows its urgent that child protection work be embedded inside resilience building and risk reduction as a part of addressing climate change. This is the gap we seek to address [1] https://www.ilo.org/manila/public/pr/WCMS_558093/lang--en/index.htm
GAF_A_Aangan_Trust_Childproofing_Climate.7. OBJECTIVES: 7. OBJECTIVESThis is the most important part of your application, as it is your opportunity to explain what you want to achieve and what will be different because of your work. We understand that social and environmental change is complex and there are a multitude of factors that contribute to change. We want to understand how you define your role in the overall change you hope to make. You may find it helpful to discuss this with your Oak Programme Officer, and others in your own organisation.   Oak Application Form     97.a. ObjectivesList here up to 3 main objectives for this grant (one sentence per objective). Think of objectives as goals that can be achieved within the lifetime of the grant.  We encourage you to think of objective(s) that are ambitious but also achievable.  1. Communities most affected by serious climate events will have increased understanding of the impact these events and the ensuing survival strategies that they adopt have on children and will work on solutions for safeguarding children along with relevant local authorities (schools, GPs) 2. Generating the evidence for and then developing a framework of the key child protection issues and indicators relevant for inclusion in state/district disaster risk reduction plans in partnership with affected communities 3. A network of CSOs working on issues of climate change, community resilience, child welfare, etc, will collaborate to advocate with the state and other relevant entities about the need for protocols, resources, and personnel and financial allocations for child safeguarding in the context of disaster.7.b. Expected Outcomes (bullet points):What do you expect will change because of this grant? What does success look like? List here the main outcomes you hope to achieve or make significant contributions towards with this grant, and for whom.  If you have concrete targets, please also list them here. Outcomes describe significant changes for people, communities, organisations or systems. Some examples are changes in policies and legislation; changes in knowledge, awareness, attitudes, beliefs, behaviours or social norms; changes in capacities, level of influence, agency or access to services. Please refer to the guidance for additional examples.Objective 1:Long-term OutcomesoEvidence of reduction or prevention of child harm (in the immediate and extended aftermath of a disaster) against key risks as identified and articulated in consultation with the community and local system.Mid-term OutcomesCommunities have the ability to advocate for and institute mechanisms to action and/or strengthen local solutions jointly with the GP and other officials directly addressing the key harms prioritizedIncreased engagement of the system (GP) and other formal actors in preventing and responding to child safety during, before and after a climatic disasterChildren have increased knowledge, strategies to recognise risk and early warning signs of harm to themselves and peers during and after disaster.Oak Application Form     10 Objective 2:Long Term OutcomesoA framework of child protection indicators for climate hazard areas in partnership with affected communities.Mid-term OutcomesCommunities are able to identify and articulate survival strategies engaged by community members that are dangerous for children before, during and after disaster that they want to prioritize so that harm can be prevented or mitigated Objective 3:Long Term OutcomesoA collaborative network of CSOs is active and working towards joint advocacy for the inclusion of child safety indicators in District and State Disaster PlansMid Term OutcomesA system of regular collaboration established with organisations across sectors operational in disaster prone areas to build a common consensus of indicators that safeguard children in areas of climatic disasters. 7.c. Activities and timeframe (bullet points):List in bullet points the main types of activities that you plan to to carry out to achieve your expected outcomes. Please keep these at a high level and and dont include the full list of every activity you plan to carry out, instead, concentrate on the type of activities this grant will fund. Activities with the Local Systems:Regular and ongoing advocacy with GP members to re-orient them  othe gaps in the local and district disaster risk reduction plan with regard to children. oon the risks identified and prioritized by the community specifically with regard to children  oon the role of the community resource groups and facilitate regular meetings between them and the community at existing forums.Activities with Children:Community Resource Groups trained to; oto establish school and community level safety networks for children and adolescents  orun sessions/conversations and meetings with children and adolescents to build their awareness of contextual risks, understand and build safety plans to safeguard oensure that children and adolescents have regular systems to share, report and voice their concerns and issues to the larger community and local stakeholders osupport adolescents in co-designing and actioning solutions for themselves and their peers Activities under Objective 2Gram Panchayats supported  oto host platforms and forums to engage with the community members to discuss prioritised risks identified by them oto organize awareness initiatives to share information on existing schemes, entitlements and services that can benefit families  Oak Application Form     12oto act on initiatives to prevent and mitigate the harm jointly with the community resource groups Data, evidence, best practices collected at a GP and block level against child protection indicators that reflect the impact of community based solutions for children Share data and evidence with block level officials risks averted and children and families made safer as a result of the joint initiatives between GPs, other officials and the community Activities under Objective 3identify and collaborate with CSOs working in climate hazard areas through individual and groups meetingsfacilitate regular workshops and consultations with CSOs to share best practices, models of interventions and potential resource sharing mechanisms lead the development of child safety indicators and joint outcomes for the collaborative of CSOs to agree upon and use.
GAF_A_Aangan_Trust_Childproofing_Climate.8. COOPERATION: 8. COOPERATION  How will you involve others in your approach to achieving change? If you are planning to engage in partnerships with other organisations, communities, people with lived experience, academics or secure the support of key individuals, please tell us about this.  Why are these the right partners to engage with?  Is there anything new about how you are choosing to work - for example, new partnerships or an approach that is different to how you usually work? (300 words):For children to be safe, multiple actors across sectors must be involved, especially in climate hazard zones where the survival strategies of family/community impact children directly. 1. Partnering with community: It is the primary partnership because:oHow families cope with disaster affects children.oCommunities must understand child harm in all its dimensions to determine priorities as stakeholders.oNarrative change is needed for harm that has been normalized/seems inevitableoCo-creating solutions with community is sustainable Year 1 focuses on community engagement through stakeholder mobilization, for exampleSHG groups, children, youth, Krishi Sabhas, and Gram Sabhas. Oak Application Form     13By Q4, communities will select a Community Resource Group (GP-level) as a key agent of change for the remainder of the project.This strategy builds on our successful evidence-based model.  2. Partnering with CSOs: Collaborating with organizations in affected districts to build an advocacy movement for inclusion of child safeguarding (indicators, and resources) with the State and other relevant private entities.   Y1: informal meetingsY2: formalized through convening joint workshops and sharing and learning sessionsY3: developing joint course of action which may include generating evidence of best practice 3. Partnering with Local Authorities: Building on learnings from ground-level, we will aim for informal and/or formal cooperation with GPs, schools and other local functionaries to build platforms to hear from and about children concerning safety as well as to find solutions and mitigate risks. Solutioning is a key activity of the project as it builds evidence for best practices. 4. Engagement with Influencers: Involving other actors, including subject experts, government and non-government functionaries, and media through the course of project, to build broader consensus and endorsement for the generated evidence to raise child safety as an important issue that needs addressing in the context of climate change and towards advocacy with the State.
GAF_A_Aangan_Trust_Childproofing_Climate.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING This section is twofold. Please tell us:a) Monitoring and evaluation. How will you know if you are achieving your objectives? Please describe briefly how you will know if you are making progress and if what you are doing is working. If you have a formal monitoring and evaluation system and if you plan to collect indicator data or conduct an external evaluation, please provide details here.b) Learning. Please tell us if there anything in particular that you are hoping to learn more about or test through this grant.(300 words):Oak Application Form     14A mixed-method approach comprising tools to measure knowledge levels, actions undertaken and the operationalization of hyper-local action plans will be developed and deployed.- We will use monitoring trackers for different stakeholders that capture key outputs. The tools include: Official Register Tracker, Community Resource Group Tracker, Minutes of Meetings format, Out-of-School Children and Attendance Tracker.- To assess their knowledge, attitudes and capabilities to respond and gauge their improvement of awareness on CS (Child Safety)- signs, laws and services- a baseline, midline and endline survey will be administered.- Case Study Tracker captures qualitative data theme-wise. Key Indicators for:  Objective 1% Improvement in perception of community about CS % Increase in agency and confidence of resource group members% Increase in actionable knowledge among group members% Increase in children attending school regularly (>=75%)% Increase in child harm cases averted out of the identified Objective 2Improved prioritization and willingness of GP to improve child supervision and family resilience % GPs adopting CS & well-being interventions in disasterA proof of concept for the demonstrated model by Aangan, which identifies best practices and recommendations for improving CS in disaster for advocacy purposes Objective 3# of CSOs in agreement to include a CS lens in their programmatic outcomes and indicators. Learning:The more significant aspect of MEL is the learning that will contribute to strengthening the state/district systems to better provide for children in the emerging climate-driven crisis. The project will answer the following key questions:  Oak Application Form     15- What are the risks (different from family-level risks) prioritized by communities for actioning, and how they hold themselves and local authorities accountable?- What mechanisms work to ensure sustained dialogue with resulting actions?- How does CS become relevant to and shared responsibility for CSOs building community resilience/risk reduction/adaptation
GAF_A_Aangan_Trust_Childproofing_Climate.10. RISKS AND CHALLENGES: 10.  RISKS AND CHALLENGESWhat are the risks or barriers that might prevent you from achieving your outcomes and how will you address these?  What are your opportunities?We understand that achieving long-lasting and meaningful change is hard and we expect that the work you want to do will mean taking risks.  We encourage you to be open to telling us these, as well as how you will address these risks.  If some of your outcomes are risky, are there any incremental achievements that you could identify? (300 words):1. The Occurrence of Serious Climate Events: this is always a possibility as this is an extremely high-risk region. As our experience shows, this changes or at least delays project plans as the work on the ground necessarily shifts focus to crisis management. Year 1 needs community engagement which is not at all feasible should such an issue arise. The tragic flip side is of course that one gets to build evidence- it just may not be with community involvement. 2. Community Push-back: Many child harms that occur are a result of survival strategies families adopt  for example child labor, or leaving children without appropriate care due to migration. Communities are more able to have these honest conversations when real alternatives exist. Sometimes these are possible through linkage to state support, schemes and programs  these are strategies that we have used in the past and will use again. They require government cooperation too- which can also be tricky to negotiate, especially if it is not an area of the governments focus. 3. Lack of Interest from State/District: The States buy-in will depend on how relevant the issue of child protection is for them, especially true for 2023-24 in the run-up to the general election. This will also impact what they prioritize in the district with regard to schemes and services. Availability of panchayats and local officials may also be affected. Building a ground-up demand for child safety is all the more important.Oak Application Form     16 4. Initiating Work in a New District: we will be initiating work in S. 24 Parganas where we dont have relationships. This is not a huge risk as much as some wariness about the teething issues that arise in a new area of work as well as unanticipated delays that may occur because of it.
GAF_A_Aangan_Trust_Childproofing_Climate.11. ADDITIONAL QUESTIONS/ Future Plans: 11.  ADDITIONAL QUESTIONSPlease use this space to respond to any specific questions from your Oak programme officer. If none were received, please leave this section blank. Modality of Working with Partners: In N 24 Parganas we have been demonstrating our model in partnership with 2 community based organizations ASHA (https://www.asha4change.org/) and Sristy for Human Society (who have been selected post a process of due diligence) and who have been operational in the area and have a deep understanding of the context, challenges, govt and local structures.  Aangan designs and develops the program structure and model, all training content, curricula,, tools and resources to be used by the community and other stakeholders involved. In addition the monitoring frameworks, tools for gathering evidence and tracking progress are also developed by Aangan.  The model and activities are implemented by partner team members in the field. Regular and ongoing training is provided on all of the above by Aangan staff to Partner teams so that implementation is smooth. Monitoring and tracking progress against indicators is done jointly by both.  Quarterly convenings are organized to share trends, challenges, best practices and to ensure qualitative learnings from the ground is being captured and worked on.  We have been working with these partners since 2015. Our decision to work with CBOs is driven partially by expedience, but more importantly to also support and promote work of smaller organisations working in the region. Going forward this is how we intend to work:N 24 Parganas  8 blocks, Aangan will work directly through its own field team (some existing and some to be hired)Oak Application Form     17In S 24 Parganas, Aangan will follow a similar structure described above and work together with a partner/s. The proposed project will be co-funded along with 2 other partners. The sub-grant for partners will NOT be a part of the budget for Oak, but will be covered by a grant from our Indian funder.

GAF_A_Society_for_Direct_Initiative_for_.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT 5a. Tell us about your governance and leadership structures, as well as staff and volunteer base. Highlight any significant recent or expected future changes. If you have an explicit approach to increasing diversity and/or advancing race equity within the organisation, please tell us. (300 words):Some social activists, environmentalists, public health experts and human rights campaigners came together in early 1995 to form a voluntary organisation - Society for Direct Initiative for Social and Health Action (DISHA).Since 1995DISHA has been active on different issues concerning environment, social health and human rights. Anybody above the age of 18 years, irrespective of caste, creed and religion and agreeing to the principles which DISHA advocates can be a member of the organisation subject to the approval of the General Body. Leadership is elected by the members in Annual General Meetings every year. List of governing body members and Governance structure are attached separately (Annexure 1 and 2).Oak Application Form     6General body is the highest policy making body.  Governing body elected by the Annual General Meeting is the highest executive body for policy implementation. Office bearers like President, Vice-President, Secretary, Assistant Secretary, Treasurers are responsible for monitoring activities. Of late a Management Committee has been appointed to execute the day-to-day activities. The Management Committee includes office bearers and two other staff who are also members.There is a team of staff of around 30 who implement the decisions of the Managing Committee and functions on full time basis.There is a good number of volunteers who help the organization to implement the planned activities in different sectors against small amount remuneration, honorarium or travel support. Thereare also some interns who work with us from time to time. There have been continuous efforts to strengthen the leadership structure with the participation of community based activists and women. More involvement of the office bearers and governing body members in the existing structure is being planned.   5b. Summarise the organisations history.  In addition, highlight 2-3 key achievements.Please keep this brief and list up to 3 key achievements as bullet points. Even though you may have many achievements, please share what is most relevant to the proposed grant. (300 words)vSociety for Direct Initiative for Social and Health Action (DISHA) was registered on 12.09.1995 under the West Bengal Societies Registration Act 1961. Since inception DISHA has been active on different issues concerning environment, environmental health and human rights.Since 2000 DISHA has been involved in protection of coastal environment on the issues of beach protection, destruction of fish resources, protection of marine bio-diversity, unscrupulous tourism, unsafe industrialization, etc. DISHA started working with the traditional small scale fishing communitieswho are the natural custodians of coasts and protect environment for their livelihood through sustainable fishing. Three key achievements in fisheries sector -Since 2003 DISHA became involved in protection of bio-diversity in Sundarban and livelihood of the fisher people who depend upon forest resources since ages. Later the issue of implementation of Forest Rights Act was taken up. DISHA conducted a study in 2009 on the Livelihood Problems of Traditional Fishers in Protected Area (www.dishaearth.org). Since 2012, DISHA became involved with inland fisheries. Policy issues like tenure rights of the small fishers, protection of their livelihood, saving the water bodies were taken up. DISHA started advocating for policies at both national and state level in favour of small-scale fishers for sustainable use of fisheries resources.Oak Application Form     7At the ground level DISHA had been engaged in organising and supporting fish workers collectives in nine southern districts of West Bengal viz., Dakshin 24 Parganas, Uttar 24 Parganas, Howrah, Hooghly and Purba Medinipur, Paschim Medinipur, Jhargram, Nadia, Murshidabad. In North Bengal DISHA is engaged in supporting collectivization of small-scale fish workers in 5 districts - Malda, Uttar Dinajpur, Jalpaiguri, Coochbehar and Alipurduar. DISHA has also been instrumental in formation of a national platform of small scale fish workers organisations in 20 states and UTs.DISHA has been supporting the small-scale fish workers campaign on right to water and natural resources, campaigns and legal intervention to stop pollution in a trans-boundary river Mathabhanga, caused by a distillery in Bangladesh, cleaning of Churni and Ichamati rivers in Nadia, rejuvenation of Buriganga river in Nadia and Bidyadhari river in Dakshin 24 Parganas, campaigns against use of mosquito net in rivers and water bodies of Murshidabad and Jalpaiguri, campaigns on several tenure rights issues like fish workers occupational identity card, credit cards, provision of implements, accident insurance, boat registration etc.5c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and decide your approach? If you have undertaken a theory of change exercise, or if you are influenced by research, policy or your own organisations experience, please tell us about this.  Have you consulted with relevant stakeholders, including your communities and others experiencing the problem? Is there an intention to address equity, diversity and inclusion? (600 words):Theory of change exercises helped us to identify and understand the main problems of the sector where we work. Also our experience and research provided us with guidance to identify the main problems and the approach to address those. The ToC exercise also helped us to identify the areas of collaboration with the Oak partners in an appropriate manner in the fisheries sector.  Apart from ToC exercise and our policy intervention, rigorous consultations with the stake holder communities at various levels helped us to specify the problems and approach to be taken to address those problems. Our intended activities utilizing the Oak funds are also being proposed on the basis of the above -  Problems Approach Activities to be undertakenMarine Fisheries1.  Problem of small scale marine fishers to sustainably access marine fisheries a. This is a common problem for all marine small scale fishing communities  So it gives a scope for developing larger unity.a. Policy intervention will be continued.b. Educative materials will be produced to launch sustained campaign;Oak Application Form     8resources and to protect those resources from over and destructive fishing and pollution i.e. problem of fisheries management.b. International covenants (of which India is a signatory) stand for the right of access of small scale fisheries to fish resources  the state is morally bound to support the small fishing communities cause.c. Awareness on destructive effect of  trawling and large mechanised boats, will be conducted.   2. Problem of beach based small marine fishing communities to have legal right to the land used in common for pre-harvest and post-harvest activities.a. Customary rights of the marine fishing communities on coastal land being used for ages should be recognised as legal rights of the local communities.b. Projects encroaching the sea fronts for tourism, ports, industries etc. should be prohibited. Only the important projects serving public interest may be allowed with the informed consent of the communities.a. Policy level intervention will be continued.b. Legal scope for implementation of safeguards of CRZ Notifications will be explored. 3. Problem of coastal governance - protecting the coast from activities destructive and detrimental to coastal ecology.a. The civil society is to be sensitised to the needs of coastal protection.c. OBJECTIVESThis is the most important part of your application, as it is your opportunity to explain what you want to achieve and what will be different because of your work. We understand that social and environmental change is complex and there are a multitude of factors that contribute to change. We want to understand how you define Oak Application Form     10your role in the overall change you hope to make. You may find it helpful to discuss this with your Oak Programme Officer, and others in your own organisation.   7.a. ObjectivesList here up to 3 main objectives for this grant (one sentence per objective). Think of objectives as goals that can be achieved within the lifetime of the grant.  We encourage you to think of objective(s) that are ambitious but also achievable.  Objective 1- Development of small-scale fishing community collectives in West Bengal towards self-assertion of their right to sustainably access fish resources and protect the same as well as water bodies from pollution, over-fishing and encroachments.Objective 2- Develop policy level interface with the Central and West Bengal Governments at national and state levels towards adoption and implementation of policies for protection of sustainable small-scale fisheries.Objective 3- Develop connection with small scale fishing communities and collectives in India, both inside and outside of West Bengal, to help develop united thrust on common issues, especially on adoption and implementation of national policies.Objective 4 - Capacity building of women fish workers to assert their rights to livelihood and social justice as well as to play proper role in governing both their work and collective organisation.Objective 5- Development of additional livelihood options to help the fishing communities sustain in a situation of diminishing natural resource and also to lessen pressure on an already highly stressed resource base. Objective 6  Establishment of a community centre in Sundarban for developing income generation skills of the tiger widows and women of the fish workers families as well as for strengthening their social position.7.b. Expected Outcomes (bullet points):What do you expect will change because of this grant? What does success look like? List here the main outcomes you hope to achieve or make significant contributions towards with this grant, and for whom.  If you have concrete targets, please also list them here. Some examples are changes in policies and legislation; changes in knowledge, awareness, attitudes, beliefs, behaviours or social norms; changes in capacities, level of influence, agency or access to services. Please refer to the guidance for additional examples.Objective 1  Expected Outcome - Awareness on right to water will spread among the small-scale fish workers through campaigns, meetings at village block and state levels, trainings, interfaces with government and conduction of study on identified issues.Oak Application Form     11Objective 2  Expected Outcome  Issues related to small fish workers  both of marine and inland sectors  especially on right to water and preferential access will become agenda at the government level and compatible decisions will be taken.   Objective 3  Expected Outcome  The network of small-scale fish workers organisations at national level will be strengthened through regular interactions and visits.   Objective 4  Expected Outcome  More women fish workers will take interest in participating in organizational activities. More participation in leadership is also expected.Objective 5  Expected Outcome  Groups of women fish workers, particularly those who are dependent on natural resources, will be able to enhance their income generation through additional means to achieve economic empowerment.  Objective 6  Expected Outcome  A community centre will be developed to provide income generation opportunities of the tiger widows and other poor women fish workers of Sundarban and also to provide office space for the tiger widow association.  7.c. (300 words):Cooperation with networks, organisations and individuals at different levels is indispensable to achieve the project goals:Cooperation with the State and National Level organizations of fish workers:i. to keep abreast of the state and national level issues concerning the small scale fish workers and learn from mutual interactions and experiences;Cooperation with the State and Central Governments:i. to sensitise the concerned authorities to consider and adopt policies and laws for protection and development of small scale fisheries including the resource base on participatory basis;ii. to assist in proper and participatory implementation of laws, policies and schemes beneficial for small scale fishing communities already in place;Cooperation with the Research & Academic Institutes:i. to learn from their research and study exercises on related subjects;ii. to utilise their expertise and resources to have studies on subjects of serious concern;iii. to get policy recommendations and suggestions prepared and presented.Cooperation with the Panchayeti Raj Institutions:i. to implement government schemes with participation of fishing communities;ii. to sensitise local self-governments to the needs of small scale fishing communities;iii. to get policy recommendations from the local self-governments.Cooperation with Civil Society Groups & Individuals:i.        to get support of civil society (NGOs, HROs, Professional organisations and concerned individuals) to small scale fishing communities concerns on environment, ecology, equality and equity;ii. to activate civil society to take up the issues of concern with the government and the society at large; GAF_A_KABIL_Strengthen_Agribased_livelih.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT 5a. Tell us about your governance and leadership structures, as well as staff and volunteer base. Highlight any significant recent or expected future changes. If you have an explicit approach to increasing diversity and/or advancing race equity within the organisation, please tell us. (300 words):KABIL is governed by a Governing Board having distinguished professionals. The eight honorary members on the Board function in their personal capacities. Executive Director of KABIL, the ninth member, acts as the ex-officio secretary. 3 of the eight honorary members are women. The Executive Director of KABIL was conferred the Distinguished Alumnus award by the Indian Institute of Technology Kharagpur last year.KABIL follows a flat hierarchy. The Executive Director is the first employee of the organisation. Other employees are appointed by him. The programme Oak Application Form     6director (level 3) reports to the Executive Director, the project leader (Level 2) reports to the Programme Director and the executive (level 1) reports to the project leader. While the category of professionals ends here, some associates assist in different functions. It is a policy in KABIL that as far as possible professional staff will directly engage with the communities and there are no positions in between. When necessary, however, volunteers are recruited temporarily, a recent instance being the COVID vaccination programme.Currently, KABIL has 20 full-time staff. 12 of them are in the professional category and the rest eight are associates. In addition, 3 experts work on a retainer basis, providing part of their time for KABIL. The Executive Director has more than three decades of experience in rural development. The experts have a similar experience span. Among other professional staff, experience varies between seventeen years and one year. While KABIL has no written down policy to increase diversity or advance race equity, we consciously promote these while recruiting staff. 9 of the twenty full-time staff are women. The staff hail from different regions of the country, and they belong to three religions.There is a possibility of the current Executive Director superannuating during the proposed project period and a new incumbent taking over. 5b. Summarise the organisations history.  In addition, highlight 2-3 key achievements.Please keep this brief and list up to 3 key achievements as bullet points. Even though you may have many achievements, please share what is most relevant to the proposed grant. (300 words)KABIL was incorporated at the end of 2012 and started its operations in early 2014. During the first four years, KABIL provided on-site project implementation support to other organisations for livelihood enhancement of the rural poor. Concentrating in North-east India, it provided such support to other NGOs and the NERLP (World Bank funded).  It also trained all the frontline functionaries of the Government of Jharkhand on livelihood promotion through natural resource management (NRM). KABIL currently works with the Assam State Rural Livelihoods Mission, Government of Assam (ASRLM) to promote climate-resilient livelihoods for members of womens self-help groups in Udalguri district of Assam. It works in Tikamgarh of Madhya Pradesh to develop water resources for livelihood promotion. It also works with NGOs in Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, and Rajasthan to harness Mahatma Gandhi Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme (MGNREGS) for durable individual asset creation.Some salient achievements include:1. Popularising micro-irrigation pumps among smallholders in rural Kamrup of Assam2. Facilitating as many as 702 individual livelihood assets in the form of farm ponds and pigsties harnessing INR 8.58 Crore (USD 1.13 million) from the MGNREGS for an equal number of rural beneficiaries in a Oak Application Form     7single community development block (Udalguri) over 4 years (2018-22). In this project, as per a recent sample survey, out of the 1920 households with whom at least three livelihood interventions were made, 59% increased their annual income between 1 lakh and 1.49 lakh because of project interventions.3. There is more demand now for KABIL from the Government. The ASRLM has invited KABIL to provide design and implementation support for their Integrated Farming Cluster Programme, The District Administration of Udalguri has asked KABIL to expand its activities to different blocks and the District Administration of Tikamgarh (Madhya Pradesh) has invited KABIL to become their technical support agency.5c. What is the problem you want to address and what is your approach? How will you use Oak's funding? How did you identify the problem and decide your approach? If you have undertaken a theory of change exercise, or if you are influenced by research, policy or your own organisations experience, please tell us about this.  Have you consulted with relevant stakeholders, including your communities and others experiencing the problem? Is there an intention to address equity, diversity and inclusion? (600 words):We want to address the problem of livelihood and income vulnerability of tea garden families in the closed and sick tea gardens of West Bengal. The majority of the tea garden workers are Adivasis (Scheduled Tribes) who are socially at the margins too. while the condition of workers across tea gardens is far from satisfactory, the vulnerability is acute in the closed and sick tea gardens.The problem was identified through our understanding of poverty pockets in West Bengal and two exploratory visits by us to the proposed project area. We discussed the problems and issues with the communities, government officials, elected representatives of the local self-government institutions and leaders of the tea garden workers. Secondary information, research etc. were also consulted. For example, Sengupta, Naskar and Datta (March 2021) describe the historical context of the current condition of the tea workers. Bera (2014) describes the poverty in the particular areas we visited and the more than 1000 reported starvation deaths since 2002. Ansari and Sheereen  (2016) describe the vulnerability of tea workers when a tea garden is locked out or the work is temporarily suspended.Our first-hand information indicates the following:Most of those who are still employed work as temporary workers. The most they can expect is 132 days of work in a year at Rs 202 per day. The rest is earned through other casual means. Migration is common. Except for those who migrate to places like Kerala or find occasional work through MGNREGS, the wages earned are always less than tea garden wages. Finding menial jobs in the nearby towns is another commonly used means. Facilitated by labour contractors, younger women and men, many of them school dropouts, travel long distances regularly to functioning tea gardens and other places to do wage work. Labour contractors take their commission from these wage earners. There is a significant transport cost and time involved in travel. Jobs available in other tea gardens are the ones which the local workers of the tea Oak Application Form     8garden would not prefer. Collecting stones and boulders from the nearby riverbanks and selling them to middlemen is a common occupation. Stone and boulder collection is a hard job and can at best earn Rs 150 (USD 2) a day. Farming and animal husbandry in the homesteads supplement income. All these together can earn a family Rs 50,000 on average.  The government is using MGNREGS to provide wages to tea garden families. There is also a Foula system in the closed tea gardens through which the State Government pays Rs 1,500 (USD 20) per month to only the erstwhile permanent workers till they attain the age of 58.Many of the dwelling units of the tea garden families, which were built by the tea garden management decades back, are in dilapidated condition in the absence of repair. Electricity and water, which were earlier provided by the tea garden are no longer available from them in the closed tea gardens. In the sick ones, the services often get interrupted because of payment and other issues. In closed tea gardens like Surendranagar and Redbank, the tea plantation area has turned into jungles. This has increased the menace of elephants.Through this project, we specifically attempt to enhance the income equity of the tribal and other vulnerable populations in the tea gardens who remain at the margins. We also attempt to foster gender equality and inclusion of women by working predominantly with women and their groups which enhances their decision-making space and leadership.

Initially, the focus would be on stabilizing and scaling up the existing activities of livestock rearing and backyard poultry that are most widespread. The second set of activities would focus on using the homestead lands for improved cultivation of vegetables and other cash crops. Fallow lands which are part of the tea garden area will be made suitable for cropping through land and water development. Attempts will be made to use the shade trees in the plantation area for cash cropping like black pepper (no outputs are committed).f. Setting up demonstrations and providing critical gap-filling financial support to the families to initiate new/improved livelihood activitiesg. Helping the SHGs to leverage finances from the government (notably MGNREGS) and financial institutions for land and water development and meeting other requirements of livelihood development of the families.  h. Capacity building of the SHGs to become platforms for planning, monitoring, implementation and negotiating with the mainstream institutions.a. Continuous training, exposure, and on-job handholding to the families to strengthen their livelihood skillsj. Incubating a set of service provider entrepreneurs from among the community, who would provide inputs, and services through their enterprise.k. Build capacities of the service providers as an alternative channel for output marketing.
GAF_A_KABIL_Strengthen_Agribased_livelih.8. COOPERATION: 8. COOPERATION  How will you involve others in your approach to achieving change? If you are planning to engage in partnerships with other organisations, communities, people with lived experience, academics or secure the support of key individuals, please tell us about this.  Why are these the right partners to engage with?  Is there anything new about how you are choosing to work - for example, new partnerships or an approach that is different to how you usually work? (300 words):Oak Application Form     11The project is by its very nature a collaborative one. Outcomes cannot be achieved without the involvement of stakeholders. As we explored the area, we introduced ourselves and discussed the problems and issues with the government functionaries, the elected representatives of the local self-government institutions, and leaders of the tea workers trade unions. As a result, we were introduced to the communities by the government functionaries working in the respective blocks.As we venture into the project, we would also explore collaboration with partners of Oak Foundation. We understand that some of them operate in the area or are planning to operate. In addition to gaining insights from them, we also expect great complementarity and further energizing of the initiatives of all the concerned partners.A collaboration with West Bengal State Rural Livelihood Mission will be much sought after because the womens SHGs promoted by them are expected to be an important platform for action. KABIL is already working with the State Rural Livelihood Mission in the adjoining state of Assam and has gained experience in collaboration with such an entity.Financial institutions like banks and market actors will have to be tapped. Communities need access to credit for their livelihood initiatives; they also require input and output linkages with the market. Relevant industry bodies like the India Tea Association will be consulted on issues and their cooperation will be sought.Last but not least, we do realise that the situation in the tea gardens is complex and more insight is needed. There are many academics and there is a wealth of research on issues in tea gardens. It will be our constant endeavour to seek input from academics and available knowledge.
GAF_A_KABIL_Strengthen_Agribased_livelih.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING This section is twofold. Please tell us:a) Monitoring and evaluation. How will you know if you are achieving your objectives? Please describe briefly how you will know if you are making progress and if what you are doing is working. If you have a formal monitoring and evaluation system and if you plan to collect indicator data or conduct an external evaluation, please provide details here.b) Learning. Please tell us if there anything in particular that you are hoping to learn more about or test through this grant.(300 words):As mentioned earlier, by end of the project period, 2,500 households are expected to earn Rs. 25,000 additional income over the current mean income of Rs 50,000. This is done in a way that includes women and sustainability is ensured. The outcome assessment will be done at the end of the project through an evaluation to be undertaken by a competent third party.We plan to conduct a baseline survey of the area while initiating the project. Data regarding the livelihood status of individual families will also be captured as they enter the project. These will act as the benchmark. An M&E framework including MIS will be developed for this project as we begin. Progress Oak Application Form     12parameters will be captured on an ongoing basis through the MIS. Some of the indicators for measurement on a periodic basis include:Number of SHGs/community groups that KABIL is working withNumber of livelihood plans made by themVolume of finance leveraged by the groupsNumber of groups monitoring the implementation of the livelihood plansNumber of households adopting improved livestock rearing and/or homestead garden practicesArea covered by natural resource development interventionsAdditional land area brought under cultivationCash crops introducedIncome realized by the families due to project interventions, etc.Sample surveys and case studies will be undertaken at the end of each year and reported.Unlike in most cases where agri-based interventions are done on land belonging to the households, in this project the land does not belong to them.  The most important area of learning for us will be how to work in tea gardens and the tea garden community benefit from the development of land that does not belong to them.  This is a new area for KABIL and this grant allows the testing of this assumption.
GAF_A_KABIL_Strengthen_Agribased_livelih.10. RISKS AND CHALLENGES: 10.  RISKS AND CHALLENGESWhat are the risks or barriers that might prevent you from achieving your outcomes and how will you address these?  What are your opportunities?We understand that achieving long-lasting and meaningful change is hard and we expect that the work you want to do will mean taking risks.  We encourage you to be open to telling us these, as well as how you will address these risks.  If some of your outcomes are risky, are there any incremental achievements that you could identify? (300 words):The risks are as under:a. The closed tea gardens have no current owners. So no consultation with the owners is possible for the activities on tea garden lands. If and when new owners are found by the government, they may not allow cultivation activities on those lands. We understand that finding owners for these tea gardens is difficult because of the deteriorated plantations and several pending court cases. Nevertheless, the project will remain in touch with the government so that any new negotiation accommodates the changed reality of the gardens. b. Elections in the local self-government institutions (PRIs) are due in May 2023. Any change in political composition thereafter can impede the Oak Application Form     13relationship. To circumvent this, the project will make its apolitical stance explicit before all stakeholders.c. Allocation under MGNREGS may be reduced by the central/state governments which will adversely affect fund leverage. In such a scenario, the project will have to tap other schemes and sources to compensate for the reduction.d. The womens SHGs formed by the Livelihood Mission may not be in a good shape to work with. In an extreme scenario, the Mission may not allow the project access to the SHGs. While we have a prima facie assurance from the local government functionaries that the project can work with the SHGs, it may have to put in additional effort to first strengthen the SHGs to work with them.The opportunities include a) a huge area of uncultivated lands which can be utilized for cultivation purposes, b) the governments concern about the wellbeing of the workers of the closed tea gardens c) Good road connectivity d) high rainfall in the area that creates a high potential for water harvesting e) Tea (Promotion and Development) bill 2022 which aims at improving the tea industry, etc.
