GAF_Development_Research_Communication_a.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 6. Context (The context section should not exceed two pages.)6a. Describe the organisation (include information on leadership, governance, structure and staff) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):DRCSC, a non-profit development organization, formed in 1982, working in 12 districts of West Bengal as a resource centre for collection, collation and dissemination of information on various socio-economic issues and to highlight the struggles of various NGOs, CBOs and individuals to ensure social justice; especially for informal sector workers, indigenous communities and small & marginal farmers/landless labourers as well as selfemployed artisans. Since 1992, the centre focused on Sustainable Agriculture & Natural Resource Management for improving food & livelihoodsecurity of the rural poor. The centre stands for ensuring food and livelihood security of the rural poor through sustainable management & protection of natural resources. Serving as a resource organization, it has trained 17 nonprofits and nearly 500 community groups to implement its models. DRCSC has pioneered various models in sustainable agriculture, community based property resources which address food and livelihood security, and impact the nutritional status of over 10,000 women and girls.DRCSC collectivizes marginalized families and trains them to undertake region-specific solutions with the help of local-partners. Its models on sustainable and climate resilient agriculture include: Integrated farming models, Nutrition gardens, Social forestry, Common property resource management, Mixed cropping in permanent fallows. DRCSCs sustainable agriculture models help increase food supply in periods of scarcity and lead to lower malnutrition, increased income from sale of surplus food, lower seasonal migration, and ecological conservation. DRCSC has helped over 10,000 vulnerable households over the last ten years to increase their food secure months by 4-5 months on average, and increase average income by at least INR 10,000 per year/per household. Since inception, DRCSC has directly helped implement over 5,000 home gardens and over 100 integrated farming systems; Our models on livelihoods, food and nutrition security and Grant Application Form, July 1 20135climate change has empowered poor and marginalized communities to endeavour in new pathways of development. DRCSC's Founder Secretary Sri Ardhendu S. Chatterjee is an internationally renowned Trainer in Sustainable agriculture/permaculture design, he has many publications to his credit, currently he is the President of the Organisation. The Chief Programme Officer has professional training on leadership and NGO management, the present Treasurer is a practicing lawyer, the Secretaryhas years of experience of working in the development sector, 4 senior management team members have longstanding experience in different areas of programme implementation & financial management. DRCSC is registered under West Bengal Societies Registration Act 1961 bearing registration no. S/39363. The Executive Council of DRCSC, which is the Governing body, presently comprises of 9 members Mr. Ardhendu S. Chatterjee (President), Mr. Dilip Kumar Sarkar (Secretary), Mr. Samir Kumar Bhattacharya (Treasurer), Dr. Sugata Hazra (Member), Mr. Avik Roy (Member), Dr. Pratap Kumar Mukhopadhyay (Member), Ms. Sudeshna Sinha (Member), Ms. Somjita Chakraborty (Member), Mr. Valentine Xavier (Member).DRCSC has 180 staff working from HO and different field offices across West Bengal. It has over 20 field offices. DRCSC has a Senior Management Team which comprises of 4 team heads and the CEO6b. Describe the financial situation (include information on annual operating costs, fundraising strategy, reserves and debts) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):DRCSC is working for at least 40 years now, and its financial health has been relatively steady and stable with an increasing trend. The average annual operating cost remain in the range of 7-8 crores per year.DRCSC is an implementing organization. It mainly looks for different grant based programmes, attend different calls. DRCSC has over 180 staff members all over West Bengal and implements different projects and programmes. It also has many volunteers who also work hard to make the projects and programmes success. Also DRCSC generates some revenue through sale of its knowledge products (booklets, audio visuals etc) and providing services like audio visual documentation, evaluation etc. As on date DRCSC does not have any outstanding debts.6c. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):Grant Application Form, July 1 20136DRCSC was established in the year 1981 and was formed as a Documentation Centre for providing relevant information to the underpriviledged so that they can fight for their rights in the sector of Natural Resource Management. Gradually as a priority, DRCSC focuses on the problems of resource-poor farmers, socially marginalized groups, concentrating mainly on ecologically vulnerable areas, and help to increase common understanding about the issues of environmental degradation both at macro and micro levels. DRCSC is committed to develop climate adaptive technologies which can be accepted and easily managed by the local communities. The organisation encourages handing over of the administrative responsibilities to user groups or their representatives in a phased manner. Its vision is to work for a sustainable future for the rural poor and marginalized communities so thatthey can break the shackles of poverty and hunger and capacitate them to act against environmental degradation. Its models on livelihoods, food & nutrition security and climate change have empowered marginalized communities to tread new pathways of development. A sample of recent accomplishments of DRCSC is presented below:1. DRCSC have been one of the 6 agencies to receive support from ADAPTATION FUND through NABARD (designated Government of India agency for Climate Change funds) for work in drought prone lateritic soil region of West Bengal.2. DRCSC have participated in and co-hosted Bay of Bengal meeting on Sunderban ecozone (a forum of the major resource agencies to focus on problems and possibilities in Bay of Bengal Region, Countries and States.3. We are known by the State Government, major NGOs and International Funding Agencies as well as Research Institution / Universities as important Leading Resource Centre on Climate Resilient Food & Livelihood Security through ecological natural resource management, as youth skill training centre, and for working on environment education (among child / adolescent) 4. All India livelihood promotion Institution Sphere India has acknowledged our resilient designs of livelihood models.5. We were chosen as a lead agency in a project supported by DST (Department of Science & Technology, Government of India) to coordinate a multi-state research project on bio-diverse integrated farming system for 4 years [12 states, 18 NGOs / Development Organisations]. Our contribution has been appreciated by BCAS, a Bangladeshi Research Organisation.6d. Describe the current strategy of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):DRCSC focuses on working with marginal community who are most vulnerable and resource poor and live in ecologically fragile zones. It works with the entire household with main focus on women. It ensures equal participation, providing best opportunity to learn, dream and fulfil their dream through promotion of low Grant Application Form, July 1 20137cost sustainable NRM models and convergences with different government schemes and services.DRCSCs currents areas of involvement is as follows :1. To build capacities of vulnerable communities and encourage them to get involved in participatory action research (that are environment friendly, economically feasible, socially equitable & viable) to develop climate change adaptive models in agriculture and allied sectors in the ecologically fragile zones.2. To increase and sustain income opportunities of the ultra-poor families through diversification of the sources of income with focus to farm and non-farm initiatives.3. To assess the possibilities of resources available in different agro climatic region and build capacities of the adolescents and youth through short term courses on natural resource based vocations so that they can process such resources and develop small enterprises either individually or collectively or earn livelihood as instructors.4. To support small and marginal farmers engaged in producing organic products to establish backward and forward linkages in marketing. 5. Consolidate our identity as a Resource Organisation for ecological agriculture and extend capacity building services at all levels like farmers, field workers, organisers, individuals and organisations interested to promote organic farming in South and South East Asia.6. To work Closely with the State and National Government and share the published results of the actions to up-scale the successful models and inspire change in the area.7. To promote school gardens, particularly in primary & secondary schools and develop garden based learning materials and build environmental consciousness among the future generation.8. To Document knowledge of indigenous resources and how they are utilised. Help in developing efficient collection method & processing technology of under-utilised or lesser known plants & animal resources.6e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):The Sundarbans ecosystem is one of the most biologically diverse ecosystems of the Indian Sub-continent. The UNESCO designated world heritage site plays a key role as the regions carbon sink soaking in around 4.15 crore tonnes of carbon dioxide (2011). However, the regions rich bio-diversity and burgeoning human population stand at a brink today with increasing threats to their very existence from exogenous climate induced shocks and its aftereffects. The principal land-based livelihoods get impacted due to increased salinity, lack of knowledge with regard to sustainable agriculture, no options for diversified agriculture etc. due to which more and more people are exploiting the natural resource base in a manner that will be difficult to sustain over the long run. Grant Application Form, July 1 20138Frequent climatic hazards (saline flood, cyclone etc) are disrupting the livelihood over and above. Agricultural lands are being converted into prawn farming ponds (Bheri) which is again not sustained livelihood option at all. The proposed interventions will be emphasized on orientation on different techniques and methods of climate adaptive agriculture, livestock farming, aquaculture, and other on-farm and non-farm income generation programmes which ultimately will help the community to diversify their income opportunities and thereby will lead to increase climate resilience. The interventions will consist of establishing seed banks through which the targeted households will be able to conserve salt-tolerant seeds for future, they will be able to learn to prepare nutrition gardens at each and every possible space they have around their homestead to get assured nutrition with their daily meals round the year. The biggest problem of Sundarbans, river bank erosion will be tried to be addressed through plantation of mangroves and protecting those plants to reduce the problem. Rain water will be harvested through different rain water harvesting structures which may help in increasing the availability of irrigation during the stress period. The facilities will be established so that the increased production of the farmers can be aggregated, value added and marketed through a cluster based approach. The proposed intervention aims at addressing the non-availability of a facilitative platform for vulnerable people in the Sundarbans to come together, diagnose their vulnerabilities and act upon the same. Such a platform has been elusive on account of high opportunity cost of participation of vulnerable groups in processes of development, lack of any favourable prior experiences, and increasing alienation from their core habitat and livelihoods.

GAF_Development_Research_Communication_a.8. COOPERATION: 8. CooperationDescribe the level of cooperation with other organisations and networks and explain how this cooperation helps achieve your goals (maximum 300 words):DRCSC proposes to work closely with all the partner organisations in the Sundarbans and will play a dual role in the project. One DRCSC will implement the project in collaboration with Rupantaran Foundation at  Gopalnanagr Hub in Patharpratima Block to understand the persistent problems there and to promote chalimate change adaptive livelihood through different capacity building programmes, model building and convergences. DRCSC will ensure the participation of local communities and identify and nurture the local leaders within the development initiative. Two, DRCSC will play the role as capacity building organisation and will work closely with other 7 collaborative organisations so that DRCSCs expertise in the sector of climate change adaptation and sustainable livelihoods can be shared with the partners and also DRCSC can learn from others experiences. DRCSC will design the capacity building programmes taking into consideration the primary needs and interests of the organisations and will help in spreading the knowledge and capacity with regard to enhance the climate resilience of the most vulnerable marginalised farming families of Sundarbans.
GAF_Development_Research_Communication_a.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. ImpactWhat is the change you want to achieve from the overall project? (maximum 300 words):It is expected to achieve from the proposed process is to see greater levels of participation and leadership of local communities in development initiatives in the Sundarbans, evident in greater centrality of their voices and roles in processes of conceptualisation of initiatives, planning, implementation, monitoring and change adaptationGrant Application Form, July 1 201311evaluation.10. EvaluationHow will progress be monitored and evaluated? (maximum 300 words):The project has been designed in a participatory way and the implementation of all the initiatives will be done through community based organizations. The community based organizations will own all the initiatives from the very beginning and DRCSCs role will be to facilitate and build their managerial and technical capacities. The facilitation will be monitored from DRCSC also, the project staff will be involved in day to day monitoring of the implementation. The project coordinator will evaluate the progress of the project on the basis of MLP. DRCSC management will help in evaluation of the progress of the project and will meet on a quarterly basis. The project staff will meet twice in every month to plan and implement the project activities smoothly. The strengthened community based organizations and the leadership in the locality will help in sustaining the initiatives in future also. The representatives of community led organizations, local authority members along with different line departments will also meet at least on quarterly basis towards uninterrupted implementation of the project activities and monitoring and evaluation of the progress of the initiative as well

(maximum 300 words):The thrust of the proposed initiative of enabling vulnerable groups in the Sundarbans to form community based farmers organizations, articulate aspirations of change and pursue community based initiatives to diversify their income opportunities through managing available natural resources and convergences with government schemes and services.  It is expected to generate good learnings with regards to dynamics of participation of vulnerable groups in community-led processes of change, besides regarding the relative strengths of a collaborative, cluster-based approach within a forum of diverse entities

Core Support  Yes:_/No:_ No4b (ii)?. Project involves Contact with Children  Yes:_/No:_Yes4c. Grant period:Start date:(dd/mon/yy)End date:4d. Currency: GBP4e. Total Project Cost:1287022 4f. Total Amount requested from Oak:998595Grant Application Form, July 1 201344g. Summarise the projects ultimate goal(s) (maximum 200 words):( NOT REQUIRED FOR CORE SUPPORT GRANTS)The Projects ultimate goal is to Reduce Socio economic vulnerability, improve livelihoods and resilience of 9,000 Tea worker communities in 5 districts of North Bengal and Assam namely- Jalpaiguri, Kalimpong, Darjeeling, in North Bengal and Sonitpur, Biswanath in Assam . The work will be undertaken across 35 gardens of which 25 gardens in North Bengal and 10 gardens in Assam. Tea worker communities constitute one of the most isolated and marginalised communities amongst various plantation workers. Having been uprooted from their native places, their lives across generations have remained confined to gardens with limited interaction with outside communities. Being under the sole authority of respective garden management, the workers have little security and safety nets other than those provided by Garden management, long working hours, lack of work security, low literacy and low skill sets have made this segment of population particularly marginalised, Further, this affects women and youth the most in terms of poor health conditions of women, malnutrition amongst the population, disenchantment amongst youth. Most often young boys and girls, out of sheer desperation take risks of uninformed migration, falling victims to trafficking and other forms of abuse. The project will be the first phase of a multi-phase intervention where the project will facilitate building of community voices and create opportunities and choices for Tea worker households. We have limited our intervention specifically to cover Tea workers and to some extent workers in Small Tea Gardens who are relatives of workers in Large and Closed Tea gardens. Small Tea Growers are not covered within the ambit of the current phase given their varied profile and more mainstream identity compared to workers in Tea estates who are covered under Plantation Labour Act. In this phase the primary focus will be to improve livelihoods and safety nets through a participatory process of needs, resources, skills and opportunity identification leading to diversification and improvement in incomes. Secondly, collectivisation of women and youth in the gardens and enhancing their knowledge, skills and sense of agency will improve their negotiation and dialogue capacities with officials within and outside the gardens enabling them to access entitlements from the Government. We see this as a critical intervention towards Trade justice  which depends a lot of building capacities of the community itself to identify and raise their issues and stand up for their own rights The project will also establish a model of climate adaptive practices through establishing small scale innovations in two Gardens and facilitate formation of informal CSO group for peer to peer learning, broadbased understanding of Labour Code and its dissemination, joint assessment of advocacy issues and actions for policy.
