GAF_Traidcraft_Exchange_UK_AddreSocioVul.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 6. Context (The context section should not exceed two pages.)6a. Describe the organisation (include information on leadership, governance, structure and staff) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):Traidcraft Exchange is an international development organization with an annual income of about  and is registered as a charity with the Charity Commission and a Company Limited by Guarantee.Through local offices in East Africa and South Asia, Traidcraft Exchange has impacted the lives of over 500,000 people through a variety of initiatives with small scale farmers and producers, focusing largely on sustainable agricultural practices, value chain development and access to fairer market linkages. Traidcraft Exchange has worked across India and has supported Tribal and vulnerable communities in Odisha, Rajasthan, Jharkhand, West Bengal, Assam and the North Eastern States.The Board of Traidcraft Exchange consists of seven non-executive directors, together with the Chief Executive, that meets about 7 times a year. All Directors are subject to re-election every three years, except the foundation Director (who is appointed by the Traidcraft Foundation. The board appoints the Chief Executive who manages the day to day operations of the charity. We have women Board Members and most members of our Senior Management Team (SMT) are women, including a woman CEO. The SMT meets regularly to monitor progress on our Annual Plan and support the operations of the organization.The number of full-time equivalent employees are 47 in Traidcraft Exchange across five offices in the UK, South Asia and East Africa. There are approximately 14 full-time equivalent staff employed in the headquarter office in Newcastle; 10 people in the London office; 5 in the East Africa office in Kenya; 12 in the Bangladesh office, and 6 in the India office. We have expertise and experience in trade and market access, supporting womens economic empowerment and environmental sustainability in supply chains. With the recent strategic review process of Traidcraft and need for reorganising, the staff position might change in near future. 6b. Describe the financial situation (include information on annual operating costs, fundraising strategy, reserves and debts) and expected changes. (maximum 300 words):Grant Application Form, July 1 20136As of 2019/20 Traidcraft Exchange had overall unrestricted reserves of 19k. We are expecting to at least break even at an operating level in 2020/21 and our budget for 2021/22 shows operating costs of .096m with income of circa .14m. We currently have no long-term liabilities on our balance sheet and little current debt. We are currently going through a restructure, which is focusing on the organisation as a whole in order to cut costs but also to make us more efficient in raising funds from our existing donor base, including individual donors, trusts and foundations and other philanthropists.In terms of fundraising, we were quick to adapt to the Covid crisis and unrestricted fundraising efforts have weathered Covid restrictions well as the charity has a fairly large, loyal donor base who have continued to give philanthropically throughout the lockdown periods.Our public fundraising strategy seeks to focus resources on high return on investment, philanthropic activity such as appeals, regular giving and legacy. With regards our restricted funding strategy we currently operate an institutional funding model whereby we seek funding from institutions such as Comic Relief, National Lottery Community Fund, the UK government and the EU to fund projects designed and delivered by Traidcraft Exchange in collaboration with local partners. However, the NGO and INGO funding landscape is shifting. We are seeking to adapt our current funding model in light of this and beginning in the next financial year we will start to seek funding from a much broader range of funders.6c. Describe the history and past achievements of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):Traidcraft Exchange (TX) was set up in 1986 by Traidcraft plc (established in 1979) to provide an alternate route to trade where people are at the heart of trade. Through its development programmes in South Asia and East Africa, and the policy, lobbying & campaigning work in the UK/EU, Traidcraft has made a difference to the lives of millions of people. Key achievements include:We have supported 500,000 producers across Asia and Africa to improve productivity, market access, particularly for vulnerable communities like women, ethnic minorities, youth and people with disability.We have set-up and promoted like-minded organisations including Shared Interest and Caf Direct.We have sourced over 1000 products from 30 countries across Asia, Africa and Latin America.We have pioneered at least 5 new Fairtrade certified products into the global Fairtrade system while supporting the Fairtrade Labelling Organisation to develop and test product standards.We have demonstrated transparent operations through social accounting and publication of these reports.We were voted one of the most innovative charities in the UK; also receiving Grant Application Form, July 1 20137awards on our policy & campaigning and public fundraising initiatives.TXs policy work led to the introduction of a supermarket ombudsman and Groceries Adjudicator to ensure adherence to a supply code of practice to benefit workers. Traidcraft has policy expertise on purchasing practices, corporate governance and accountability, fair and ethical trade, and international trade policy, including working with the UK government on trade policies post Brexit. Our work in India has revolved around complex and labour-intensive value chains such as tea, textile, cotton and jute, supporting about 150,000 households. TX India has worked with a range of target groups, including women from ethnic minorities and tribes.In the tea sector for example, our work in India has benefited 70,000 small tea growers, with recognition of this sub-sector for the first time in the 11th Five Year Plan. We also supported the set-up of a Small Grower Directorate, the formation of the Confederation of Small Tea Grower Associations, and the co-option of Small Grower representatives on the Tea Board.Who Picked My Tea campaign facilitated by Traidcraft enabled the tea sector to move from complete silence over sourcing to gaining increased transparency in the tea sector in the UK enabling consumers to track the tea they drink from leaf to cup.We are currently implementing the Pahadiya Samriddhi project in Jharkhand which aims to reduce vulnerabilities of 3000 Pahariya (Primitive Tribe) households by providing better access to markets and improve management of natural resourcesWe launched the first fair trade label in India called Shop for Change which is now managed by a private body, and our cotton project helped test the first Fairtrade standards for cotton by the Fairtrade Foundation in the early 2000s. Additionally, our work in the textiles sector has enabled the 12th Five Year Plan to focus on the occupational health & safety of artisans.Currently, we are working with Adivasi and Dalit communities in Madhya Pradesh to address the systemic and structural vulnerabilities of agricultural communities to forced, bonded and child labour. We support the creation of alternate avenues of income generation, and of peoples institutions that work together to prevent exploitation.We are also currently growing our expertise on modern slavery issues in agricultural supply chains, improved working conditions for invisible workers in the textiles sector (particularly homeworkers), and the promotion of sustainable agriculture.6d. Describe the current strategy of the organisation. (maximum 300 words):Traidcraft Exchange uses the power of trade to bring about lasting solutions to poverty. We are on the side of people who are most vulnerable in trade - marginalised workers and producers whose work goes unseen and whose voices go unheard. We aim to support the most vulnerable groups including women, ethnic minorities and people with disabilities. Grant Application Form, July 1 20138 TX is committed to transforming ourselves from a UK-centric model into a locally rooted, globally connected organisation.  Pursuing this model enables us to devolve responsibility and decision-making to our in-country teams and beyond that, to cede power to the producers and workers who we are supporting. The overarching aim is to put communities in the driving seat of decisions and processes related to their lives and livelihoods by using participatory methodologies and listening to communities and partners.  In this context, Traidcraft Exchanges core purpose is to identify, support and invest in farmer associations, worker collectives, social enterprises and civil society organisations that are challenging the negative impacts of mainstream trade and developing alternative business models that put people and planet first. We will be standing alongside communities who are vulnerable and have been marginalised, supporting them to develop businesses that work for them, that protect and respect their local eco-systems and that build their resilience. And in doing this, we will support them to build their power. Our UK advocacy and campaigns work will complement this work and be rooted in the lived experiences of farmers and workers and the priorities of advocacy partners in-country, addressing the systemic and structural issues affecting peoples lives. Further, some of the key lessons derived from our past work in the tea sector (including programmatic work in India and policy/ campaigning work in the UK level) that forms part of the strategy for this project are:Need to engage with multiple stakeholders (including the garden management, supply chain actors, government institutions like tea Board, TRA) to be effective on-ground. We have planned for such engagements in the current application, whereby we shall involve garden management team in specific workstream; and also plan to do dissemination events including multiple stakeholders.Creating community-based platforms for sustaining work in future phase. In our work with small tea growers (STG), as part of the EqualiTea project, we facilitated STG associations at ground level, including national level STG federation taking forward the work with relevant stakeholders. These community institutions (associations and federation) are still active more than a decade since the project timeframe. In the current programme plan, we have kept provision for creating community collectives of women and youth in the Tea garden communities. These community institutions will provide us the platform for work in the next phase of programmes (especially as we tackle some of the sensitive issues such as human trafficking and gender based violence in tea garden communities in future phase of work)   Campaigning and media engagement does help in highlighting key issues with brands and buyers: Traidcraft policy and campaigning unit, continuously engage with UK based consumers to pressurize brands and companies to adopt ethical sourcing practices. We have run effective campaigns for Tea sector (such as #WhopickedmyTea campaign; https://traidcraftexchange.org/tea-answers ) for greater transparency in supply chains of leading UK based tea brands. We are looking to take advantage of the network of our Policy unit to disseminate information about our project activities to a wider audience with reach to international brands and buyers.Grant Application Form, July 1 201396e. What problems are you addressing? What are the opportunities and challenges in addressing these problems? (maximum 600 words):The tea industry in India is the countrys second largest employer in the formal sector. A large proportion of the tea produced in India comes from the four States of Assam, West Bengal, Tamil Nadu and Kerala. Directly and indirectly, the industry employs over 3 million people, a majority of whom are women. Indian tea remains an important supplier to the global market even as the domestic consumption base increases. Our study on the tea industry has focused on the conditions of workers in the tea gardens of Assam and West Bengal. The study covered a total of 15 large tea estates (LTE); 23 small tea growers (STGs) and 6 closed tea estates (CTEs) across the four clusters of Assam and West Bengal, interviewing a total of 308 tea worker respondents. We have also sought to understand some of the challenges faced by the industry as a whole. We have scanned research reports on these topics from within the industry as well as from independent academic researchers and institutions. We have also spoken to industry leaders as well as civil society organizations working with tea workers. Key problems of the tea workers are:Alienation and Lost Identity: Most workers in the tea estates especially in Assam are descendants of workers who came to Assam under the indentured labour arrangements of British India. They trace their roots to the Adivasi Communities- mostly Mundas and Oraons of the Central India Belt- Odisha, Jharkhand, Madhya Pradesh, Bihar and West Bengal. Today they are recognized as Tea and Ex  Tea Garden tribes and recognized as Other Backward Classes by the Government of Assam. In West Bengal, since Colonial times the workers were not indentured. Instead, plantation owners recruited them mostly from Nepal, with some monetary compensation. Besides this, the workers are also santhals and adivasis from central India such as Oraons and Mundas. The incentives were mostly non-monetary in nature and included housing. These houses continued to belong to the plantations and workers were only allowed to live and are expected to maintain the house for as long as they occupy them. Uprooted from their original roots, the workers are not connected to their social community. Living in isolated gardens with limited means of communication and exposure, most workers live only as Tea workers with other identities almost insignificant. Aggravating this is the hostility and alienation faced from the natives of the state- especially Assam due to which the Tea worker community face estrangement and a sense of lost identity.Working conditions of workers: Our secondary research has brought up many individual studies (Oxfam-2019, Banerji and Willoughby-2019, University of Sheffield-2018, Behal-2017, CEE-2009), that describe the difficult living and working conditions of tea workers. The colonial legacy of the industry continues to inform the relationship between the management of tea gardens and their workers. The workers unions that represent the workers collective interests have been unable to represent these issues and have been vulnerable to the influences of mainstream political parties and estate management. The national laws governing the industry, specifically the Plantations Labour Act, 1951, have many enabling provisions but compliance monitoring is inadequate. The Act stipulates that all tea estates shall provide to its workers amenities such a drinking water, separate toilets, medical facilities, creches for child care, canteens, recreational facilities, educational facilities and housing facilities. Our primary data suggests poor availability of these facilities across all categories of the tea gardens. Less Grant Application Form, July 1 201310than a third of study participants reported satisfaction with the quality of the housing they lived in. Drinking water is a serious issue in the gardens affecting women the most. Coupled with this, poor nutrition , very hard nature of work result in health complications of women members in particular. The issue of low wages has been a consistent problem in the tea sector and has been a long-drawn struggle for tea workers. The wages of tea estate works are neither aligned to MGNERGA norms nor anything in line with indices of the consumer price index. The vulnerable workers often become victims of one upmanship between trade unions & employers who often work at cross purposes.            Lack of awareness of workers and poor linkages to government schemes: Our study highlights low levels of awareness among workers. In responses to questions about work promotions, only 7% of the participants in the LTE replied in the affirmative. The issue of inadequate wages has been reported by many participants. However, only 27% of the participants showed awareness of regular deductions from their wages. A third of the participants said that it was difficult to access government schemes and within that group 50% are women.. The reasons that they cited for this include the lack of awareness about the schemes, lack of necessary documents and lack of timely information on the process to be followed, general apathy of government officials towards tea worker community  Low family income, unemployment and underemployment: Low wages, poor access to education and social differences with neighbouring communities have all contributed to a poor capital accumulation within the tea workers community. Most of them do not possess land or if they do (as among the West Bengal tea workers), it is just enough for homestead garden plots. Small livestock rearing is challenging due to the lack of space and common land. Participants reporting access to school beyond the primary level were only 18% of the sample and to high school only2%. A little under half of the participants cite financial difficulties as the reason for the discontinuation of their education. This circumstance has spawned several other social problems such as bonded labour, child labour, destitution and trafficking of women and children. The nature of hiring workers within the tea industry & growing aspirations of youth creates a context of underemployment and unemployment within the tea estates. This forces youth to migrate out to urban centres in search of more gainful employment, often trapped and exploited by the traffickers.Climate and sustainability of the tea sector: On another front, the tea industry is vulnerable to climate change. Extreme climactic events affect both production and processing cycles of the tea crop. These changes in the meteorological factors have also a negative impact on the number & severity of incidences of pests and disease infestations, soil quality and soil erosion. If this trend continues, large parts where tea is grown currently will become unviable for commercial tea production in two to three decades. The industry is also facing multiple problems related to output price stagnation, higher factor costs of production, ageing of the bushes in the organized estates, labour shortages & absenteeism, regulatory hurdles, lack of policy support & reforms, current market structure & the gradual shifting of consumer preference towards other beverages. Given the complex multi-layered issues of vulnerability among tea workers and the tea sector as a whole, a multi phased approach to ensure a sustainable intervention is required. This is intended to be the first phase of a multi-phase intervention, where an enabling eco-system for dialogue and mutual trust will be built with the various stakeholders. This approach is informed by our understanding that to achieve any sustainable change in the lives of tea workers, interventions will have to work at multiple levels of the worker communities, tea estate management as well as government. The projects aims to create win win Grant Application Form, July 1 201311situation for workers, Garden management and Government by addressing practical issues like livelihood enhancement of workers, bridging entitlement access gaps , demonstrating pilots for better living conditions in gardens through solutions for drinking water etc. An enabling eco-system that includes collaborative engagement will lead to improved and dignified quality of life of workers in the long run.  We intend to play a catalytic role through establishing a model which engages various stakeholders and is guided by our own strength and mission of shifting the power in trade. In the first phase 42 months, we propose to undertake entry point interventions with large tea estates (LTE) and closed tea gardens (CTG)), that will address the issues of:a) lacking skill & income enhancement opportunities for tea worker communities;b) Improve awareness and access to social entitlements through joint action between tea worker communities, tea garden management, government officials etc.c) Address solidarity and Cooperation through mobilizing women and youth in the Tea gardens for regular capacity building, information sharing and enhancing their role within the community;d) Pilot interventions to address Climate Change impacts in collaboration with Tea Research Association and other multistakeholder forums like Trustea/ Trinitea etc.e) Create informal platform of likeminded CSOs and representatives of Tea worker communities working in tea sector with a view to learn and promote good practices and strengthen sectoral understanding on the issues of Tea workers and Tea sector as a whole; andf) Build capacities of local partner organizations on facilitation skills, worker rights, skill trainings and migration so they can lead the change process in the future. In the subsequent phases, besides broadening its intervention to gardens, the work will build upon the stakeholder forums, community institutions and technical innovations developed during this phase.  Intensive and deepened work around working conditions and worker rights will be facilitated through constructive dialogue and consultations with the Tea estate managements and stakeholders forum. Simultaneously, issues of domestic violence against women, issues of trafficking and safe migration for youth will be addressed upfront by the empowered community institutions built in this phase. Using its experience in Consumer and brand engagement, Traidcraft will also work towards raising consumer awareness in domestic and international markets through campaigns and engage brands to adhere to transparency & ethical standards. Traidcraft will also leverage its experience gained in working with Large Tea estates to promote Sustainability standards by informing the Garden management on standards, facilitating them in adoption of practices to qualify for standards like Trustea/Trinitea for the domestic tea industry and ensuring their accountability through transparent self-disclosures. The informal network of CSOs and likeminded agencies, individuals, workers representatives etc. will be steered to evolve as a resource network for tea agencies/gardens and other CSOs to learn, ensure that tea workers voices are amplified, promote best practices and engage in facilitating programs and funding. Traidcrafts new portfolio approach to work on the issues of workers and Tea workers being one of the key programmatic focus, will enable its long-term commitment to the issue and bring in additional investment for future phases and programming.                Grant Application Form, July 1 201312 The next sections in the document outline in detail the intervention plan for the Current phase.
GAF_Traidcraft_Exchange_UK_AddreSocioVul.7. OBJECTIVES: 7. Objectives (maximum 2,200 words)For a core support grant, state the purpose of this grant request and complete the objectives.  After consultations with an Oak PO, you may decide to summarise your mission as one broad objective. In this case, it is still necessary to specify activities and results/outcomes for this objective.For project support grants please list your objectives for this project in bullet point format. (You may use additional space if you have more than three objectives)?. Under each objective describe the activities that your organisation will undertake to achieve it, including time frame and the results or outcomes you expect to achieve.7.1.a. Objective 1 (maximum one sentence):Strengthened community groups of Women and Youth representing 9,000 tea worker households from 35 tea estates (Closed and Large Tea gardens; 10 in Assam and 25 in West Bengal) to access rights, schemes and entitlements through improved awareness, leadership and joint action           7.1.c. Objective 1 Activities and timeframe (maximum 300 words):Access to information and awareness of rights, government schemes and entitlements within the tea worker communities has been found to be quite poor, preventing many of the tea worker families to access the benefits of the schemes. Their awareness related to the workers rights has been also found to be quite low as only 9% of the tea workers working in the large tea estates responded that they were aware of laws protecting their rights. As a result, uptake on social security 7.1.b. Objective 1 Expected results/outcomes and timeframe (maximum 300 words):Key results achieved under this objective are:a. 246 Womens Groups and 35 Youth forums demonstrate enhanced confidence and leadership to access their rights and entitlements. About 60% households in Assam and West Bengal (6600 HHs) will be linked to minimum 1 Government programs or entitlements.b. Garden management, Panchayats and Government working together with the community groups to address the issues of access, quality & timeliness of entitlements     Grant Application Form, July 1 201313schemes, health and nutrition benefits is also low despite high levels of malnutrition and poor health of women and children, Even in the closed tea gardens where the District Administration takes over the management and facilitates these entitlements, most often lack of community demand and remoteness of the gardens, the workers are left out. On the other hand, underemployment and unemployment of youth are on the rise which leads to forced migration. Most people migrate to other cities and states through local agents who promise them of lucrative opportunities which quite often becomes a vicious trap of exploitation. The primary research threw light on many cases of trafficking that is on the rise. Cutting across these, is a deep sense of alienation and isolation of the community who are mostly tribal people with a colonial history of being uprooted from their original villages. Life in the tea gardens has not helped in integration with the mainstream people of the West Bengal and Assam. There is despondency and lack of agency which pushes them further to the margins. Hence, there is a need to collectivise and build on the community strength to exert their voice and improve awareness and knowledge on their rights and entitlements besides nurturing their sense of community and leadership.  The activities will be done through a participatory approach with engagement and handholding of women and youth to be able to lead their own pathway of change, expand their networks and articulate their needs. Following are the key foundational activities planned: 1.Mobilising Communities  Women groups and Youth Forums: At the outset of the project, mapping of the 10 selected tea gardens in Assam and 25 tea gardens in West Bengal to assess the status of the existing womens group formed in the past (as part of government initiatives) which now are either dysfunctional, inactive or weak will be undertaken.Alongside, youth in the tea gardens will also be mobilised and organised as youth forums. These Youth forums will provide an open space to youth to express themselves, build their skills and engage in welfare of their community members. Through mobilising support from expert agencies, Traidcraft will build capacities of partners in developing a structured approach to youth engagement,Depending on their social cohesion, the community will be organised as per their settlement pattern  for example in Assam the women groups will be organised based on their labour lines (this is how housing is defined on tea estates); whereas in West Bengal, women will be organised considering the size of the group (30 women per group). A total of 246 Womens Groups (200 in West Bengal, 46 in Assam) and 35 Youth forums (25 in West Bengal and 10 in Assam) will be formed in Year 1.2.Capacity Building and Awareness: Womens groups will be capacitated on livelihood activities, nutrition and health, social security schemes etc, Capacity building of youth groups entail building soft skills, cultural identity, youth and development, rights and entitlements, safe migration and career counselling.. In order to build networks, relevant resource agencies and government officials will be brought in to deliberate on the topic of their relevance. The activity will be undertaken both on Year 1 and Year 2 3.Facilitation for access to Entitlements: Community institutions i.e. Womens groups and Youth forums will be facilitated to support in accessing Grant Application Form, July 1 201314the various entitlements and schemes.  This would include mapping the households eligible for social security, health and nutrition and other relevant entitlements; assistance in registration, documentation etc. Community groups will also be supported to monitor the services of ICDS and Health centres and facilitated to liaise with the relevant authorities to access quality services. The project will also facilitate setting up a coordination committee at the block level engaging Panchayats and relevant government departments to facilitate the access of various schemes.  Schemes and entitlements that would be facilitated are: a. Pension schemes (example - National Old Age Pension, Widow Pension, Arunodoi - financial assistance to women - widow, differently abled, unmarried, divorcee); Student scholarship & Financial assistance for students/youths for studies and self-employment; skill development programs such as Swahid Dayal Das Panika Swaniyojan Achoni (specifically designed for the tea worker communities in Assam) etc.7.2.a. Objective 2 (maximum one sentence):3500 HHs (3000 HHs in West Bengal and 500 HHs in Assam) & 1500 youth (1000 in West Bengal and 500 in Assam) have increased resilience and choices through knowledge of improved practices, new skills, services and information thereby improving their livelihood and income opportunities7.2.c. Objective 2 Activities and timeframe (maximum 300 words):Our primary study reveals that the incidences of underemployment, seasonal unemployment & permanent unemployment are very high among tea workers & youth of the family. This is further aggravated by low wage rates, low levels of skills & lack of avenues for alternative employment. As per the study, on an average a permanent worker in a tea garden worker earns ? 44,000/- per annum with 271 working days; whereas a temporary worker in the garden earns ? 31,300/- per annum with 187 working days. Further, the study highlighted that 80% of the participants have been provided access to primary school for their children but access to the next stage of schooling is only 18% and under 5% report access to secondary and higher secondary schools. Thus, the tea workers & youth 7.2.b. Objective 2 Expected results/outcomes and timeframe (maximum 300 words):a. 3500 Tea worker households have increased access to information, knowledge about improved farming and allied practices to diversify income. About 60% of the HHs will show 20-30% increase in their income1500 Youth from Tea worker community have increased opportunity for jobs or enterprise through improved knowledge and skills on specific market-oriented trade. About 50% of the trained youth who are placed/started their enterprise continue to work in the same vocation.    Grant Application Form, July 1 201315of the family (both male & female) often migrate to distant locations & engage in low paying unorganized sectors. Without informed choice many of them also fall prey to trafficking as this is seen as the only way out of this situation. Hence the creation of alternative livelihoods and the generation of supplementary income are key areas to intervene for sustenance of the families of tea workers.   The proposed action, both farm and farm allied income generating opportunities will be carried out with 3500 households (3000 HHs in West Bengal, 500 HHs in Assam). Simultaneously, 1500 youth (1000 in West Bengal and 500 in Assam) will be trained on vocational skills and provided with jobs and opportunity to be self-employed.       a.Farm and Farm allied income generation with 3500 Households: Livelihood planning for each household will be based on a participatory assessment and analysis of resources, skills, capacities of the Tea worker households. Our approach would entail optimum use of their homestead lands and increase in their productive assets, mostly around livestock. We understand that workers have no ownership rights on their dwellings or homestead lands, therefore interventions will be planned and carried out with active engagement of respective garden managements to mitigate the risks of unanticipated decisions of garden managements. Tea worker households will be able to utilise their resources optimally through inputs and trainings on improved and scientific practices, diversification and improved skills.. All this will be facilitated by creating local cadres of trained people who can continue to provide these services and knowledge to the local community. Key activities would include: i.Optimum utilisation of Homestead Lands: The project would facilitate promotion of multi-layered kitchen gardens meeting nutritional as well as income needs of the tea worker families. Model of kitchen gardens will be established considering the seasonal variation and will include Vegetables such as brinjal, leafy vegetables, tomatoes etc.; Creepers such as bottle gourd, pumpkin; and Spices such as coriander & garlic. This will ensure access to low-cost healthy diets throughout the year, save household expenses & also provide opportunity for additional income.  A total of 600 kitchen gardens will be promoted (150-200 kitchen gardens each year) during the project duration. (Ongoing-Year 1,2,3 & 4)ii.Improvement in Productive assets - Livestock: The project will also provide scientific technical trainings on backyard poultry, piggery (in Bengal only) and goatery which will help reduce the high mortality rate of the existing inventory of livestock & enable households to increase their overall HH income. This will be done through establishing both backward and forward linkages. Exposures and capacity building sessions by technical experts in Bengal & Assam will be carried out to develop a community cadre (30), which will essentially take care the necessary need of vet care services. Simultaneously, efforts will be made to collectivise and facilitate the collective sale through the existing womens group. Further convergence with line departments like animal resources departments, agriculture departments, horticulture departments, KVKs (Krishi Vigyan Kendras) will be made for ensuring scale & sustainability beyond the project. (Ongoing-Year 1,2,3 & 4)Black pepper plantation around Areca Nut Tree: Many of the Tea workers Grant Application Form, July 1 201316households have Areca nut Tree in their homestead land. Black Pepper is the most compatible perennial spice crop with areca nut and can be profitably grown. The project will promote Black pepper and help tea worker households to learn the basics of its management. It takes three years for the black pepper to fruit, and in this period the project will also undertake market assessments to help the Women groups market these produce at fair prices, thereby augmenting their incomes. b.Vocational Skills with 1500 Youth: Given that youth segment has an aspiration for other jobs beyond tea gardens, the project will work with youth (both Male and female) to help them with relevant employable and self-employable skills and assist them in getting jobs and/or start their own enterprise. Given the limited opportunities in the area, the project will make an assessment of the skills and trades in which youth are engaged when they migrate out of the state. Focussing on some of these trades will enable them to seek better wages at their destination locations. Youth who would want to set up/establish their own enterprise, targeted business and financial skills will also be imparted. Besides this, the project will also engage in building their self-esteem and leadership that are rooted in their cultural context and identity.         The proposed action is based on the interest and aspirations of the youth. Identification of vocational courses will be done based on assessment of their interests and willingness to pursue the same as their career choice as well as market demand. Relevant training and courses will be offered in collaboration with Government recognised skill training institutions or other institutions having specialised modules for selected trades. Post training, efforts will be made to link trained youth to placement companies for jobs in the mainstream market or to financial institutions for setting up small business. Key activities include: i.Needs and Skills assessment for prioritising vocational courses and enterprises for skill trainings and enterprise promotion (Year 1): The project will introduce a process of selection based on individual choices and interests of youth. For example  in West Bengal counselling and career guidance will help youth to take informed choices around the various offerings. At the same time, in Assam, an open discussion with the youth of the gardens and availability of local opportunities/offerings will help youth to share their willingness to join relevant courses. The project will also map some of the skill gaps highlighted from major employers which would also inform their choices in pursuing their career aspirations.ii.Enterprise development, Skill trainings on the identified vocational courses through Resource Organisations or Government sponsored trainings such as Skill Mission, Rural Self Employment Training Institutes (RSETI) etc. (Y2: 500; Y3: 750; Y4: 250): Based on the skill gap and the choices shared by youth, the teams will organise the training offerings either through linking them with government run skill centres or resource organisations specialised in offering the courses. In Assam, an incubation centre will be set up for youth who wants to pursue the courses to set up their own enterprise. Besides technical training, additional trainings on Business and financial skills will also be imparted to them.  Few of the vocational courses to be imparted to youth (as highlighted during our study) are  Police, Driving, Hospitality, Chef, Motor Mechanic, Beautician, Sewing Grant Application Form, July 1 201317Operator etc.       iii.Counselling sessions, placement linkages and financial linkages through collaboration with placement agencies and financial institutions (Ongoing): The project will have a dedicated resource to work with various placement and employer companies to be able to support the trained youth in assuring their placements. Before the completion of the vocational courses, counselling sessions and softer skills to handle the changes in a new work environment, adjustments to the new place, dos and donts of working will be undertaken. Youth who are keen to set up their own enterprises will be either linked to Banks for seed capital or linked to government schemes such as MUDRA loan, Start Up India scheme, etc.7.3.a. Objective 3 (maximum one sentence):To establish model for improving productivity and mitigating risks of climate change through adoption of climate adaptive practices in two tea select gardens of West Bengal  7.3.c. Objective 3 Activities and timeframe (maximum 300 words):As per the research done by Tea Research Association, climate change is impacting the tea producers in a significant way, as tea is mainly grown under rain-fed mono-cropping systems and weather conditions determine optimal growth & quality of tea. The current trend of irregular nature of rainfall in the area, forces the growers to invest in irrigation facilities which also increases costs besides severe shortage of drinking water to the tea workers, who live on the gardens. Furthermore, declining productivity, increased incidences of pests and diseases compels the garden managements to use heavy doses of pesticides and chemicals having bearing on soil, the food safety standards & impacts severely on the health of the consumers and workers who are exposed to such chemicals. The study done by TRA assess that if this trend continues, large parts, where tea is grown currently will become unviable for commercial tea production in two to three decades.  7.3.b. Objective 3 Expected results/outcomes and timeframe (maximum 300 words):a. Results of the Innovations and climate adaptive practices shared widely with the other Tea Gardens/planters including government thereby improving visibility and demand from the other tea gardensb.   Garden management and workers in 2 tea gardens show enhanced understanding and adaptation to climate change practices, perceives reduced risks and costGrant Application Form, July 1 201318Hence, the project intends to demonstrate and pilot innovative adaptive measures and create models of best practices to be further promoted & replicated to other tea gardens.  The project will work with two tea gardens in West Bengal. These two gardens will be selected based on the level of cooperation extended by garden management and secondly on the extent of scarcity of drinking water in the gardens.The proposed activities related are: a.Water Recharging and harvesting measures: Since most of the tea gardens are located on undulating terrains, the runoff levels are high leading to drying up of natural springs which are the lifeline in the regions. One hectare of mature tea plants require 10,000 litres of water per day which is equivalent to 2.5mm rainfall. Tea plants also need water after pruning which is generally done during the months of Nov- Dec. This is the period when there is less rainfall resulting growers to invest in irrigation facilities. Therefore, interventions on recharging ground water, protecting catchments and reviving springs are critical and requires conjunctive interventions by tea management as well as government. Following pilots will be initiated:  oWater recharge through rainwater harvesting will be initiated in the gardens in convergence with the Government and garden management leveraging existing Government programmes. This would start with the development of a well recharge plan based on the principles of springshed management. A total of six such recharge structure (three each in 2 Tea Gardens) will be undertaken (Y1 and Y 3).    oTwo pilots on providing drinking water will be carried out. This will be a low cost and zero energy intensive model by diverting natural springs and using gravity, channelling the water to the households. Households will have potable water close to their homes which can be used for drinking and also for irrigation in their homesteads. This will be done in Year 2 and Year 3   b.Climate adaptive practices: In this area, the activities will include training Tea garden management and workers on good climate resilient practices and in situ management. Demonstrations in propagation of drought and stress tolerant cultivars, promotion of shade trees, intercropping, nutrient management through vermicompost, pest management etc. will be done in collaboration with the Garden management in the two gardens. This will enable the garden management to experiment and introduce new practices in the garden. Trainings will be carried out in collaboration with Tea Research Association (TRA) in Year 1 and Year 2. Additionally, in association with TRA or private companies, environmental stewardship training shall be conducted in the two gardens to reduce environmental load of agro- chemicals and also workers safety at workplace. A total of 2 such trainings will be done in Year 2 and Year 3.c.Sustainability Standards: There is a growing trend in consumer awareness and brands across all segments are working towards engaging with consumers to enhance transparency in sustainability practices adopted by them. Certification is usually done by third party agencies which is a means of providing assurance to the consumers on the sustainability standards adopted by the organisations. In association with certification agencies such as Trustea, Rainforest Alliance and others, the project will facilitate trainings for the two garden managements on standards for Grant Application Form, July 1 201319certification and also expose the garden management to other gardens who have implemented these standards. The project will encourage the garden managements in developing an implementation plan to meet the standards for certification and also assist them in case of further need. This activity will be initiated in Year 2 and carried on in Year 3. The project will facilitate the tea gardens to adopt the best practices as per the sustainability standards, however, the garden management will bear the cost of certification.  Documentation and development of IEC: The project will document and understand the results of the various innovations and best practices adopted by the tea gardens. Appropriate IEC and communication materials will be developed and shared widely with various platforms and importantly across the gardens of intervention. Longitudinal study will be carried out on an annual basis to be able to understand the changes, inform and develop the IEC and communication materials7.4.a. Objective 4 (maximum one sentence):Informal Forum of Civil Society Organisations constructively engage for giving greater voice and visibility to the conditions of tea worker community through collective action and advocacy.7.4.c. Objective 4 Activities and timeframe (maximum 300 words):The baseline research highlighted the multidimensional nature of vulnerability and issues of Tea worker communities across gender, age and social factors. Several CSOs, national and international organisations have worked towards addressing some of these problems. With the changing context and policy regime affecting the tea industry, there is a constant need to learn and share knowledge, practices and create an enabling platform for cooperation and collaboration amongst various organisations working on Tea worker issues in particular and Tea sector in general. The new labour code that is expected to replace the Plantation Labour Act 1951 offers an important opportunity for broad based understanding and wide dissemination of the labour Code. There is scope for like-minded organisations to come together as a support for Tea workers using their collective strength, experience and influencing powers. This will provide greater visibility to the nearly 7.4.b. Objective 4 Expected results/outcomes and timeframe (maximum 300 words):a. CSO forum identifies at least two policy areas affecting tea workers and undertake joined up action as per the advocacy plan  b. Communication materials on new labour Code allows for easier and broad based understanding of the provisions for all stakeholders including garden management and tea workersGrant Application Form, July 1 201320invisible workers of the most popular beverage of the country Traidcraft has past experience of successfully carrying out campaigns, research and advocating for policies regarding small tea growers and issues pertaining to Assam Tea workers. Building on this experience, Traidcraft India along with its experts from the Policy team at Traidcraft UK would facilitate and steer the informal forum of CSOs for peer to peer learning, sharing practices, capacity building, issue based work and policy advocacy. The following activities will be done under this objective: a.Setting up the forum and joint agenda setting: The project will map relevant CSOs, understand their expertise and assess their interest in working with the Tea workers. In the Year 1 of the project, it would organise meeting with the CSOs that show their interest and co-create its agenda and set policy goals. The informal CSO forum will work on creating awareness on identified topics through print media, social media and policy briefs. One of the key agenda for the group would be to work on the Labour Code which replaces the Plantation Labour act. Specifically, the work would be around simplified understanding of the key aspects of the new Labour Code, translations in local language and wider dissemination through workshops and round tables. Other areas identified at this stage are to map gaps in specific State level rules post transposition of Central level Labour Code which affect Tea workers adversely. Mapping of these gaps would lead to identification of Policy asks and strategize accordingly.b.Issue Based Workshops and Round tables: Periodically, Traidcraft would facilitate knowledge sharing through issue-based workshops and round tables for shared understanding on specific issues - for e.g. workers rights, new labour code, women and violence, trafficking etc. Four round tables and issue-based learning sessions over Year 2 and Year 3 would be organised. This would also help strengthen capacities of the CSO partners of the forum besides developing collective strategy and joined up action to address the various issues of the Tea workers, both in West Bengal and Assam. This would be complemented by Policy Advocacy team at UK taking up an assessment of business performance of Tea companies to assess the overall viability of the companies and scope to invest for welfare of workers. Insights from this study will feed into advocacy strategy at UK and India level in the next phase.Communication and Dissemination event: Working paper, discussions from the round table, communication materials on the new labour code, learnings from the project, results from the longitudinal study etc. will form some of the key documents and knowledge product of the project. Communication material in form of audio visual would also be developed for creating visibility on the of issues of tea worker communities. The same will be disseminated as part of the National level dissemination event and other forums, that will be organised in the Year 4.  Grant Application Form, July 1 201321
GAF_Traidcraft_Exchange_UK_AddreSocioVul.8. COOPERATION: 8. CooperationDescribe the level of cooperation with other organisations and networks and explain how this cooperation helps achieve your goals (maximum 300 words):Traidcraft Exchange will work closely with local partners Prasari in West Bengal and Pajhra in Assam in a spirit of co-implementors with Partners driving the work on the ground, and Traidcraft providing the technical support, and amplifying tea workers voices by convening forums and use of social media. Both CSOs have been working in the region and have good relationships with the tea communities. Traidcraft will work with its India counterpart - Traidcraft Services Private Limited (TSIPL)  a wholly owned subsidiary of Traidcraft Exchange. TSIPL is a social enterprise working towards trade justice and climate justice. TSIPL supports fair trade and responsible business practices that benefit workers and producers and offer strategic advisory and consulting services that are backed with the capacity to support on-ground implementation across Indias diverse geographies. Besides managing the overall program, Traidcraft (TSIPL) will specifically lead the work on Climate adaptive practices (objective 3) in collaboration with Tea Research Association, Tea Garden management and on ground support from Prasari. Simultaneously, Traidcraft including the Traidcraft Exchange policy unit in UK will lead in setting up and coordination of the informal CSO group (Objective 4). Parallelly, the Traidcraft team will also support both Prasari and Pajhra in market linkages and help trained youth find jobs in Companies, build linkages with placement agencies and help set up robust collective enterprises (Objective 2). Importantly, the projects learning will be facilitated through annual planning and reflection workshops, enabling both Prasari and Pajhra synergies their on-ground actions for future.                             PRASARI, established in 2007, works specifically in the areas of water security, diversion-based irrigation to augment the water, and income and nutritional security of the rural households. It works through establishing multi-tiered women-led institutions which are the building blocks to execute any programme. They are active in the Dooars region (Jalpaiguri, Darjeeling, Kalimpong, Alipurduar) of West Bengal and have successfully piloted diversion-based irrigation projects in collaboration with the government and other philanthropic donors. Prasari will implement the project across 25 tea gardens across Jalpaiguri, Kalimpong and Darjeeling. Specific role of Prasari in this project includes: a) establishing robust women and youth forum in all the 25 Tea Gardens in West Bengal; b) work closely with government and Tea garden management in linking up with various social entitlement schemes including nutrition, drinking water, enterprise development etc.; c) establishing farm based livelihoods to 3000 households and counselling and ensuring skill training of 1000 youth; and d) undertake innovative pilots around spring shed, well recharge and diversion based drinking water. While they have been working specifically with women primarily looking at water, livelihoods and nutritional security, working with youth and using a rights perspective from the workers point of view would be a newer area for them. The project will support building their capacities by bringing experts working on youth mobilisation and development. Exposure to Assam and Pajhra will inform their orientation on youth mobilisation as well as build their workers rights perspective. Traidcraft will also help them in bringing in a market perspective for some of the on-farm and off-farm livelihoods besides building linkages and networks for the placement of skilled youth in urban areas.                  Grant Application Form, July 1 201322PAJHRA was established in November 2001 by a group of Adivasi social activists and leaders. It works towards building capabilities of the Adivasi community to access their entitlements, improve their socio-economic status in the society and their wellbeing, and promoting social integration of Adivasis from all walks of life in Assam. Pajhra will implement the project across 10 tea gardens across Biswanath and Sonitpur districts in Assam. In this project, Pajhra will specifically lead on: a) establishing robust women and youth forum in all the 10 Tea Gardens in Assam; b) working closely with government and Tea garden management in linking up with various social entitlement schemes including nutrition, drinking water, youth scholarship, enterprise development etc.; c) establishing farm based livelihoods to 500 households and counselling and ensuring skill training of 500 youth. In addition to this, Pajhra will also bring its knowledge on the issue of Tea workers and build perspective around wage and living wage within the CSO group.  Pajhra has been working with tea workers, which are primarily Adivasis, and have been actively developing youth and women leaders within the community. Skill building, enterprise development for youth and climate adaptive practices will be a newer area of work for them. Traidcraft will mentor Pajhras implementation team in ensuring business and market linkage support. At the same time, engagement with TRA and exposure to Prasaris project area will build their perspective on climate adaptive practices.  Another area of cooperation and support sought by both organisations is in the area of Organisational Development. Pajhra has expressed their need for reviewing their organisational work and identify areas that require improvement or strengthening. Based on the review, Pajhra would also be open to consider a possible restructuring. This has been also mandated by their Board and would have full support from their leadership team. Prasari, who has recently undergone an Organisational Review Exercise and is already implementing the recommendations, is keen to develop inhouse capacities within management team to take up Organisational Development (OD) and Learning in future. They would like to invest in capacity building of management team members on OD processes. Apart from these two field partner CSOs, the program will also engage other stakeholders and agencies, primarily towards achieving its objective for piloting climate adaptive practices & sustainability standards in the tea gardens and establishing an informal CSO group working for the welfare of tea workers both at regional and national level. Traidcraft will spearhead both the partnership and leading the thematic area, given its own capability and knowledge in the tea sector and understanding of the system of managing and implementing standards.For climate adaptive practices, we would partner with the Tea Research Association (TRA)  which has been set up principally to improve the overall productivity and quality of the tea. It is a pioneer and innovator in tea research and provides extension services to the tea industry. We are already in discussion with TRA HQ in Kolkata and they have their field offices both at Jorhat (Assam) and Jalpaiguri (West Bengal). In relation to improving and promoting sustainability standards (both climate as well as worker friendly) in the tea gardens where we would work, we will engage with multi stakeholder initiatives such as Trustea (an Indian sustainability code and verification system for the tea sector working with smallholder tea growers, bought leaf factories, estates and packers to address some of the key challenges in the industry including working conditions, health and safety of tea workers, water pollution, food safety, soil erosion and contamination) and/or Trinitea (an Indian initiative to transform the tea smallholder segment in India while taking care of the social and environmental issues).Grant Application Form, July 1 201323    For initiating the informal CSO group, we will partner with a number of like-minded CSOs and MSIs that are active in working for the welfare of tea workers and the tea sector overall. Organisations like Oxfam, Nazdeek, UNWomen, Unicef, Solidaridad and many more will be contacted to be a part of this initiative. We have discussed the idea with Oxfam, and they have shown a very positive response on the same.       In addition to this, expert organisations working on the issues of youth, skill building, leadership and domestic violence will be roped in as resource agencies to be able to support the partners capacity development.
GAF_Traidcraft_Exchange_UK_AddreSocioVul.9. MONITORING, EVALUATION & LEARNING: 9. ImpactWhat is the change you want to achieve from the overall project? (maximum 300 words):In this phase, the project will be able to build the foundation of stronger and empowered tea community across 35 tea Gardens. Besides this, an enabling environment and engagement model between tea garden management, tea communities, government and CSOs will be strengthened. Successful models of climate adaptive practices will be tested and will be ready to be scaled to other tea gardens. At the end of the project, following expected impacts are envisaged:The following changes are envisaged at the end of four year: Strengthened community groups and forums working with the Garden Management, Panchayats and Government officials to improve the delivery of various services and entitlements. Improved choices and alternative options of Tea worker communities through diversified livelihoods, skills and knowledge. Around 60% of participating households (3500) have increased income of 15-30% (baseline survey and Annual monitoring on sample basis)Tea worker communities especially youth experience a general improvement in their status and are able to articulate the changes in their personality, attitudes, behaviour and sense of social responsibility which are evident in the initiatives taken by them. (Case studies)Visibility from the success of the Climate resilient production and management practices within Tea Gardens serve as lessons for further scale up as reflected through enhanced demand from other Tea Gardens.Civil Society forum builds on their collective strength to formulate a common strategic framework of work to support Tea workers and the sectorLocal partners feel empowered and capacitated to address the issues of Tea workers and gain credibility with various stakeholders- especially Garden management and Government agencies and the community at large.Grant Application Form, July 1 201324 10. EvaluationHow will progress be monitored and evaluated? (maximum 300 words):Our commitment to understanding the impact of our programmes and driving continued learning and improving, requires that we utilize robust M&E methods, systems and tools. Following mechanisms will be put in place to assess the progress, monitor and evaluate the success of the project; a. Participatory approach to MEL: Traidcraft Exchange will adopt a participatory approach for monitoring the progress of the project. This will be determined by the local communities identification of the metrics of their progress based on the ground situation and the baseline. Supporting project participants to themselves determine their metrics will enable a process of empowerment of local workers in the tea estate which will strengthen their sense of agency and also increase their mutual collaboration for collective benefit. Traidcraft has experience to support local collectives on participatory monitoring of their own development and will guide the process in the duration of the project. In addition to this, engaging selected beneficiaries for longitudinal case studies which is a more qualitative approach to capture changes in their lives over a period of time, will be undertaken by the project. Such studies supported by case studies will capture degree of change in confidence and leadership abilities of the target group. This will include improvement in livelihoods, agency and aspirations, access to entitlements etc. b. Logical Framework Analysis (LFA) based progress assessment: Complementing the above participatory approach to MEL, the project will have a clear set of indicators for each outcome and output area outlined above based on the LFA framework. Development of the LFA and monitoring framework at the outset of the initiation of the project will be carried out in collaboration with the on-ground partners  viz. Prasari and Pajhra. This will be guided by a detailed baseline that will be done in the first year of the project.  Data will be collected against the set indicators for the above-mentioned Outcome areas. Specifically, data on current levels of production in the two pilot gardens, availability and accessibility of drinking water, sources of water and cultivation practices will be collected in baseline and mapped annually to understand the changes on these parameters as well as adoption of recommended practices on environment and safety measures.  A dynamic excel based project MIS will be developed to capture the data and track the progress.   Grant Application Form, July 1 201325c. Ongoing Monitoring and Learning: Traidcraft India will manage all M&E activities with support from our UK-based Quality & Impact Lead. Monthly review meetings with partners will be done as part of planning and monitoring. External members of Traidcraft will join quarterly meetings which will be documented through quarterly reports and meeting minutes. These meetings will provide opportunities for the project team to reflect on progress, learning and implications for adaptive programming. In addition, the project will also organise annual partners meet for reflections and planning for the upcoming year. These annual reflection exercises are facilitated to capture individual and collective learnings on the project, that are essential for future planning. In addition, it helps in identifying shortcomings and build common strategy to address as a group. Annual Narrative and Financial Reports will be prepared that will be shared with Oak Foundation on a periodic basis. d. Mid term and Endline Evaluation: A mid-term evaluation will be done by the second year end for reviewing progress and learning based on which recommendations will be incorporated. Mid term assessment typically involves assessment of the progress, more importantly capturing the key learnings and assessment of any mid-term course correction requirement in the project. It is carried out by Traidcraft team members who are not directly associated with the project management or implementation. A final evaluation will be conducted by the project end using mixed methodology (both qualitative and quantitative tools with participatory approaches) to assess the projects impact and learning including progress against all indicators, outcomes and objectives. It is especially important as proposed work is a multi-phase programme, where the learnings from the endline evaluation will contribute to the design of the next phase.
GAF_Traidcraft_Exchange_UK_AddreSocioVul.11. ADDITIONAL QUESTIONS/ Future Plans: 11. Future PlansHow will the grant influence the organisation and future plans? (maximum Grant Application Form, July 1 201326300 words):Traidcraft is keen to work to resolve issues of tea workers and so this is a long term partnership. Along with our local partners we will support interventions to improve the livelihoods of the tea worker communities and help in developing sustainable models for income diversification while imparting new skills and knowledge. Based on this, there is significant scope of expanding these initiatives in similar geographies with similar issues. The grant will also demonstrate multipronged intervention models based on an assessment of skills, resources, capabilities and aspirations of the community of tea workers. While Traidcraft has already gained an understanding of multidimensional vulnerability in the lives of tea worker communities, the interventions require a long-term engagement with the community. Having suffered from such issues across generations, there is a sense of hopelessness and erosion of agency. Therefore, it is imperative that interventions build incremental improvement and thereby confidence to exert their agency. Thus the intervention design will span multi-phase interventions, of which the current phase is primarily the entry point, aimed at establishing rapport and confidence as well as an enabling environment to piggy back other interventions addressing issues of rights, working conditions, migration, trafficking, violence and climate change. In this, there is opportunity to scale operations in other geographies in the north east as well as other tea growing regions. Traidcraft UK, through its previous interventions with global brands, has significant experience of creating transparency in sourcing tea and also raising consumer awareness regarding issues on the ground. A long-term model for domestic area can be designed to raise consumer awareness regarding the issues faced by workers and engaging local brands and other stakeholders in promoting more transparent ways of operating. This will create a new wave in consumer awareness and brand engagement in the country which has one of the highest tea consuming population. Traidcraft also will take a lead role to create a multi-stakeholder platform for the issues in the tea sector. This platform will have civil society organisations, donor agencies, local activists and government representatives who will work towards improving policy and action taking into account the voices of the affected people. We envisage that such a platform will provide Traidcraft the opportunity to highlight the issues of the tea worker community and create an enabling environment overall. Given that climate change has a significant impact on productivity in the tea sector Traidcraft, through this project will rope in other stakeholders like the Tea Research Association etc. to provide the needed inputs and knowledge on better management practices suitable to changing climatic conditions which will provide useful directions to other tea estate managements in the regions. Traidcraft will actively disseminate these learnings amongst a wide audience so that there is greater awareness on the issues of tea.  This will enable a more equitable playing field for various actors engaged in the tea industry, especially the tea estate workers who constitute the weakest link in the chain.Grant Application Form, July 1 201327

(scale up our current work) or (provide continued support to) (75 words) The project aims to develop a community-led climate resilience model for informal workers in the Kolkata Metropolitan Region (KMR). It will empower women-led community action groups across 35 urban settlements, promoting access to social security entitlements, social protection, and climate adaptation awareness. The initiative will focus on applying affordable solutions for climate-resilient livelihoods, enhancing the capacity of these communities to adapt to climate challenges. GAF_MHT - Final.pdf.5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT: 5. ORGANISATION CONTEXT   5a. Tell us about your governance and leadership structures, as well as staff and volunteer base. Highlight any significant recent or expected future changes. If you have an explicit approach to increasing diversity and/or advancing race equity within the organisation, please tell us. (300 words): Mahila Housing Trust (MHT) is a not-for-profit organization which works with the mission to organize and empower women in poor communities to improve their habitat. MHT is working in 34 cities across 9 states in India on three major domains: Habitat Development, Climate Resilience and Participatory Governance. Over the last 28 years, MHT has made a significant impact in improving the lives of urban poor across 1126 slum settlements and currently has in place 983 Community Action Groups (CAGs) consisting of 11-15 members each who are grass-root women leaders in those slum communities. MHT thus possess a strong social capital of 15,954 grass-root leaders serving as amplifiers in the slum communities. They further come together as a peer group   Oak Application Form     5 of informed and articulate citizens to participate in shaping urban policies, including those, on climate change. We also work in Nepal and Bangladesh, through our partners.  MHT prides itself in the fact, that, it is a grass roots technical organization. It is also a Gandhian organization. Our staffing consists of professionals like engineers, architects and urban planners to grassroots women leaders, in an equal proportion. Additionally we also have what we call spearhead teams, who are women from the community itself who work on an honorarium with us. We have 150+  fulltime staff/consultants and offices across eight states in India More than 80 percent of our staff is women and all programmes are women led.  Our Governance constitutes of nine members on our Board of Trustees, of which two are men and rest are women, making us a women led organization. Three women members in a board of nine(33%) are from the minority community and including backward classes in India. Two members of the three as mentioned above are also from the grassroots, (the rest being professionals). The grassroots board members, largely perform  the roles of watch dog to safe guard and speakup for the rights of  the poor women and ensure that MHT adheres to its vision and mission. Over the past two years we have been specially focusing on developing the leadership of tribal and muslim women through our programmes and have a geographical focus on regions which has a larger population of these two communities in particular. Again since our work enables poor women, to execute their right in for basic services, land, housing,  sanitation water and clim ate change,  we are also focusing for the next few years to build the leadership of adolescent girls in these focus areas.    5b. Summarise the organisations history.  In addition, highlight 2-3 key achievements. Please keep this brief and list up to 3 key achievements as bullet points. Even though you may have many achievements, please share what is most relevant to the proposed grant. (300 words) Founded in 1994, with the mission of promoting sound habitats and living environment of poor women in the informal sector, Mahila Housing Trust (MHT), believes, that if the capacities of the marginalised especially women, are enhanced to exercise their civic rights, poor women can become drivers of sustainable and inclusive urban development in their communities and citiesAmongst other achievements, till date, we have provided clean energy access to 355,543 individuals, reached habitat development services to 39,39,261 individuals, developed 13,732 climate leaders, 22,636 household property titles worth USD 22.14 million registered in the name of poor women.  Our poor women led model for climate resilience in South Asia, has received the 2019 award by United Nations Disaster Risk Reduction followed by UNFCCC momentum for change award in the women for results category. More recently, we were a  finalists for the 2020 WRI ROSS Prize For Cities, finalists for the Ashden Award, 2020, in the cooling in informal settlements, category and  2021 Prince Talal International Prize for Human Development.
