(600 words): Context Informal workers form the mainstay of the Indian economy. Informal workers in Kolkatas slum settlements face numerous challenges. Economically, they endure unstable incomes, lack social security, and are often exploited. Housing is overcrowded and poorly constructed. Health issues are rampant due to unsanitary conditions, limited healthcare access, and poor nutrition. Educational opportunities are scarce, with many children forced into labor. Environmental hazards, such as pollution and vulnerability to natural disasters, exacerbate their living conditions. Basic infrastructure, including clean water, electricity, and proper sewage systems, is often inadequate.  The Kolkata Metropolitan Area is a metropolitan area in the Indian state of West Bengal, centred around the city of Kolkata (also known as Calcutta). It is the largest urban agglomeration in the eastern part of India and the third largest in the country, housing over 14.85 million people, as of the 2011 census. The Kolkata Metropolitan Area is comprised of the city of Kolkata, its suburbs, several neighbouring towns (including 4 municipal corporations, and 27 municipalities) and adjoining rural areas. It is the economic, cultural, and educational hub of eastern India and hosts several major commercial and industrial centres, making it one of the most important economic zones in India.[3] Informal workers like street vendors, domestic workers, construction workers and waste pickers are expected to be around 20 - 25 lakh (over 2 million) in a similar situation as other parts of the country, without much social security and living in the margins of the current developmental discourse. The KMA also has a large informal sector that employs a significant number of migrant workers, particularly in construction, domestic work, and small-scale industries. These workers face compounded challenges such as low wages, long working hours, and poor working conditions. Many of them live in makeshift housing and lack access to basic amenities like clean water, sanitation, and health care. Migrant workers face social challenges, such as discrimination, isolation, and limited access to education and health services. It is estimated that around 50% of the informal workers (1 million) are migrants, with an equal percentage from other districts of Bengal and migrants from other states like Bihar, Odisha, Jharkhand, and Assam. An equal or similar share of outmigration is reported as well.[4] The Kolkata Metropolitan Area is also located precariously. Like many other coastal cities in the world, is facing a range of impacts from climate change and is listed in the top eight megacities to be first impacted by climate change. The city is in the deltaic region of eastern India, which makes it vulnerable to sea level rise and increased frequency and intensity of extreme weather events such as tropical cyclones, heavy rainfall, and heat waves.[5] The changing climate is leading to an increased risk of coastal flooding and erosion, as well as water scarcity, particularly during the dry season. The city's infrastructure and public services, including transportation, energy, and water systems, are also vulnerable to the impacts of climate change, which can strain these systems and result in economic losses. In addition to the physical impacts, the changing climate also has social and economic impacts on the people of the Kolkata Metropolitan Area. The most impacted areas overlapping directly with the informal worker settlements in the region are vulnerable to displacement, loss of livelihoods, and increased poverty because of climate change.   Oak Application Form     7 To address these challenges, the government in the Kolkata Metropolitan Area, led by the Kolkata Municipal Corporation are taking steps to increase the region's resilience to climate change. This includes implementing flood control measures, improving disaster preparedness and response, investing in climate-resilient infrastructure, and preparing climate action plans for their cities.[6][7] The major concern in the slew of positively directed actions is that informal workers, their live-work settlements and their livelihoods as of now are not a major focus area of the climate resilience actions pushed by the state and authorities. Thereby ignoring the most vulnerable, impacted informal workers from the climate resilience action plans for the region. Also straight-jacketed approaches of focusing on the urban infrastructure building, without focusing on capacities and linkages ignoring migration from climate-impacted rural regions is another gap amongst many in the climate resilience actions. This approach requires a change: in perspective and in action.  That is what this intervention sets to achieve  CHANGE that is for and led by the empowerment of the most vulnerable informal worker communities. [1] In India, informal workers are those individuals who work in unorganized sectors and are not covered by labour laws or social security measures. This segment of the workforce includes self-employed individuals, casual labourers, street vendors, domestic workers, and other unorganized sector workers. [2] The labour codes in India refer to a set of laws and regulations that govern various aspects of employment, including wages, working conditions, social security, and industrial relations. In 2020, the Indian government introduced four new labour codes, namely, the Code on Wages, the Industrial Relations Code, the Occupational Safety, Health and Working Conditions Code, and the Social Security Code. [3] https://kmda.wb.gov.in/ [4] https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/more-migrants-to-city-from-other-states-than-districts/articleshow/70354414.cms [5] https://www.downtoearth.org.in/news/climate-change/disaster-deaths-sinking-unprepared-kolkata-face-multiple-climate-risks-warns-ipcc-report-82004 [6] https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/kolkata-set-to-get-own-climate-action-plan-2nd-city-after-mum/articleshow/92049423.cms [7] https://www.downtoearth.org.in/news/governance/cop27-kolkata-presents-climate-action-roadmap-announces-city-level-summit-86026 MHT with support from the Oak Foundation will implement the project titled Community Led climate resilience for informal workers with an objective to build resilience of urban poor families.  The project will be implemented based on MHT approach as mentioned below:  1. Support disenfranchised communities to build social capital and empower them with technical knowledge to affect change 2. Facilitate last-mile delivery of social security and habitat services by creating awareness and enabling access to various schemes of Government. 3. Build on its grassroots experience to bring other policy and regulatory changes towards more inclusive planning and service delivery processes.

The process of enabling women leaders through Community Action Groups for climate resilience and to access benefits of social security schemes will be implemented with following activities. i. Community Mobilization: In the challenging and often marginalized environments of urban settlement in both ULB, community mobilization plays a pivotal role in initiating and sustaining positive change. MHT will deploy diverse methods such as folk media, community meetings and video screenings to engage residents based on their local context and acceptance. The overarching goal is to raise awareness about the organization and project details while establishing a strong rapport with the community. This approach ensures active community participation and a sense of ownership over the projects.   ii. Research study  Baseline study on social security: In the inception stage of the project (1st quarter) household level social security survey will be carried out in 30 project slums. Survey will be conducted with below given objectives: Assess Accessibility and Awareness:  Objective: To evaluate the current level of accessibility to and awareness of existing social security schemes among households in the project slums.   Oak Application Form     10  Rationale: Understanding the baseline accessibility and awareness will help identify gaps and barriers preventing households from fully benefiting from these schemes. Identify Needs and Preferences:  Objective: To identify the specific social security needs of households and their preferred methods for receiving services.  Rationale: Gathering information on households' needs and preferences will enable the project to tailor interventions and recommendations to better meet the community's requirements. Evaluate Willingness to Pay:  Objective: To determine the willingness of households to pay for social security services and their expectations regarding service delivery.  Rationale: Understanding the financial willingness and expectations of households will inform the design and implementation of sustainable social protection schemes that are both affordable and acceptable to the community. iii. Landscape study- integration of climate resilience in existing policy: To enhance climate resilience for the urban poor and informal sector workers, we propose conducting a comprehensive landscape study of existing state and local government policies and programs. This intervention will involve a detailed analysis of current policy frameworks to assess the extent to which climate change considerations are integrated. By identifying gaps and opportunities, we aim to pinpoint strategic entry points for strengthening climate resilience measures within social security programs. This approach will enable us to develop targeted recommendations for policy enhancements that not only address immediate social security needs but also build long-term resilience against climate-related vulnerabilities, ensuring sustainable and inclusive growth for the most marginalized populations. iv.  Formation and Trainings of CAGs : It is increasingly accepted that the social capital of communities can contribute to beneficial economic and social outcomes in urban development. MHT believes that if the grassroots collectives of women are provided with the requisite knowledge, technology and skills to identify and assess development issues, they will be able to constructively engage with governance and planning processes to lead transformation in their own communities. Based on this philosophy, MHT will organise and train women leaders from urban poor communities across city. These women leaders will undergo extensive training on various subject like collective leadership, government structure, map sharing & participation, formation of slum development plan, climate change etc. These women leaders will then lead project activities in urban poor settlements across both ULB. They will play pivotal role in connecting urban poor communities with city government, elected representative and other stakeholders. Understanding of its impacts and the critical role women can play in climate stress. Empower participants to increase their capacity to respond effectively to climate challenges and promote gender-sensitive climate solutions. 2 20 4 Training on important climate stress To educate participants on the impacts of climate stress factors such as heat, flooding, vector-borne diseases, and air pollution, equipping them with knowledge and strategies to mitigate these effects and promote community resilience and health. 2 20  v. Improving access to entitlement and social security programs  Entire process will be completed in a systematic way as mentioned below.   MHT will establish a dedicated spearhead team, each team member responsible for 3 slums and visiting the slums at least 2 times per week.   MHT team to re-visit government portal/office to re-confirm detail about all identified social security schemes and make necessary changes where required. Awareness drive on relevant social security schemes with aim to encourage people to get enrolled. Awareness campaign will continue throughout project duration and messaging will change based on field/project need.   Identification of new eligible beneficiaries if any by CAGs  Completion of application form and collection of required supporting documents by CAGs & MHT field staff  Submission of application form to relevant government department by CAG member & MHT field staff  Follow-up with government department for timely processing of the application by CAG members and MHT field staff  CAGs to keep beneficiary informed regarding their application status  CAG & MHT field staff to keep record of successful application and availed benefits  vi. Conduct Climate Vulnerability Assessment  Community-based Vulnerability Assessment is being done with special toolkit which is a set of seven participatory tools, which aimed to create an understanding among the community about climate change and its varied impacts. The purpose of this exercise is to create a understanding in terms of climate change. The first stage of the exercise is the realise stage, where the purpose is to inculcate a understanding where the community starts to envision the harmful weather effects that they are facing with climate change. The second stage is the Analyse stage, where community starts to interlink the effects and initiate a thought process from systems thinking approach. The third stage contains visualization of effects with respect to their areas. In the last stage, based upon the previous processes where risks were identified, community will synthesis a resilience plan.  vii. Develop Climate Resilience Action Plan : Based on the vulnerability assessment, the leaders will be trained to make action plan. CAGs along with other active members from settlement will prioritize activities, timeline, budget to accomplish the activities.    viii. Implementation of Climate Resilience Action Plan  Based on the settlement climate resilience plan, Community Action Groups (CAGs) and other active settlement members will take the lead in implementing the plan. MHT will play a pivotal role by demonstrating key activities in selected settlements to inspire and encourage leaders to mobilize resources effectively. This hands-on approach will provide a practical framework, showcasing successful strategies and fostering confidence among leaders to prioritize activities, establish realistic timelines, and allocate necessary budgets. Through this collaborative effort, the community will be better equipped to enhance its resilience against climate-related challenges, ensuring a more sustainable and secure future.   Oak Application Form     13  ix. Provide technical assistance to social enterprise to make livelihood climate resilience  Providing technical assistance to social enterprises of urban informal workers to enhance climate resilience involves several steps. Trainings awareness will be offered on climate-smart practices, such as sustainable waste management, energy-efficient technologies, and climate-resilient livelihood, accessing marketing support, finance etc. Collaborate with local government and service providers to create support networks. Networking support will empower informal workers to sustain their livelihoods amidst climate challenges.  x. Demonstration of climate resilience Solution : Based on priority, need, and vulnerability assessments, climate resilience solutions for various climate stresses, including heat and flooding, will be planned. MHT's extensive experience in heat and flooding resilience technologies will be leveraged, incorporating solutions such as solar reflective white paints, net zero cooling stations, and vector-borne disease control drives. These interventions will be strategically implemented to address specific vulnerabilities, ensuring the community is better equipped to withstand and adapt to climate challenges. MHT's expertise will guide the community in adopting effective, sustainable practices to enhance overall resilience and improve living conditions. (300 words): Monitoring plan of MHT All projects implemented by MHT begin with the Slum profile/ baseline and sets the targets to be achieved. Regular field visit and monitoring meetings by Program Manager will provide support for timely implementation/operations. These visits will serve to review project impact, engage with stakeholders, and make informed decisions regarding any necessary corrective actions. Additionally, Mahila Housing Trust possesses an online Management Information System that will be used for real-time monitoring of project progress, allowing us to maintain a continuous and up-to-date understanding of project developments. (300 words):   Kolkata Sanved started with a team comprising of the Founder Director and founder members who were survivors of sexual violence and trafficking. The organization included professional expertise with time and expansion of its programmes. Kolkata Sanveds organizational structure functions as an adhocracy where roles and responsibilities are flexible and varied. It also has features of a professional bureaucracy where a lot of the decision-making power rests with the operating core of which 60% consist of ind ividuals from marginalized communities. Kolkata Sanveds work is overseen by the Executive Director who is guided by a governing board. The role of the Board is to give the organization strategic direction. The Board ensures representation from all stakeho lders and includes a member who is a survivor.  With the current financial landscape and sustainability in mind, Kolkata Sanved has developed a unique strategy for employing and engaging individuals within the organization. The core team at KS consists of 23 permanent members who shoulder all liabilities. Additionally, there are 7 full -time project staff members who receive social benefits. The rest of the team is employed as consultants and on a contractual basis, allowing them to work with KS as well as other organizations.  Employees who emerge from grassroots initially spend their first year engaged either as consultants or project staff. Following this period, they have the opportunity to join the core team. This approach not only ensures a sustainable employment model but also fosters a culture of growth and development within Kolkata Sanved.   Founder Director mentors the team, is actively involved in leadership development, research and academic programme development, high-level training, relationship building, fundraising, visioning and guiding the organization in crisis situations.   A nine members Senior Lea dership Team (SLT) execute strategic activity, takes core decisions, and provides directions for regular functioning for achieving and sustaining excellence. 4 founder members who are survivors are part of the SLT. Director Development: plays a key role in helping KS build sustainability.  Head of Programmes: The Head of Programmes is responsible for leading and managing all programs of Kolkata Sanved. This role is tasked with ensuring the quality of all programming by clearly communicating the vision and ob jectives of all Kolkata Sanved programs plus providing sufficient support for the fulfillment of these objectives. Summarise the organisations mission and history. In addition, highlight 2-3 key achievements. Please keep this brief and list up to 3 key achievements as bullet points. Even though you may have many achievements, please share what is most relevant to the proposed grant.  (300 words):  Founded in 2004, Kolkata Sanved (KS) is a women -led pioneer organization in the field of Dance Movement Therapy (DMT), promoting holistic well -being and quality life enhancement. KS has contributed to gender equality, mental health and well -being by working for empowerment of marginalized individuals (children, adolescent girls, youth & women) using DMT and other creative arts.  In the 1990s, Sohini Chakraborty began experimenting  with DMT to complement the traditional rehabilitation process with the residents of an NGO -run shelter home in Kolkata. The initiative grew into a full -blown project and finally culminated in the establishment of Kolkata Sanved in 2004 to serve as a platf orm for using DMT in psychosocial rehabilitation.  Sohini was awarded the Ashoka Fellowship for her   Oak Application Form8 innovative and unique idea that incorporated creative therapies within traditional rehabilitation programmes, and more importantly: in building capacity with in the participants to become DMT practitioners themselves, able to earn a living as well as live a life of dignity and respect.    KSs culturally contextual model Sampoornata (meaning fulfilment) focuses on holistic well-being and bringing about a cha nge within. This includes physical, emotional, mental, spiritual and social aspects. The model focuses on psycho -social rehabilitation of survivors of violence & marginalization, prevention of violence & promotion of mental health. The hallmark of Sampoornata is to create DMT practitioners, leaders and change-makers from grassroots. 60% of KS core employees are from marginalized communities with representations in primary constituents, Board & Senior Leadership Team.   KS has broken new grounds by taking i ts work to various non -profits, marginalized communities, mainstream schools, NGO &Govt.  run care institutions, mental hospitals etc.by collaborating with 60+ organizations and government departments across South Asia. Working with diverse population, KS has expanded its reach to seven states.The establishment of the Dance Movement Therapy Leadership Development Academy (DMTLDA) signifies a structured approach to facilitate the growth of DMT practitioners from underprivileged communities. 130+ such individ uals have developed skills to become DMT practitioners & change -makers with recognition of 10+ such DMT practitioners at the national and international level. Along with this, KS, in partnership with the Tata Institute of Social Sciences, Mumbai, offers a Post Graduate Diploma program in DMT. This significant milestone places DMT within the realm of academic rigor and formal recognition, contributing to the creation of a new discipline and profession with 200+graduates.Over the years, KS has established a strong collaboration with the Department of Women and Child Development and Social Welfare, Government of West Bengal &Maharashtra. Kolkata Sanved was featured in an international documentary film called "Little Stones," with over 70 screenings globally. KS's work was showcased on the Oprah Winfrey Network (OWN). The Kolkata Sanved Sampoornata model was published as a book by Routledge - Taylor and Francis Group. To date, Kolkata Sanved has served 65,000+ members of marginalized communities and connected with 200,000+ citizens.    KSs V ision is to form a healthy, violence -free, gender -equal, creative society of empowered individuals.   Our Mission is to enhance gender equality and improve mental health and wellbeing of individuals and communities by building an ecosystem for DMT for social development. We strive to create DMT practitioners, leaders and change -makers in the field from vulnerable & un derprivileged communities by establishing a Centre for Creative Wellbeing and Social Change.   5f. (600 words):  India is home to the world's largest youth population, totalling over 808 million individuals, constituting around 66% of the overall populace. The mental health and well -being of adolescents and young adults are pivotal for comprehensive development. Give n that a significant portion of mental health conditions emerges by the mid -twenties, a systematic approach to addressing youth mental health is imperative. India, with a youth demographic of over 250 million aged 15 24, grapples with unique challenges suc h as academic pressure, interpersonal relationships, vocational concerns, and discrimination based on caste, social status, and gender norms. The National Mental Health Survey for India discloses alarmingly high suicide rates, standing at 17.1 per 100,000 among young adults and 9.52 per 100,000 among adolescents. The COVID -19 pandemic exacerbated existing challenges, leading to increased stress, depression, anxiety, post -traumatic stress, substance abuse, and suicides among young people. The pandemic widene d existing inequities, disproportionately affecting those in poor communities, who face additional barriers in accessing resources for health, education and social welfare.  Despite being viewed as the energetic force shaping society's future, the youth ar e susceptible to various challenges and vulnerabilities. These encompass engaging in high -risk behaviours exposing them to criminal activities, accidents, physical injuries, emotional distress, and various health issues. Limited employment options, restric ted access to information, and economic displacement have a lasting psycho-social impact on children, youth, and their families, particularly concerning mental health. This impact manifests in feelings of isolation, identity struggles, and a prevailing sense of hopelessness. The youth in North Bengal's tea gardens face multifaceted challenges that hinder their growth, development, and wellbeing. These challenges stem from the historical context of the tea industry's crisis, economic disparities, and lack of  access to education and opportunities. Although tea estate employees constitute a substantial workforce, their socio-economic conditions remain deplorable. Within this context, the youth in tea gardens confront an array of challenges, including severely limited access to quality education, healthcare, and employment opportunities, fostering a pervasive sense of hopelessness and disempowerment. Many youths and teenagers in these areas struggle for survival, with educational opportunities remaining distant dreams for most. Children and youth often fall victim to trafficking for labour and other forms of exploitation, exacerbating their challenges. Sustained psycho -social support interventions are essential to empower the youth, enhance their mental and emotio nal resilience, and provide them with opportunities for a brighter future.  Our approach involves engaging youth groups and key stakeholders through Dance Movement Therapy (DMT) sessions, ensuring a participatory process that incorporates their voices and perspectives into the design of future interventions. In accordance with the Kolkata Sanved model, the process for establishing the demand for mental well-being interventions follows a strategic sequence. Initially, our model operates in collaboration with  existing organizations in the region and the target community, leveraging established networks and resources. Secondly, a community network is cultivated, providing orientation to individuals on the benefits of mental well-being to raise awareness and pro mote understanding within the community. The intervention itself   Oak Application Form10 incorporates a unique feature, offering participants the opportunity to undergo training as Dance Movement Therapy (DMT) practitioners and change-makers. This approach not only enhances the s kills and knowledge of community members but also empowers them to actively contribute to mental well -being initiatives. A pivotal role is played by the youth leader who, having undergone training becomes an ambassador through this process, and conducts well-being sessions within the community. This individual effectively bridges the gap, meeting the demand for mental well-being interventions at the grassroots level.   6. Phase 1: Formative Research and piloting DMT session: 18 months   In the first half of the project, our primary focus will be on conducting a thorough Needs Assessment and Situational Analysis. This step is pivotal for understanding the unique challenges and aspirations of the local youth, communities, and stakeholders within North Bengal in relation to mental health and well -being. This phase will involve multiple crucial activities including a pilot of DMT sessions within the new region. To start off with, Kolkata Sanved will conduct an orientation on the program with all the concerned stakeholders.  The broad activities will include:   Preparation: Project team formation, partner identification, stakeholder mapping, location identification  Situational analysis and assessment: Research design and methodology, data collection, DMT sessions with the youth, data analysis  Community engagement  through DMT, DMT based workshops with youth and stakeholders  Developing Final Module and Intervention Plan: Dissemination with local stakeholders  Monitoring & Documentation In this participatory research methodology, the tools that will be used for data c ollection are a combination of the following, which includes survey, Focused Group Discussions (FGD), one to one interview, self -reporting through questionnaires and Dance Movement therapy-based workshops. Kolkata Sanved plans to engage Praxis for implemen ting this research.  This situation analysis will be a community led research where the youth and community members will be involved in the research process. For example, having a discussion with them to develop research questions in order to design the intervention around their needs.  The formative research will largely focus on the current reality of North Bengal Youth whether the planned intervention will fulfil the needs and complement those reality. The research will include sample locations with a mi x of socio -cultural identities, including gender and a few other categories such as education, opportunity, aspirations. Ideally, we are planning for 3 locations in each district to get a comprehensive scenario. As this   Oak Application Form12 intervention will be focused on ment al health, wellbeing and agency building, we will also include a mental health expert in the team.  Phase 2: Implementation: 18 months In the second half of the project, our focus will be to implement the intervention plan in at least one block in Jalpaiguri and Kalimpong division, targeting approximately 100 youth through DMT-based regular training and workshops. Our goal is to create at least 20 youth leaders, engage 10 key influencers, and involve 200 community members.  Training Of Trainer with youth. YES   Kolkata Sanved is in the process of creating its Centre for Cre ative Wellbeing and Social Change, where we have received our first funding support to lay down the infrastructure. This centre will gradually transform into an institute. With the establishment of the institute, Kolkata Sanved has a tremendous opportunity  to leverage its partnerships and revenue -generating activities. Our goal is to create Dance Movement Therapy (DMT) entrepreneurs from this institute. The institute will serve as a hub for training programs, workshops, and academic courses, attracting both students and professionals from various regions.   Kolkata Sanved is unique in its commitment towards staff well -being and skill building, leading to organizational enhancement. We firmly believe that capacity building of staff contributes to the strength  of the organization which aids in its growth and impact in the sector. We believe in and practice honoring lived experience. The power of lived experiences is encapsulated in our model and reflected in our programme and journey. 60% of our employees have emerged from grass root backgrounds, a testament to our inclusive ethos. Their presence extends not only within the Senior Leadership Team (SLT) but also our governing body.   Presently, we are actively engaged in strengthening our second -line leaders (SLT), aiming to develop a Collective Leadership Model within the organization. To develop this model, Kolkata Sanved intends to invest on a process -based approach on its SLT over a span of 3 years. This model ensures that leadership is distributed across the organization, tapping   Oak Application Form13 into diverse perspectives and expertise. Additionally, this model empowers employees at all levels, creating a sense of ownership and commitment to the organization's mission.   The trainings under this model will include personal growth sessions, group development workshops, strategic planning workshops, and mentorship sessions. By prioritizing these aspects, KS fosters a culture of reflective leadership, where leaders are encouraged to continuously learn and grow. This not only benefits the individual employees but also creates a work environment where everyone feels supported, valued, and empowered to contribute effectively.  The activities will include:  1. Personal Growth sessions: Personal growth sessions give employees opportunity to nurture self -awareness, resilience, and emotional intelligence which are essential qualities for effective leadership. Improved mental health leads to higher productivity and better decision-making skill. This activity will comprise of a total of 20 group personal growth sessions for 5 groups @ 4 sessions per group per year for 3 years.  2. Group Development workshops: These workshops will emphasize on team building and strengthening efforts with specific focus on nurturing communication skills, feedback skills, appreciative inquiry and creating a sense of ownership. Strategic Planning workshops: These workshops will help to create the framework and develop key principles of Collective Leadership Model. It will comprise of 4 days of workshop with the SLT in year 1 and 2 days of review workshop in year 2.  4. Mentorship sessions: These sessions are required for mentoring SLT members on a regular basis on issue -based understanding of the working field as some members come from non-academic background and did not get the opportunity for a ttending formal education. They have mostly acquired knowledge on the sector through lived experiences. This will include 2 days of session and 1 day assessment (total 3 days), every 6 months for 3 years. (300 words)  Throughout the project period, a comprehensive assessment will be conducted to evaluate the project's achievements and shortcomings. This reflective process aims to extract valuable insights that can frame future initiatives and strategies to scale up this model in the N orth Bengal region. Lessons learned will be carefully documented, highlighting successful methodologies and areas for improvement. Stakeholder feedback and project outcomes will be analyzed to enhance understanding and contribute to the organization's continuous growth.  - At least 2 monitoring meetings will take place during phase 1. Monitoring meetings will take place with the team members at every quarter. - At least 3 monitoring visits will take place during phase 2 of implementation. These visits will be c onducted at the block level, which serves as the unit of implementation. The above-mentioned monitoring meetings and visits at the site will help to assess the teams progress on the work done and mitigate challenges in the course of its work. This will also help the organization to assess whether the course of work is proving to be effective for the service receivers or requires modifications.  - As part of the intervention plan developed after formative research, KS will establish specific indicators for the project. These indicators will guide the mapping of the intervention's progress, with data collected at baseline and end line. Formats will be created to facilitate data collection by DMT practitioners and social workers. These formats will primarily focus on three key areas:  A checklist of indicators mapping project progress   A checklist of indicators mapping the formation of the collaborative network  A checklist of indicators mapping healing, wellbeing and psycho -social and leadership skills within the adolescent girls and youth. Learning: Through the first phase of this program consisting of formative research, we will formulate an understanding of th e mental health and wellbeing needs of a new   Oak Application Form16 demographic group  youth of North Bengal.  We will be testing an implementation plan based on the research and participation of youth and key stakeholders.  Kolkata Sanved has its own customized internal assess ment/evaluation set -up for supervising and understanding the impact of Dance Movement Therapy (DMT) sessions on its participants. This process starts at the very beginning, with the commencement of any new programs/projects. Our current assessment strategies also include daily session reports by Dance Movement Therapy Practitioners, Self-reporting by participants through feedback and reflections, base -line, midline and end line survey, case study interview, monthly output tracking, attendance keeping, eval uation and review, learning and reflection meetings with DMT practitioners.   The Assessment /Evaluation Process comprises of methodical collection of data on a project basis and a quarterly/yearly basis, to assess what has happened in order to improve future work, and provide links between past, present, and future work. In order to assure a lack of bias, third party external evaluators are hired to assess our DMT impact as well. Final assessment reports are always available for participants, stake holders , to the collaborative organizations, donors, students or anyone who wants to read.
